column2: ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The longest legislative deadlock in more than half a century dragged through its seventh day today with no resolution imminent.
A three-point program designed to foster the theater in depressed areas of the city was announced yesterday at Gracie Mansion.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The Douglas Aircraft Company proudly rolled off its assembly line today the first DC-9 -- a new jet-liner designed to serve 98 per cent of the nation's civil airports.
LONDON -- Lord Snow stood at the rostrum at Downing College, Cambridge, adjusted his glasses and wasted no time getting to the point:
The bond market was taken by surprise yesterday by the announcement of the results of last week's advance refunding operation by the Treasury.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Commissioner Joe Foss of the A.F.L. said today he was in accord with "many parts" of the Corbett committee report to the N.C.A.A. convention. He had no comment on the N.F.L. declaration and said there was no urgency for him to issue any regulations.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Wagner scored 6 straight points in a two-minute span late in the game to down Rider, 95-92, in a Tri-State League contest tonight. Art Grannis scored two baskets and John DiMaggio one in the Seahawks' spurt after Rider had battled back from a 15-point deficit to tie the game at 78- all with 5 minutes 19 seconds left.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 12 -- Britain has agreed to remove most of her 1,500-man army garrison from Libya this year and has begun to prepare for the withdrawal of units from the Tripoli area, reliable sources said today.
BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Hecklers repeatedly silenced Chancellor Ludwig Erhard with catcalls and scuffling at a Christian Democratic party rally in West Berlin tonight.
The British pound rose moderately in fairly active trading on the foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.7920, up 5 points from the Monday level.

A Coast Guard board of inquiry was told yesterday that the 19-year-old Victory ship Smith Voyager, which sank in the Atlantic on Dec. 27, had developed a severe list on a previous voyage and had been badly battered in storms at least twice.
The City Council Committee on Codification approved a bill yesterday giving the city's meter maids authority to ticket motorists for all types of parking or standing violations.

The resignation of Dean Burch as chairman of the Republican National Committee was the necessary first step in the revitalization of his party. Former Senator Goldwater finally recognized that his faction could not cling to exclusive control of the party's national headquarters in opposition to the intensifying pressure from all sides for a fresh beginning.

"The first six months of 1965 should be particularly strong for retailers of apparel fashions, but I must agree with the many economists who are hedging on prospects for the second half," John W. Sheldon, president of the Charles E. Stevens Company, Chicago specialty store, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The Veterans Administration advised members of Congress today that it would close 14 hospitals and 17 regional offices across the country. It estimated the saving at $25 million a year.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 12 -- Taking the pulse of voter attitudes and then doing something about it has become the political trademark of Raymond Charles Bliss, the Republican state chairman in Ohio.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- Temple University gained its 26th consecutive victory on its home court tonight as it defeated Hofstra University, 76 -- 65. The victory was the Owls' third against no losses in Middle Atlantic Conference play.

At the turn of the year, state of the union messages or their equivalents are delivered in a great many countries, and Spain is no exception. This year Generalissimo Franco dropped a small bombshell. He came out in favor of "the exercise of freedom of conscience."
The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday the appointment of Donald S. MacNaughton as executive vice president and Proctor H. Barnett as senior vice president.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- The pre-college enrichment program at Franklin and Marshall College was developed out of a number of suggestions by faculty and students eager for the college to participate in helping Negroes to achieve equality of educational opportunity.

A progressive, enlightened program for improving aid to education, combating air and water pollution, furthering urban renewal, establishing a Garden State Arts Center and many other worthwhile proposals was outlined yesterday by Gov. Richard J. Hughes in his annual message to the New Jersey Legislature.
New Jersey sold $45 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting group led by the Chase Manhattan Bank, the First National City Bank, Lehman Brothers and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 12 -- Dean Burch will resign as Republican National Chairman April 1. The Ohio Republican Chairman, Ray. C. Bliss, has agreed to take over the job with the blessing of Barry Goldwater.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The 15th annual National Basketball Association All-Star game will be played in the St. Louis Arena tomorrow night.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 12 -- The horses and the sulkies didn't get a chance to do their best on the "spiral" curves at the Phoenix Trotting Park last night in the first sanctioned night harness races west of the Mississippi River.

The school of journalism, a relative newcomer to the university campus, is progressing in its struggle to achieve respectability in the eyes of the older disciplines, according to Dr. Wesley C. Clark, dean of the Syracuse University School of Journalism.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 12 -- Indonesia accused Britain today of massing military forces in Malaysia with the intention of staging "another Suez." Ganis Harsono, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, described the concentration of British forces as "unprecedented in peacetime."
Some adroitly timed switching diamond rings by an elegantly dressed woman with a sure knowledge of diamonds has left one Fifth Avenue jeweler $38,500 poorer, another $7,500 richer.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Edgar M. Gemmell, administrative vice president of Princeton University, announced today that he would retire at the end of the academic year.

Your thought-provoking editorial stand suggesting neutralization of all states that formerly made up Indochina -- neutralization under strict U.N. supervision -- deserves series consideration in our current dilemma with Vietnam.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- The Frefnch and Hungarian Foreign Ministers discussed "the German problem" today in the context of the evolving situation in Eastern Europe.
"A kid will say, 'I hate you, I can't stand you.'"
With no $400,000 professional tennis offers dangling before him, Chuck McKinley has decided to settle for the security of a Wall Street investment career.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Republican Senators agreed today to distribute choice committee assignments more equitably in the future.
The New York Times reports (Jan. 5) opposition by clergymen (Protestant, Jewish, Roman Catholic) to the opening of an "opinion library" by the John Birch Society in a Chicago suburb.

MEXICO CITY -- Some six years ago Mexico adopted an 11-year educational plan calling for development at three levels: primary and secondary school; vocational and technical training, and higher education. Today the country is considerably ahead of this 11-year program.
A new rush-hour shuttle-bus service between the East Side and the Hunters Point Avenue station of the Long Island Rail Road in Long Island City, Queens, was proposed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 12 -- Higher consumer taxes were proposed today by the Swedish Government to pay for bigger pensions and children's allowances.
Many high Republican leaders said yesterday that the settlement of their bitter dispute over national leadership would bring unity to their badly beaten and seriously divided party.

Pre-kindergarten programs designed to help slum children break out of a pattern of school failure are new on the educational scene. But already they are being pushed to the head of the class as a cure-all -- perhaps prematurely, according to one authority in the field.
BOGOTA -- The Alliance for Progress has had two effects on education in Colombia. One is tangible, the other is hard to measure, intangible, but real, nevertheless.

American Broadcasting Paramount Theatres, Inc., announced yesterday the election as a director of George P. Jenkins, financial vice president and a director of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Seagoing unions of the merchant marine called yesterday for immobilization of all East Coast and Gulf Coast passenger liners under the American flag in support of the coastwide strike of the International Longshoremen's Association.
PARIS -- Discotheques are now as cherished here as good bistros and Beaujolais, but the French never call them by this name.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- All four of New York's major indoor open track meets will probably have no trouble attracting college athletes this winter because of a sudden change in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's position on its ban against open track and field meets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 --President Johnson has been considering the creation of a blue-ribbon commission to review Federal farm programs and propose new approaches to questions of price supports and other subsidies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Commerce Committee approved today President Johnson's nomination of John T. Connor to succeed Luther H. Hodges as Secretary of Commerce.
The National Labor Relations Board's new regional office in Brooklyn will open Monday at 16 Court Street, with Samuel M. Kaynard as its director.
Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol ruled yesterday that a savings and loan association must show its list of members to a savings account holder who wants to wage a proxy fight.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson today stepped into the controversy over proposals to cancel production of Britain's newest military airplane, the TSR-2.
HAVANA -- The Cuban revolution's massive education program is the most impressive accomplishment of Premier Fidel Castro's six-year-old regime.

New York City may get almost $50 million as its share of President Johnson's school-aid program, according to Washington education experts. Of this total, $10 million would be shared by public, private and parochial schools, and $40 million would go to the public schools alone, if Congress follows the President's proposals.
HOUSTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The player pension fund will be one of the biggest losers resulting from the transfer of the All-Star game from New Orleans to Houston.
BONN -- West Germany is belatedly moving to reform an outdated education system that some alarmed experts believe is rapidly turning the Bonn Republic into an intellectually underdeveloped country.

The carrying technique used by Boy Scouts has become the corporate symbol of the Oppenheimer Fund. After dismissing a variety of animals and the Bible's David, Gordon Weiss, Inc., the agency, proposed the interlocked hands symbol to the fund.
Fueled by a pessimistic winter crop report from the Department of Agriculture, trading in Maine potato futures soared to a historic high yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that if so many people wanted to block Consolidated Edison's hydroelectric project on Storm King Mountain, they ought to band together and buy the land.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 -- The head of the Soviet oil industry said today that the Russians expected to keep up a high growth rate in petroleum production and would sur pass the United States in the early seventies.
The Seeburg Corporation, a manufacturer of vending equipment, coin-operated phonographs, hearing aids and electronic organs, reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings in its 62-year history.
Perched awkwardly on a Lilliputian chair during the semi-annual rite known as Parents Meeting, a young, mother raised her hand to demand, "But when is my child going to read?"
TRAMORE, Ireland, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Doors were ripped from hinges today in a courtroom melee when nine men appeared to face charges of fomenting disorder during Princess Margaret's visit last week.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association asked professional football teams today to put a stop to premature signings of college athletes who had not completed their undergraduate eligibility.
MONTREAL, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A record-bent Bobby Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks scored three goals and one assist last week to maintain a comfortable lead in the National Hockey League scoring race.
HOUSTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The American Football League, both the players and the office staff, struggled today to set up the A.F.L.'s transplanted All-Star game, with only four days to prepare.
The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday the election of Walter P. Marshall to the new post of chairman and chief executive officer.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 12 -- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers announced today, that it had signed an agreement with Eastern railroads providing full job protection for all firemen on their rosters.

President Johnson's education message is a skillful effort to fix national priorities while avoiding paralyzing controversies. It emphasizes the vast cost to the United States in human misery and economic waste of educational neglect. Perhaps most important, it warns that the nation dare not overlook quality in building up the world's largest mass-education enterprise.

CONCURRENTLY with the four concerts of Twentieth Century Innovations, which are directed by Gunther Schuller, are the four concerts of Evenings for New Music. These are directed by Lukas Foss, also in Carnegie Recital Hall.
Chi Chi Rodriguez, a leading touring golf professional, expressed hope last night that the rules of the Ryder Cup international matches would be changed to include golfers from Puerto Rico.

THE result of the Bridge World match beginning here Friday between teams representing traditional bidding and convention-full science is not easy to predict. One of the question marks relates to Alvin Roth and Tobias Stone, whose celebrated Roth-Stone system will be operating on the side of science.

The Atlas Corporation, a former investment company and now an operating company engaged in natural resources, mining and other activities, announced yesterday a broad reorganization of its top management.

The State Investigation Commission is studying alleged kickbacks and possible improper influence in a $3 million city-aided Harlem housing project with which J. Raymond Jones was involved. Mr. Jones was then -- as he is now -- a powerful Democratic leader.

Somewhere over eastern Ohio, American Airlines Flight 24, scheduled to arrive at Kennedy International Airport at 5:40 P.M. from San Francisco, began its descent. "Fasten Seatbelts -- No Smoking Please," read the sign on the bulkhead.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (Reuters) -- A man who served three and one-half years in jail for armed robbery has been appointed technical adviser to a series of British television programs about crime.
The election of Donald E. Meads as president of the International Basic Economy Corporation, an international investment and development company, was announced yesterday.

ON MAY 5, 1949, a gangly, gray-haired American checked into the Palace Hotel in Prague. His name was Noel Haviland Field. His reputation, slightly tarnished in some quarters, was nonetheless impressive. His future was uncertain.
TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- A new stock-buying syndicate to help support Japanese stock market prices was officially established today with the backing of the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan.
OLYMPIA, Wash., Jan. 12 -- Use of the atom as the cornerstone of the Washington State economy was urged on the Legislature today by Gov. Albert D. Rosellini.
Several companies announced plans for expansion and modernization yesterday.

JACKASS FLATS, Nev., Jan. 12 -- Scientists of the Atomic Energy Commission deliberately blew up a million-dollar nuclear reactor today on a railroad track here at the agency's 1;000-square-mile Nevada Test Site.

CAIRO, Jan. 12 -- Thirteen Arabs Premiers announced today that they had agreed on a unified policy against foreign countries that either establish new relations with Israel or "consolidate Israel's aggressive military efforts."
Roman Catholic schools in and around New York City took a spectacular step during the year with the announcement of plans for closed-circuit television.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- House Republicans prepared today for another intraparty battle. It promised to Provide a severe test of strength for the new minority leader, Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan.
Legislation proposed yesterday by the Board of Education would make it a violation for anyone to help or encourage pupils to remain away from school during boycotts.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 12 -- County Judge Charles C. Mathis Jr. refused today to hear arguments on nine civil rights cases remanded to his court by a Federal judge. Judge Mathis said that to hear the cases would subject him to contempt charges in Federal court.
TRENTON, Jan. 12 -- New Jersey plans to establish a major new arts center this year at no cost to its taxpayers.
In the last year, greatness has been thrust upon American education -- and education is groaning under the burden.
The public libraries of nation, which have cherished their old place in education as the poor-mans university, are increasingly becoming the annex to the ordinary high school and college.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman tightened controls today on the million-acre "canoe area" within the Superior National Forest on the Minnesota-Ontario border.
BOSTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion, said today he felt ready to resume training for his postponed title rematch with Sonny Liston.
BOSTON, Jan. 12 -- Segregation through racial concentration exists in the public schools of Springfield, Mass., Federal Judge George C. Sweeney said in a ruling last night in Boston.
A new generation of parents is infiltrating the ivy-covered curtain that separates the worlds of the public and the private schools.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 12 -- Yale avenged an early-season defeat and defeated Brown, 87 -- 55, for its first Ivy League basketball victory tonight. The Elis took a 22-13 lead midway in the first half, built it to 49-33 by halftime and coasted home.

Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson in a letter published Jan. 5 stated that "4,845 young men and women who freely attended colleges outside New York had the financial capacity to do so and were not restricted in their choice by lack of money." As one of these "4,845," I would have to differ with him.
Several donors sent their first gift to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and wrote that they intended to establish a custom of contributing to the appeal each year.

ITHACA, N.Y. -- Sometime during the second month of my first year as president of Cornell, I received my one-hundredth inquiry as to what it was like to be working the other side of the street. On good days I was asked if I still believed it more blessed to give than receive.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Only last week there had been a Bar Mitzvah in this bright, cheery meeting hall, and today, on the spot where a 13-year-old boy had entered religious adulthood, a skinny little man in a green hat was whispering, "Straight right, hit, hit," and toothlessly grinning when George Chuvalo, boxing's latest Moses, pummeled the air.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A spokesman for the nation's major cigarette manufacturers said today that yesterday's meeting on smoking and health produced "no new scientific data" to support contentions that cigarettes are a major health hazard.

"Running a private college or university these days is like operating a giant company," the financial officer of a large university in the East commented recently. The only difference is, he said, "ours is not a profit-making operation."
GARDENA, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A retired machinist fired a small arsenal of guns into three poker parlors today. More than 30 persons were wounded, one critically, the police said.
Prices moved narrowly in quiet trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
Bing Crosby, who started his first weekly television show last fall, expressed doubt yesterday that the series would continue next season.

PARIS, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- French Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing reaffirmed today France's desire for collective action this year by the 10 richest countries of the non-Communist world to reform the international monetary system.
LONDON -- The British are in a surprising state of ferment about their education.

The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, Inc., has leased three floors, containing a total of 51,000 square feet of space, in the new 41-story skyscraper at 90 Park Avenue, between 39th and 40th Streets.
PARIS, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The price of gold, which dropped sharply on the French market yesterday, registered another decrease in today's trading on the stock exchange here.

Wilt Chamberlain, whose forte is putting the ball in the basket, and Bill Russell, whose forte is keeping the ball out of the basket, enjoyed big leads in their specialties at the halfway mark of the National Basketball Association season.

Stanley H. Lowell, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, proposed yesterday several amendments to the city's fair-housing law. He made the proposals after a number of civil rights organizations had urged changes.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 12 -- The Government concluded today the presentation of new evidence in the murder of three civil rights workers near Philadelphia, Miss., last summer.

BEAVER MEADOW, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Jack is a little beagle with clean lines and a somewhat chagrined expression, as if he expects to be caught doing something he shouldn't. He bears the mark of an outstanding past.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Treasury reported today that last week's mammoth advance-refunding offer was a success, with public holders of $9 billion of short-term securities accepting longer-term securities in exchange.
ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Jack E. Bronston, an aspirant for the Senate majority leadership, presented a program today for "a complete updating of the New York State Legislature."
The first specialist to evaluate the New York City public school system for us was the doorman.
The New York Zoological Society reported yesterday that it had raised $7,240,000 toward a goal of $10 million for an expansion, conservation, research and education program.
"All of a sudden you discover that there are problems you didn't know you had."
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 12 -- Fifteen paintings in the Uffizi Gallery dating from the 14th to the 18th centuries were defaced and seriously damaged here today.
MOSCOW -- There has been unusual ferment in Soviet education, both at the public school and university levels, since the overthrow of Premier Khrushchev last October.
Rumors that Great Lakes Chemical Corporation had discovered a promising deposit of molybdenum ore on its property in California were confirmed yesterday by Charles S. Hale, president.

MOSCOW -- About 10,000 students from developing countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America are now attending Soviet universities, Nikolai N. Sofinsky, Deputy Minister of Highed Education, announced at a recent news conference.

A 12-story fireproof loft building at 237 Lafayette Street, occupied by manufacturing concerns, has been sold to a client of L.V. Hoffman Co. The building, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, is fully rented and has an annual roll of $70,000.

The Mobil Oil Company, a division of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, announced yesterday the election of Frank C. Bolton Jr. and Kenneth R. Joynt as vice presidents. Mr. Bolton, who is 50 years old, will handle staff coordination for natural-gas resources.
VALENTINE, Neb., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A ranch-country bank president was sentenced today to 8 to 15 years at hard labor in prison for an embezzlement that he admitted might total almost $3 million.

A TELEVISION tour of the Capitol in Washington was presented last night in an hour-long documentary over the National Broadcasting Company network. The program was a painstaking undertaking on the part of Lou Hazam, the producer, but the hour turned out to be history of a rather dry and unexciting order.
Eddie Stanky, the graduate "Brat" of the Brooklyn Dogders, gave a resounding report yesterday on a new generation of brats who play for him on farm teams of the New York Mets.
Personnel changes at Bonwit Teller's that began with the resignation of William Leigh Smith last Friday have extended to William E. Humphreys, second in command of the specialty chain.
Negro securities salesmen are rarely found in member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, but three of them have gone to work for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.

ANDOVER, Mass. -- Five Negro boys came to Phillips Academy this September from A Better Chance summer program at Dartmouth. One boy entered in the eleventh grade, two in the tenth and two in the ninth.
PANAMA, Wednesday, Jan. 13 -- National Guard policemen used a barrage of tear-gas bombs last night to stop a mob advancing on the Canal Zone.
Many of New York's smaller parks have become "backyards for derelicts," city officials agreed yesterday as they sought to find remedies during a two-hour meeting at the Borough President's office.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan suggested today that the solution of the Vietnamese problem lay with the nations of Asia, not the West.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Jim Brown's jump shot with 2 minutes 57 seconds left in the game capped an uphill fight for Fairfield University tonight and sent the Stags on their way to a 63-58 victory over Iona at O'Connell Gymnasium.
The great era of curricular change that began almost a decade ago with soul-searching about why Johnny can't read land the shock of Sputnik is entering a new phase.
NEW DELHI -- For the first time since Lord Macaulay introduced Western schooling into India 130 years ago, the educational system here is being basically overhauled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Agency for International Development decided today to spend $25,000 to record the story of the Republic of China's progression from an agricultural backwater to a booming modern economy with $1.4 billion in United States aid.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday either Thomas J. Mackell of Queens or Manfred Ohrenstein of Manhattan would make a good leader of the Democratic majority in the State Senate.
Bernard Gittelson, the chief figure in an alleged bribery plot in a parking meter contract with the city, won a postponement of his perjury trial yesterday until Feb. 8.

ENUGU, Nigeria, Jan. 12 -- Dr. W.A. Visser 't Hooft, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, declared tonight that the drive to bridge the differences between Protestants and Roman Catholics had reached a point of "great uncertainty."

BOLSENA, Italy, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A 13th-century fresco of Pope Urban IV establishing the feast of Corpus Christi has been discovered at the scene of the "Miracle of Bolsena," that prompted his action.

NEW HAVEN, Conn. -- The purposes of the Yale Summer High School were to take 100 10th-grade boys -- Negro and white, Northern and Southern, urban and rural -- bright boys whose progress toward college was being impeded by social and financial barriers, and, in six weeks at an intensive boarding school, put them on the way to realizing instead of wasting their high intellectual potentialities.

BECAUSE anything can happen in an ice show and usually does, it is quite reasonable to agree with the closing song of the Ice Follies of 1965 that "Everything's Coming Up Roses" at Madison Square Garden.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 12 -- Police Inspector James R. Ketcham was named today to succeed Thomas M. Dugan as sheriff of Nassau County.
I have been reading your editorials and news stories of the welfare workers' strike with sadness. As a social investigator for New York City I realize that only half the picture is being painted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The Federal Power Commission refused today to disqualify Commissioner David S. Black from taking part in its hearings on proposed natural-gas price ceilings for the Permian Basin producing area in Texas and New Mexico.

The suspicion that many Americans look back with less than enthusiasm on the music "appreciation" imparted to them in public school has been confirmed by reports of the Yale Seminar on Music Education, held the summer before last.
A carefully planned plot of five students to glue all the doors of a Washington Heights school was uncovered by the police last night.

TRENTON, Jan. 12 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today that he would submit on Feb. 1 a state budget that will not call for any tax increases. As required by the State Constitution, the budget will be balanced.

The Coast Guard cutter Rockaway returned yesterday to her berth at St. George, S.I., from a month of routine weather station patrol in the Atlantic, north of Bermuda, with a few log entries that were a chronology of anticlimaxes.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 -- Some aspects of the Pure Oil Performance Trials, which are to be run here Jan. 23 through Jan. 27, could be used to create a super automotive gymcana. These trials, conducted here annually under the supervision of the National Association for Stock Car Racing, consist of three events -- a gasoline economy test, an acceleration test and a braking test.
The stock market advanced yesterday after two days of indecisive trading.
Robert L. Hoguet Jr., president of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, said yesterday that Joseph Papp had not been offered the post of artistic director of the theater.

A total job-security program negotiated by the United Steelworkers of America with a small Pennsylvania company this week appears likely to serve as a pattern the union may seek to establish in the can industry and subsequently in basic steel.
Militancy was the keynote of the year among teachers, with the National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers vying for support.
The chances of recovering the 100-carat DeLong Star ruby stolen from the American Museum of Natural History were described yesterday by detectives as being 50-50.

GENEVA, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- An American delegate to a United Nations meeting on discrimination challenged Moscow today to let the world see for itself whether racial and religious discrimination was being practiced in the Soviet Union.
A 15-to-17-cent increase in the city's basic real estate tax rate was predicted yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission on the basis of the city's debt position.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is reported negotiating to buy the east blockfront of Nassau Street immediately north of its office in the financial district.

As Rudolf Serkin began the first-movement cadenza of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 1 in Carnegie Hall last night, one of the piano strings snapped. If the pianist's physical intensity caused the mishap, it also seemed as if the instrument found the emotional tension too strong and had to find a release somehow.

Ornette Coleman, who was hailed in some quarters as the jazz wave of the future when he was first heard in New York five years ago, has emerged from two years of retirement to resume his career at the Village Vanguard.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Harry Stuhldreher, one of Notre Dame's famed Four Horsemen, was named today as the winner of the Stagg Award by the American Football Coaches Association.

Two city officials, linked by the brotherly bonds of the municipal government, are straining the ties of that not always overwhelming affection. Newbold Morris, Commissioner of Parks, and Henry A. Barnes, Commissioner of Traffic, are engaged in a public correpondence of declining civility.

Andrew Fetler, born in Latvia and now a member of the English department of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst College, has written "The Travelers," a novel laid in Germany in December, 1938, which Houghton Mifflin will publish on Feb. 15.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Face the Facts and Chop House captured separate divisions of the Santa Monica handicap today at Santa Anita.
WOLFSBURG, Germany, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Volkswagen has stopped buying British-made parts, a company spokesman said today.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Three Federal tax liens totaling more than $35 million were filed in Martin County Circuit Court today against James Rand, inventor of the dial telephone and former head of the Remington-Rand Corporation.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Government tentatively approved today a proposal that the people of Sabah be given a chance to say whether they want to join the Philippines or stay in the Malaysian Federation.

After months of negotiation the counties of Nassau and Suffolk have reached an agreement to create a joint planning board. Financed mainly by Federal funds, the new regional agency will attempt to work out solutions for problems arising from the basic economy, employment, transportation, conservation and recreation of the area.
JAKARTA, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Foreign Minister Subandrio ordered the director of United Nations activities in Indonesia today to close his office and end all projects in the country.

MIAMI, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Florida Council for Senior Citizens says thousands of elderly couples are living together, out of wedlock, in the Miami area because marriage would mean reduced Social Security payments.
A 41-year-old police sergeant, dismissed in a gambling inquiry, has been reinstated following a court order.

Armour Co. filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering to shareholders of rights to subscribe for 650,000 additional shares of common stock.
The Interchemical Corporation, chemical processing concern, announced yesterday the election of James T. Hill Jr. as executive vice president.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller will be asked by a group of Westchester County Mayors to prevent a proposed reduction in commuter service by the New Haven Railroad.

Don Chandler, the kicking star of the Giants who played on six championship teams in his nine seasons with the New York team, was traded yesterday to the Green Bay Packers. In return for the 30-year-old Oklahoman, the Giants received an undisclosed but high future draft choice.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- John Konrads, who broke more than 30 world records when swimming as an amateur and won the 1,500 meter gold medal in the 1960 Olympics, turned professional today with a contract to coach swimming.
The Graduate School of International Studies at the University of Denver has announced plans to build its own building, after only four years of life.
TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- Ten Japanese poems, each of 31 syllables and selected from more than 35,500, were read before Emperor Hirohito at the annual Imperial Poetry Party today.

The Christiana Securities Company announced yesterday that a registration statement covering a previously announced offer to exchange up to 8.4 million shares of General Motors Corporation common stock it holds for outstanding shares of Christiana common stock has become effective.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- The Soviet Union implied today that the activities of the United Nations Special Fund were of greater help to the Western powers than to the developing nations they were intended to assist.
PHILADELPHIA -- Never before have the independent school's four walls been as traversible -- and as traversed -- as today.

In cities across the country, where the nation's great urban universities are situated, a new partnership of town and gown is emerging to replace a historical hostility. It is a partnership rooted in the knowledge that the future of these institutions and the destiny of their communities are inexorably linked.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The bitter custody fight between Vic Damone and his ex-wife, Pier Angeli, was settled today when the singer agreed to return their son, Perry, to his mother on condition that he will have the boy himself two months a year.
The Committee for Netherlands Music presented a concert of three string quartets last night at the Donnell Library Center that did little to generate enthusiasm for its cause.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The pound continued to improve in the London foreign exchange market today with the rate rising to $2.79 7/32, its highest level since early December.

Herbert Callender, the man who tried to arrest Mayor Wagner in City Hall last July for allegedly alowing public funds to be spent on projects in which racial discrimination was permitted, was sentenced in Criminal Court yesterday to 60 days in the workhouse.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- Lynn A. Townsend, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that the United States automobile industry might increase its Canadian investments if an agreement is reached to erase tariff walls between the two countries.

THE match between the bridge "traditionalists" and the "scientists" that begins here tomorrow is essentially a clash between players who use hardly any conventions and players who use many.

A $45 million capital improvement program for this year, the largest in its history, has been approved by the board of directors of the Chicago North Western Railway, Ben W. Heineman, chairman, announced yesterday.

An air of uncertainty permeated the soybean, futures market yesterday following the sharp advance on Tuesday. At the close of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, prices were unchanged to 1 1/4 cents a bushel below the previous day's last quotations.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- The Governing Council of the United Nations Special Fund approved its administrative budget for this year today after much wrangling about the increasing cost of operations.

The election of Eugene R. Black as a director and a member of the policy and finance committee of the F.W. Woolworth Company was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to adopt new immigration legislation that would abolish the system of quotas based on national origins.

THE first phrases Birgit Nilsson sang last night in her seasonal return to the Metropolitan Opera were those in one of the most taxing and vocally spectacular scenes ever conceived for a soprano.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Jan. 13 -- Daniel J. Evans, a Republican moderate who shunned involvement in the Goldwater Presidential campaign, took the oath today as Washington's Governor. His induction ended an eight-year Democratic hold on the state's elective offices.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Democratic leaders abandoned last night all hope of organizing the Legislature this week. As the protracted tug-of-war between legislators allied with Mayor Wagner and those opposed to him went through its eighth day, more roll-calls were taken and more negotiations were held. But no progress in selecting leaders was visible.

The Festival Orchestra of New York has canceled five of its remaining programs this season at Philharmonic Hall for economic reasons. The dates are Feb. 12, Feb. 19, March 5, April 9 and April 30. Previously, the orchestra had canceled all of its remaining Carnegie Hall concerts on Wednesday nights, each of whose programs duplicated one at Philharmonic Hall the same week.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 13 -- Eight more paintings at the Uffizi Gallery here were discovered damaged today. Deere Co. realized a 23 per cent increase in earnings during the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 on a sales gain of 19 per cent. The big farm equipment producer had the best year in its 127-year history.

Five hundred community leaders last night paid tribute to Salim L. Lewis, investment banker, who retired from the chairmanship of the City of Life Building Fund campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

The New York Philharmonic will play at Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30. Thomas Schippers will conduct, with Martina Arroyo, soprano; Beverly Wolff, mezzo-soprano; Tito Del Bianco, tenor, and Justino Diaz, bass.
A special committee of the New York Stock Exchange opposes the creation of associate memberships and the splitting of commissions with broker-dealers that do not belong to the Big Board.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 13 -- Peter Forbath, chief of Time magazine's African bureau, was declared a prohibited immigrant by Kenya today and given 24 hours to leave.
Long-term Government bond prices rose slightly yesterday in the first day of trading following the announcement of the results of the Treasury's recent advance refunding.

Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, said yesterday that Federal funds could be used for parochial-school students in New York despite a Constitutional ban on the use of state funds for that purpose.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 13 -- Premier Moise Tshombe canceled his trip to Brussels today as Belgian-Congolese relations deteriorated rapidly.
ST LOUIS -- The Golden Arrow, a new 93-foot packet boat of some splendor, points to the coming development of the riverfront here as a locale for recreational boating on a grand scale.

The DeLong Star ruby, described as "still in perfect condition," is believed to be in New York City, according to information received yesterday by the police and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office.

New Year's Eve comes twice a year and in two languages to New York's White Russians. Last night the Happy New Year greetings of Dec. 31 were translated into S Novym Godom as some 50 members of the old guard and 250 friends wished one another good fortune at Le Bal Blanc, the annual celebration of the old Russian New Year's Eve in the St. Regis Roof.
PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Northern New Jersey banks, which were robbed of more than $600,000 in cash in five holdups in the last two months, are introducing armed guards in their branches.
The 41,000-mile Interstate Highway System will cost $5.8 billion more than the 1961 estimate of $41 billion, according to a report the Commerce Department sent to Congress yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The United States Information Agency's director, Carl T. Rowan, issued orders today forbidding a United States Government camera team from staging mock battles in South Vietnam for a film on how the war there is going.

TORONTO, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks increased their first-place lead to 2 points and the Toronto Maple Leafs ran their unbeaten streak to six games tonight when they played the first scoreless tie of the National Hockey League season.
The first sailboat it has built and a new "sandwich" construction of aluminum, foam and fiber glass are being featured by the Lone Star Boat Company of Plano, Tex., at the Coliseum.
TORONTO, Jan. 13 -- Viola R. MacMillan, under fire as a central figure in the Windfall scandal on the Toronto Stock Exchange, has quit as president of the Prospectors and Developers Association.

Two more inconclusive ballots in Albany have left the deadlock for the post of Senate majority leader unbroken. Senator Bronston of Queens, candidate of the out-of-New York City forces, remains in the lead with 19 votes and Senator Mackell of Queens, supported by Mayor Wagner's followers, still has 14. Meanwhile, the Legislature is unable to transact any business.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- U Thant, the Secretary General, took the initiative anew today in efforts to break the deadlock over payments to the United Nations. The impasse has blocked voting in the General Assembly.

The Citizens Committee for Children has performed a public service by warning against possible abuses of sociological devices for predicting delinquency in young children. The prediction tables, developed by Prof. Sheldon Glueck and Dr. Eleanor Glueck of the Harvard Law School, constitute valuable research in human behavior and in demonstrating that deficient environment breeds antisocial behavior.
HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) -- The American Football League commissioner, Joe Foss, said today the league was in much better financial shape than it was last year.
The New York Philharmonic has resumed its search for a site for free outdoor summer concerts in the Bronx, its manager, Carlos Mosely, said yesterday.

Executives attending the National Retail Merchants Association's annual convention at he New York Hilton Hotel this week represent many of the largest retail organizations in the nation. Collectively they have more than 1,000 years of retail experience.
Prof. Walter S.G. Kohn's letter published Dec. 30 raises the issue of bicameralism, something usually taken for granted in this country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Two Air Force jet fighters, on a combat mission against Communist supply lines in Laos and South Vietnam, were shot down over central Laos today.

Dr. Louis T. Rader, vice president and division general manager of the General Electric Company's industrial-electronics division, announced yesterday the appointment of Robert B. Curry as manager of division planning of information processing.

THE annual meeting of the American Football League, its venue changed from New Orleans to Houston by 21 Negro football players, opened yesterday in the Texas city. The delegates were asked to avow or deny a proposal put to them indirectly by their league's stanchest antagonist, a fighter who survived the name of Alvin.

National Advertising Week, set for Feb. 7-13, will mark the introduction of the 1965 advertising program for the industry itself. The campaign is sponsored by the Advertising Federation of America and the Advertising Association of the West.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The director of the United Nations Special Fund, Paul G. Hoffman, said today that "not a single representative of a developing country" supported recent Soviet charges that United Nations development work failed to benefit the recipients.

Commissioner Henry Barnes' letter (Times, Jan. 7), patronizing in tone and replete with elegant literary allusions, contains precious little factual evidence to support his contention that a parking garage under Madison Square Park will not adversely affect its viability.
East-West trade appears to be entering a new era, one in which the prospects for substantially expanded commerce between Communist and non-Communist nations seem brighter than ever before.

ONE of the nicest things about the modest dance work introduced last night by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater is that it is set to some of the prettiest music Leo Delibes ever wrote.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- The first effort by a Pennsylvania school district to develop a course on the "literary and historic qualities" of the Bible was rejected unanimously today by the State Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The head of the American Legion said today that the decision of the Veterans Administration to close 14 hospitals and 17 regional centers was shocking and unjustified.

THE uncommonly interesting New York Philharmonic program conducted last night in Philharmonic Hall by Thomas Schippers had the Rossini "Stabat Mater" as its highlight. But the Rossini was preceded by another choral piece, and one that must have come as a curiosity.
PHILADELPHIA, Friday, Jan. 15 -- A citywide transit strike scheduled for 12:01 A.M. today, was averted by an agreement reached in the City Hall reception room of Mayor James H.J. Tate.

Mayor Wagner and Senator Robert F. Kennedy acknowledged the obvious yesterday: the continuing deadlock of the Democratic majorities in both houses of the Legislature, now in its second week, is a serious threat to the party's future in this state. The Mayor said it was time that "a suitable understanding" was worked out; the Senator asserted that compromises were inevitable and that the legislators should make them and get on with the state's business.
Bobby Richardson signed his 11th New York Yankee contract yesterday, three months after he had decided to quit baseball.
A Brooklyn hippopotamus was loaded into a moving van under armed guard yesterday and started on a four-day trip to Texas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A bill designed to provide greater safety and financial security for Americans patronizing foreign-flag cruise ships was introduced here today by Representative William S. Mailliard of California.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 14 -- Gov. George Romney suggested today that the Michigan Legislature should pass a tax-reform program during his second two-year term.
TRENTON, Jan. 14 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes escorted state officials today on a tour of New Jersey's new $7.2 million cultural center here.

In one of the ancient Egyptian tombs there is a painting of a lion looking back with horror at a little mouse crossing the street. Our recent attitude toward the United Arab Republic reminds me of that caricature. The U.A.R., in our scales, is not really formidable, but we are frightened.
PARIS -- On the first day of the New Year, France joined Germany and Switzerland in an international ZIP Code, and Europe took another step toward unity.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 14, (AP) -- Jerry Como Jr., a 17-year-old, 135 pound novice boxer who collapsed in the ring during a Golden Gloves match, died today. Death was a result of a heart condition and did not come from a punch, the coroner ruled.

STILLWATER, Minn., Jan. 14 -- Senator Gaylord Nelson advocated today that America's rivers be classified as working rivers, wild rivers and recreational rivers, to check what he described as cannibalism of natural resources.

CLOVIS, N.M., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Capt. Charles L. Ferguson, one of two United States Air Force pilots shot down over Laos yesterday, telephoned his wife in Clovis today to say, "I'm safe and all right."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Johnson sought today Congressional approval for a $3.38 billion foreign aid authorization for the next fiscal year.
High noon, an ominous time in the annals of Western epics, will bring nothing but pleasure here today for boating buffs.

MADRAS, India, Jan. 14 -- Communists will oppose Communists in the Kerala Assembly elections March 4 because of a breakdown yesterday in talks aimed at forming a front of rightist and leftist factions and associated groups.
MILAN, Italy -- Out of the devastation of war, a rebuilt, still expanding Milan has become the symbol of Italy's industrial progress.
A photographic interpretation of Pope John XXIII's encyclical, "Peace on Earth" (Pacem in Terris), will go on public exhibit at the Hallmark Gallery, Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, beginning Monday.
A gray seal named Pierre has become a mother at the Coney Island Aquarium. One result is that Pierre's name will be changed, perhaps, to Michele.
A Florida man and his son told yesterday how they spent a harrowing 38 hours in a small liferaft drifting 200 miles in rough seas off the East Coast.
New Yorkers must suffer still another indignity at the hands of Californians, who outnumber New Yorkers, own more cars, buy more life insurance and shamelessly loll in more swimming pools.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 14 -- The seesaw election between Francis X. Altimari of Westbury and Julius R. Lippman of New Hyde Park for judge of the Third District Court brought another dramatic tie here today.
Two prosperous-looking businessmen were arrested by Customs agents yesterday on charges of possessing seven and a half pounds of pure cocaine worth more than $3 million in the illicit market.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Foreign Ministry issued a "wanted" notice tonight for the press attache at South Vietnam's Washington embassy, who apparently has disappeared after being called home at the end of the year.
A $200 million issue of World Bank bonds, priced to yield 4.475 per cent, sold out quickly yesterday soon after it was offered to investors.

Albert Schweitzer was given two birthday presents last night at Town Hall. The concert by the Esterhazy Orchestra, which had John Ogdon as piano soloist, was played in tribute to his 90th birthday, and the proceeds of the concert -- $4,070.50 -- were donated to the Albert Schweitzer Fellowship, Inc., to be sent to the Schweitzer Hospital in Africa.

Union lawyers filed applications yesterday asking for individual hearings for about 6,000 Welfare Department workers to protect their rights to jobs from which the city had suspended them because of a strike, which went through its eleventh day.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Kenya refused today a{ request by [he United States{ Ambassador, William Attwood,I to rescind the expulsion of an American correspondent, Peter Forbath o9 Time magazine. Mr. ! Attwood was told that Kenya l supported neighboring Uganda, I which expelled Mr. Forbath last j week. He had been investigat-] ing reports that CongoleseI rebels were receiving supplies through Uganda.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 14 -- Earle Hyman has been named best actor of the season here for his performance in the title role of Eugene O'Neill's "Emperor Jones."
A boyhood letter by President Kennedy stole the show last night at an auction sale, bringing the highest price, $2700.
Plans for a middle-income housing development to be built above the Fourth Avenue BMT subway station in Brooklyn were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
FOR the last production arranged under the suddenly terminated consulship of Robert Whitehead and Elia Kazan at the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater there was an unexpected prologue last night.

In Britain, an automotive leader and a woman management consultant. In Israel, a refugee who became an investment executive. Six vigorous executives for a surging economy in Europe. Their sketches follow:

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Qualified sources said tonight that President de Gaulle would accept the proposal of Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany for a meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the European Common Market this spring to discuss European unity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Johnson's foreign aid message to Congress today:
BRUSSELS, Jan. 14 -- Schools and public buildings began closing in Belgium today as the nationwide petroleum strike ended its fourth day. Hundreds of filling stations also were closed.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Fifty Passaic County law enforcement officials and bankers today formed a standing committee of 12 to draft security recommendations designed to discourage bank robbers. A report is due in about 10 days.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 14 -- President Sukarno declared today that the only means of settling Indonesia's quarrel with Malaysia was to have another United Nations survey of political sentiment in Sarawak and Sabah, the Malaysian states on the island of Borneo.
CAIRO, Jan. 14 -- Akbar Muhammad announced today that he had quit the Black Muslim movement in the United States led by his father, Elijah Muhammad.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 14 (Reuters) --Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein declined comment today on a remark by General Omar Bradley of the United States that the British field marshal was "scared" during the Battle of Normandy which followed the 1944 allied invasion of Europe.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 14 -- President Guillermo Leon Valencia, struggling with what is considered the gravest economic and political crisis he has faced, continued his efforts today to avert a general strike.
ISTANBUL, Turkey -- The year ended here in an atmosphere of slow recovery following a disheartening first half, when the Turkish economy suffered because of the Cyprus crisis.
SELMA, Ala., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told 800 cheering Negroes tonight he would begin a massive test of the 1964 civil rights law here Monday.

ILANOT, Israel -- During the period of the mandate, a British soil officer reported that Palestine was "one of the worst eroded areas of the world." He added ominously that erosion "has been the downfall of many ancient civilizations," and made some alarming observations about disastrous soil practices in the United States.
A State Supreme Court justice ordered the Statler-Hilton yesterday to permit a left-wing meeting at the hotel tonight despite threats of demonstrations by a neo-Nazi group.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 14 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Belgium's Foreign Minister, assured Premier Moise Tshombe today that the Belgian Government had not invited Cyrille Adoula, former Congolese Premier, to Brussels.

Repeating tactics that proved successful last year, President Johnson has pared down the foreign-aid budget once again in order to forestall Congressional ax-wielding. His request for $3.3 billion for both military and economic assistance is the smallest amount sought for foreign aid since the program was launched.
The underworld family of Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, missing Mafia leader, may be falling apart, a Government source said yesterday.
PARIS -- The flow of capital to the world's "have not" nations from the "have" nations hovered nearly unchanged last year despite a dramatic plea by the underdeveloped countries for more help.

HOUSTON, Jan. 14 -- Jeanette MacDonald, the soprano who starred with Nelson Eddy in many popular Hollywood movies, died here today of a heart attack. Miss MacDonald, who was 57 years old, had been admitted to the hospital two days ago for heart surgery.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- French capital and labor took a largely negative attitude today toward Government efforts to maintain restrictions on prices and wages.
BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The whole world has heard about the tremendous Aswan High Dam. It is less aware of other projects in the Arab Middle East.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 -- Newspaper advertising executives were told today that everything was good in the newspaper advertising business these days. With a glint in the eyes of the speaker, they were told, too, that everything was not so good for advertisers in the rival medium -- television.

PARIS -- At the end of 1964, France put on a brave show of economic solidity. Her citizens went on one of their greatest spending sprees in stores packed with goods from everywhere. Her leaders spoke with the self-assurance and independence of people who know they have money in the bank.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The 59th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association convention produced one major policy change yesterday when it elected an athletic director as president. But the change only points up the N.C.A.A.'s unyielding attitude in its dispute with the Amateur Ath letic Union.
" The Family Way," which opened on Wednesday night at the Lyceum, will give its fifth and final performance tomorrow night. Negative reviews were responsible for the decision to close.
A cold wave from Canada brought the city its bitterest weather of the winter last night.
BROADWAY is blase about long lines of girls crowding its sidewalks. When rock 'n' rollers like the Animals aren't drawing mobs, there is Richard Burton.

Bond prices showed almost no changes yesterday in a display of stability that dealers found somewhat remarkable in view of news of increased gold outflows and an increase in the amount of Treasury bills to be auctioned.

To write a scholarly book about the politics of the former Belgian colony is a bold venture. The new republic is a jungle-and-savannah land one-third the size of the continental United States, inhabited by 13 million spirited people who are novices at self-government.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Michigan Supreme Court ordered today trial April 6 on legislative reapportionment. The trial was sought by 33 Michigan Republicans.

A number of the state's political leaders have appealed to President Johnson to order that phasing out of the Brooklyn Navy Yard be extended over five years.

THE Cambridge Circus, which lacks animals but does possess a Cambridge accent, put on a new show last night and proved that it goes over much better with its public of downtown squires sprinkled with New York University faculty than it did with the Broadway public last fall.
Lieut. Billy Mills, the winner of the 10,000-meter run at the Tokyo Olympics, was among those honored at the 32d annual Sportsmanship Brotherhood awards dinner last night.

TORONTO -- Canadian bond financing in the United States resumed in force last year following Canada's formal exemption from the interest-equalization tax imposed by the United States on sales of foreign securities.

DUBLIN, Jan. 14 -- Deep satisfaction was expressed in all political camps tonight over the meeting of the two Irish Prime Ministers in Belfast. But most spokesmen were careful to stress that the big constitutional issues dividing North and South remained untouched.

Despite much weeping over a restrictive new tax law, that popular executive fringe benefit -- the stock option -- has not lost its appeal. Option plans drew new fire on Wednesday when corporate insiders gave the Securities and Exchange Commission their usual monthly reports on dealings in their own companies' stock.
DUBLIN -- The major Irish business development of 1964 took place in Britain. It was the new British Government's inposition of a 15 per cent surcharge on most imports from Ireland.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the Transit Authority's proposal to build the controversial East Side subway tunnel at 63d Street instead of 64th Street as previously planned.
" There's a good, four-letter word that describes what retailers have to do to cope with the worsening profit squeeze. It's spelled W-O-R-K. A synonym might be blood, sweat and tears."

MANILA, Jan. 14 -- Some of the background of the current wave of anti-Americanism in the Philippines recalls lapses in United States military information policy that helped ignite a similar outburst in Japan a few years ago.
LUXEMBOURG -- One of the biggest economic events of 1964 for the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg was the opening of a new manufacturing plant here by America's oldest tobacco company.
Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan paid a formal visit to the city yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Union announced today that the East European military organization would meet next week in what may be a high-level conference on the proposed allied mixed manned force.

The City Stores Company, which operates a chain of department stores, announced yesterday the election of Leonard J. Novogrod as a vice president and Louis G. Melchior as a director. Mr. Novogrod, who is 59 years old, is president of the W. J. Sloane Company, a retailing subsidiary acquired in 1961.

Anna Moffo sang Norina and Elfego Esparza sang the title role in "Don Pasquale" for the first time with the company last night at the Metropolitan Opera. Both were impeccable in style and splendid in voice.

MADRID -- "Spain Is Different," one of the most successful advertising slogans of our era, conjures up visions of gypsies dancing the torrid flamenco and toreros arrogantly courting death in the afternoon.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Legislature suspended its efforts to organize today, but the Democrats were hopeful that their leadership stalemate would be resolved early next week. A more optimistic mood seemed to come over many Senators and Assemblymen this morning.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 -- A Soviet drive for freer discussion and more democratic practices in the Communist party was given a new lift today in Pravda.
BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The lone stronghold of private enterprise in the Arab Middle East, Lebanon, is heading into 1965 with confidence, one might even say gaily.
No decisive trend developed on the stock market yesterday.

The annual Ball of the Roses was held last night to benefit the Free Medical Care Fund of Roosevelt Hospital. Several cocktail parties were given before the ball, which took place for the 12th consecutive year at the Plaza.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 -- The Government took firmer hold today after the crisis that nearly crumbled the political structure upon which success depends in the war against the Vietcong.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The military caps that rest on the mound of evergreen boughs at President Kennedy's grave, to the puzzlement of millions of visitors, will be replaced soon for the second time.
The growth of Protestant congregations soared from eight-tenths of 1 per cent in 1962 to 3.2 per cent in 1963, according to statistics released yesterday.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- In the first European reaction to President Johnson's foreign aid budget The Daily Telegraph, a Conservative newspaper, said today.
ATHENS -- Drastic reforms in Greece's antiquated education system hold out hope for this nation's long-range bid for economic development, which is now held back by a widespread lack of know-how.
Jurors who convicted George Whitmore Jr. of assault and attempted rape in Brooklyn are to be summoned back to court so that it may be learned whether racial bias played any part in their verdict.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The nation's total output of goods and services grew by $38 billion last year, though automobile strikes slowed the growth in the fourth quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 15 -- Excavators on a building site in London have turned up a coffin with the remains of Anne Mowbray, the infant bride of the Duke of York, one of the two little princes murdered in the Tower of London in the 15th century.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- All securities firms doing a general securities business will be required to have on hand a minimum of $5,000 in liquid capital to back up their operations under a new rule proposed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

One thousand men, women and children picketed in front of the German Consulate at 460 Park Avenue yesterday afternoon in protest against the West German Government's refusal to extend its statute of limitations on Nazi war crimes.
World sugar futures tumbled to new contract lows yesterday in unusually heavy trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Declines ranged from 0.10 cent to 0.17 cent a pound.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., Jan. 14 -- The 12,100-ton Mormacdraco, the last of a class of six fast and highly automated cargo ships being built here for Moore-McCormack Lines of New York, slid down the ways of the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation this afternoon.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- R. Peter Straus, president of Radio Station WMCA, demonstrated on television here tonight how State Assembly and Senate districts could be reapportioned by computers.
Industrial issues led the way to a moderate advance on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange announced plans yesterday to help set up a computer accounting center for the use of its members.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Representative Albert W. Watson, Republican of South South Carolina, submitted his resignation today from Congress.
CARMEL, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Plans for a $28 million brewery in this Putnam County community threatened to dissolve tonight.

Stockholders of Unarco Industries, Inc., have approved an increase in the company's authored shares to 1.8 million from 900,000. This paved the way for a two-for-one stock split of its common stock, which became effective yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Manufacturers of a vaccine against adenoviruses, used primarily by the Army to prevent respiratory ailments, have been asked by the United States Public Health Service to stop production as a precautionary measure.

ENUGU, Nigeria, Jan. 14 -- The World Council of Churches tonight ended a three-day deadlock over a successor to its general secretary, Dr. W.A. Visser t'Hooft by asking the 64-year-old Dutch theologian to stay until mid1966.

A TOP Lebanese in most characteristically Lebanese of all business activities -- banking -- is Pierre Edde. . . . Three times Minister of Finance. . . . Now president of the Beirut-Riyadh Bank and president of the Lebanese Bankers' Association. . . .

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Coach Wally Lemm signed a two-year contract with a reportedly "whopping pay increase" today and said he was determined to lead the St. Louis Cardinals of the National Football League to an Eastern Conference title.

BRUSSELS -- Renee Van Hoof, chief interpreter of the European Common Market, typifies the new freedom movement in Europe -- the movement of European women in the postwar era out of the house and into the labor market.
PARIS, Jan. 14 -- Spending for advertising in the major countries of Continental Europe has risen by 50 per cent in the last four years -- double the advertising growth rate in the United States.
BONN -- Summing up the state of the nation as the calendar turned to 1965 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard described West Germany as "one of the stablest, healthiest and most modern countries in the world."
Although the American Stock Exchange was subject to some late selling yesterday, stocks generally closed up in active trading. Advances amounted to 289 compared with 273 declines.

OPERATORS of ski areas in the north country were still hoping for more new snow yesterday despite a sizeable storm that hit the upper reaches of New England and New York's Adirondack country Wednesday.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 14 -- The Prime Ministers of Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland met today for the first time since Ireland was partitioned, more than 40 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Representative Jonathan B. Bingham paid the price today for his Congressional victory over Charles A. Buckley, longtime Bronx Democratic leader and former Representative from the 23d District.
The Board of Estimate heard arguments last night on the question of franchises for a community antenna television system.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 14 -- Animated cartoons, which have almost faded away from movie-theater screens, seem ready for a comeback. Such creatures as the Pink Panther and Yogi Bear are adorning theater screens across the country, and even the durable Tom and Jerry are about to experience a rebirth.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The Government is expected to announce next Tuesday, five days before the end of Prime Minister Harold Wilson's first 100 days in office, new plans for encouraging British exports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Republicans collected $4 million in the final five days of the Presidential campaign but held on to much of this money as a reserve against bills they knew were still outstanding.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 14 -- Mayor Thomas J. Whelan called today for a local rent control law in New Jersey to serve as an economic lever to prevent the creation of slums.
PARIS -- Trade follows the flag. Or does it? The French are beginning to wonder.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- Italian legislators condemned today as inadequate the surveillance of the nation's art treasurers that permitted a vandal to disfigure 24 masterpieces in Florence's Uffizi Gallery on Tuesday.
Two concerns in the mutual funds industry named top-level executives yesterday, while a leading closed-end investment company added a director.

OAK, long absent from the home scene, is being revived, judging by the prevalence of the venerable wood in Macy's model rooms, which go on view today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 14 (Reuters) -- The American Federation Cup women's tennis team was forced to halt practice with men players today when told that the court could not be used by men.

JERUSALEM (Israel Sector) -- Israeli's water problem has been thrust by two developments in the past year into unusual national and international attention.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- The Florida East Coast Railway, involved in the longest strike in railroad history, was ordered today to resume passenger service despite its plea that customers would be endangered.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 14 -- The European Economic Community disclosed today a vital new plan for eliminating all industrial trade barriers among the six member nations by July 1, 1967.

LONDON -- A modest industrial boom, with the prospect of more to come, gladdened the heart of many a Scot in 1964. At year's end, most of Scotland's economic indicators seemed to be pointing upward, in dramatic contrast to Britain's general economic decline.
BOSTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Murray Oliver's three goals tonight paced the last-place Boston Bruins to a 5-2 victory over the New York Rangers in a National Hockey league game.
LONDON -- The fiercest speculative attack against the pound sterling in three decades raised the cry in Britain last year for a new "Spirit of Dunkirk."
CORAL GABLES, Fla. Jan. 14 (AP) -- Fourteen horses were entered today for the $66,100 Tropical Park Handicap at 1 1-8 miles, the closing-day feature at Tropical Park tomorrow.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Court of Appeals upheld unanimously today the dismissal of a suit by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People seeking to halt nearly $10 million in state and city construction.
