WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- (UPI) -- Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, whose work led to development of the nuclear submarine, received the Government's highest atomic science award today.

Consolidated net income of the Ingersoll-Rand Company last year increased 8 per cent to $33 million from $30.7 million in 1963, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday by Robert H. Johnson, chairman of the diversified industrial machinery and equipment maker.

MONTREAL, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Bob Pulford's second goal of the game and Pete Stemkowski's first National Hockey League goal lifted the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

PROFESSIONAL basketball, always the stepchild of the major league sports scene (for understandable if regrettable reasons), has finally staked out its own little corner in the publicity-producing area of the day. The idea is to confuse, and thereby intrigue, the customers.
The Board of Estimate, in a unanimous vote, gave all but final city approval yesterday for commercial helicopter operations from the roof of the 59-story Pan Am Building.
THE new president of Bonwit Teller -- Mildred Custin -- gives the lie to the notion that successful women executives are armed aggressors before whom strong men quake.
In a world of divided nations and rancorous political antagonisms, a news dispatch from Belfast sounds a small note of hope.
The Ford Motor Company, created yesterday an important new post for Lee A. Iacocca, the executive who led the successful introduction of the Mustang sports car.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The economic and political life of the Arab Middle East was dominated in 1964 by the United Arab Republic's economic difficulties. And it looks as though Cairo's problems will, more than ever, be the source of the area's problems in 1965.
NICOSIA, Cyprus -- In 1963 the island of Cyprus was in a fair way to becoming 3,500 square miles of prosperity.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The United States delegation believes that the showdown over unpaid Soviet assessments for peace-keeping forces cannot be avoided when the General Assembly reconvenes next week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell said today he would introduce legislation to raise the Federal minimum wage to $2 an hour and reduce the standard work week to 32 hours.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The visit of Premier Sato of Japan to President Johnson made very little news, but it was historically and symbolically important just the same.

ROME -- Just as prosperity brought a soaring demand for meat in the United States in the nineteen-forties and in France a decade later, so is it currently whetting Italian appetites for cutlets, chops and steaks.
STOCKHOLM. -- Optimism among Sweden's economic oracles was restrained at the beginning of 1964. Looking back today, they can establish these facts:
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 14 -- Yale University announced today a $100 million development program for the next five to 10 years.
Losses in the waterfront strike are running up to $67 million a day throughout the country, the top Federal maritime authority warned yesterday.

LONDON -- Late last month one of the biggest and most sumptuous gambling casinos in the world opened here. Earlier in the month the first meals were served at an exclusive new Italian restaurant overlooking the Thames.
International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported late yesterday that it was planning to acquire Avis, Inc., the nation's second largest car-rental company.
MADRID -- Like other nations in similar stages of development. Spain displays an economic-social split personality.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Want to buy a cannon? A London bookshop is selling a pair because what it thought would be an attractive frontpiece has been classified as obstructions by the city.
LISBON -- Day by day the Portuguese dream for economic change is taking concrete form as a monumental suspension bridge rises over the Tagus River.
A $200 million decline in the Treasury's gold balance was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The First National City Bank is about to enter the factoring business. It will buy for $12 million in cash a small factoring concern, thereby getting into the business of advancing money to small manufacturers who must pay for materials and labor before they are paid by their customers for the finished goods they turn out.
ROME -- The Italian economy, still a bit weak and drawn after a two-year bout of price inflation and productive recession, was sitting up and taking a little light nourishment as the year ended.
MOSCOW -- The Soviet consumer may not be king yet, but he is moving up fast in the line of succession.
" It was absolutely remarkable the way the London stock market held up throughout most of the year despite one buffeting after another," a Wall Street securities analyst remarked recently.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- After 20 years of counting Republican votes in the House, Representative Leslie Cornelius Arends of Illinois was pretty certain by last Tuesday that he had the job of minority whip sewed up.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain, whom the San Francisco Warriors traded to the Philadelphia 76ers last night, warned his new club today that he might retire after this season.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller said today he had not determined what new taxes he would recommend to balance his forthcoming budget.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- All across East Europe the slogan of the day is economic reform.
The British pound was firm in light trading on the foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed $2.7920, dipping one point from Wednesday's level.

MARLBORO, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Nine abandoned children's swings move with the wind that sweeps over the rolling countryside, and snow clots on the skeletal trees around the ramshackle building where Floyd Patterson is once again preparing for some strange destiny.
A Nebraska merchant received yesterday the most coveted award of the National Retail Merchants Association.

Recurring reports from Albany that the Rockefeller administration is considering a state sales tax may be in the nature of trial balloons, to be shot down at will by official denial, but they cannot safely be disregarded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Christian A. Herter, the President's special representative for trade negotiations, issued a special statement today reaffirming United States backing for across-the-board tariff cuts in the Kennedy round of trade negotiations.
LONDON -- A six-legged, fire-breathing dog sits atop 65 new gasoline stations in Britain.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 14 -- The director of the commercial service of the Ceylon radio, Livy Wijemanne, has apologized to the Prime Minister, Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, for the service's faux pas in playing Beethoven's Pathetique Sonata immediately after Mrs. Bandaranaike's broadcast to the nation Sunday night on the coming general election.

WEST GERMANY's versatile mail-order king, Josef Neckermann, won equestrian Gold Medal at Tokyo Olympic Games just about time his mail-order house became first in Germany to enter insurance business. . . .

Many companies in the Common Market and throughout the West could function within the framework of their own financial structures by greater use of equipment leasing, ac cording to Jay B. Langner, president of the Hudson Leasing Corporation.

Early bird moviegoers, hoping to catch the 10:30 A.M. screening of "Baby, the Rain Must Fall" yesterday at Loew's State Theater, Broadway and 45th Street, found their way blocked by a large, black and white sign out front that read: "Stockholders Meeting Today. Regular performances Start at 1 P.M."
A dramatic expansion of petroleum operations in the Eastern Hemisphere is in full swing.
COPENHAGEN -- Denmark is contemplating with dismay Britain's 15 per cent increase in import duties, and with hope, her prospects for increasing exports to the United States.
TEHERAN, Iran -- Perhaps nowhere else in the Middle East have such broad, basic steps been taken in quest of economic progress as in Iran.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 14 (UPI) -- Gene Littler shot a nine-under-par 62 on the Stardust Country Club course today, but it was good for only a two-stroke lead in the opening round of the $35,000 San Diego open golf tournament.

Duell, Sloan and Pearce will issue in March a new edition of "The New World, The First Pictures of America," edited and annotated by Stefan Lorant. The book contains 64 water colors made in the late 16th century by John White, governor of the second colony on Roanoke Island, which was wiped out later by Indians.

In response to President Johnson's promise "to help deal with the explosion in our world population," Msgr. John Knott, director of the Family Life Bureau of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, reasserts that "Catholics will not support any public assistance . . . to promote artificial birth prevention."
A record budget of $368,408,600 was adopted yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

BRUSSELS -- The big question for the Common Market as the year began was: How much further will its members be able to move toward common economic goals in the face of continuing conflicts over political unity and nuclear defense?
A man described by Federal narcotics agents as "a major wholesaler" of narcotics was arrested after a fierce gun battle on an east Bronx street in the early hours yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- House Republicans disregarded the expressed wishes of their newly chosen leader today and re-elected Representative Leslie C. Arends of Illinois as minority whip
BELFAST -- Under its driving 50-year-old Prime Minister, Capt. Terence O'Neill, the Northern Irish Government hast made social and economic planning a new basis of policy.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A St. Louis producer of documentary films says one of his film crews staged battle scenes in South Vietnam because of the danger and difficulty in getting the real thing.
City Council President Paul R. Screvane announced yesterday that the city was prepared to resume its regular support of Mobilization for Youth at least until next June and "probably beyond."

WADDINGTON, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The ice on Brandy Creek leading into Lake St. Lawrence was booming and cracking early the other morning when this visitor with Steve Nemeth and Nick Karas of Kings Park, L.I., tested it to see if it was safe for ice fishing.
The City of El Paso, Tex., sold yesterday two issues of bonds totaling $14.4 million.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- At least 3,000 Texans plan to be on hand to see their native son sworn as the 36th President of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Intercity truck tonnage and loadings of revenue freight increased in the week ended Jan. 9, it was announced today.

LONDON -- It was 4:15 in the morning and it was cold and quiet outside the Hotel des Bergues in Geneva. The moon hung high and full like a copper ball over Mont Blanc and its rays shimmered on the black waters of Lake Geneva.

Catherine Wepy in a letter printed Jan. 2 states that "it seems self-evident that the 'considerable support' among anthropologists mentioned by Mr. Krock for the view mentioned [that Negro-white fusion in particular has a deteriorating effect upon both races] does appear to exist, without question."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Senate investigators of the affairs of Robert G. Baker have alerted Walter W. Jenkins, the former White House aide, that he will be called shortly after President Johnson's inauguration.

FOR the first time in thirty years, a major bridge match aimed at demonstrating something more than the merits of the teams concerned will get under way today.

A fashion designer who has straddled two fields -- Seventh Avenue and Broadway -- will have a dual opening Feb. 10.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- For the first time in his 10 years as the undisputed champion of Congressional foreign-aid cutters, Representative Otto E. Passman has called for outside help.
The Neediest Cases Fund received a $50 contribution yesterday from a group of girls whose initial plans for using the money could not be carried out.

Anyone who cherished the notion that the fight for women's rights was a thing of the faded past would have been instantly disabused yesterday if he had stumbled into the luncheon rally here of the Lucy Stone League.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. Four stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.

It is unfortunate that your editorial of Dec. 30, commending the State of New Jersey for its "bold and humanitarian step" in combating drug addiction with voluntary hospitalization, should also serve to decry New York's efforts in this field.

BERLIN, Jan. 14 -- East Germany's industrial production is to rise by 6 per cent in 1965, according to its economic plan for this year. The plan, which was adopted today, envisions increasing heavy industry and consumer goods production almost equally.

HELSINKI, Finland -- "We apparently are too lazy and too soft to be good salesmen," Finnish newspapers have been saying for years about Finnish manufacturers for their lack of initiative in the international market. "Let's snap out of our dreams and get to hard work."

Joan Sutherland, one of the Metropolitan Opera's most popular stars, will not appear in the United States during the entire season of 1965-66.

Directors of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., the nation's largest food chain, declared yesterday an extra dividend of 30 cents, the regular quarterly cash dividend of 30 cents and a stock dividend of 1 per cent.
PARIS -- The Kennedy Round is about to begin in Geneva -- again.
Twenty-three youths were arrested on a Bronx bus yesterday after eight of its windows had been smashed and several seats tossed out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- In light of a sharp worsening of the deficit in the nation's international payments in the final quarter of last year, President Johnson will probably send a special message on the balance of payments to Congress in a few weeks.

" Martin's Lie," Gian Carlo Menotti's 45-minute opera commissioned by the Columbia Broadcasting System, will be televised at 9 P.M. on Sunday, Jan. 24.

The settlement of a long, often acrimonious dispute between Bart Lytton, a California savings and loan executive, and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The largest yearly gain in nonfarm payroll employment since the recovery year of 1959 was made in 1964, the Labor Department reported today.
The case of gold fever that broke out a few days ago subsided after the Treasury Department pledged to maintain the dollar price of gold. But the problem is not solved.

A record $85.3 million in State of Israel bonds were sold last year in this country and other parts of the free world. The proceeds from them are used for economic development, absorption of immigrants and expansion of industry in undeveloped regions of Israel.

The British pound dropped 12 points to $2.7908 for Monday delivery in quiet trading on the foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

An abandoned subway station -- the first and most elegant ever built in New York -- has been proposed as the site of a Transit Authority museum, and the Transit Authority Commissioners say they are enchanted by the idea.
Organized labor will step up its drive to form a new union for New York's 40,000 taxicab drivers with demonstrations in four boroughs today.

A former Harlem landlord was sent to jail for 43 days yesterday after he failed to pay fines totaling $955 imposed for 23 violations of the Multiple Dwelling Law and Administrative Code in 11 tenements.

The one remaining barrier between a profligate Executive and Congress and the value of the nation's currency is the stipulation that the note and deposit liabilities of the Federal Reserve be backed by gold, presently 25 per cent.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 15 -- President Johnson and Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson of Canada will sign an agreement tomorrow to eliminate tariffs at the manufacturer's level on automobiles and most parts.

BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- John Havlicek led a third-quarter uprising tonight that carried the Boston Celtics to their 13th straight National Basketball Association victory by a 104-95 count over the Philadelphia 76ers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Industrial production rose by 6 per cent last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

After a year's search for a new City Administrator-Deputy Mayor, John V. Connorton has been chosen by Mayor Wagner. He is an old friend of the Mayor, and in fact was his intermediary in getting Dr. Luther Gulick to be the first City Administrator in 1954 when Mr. Wagner took office. Mr. Connorton then served for a year as a Deputy City Administrator.

Sal (The Barber) Maglie, the man with the 2 o'clock shadow, officially gave up baseball for boxing yesterday. The former star pitcher for the Giants, the Dodgers and the Yankees was sworn in as a deputy commissioner of the New York State Athletic Commission, a job that will give him supervisory powers over professional boxing and wrestling activities in 17 northern counties of the state.

The city agreed yesterday to provide an extra two million gallons of water a day to Carmel, N.Y., for a proposed new brewery -- but on condition that the community develop its own water sources within five years.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 16 -- Sir Winston Churchill has suffered a stroke and slipped into a deep sleep. He was 90 years old Nov. 30.

The repetition by captive dolphins of bursts of sound uttered by a laboratory experimenter are interpreted by Dr. John C. Lilly to mean that the animals are attempting to communicate. This view was expressed by Dr. Lilly in a recent interview in Miami.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Transportation Company asked the Public Utility Commission today for a five-cent transfer charge, part of the price of averting a transit strike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to increase the budget of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency "to assure the continuing leadership of the United States in the purposeful pursuit of peace."

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 15 -- A Federal grand jury handed down indictments today in connection with the slaying three civil rights workers near Philadelphia, Miss., last June. Federal Judge William Harold Cox ordered secrecy until arrests were made.

THAKHEK, Laos, Jan. 15 -- Communist policy in Thakhek Province, in central Laos, appears at present to be one of subversion as opposed to large-scale military action, according to the area commander, Colonel Kongsy.
The city said yesterday that it would move on Monday to get contempt citations against four union leaders in the two-week strike by Welfare Department workers.
" Turandot" will be given today by the Metropolitan Opera at 2 P.M. and "The Marriage of Figaro" at 8 P.M.
Preliminary figures indicate that the Wheeling Steel Corporation's 1964 results "will be comfortably in the black."

Dick Whitman, John McDonnell and Pete Whitehouse, who will run in cup races tonight at Boston, won titles last night in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships. So did Henry Laskau, who hadn't raced in eight years and won't race again until June.
MOSCOW, Jan. 15 -- The Soviet Union disclosed today additional details on its space ship Voskhod (Sunrise) in which a three-man crew made a 24-hour flight last October.

LOOKING for a quiet place to lunch far from the madding crowd ? A reasonable Greenwich Village restaurant in which to dine ? A spot to repair to after the bars close and the conversation has still left much unsaid?
Richard S. Aldrich, a Manhattan Councilman at Large and a cousin of Governor Rockefeller, is emerging as a leading Republican contender to run against Mayor Wagner this fall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The House has finally got its own subway.

A plan to merge Hewitt-Robins, Inc., with Litton Industries, Inc., was approved in Buffalo yesterday by holders of more than two-thirds of the outstanding Hewitt-Robins shares, not taking into account 125,000 disputed shares, and by stockholders of Litton.
THE "traditionalists" built up a substantial lead yesterday in their match against the "scientists" at the Park Lane Hotel. After 45 boards the "traditionalists" led by 53 international match points.

SEATTLE, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- The defending champion, Ronnie Frank of Paramount, Calif., held a commanding lead in the senior men's competition today after the compulsory figures in the Pacific Coast figure-skating championships being held here.
UPPSALA, Sweden, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union apparently exploded a large nuclear device underground today. Swedish experts said that it was most likely a hydrogen bomb.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Justice Department filed suit today against the state of Alabama, charging that its new voter registration test was too difficult and illegally discriminated against persons trying to register.
American Express Company, for the fourth time since last April, once again extended the deadline on its offer to settle about $140 million in claims pending against one of its subsidiaries.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 15 -- More than 2,000 children marched through the streets of Leopoldville today in a demonstration against former Premier Cyrille Adoula and countries said to be supporting him.
The case of the three men accused of stealing 24 precious stones from the American Museum of Natural History was marked off the court calendar yesterday without a new date being set.

NEWARK, Jan. 15 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested three men today and charged them with the armed robbery of $23,000 from the Delawanna branch of the New Jersey Bank and Trust Company in Clifton on Jan, 11. Two of those arrested were free on $5,000 bail in connection with earlier bank robberies.
OTTAWA, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Paul Martin said today that Canada had halted, for clarification, the sale of 12 transport planes ordered for use in West Irian.

Your gracious and comprehensive news recital on Dec. 27 of the varied achievements of our late beloved Columbia Dean Emeritus, Harry J. Carman, warrants a further brief addendum for the public record.
MIAMI, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Hialeah Park will open its 40th racing season tomorrow with 12 of the best sprinters in Florida entered for the $25,000- added Royal Poinciana Handicap.
The Kohon String Quartet, in its second recital of a series of three at Town Hall, offered last night only rarely played works.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Secretary General U Thant said tonight that he would make a new appeal Monday to all members to find a way out of the current financial-political crisis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Premier Pierre Ngendandumwe of the African nation of Burundi was assassinated in Bujumbura, the capital, today as he left a hospital after a visit to his wife who had recently given birth to a baby, a State Department spokesman said tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- A small California electronics concern filed a $150 million civil antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday in the United States district court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- With the aid of a friend, who is a mechanic, a New Jersey plasterer has solved a bothersome problem of this trade. He can now mix the smooth cement needed for interior dry walls while on the job.
The Mayor's Committee on Job Advancement reported yesterday that 65 major advertisers in 1964 used models representing minority groups "to help bring into focus a truer picture of America."
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 15 -- Australia is steadily preparing to cope with possible greater involvement in the conflict between Indonesia and Malaysia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The divisive consequences of the nomination of Barry Goldwater have brought a seemingly endless series of troubles to the Republican party.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15 -- The United States went ahead today with its program of expanded military and economic aid for South Vietnam in the war against the Communist guerrillas.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The European Common Market said today the growth of its industrial production slowed during December. It reported rapid growth only in West Germany and the Netherlands.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The nude body of a well-to-do artist -- his skull crushed by a saw-toothed Polynesian war club -- was found today at the foot of tiki gods and artificial palms in his downtown hotel room.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Senator George McGovern said today that the United States was not winning in South Vietnam, could not produce a military victory and should seek "political settlement" with North Vietnam.
SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Suburban parents who are concerned about teen-age behavior should look to their own conduct.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz gave farmers who hire foreign workers no encouragement today in their fight to have the so-called bracero program reinstated.
WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Holy Cross turned free-throw accuracy, superior rebounding and John Wendelken's 28 points into a 93-74 basketball victory over Dartmouth tonight.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission opposed here today the repeal of the equal-time requirement for political campaign broadcasts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, led in the Senate today a wrathful denunciation of Administration plans to close 11 veterans' hospitals as an economy move.
The bond market yesterday provided almost no excitement as prices remained stable and trading volume dried up almost entirely.

More than 40 entertainment unions from all over the free world have scheduled a March meeting in Brussels in an effort to organize an international labor secretariat to deal solely with problems affecting them.
Industrial Issues led a moderate advance yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

The advice in your Jan. 4 editorial that the Un-American Activities Committee of the House be abolished was fine. Unfortunately, it was frustrated by the refusal of Speaker McCormack to recognize Representative Edwards for the purpose of moving that the rules be so amended.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The State Department declined today to say whether the United States still felt bound by the Geneva accord prohibiting foreign military intervention in Laos.

Bache Co., the nation's third largest brokerage firm, plans to change from a partnership to a corporation on Feb. 1. This was disclosed yesterday in the official bulletin of the New York Stock Exchange.
NEW ORLEANS; Jan. 15 -- The future growth of newspaper advertising was linked in large measure today to the newspapers' increased ability to use color in their ads.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Thomas J. Mackell, who is now carrying the banner of the pro-Wagner forces in the campaign for the Democratic leadership in the State Senate, got his basic training in political warfare in intraparty skirmishes in Queens.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- The Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, former leader of the banned Zimbabwe African National Union, won a High Court appeal today against his conviction and 12-month prison sentence on charges of having published a subversive pamphlet.

I am profoundly shocked by the treatment of the Jewish people in the Soviet Union. I would like strongly to endorse the moral protest and appeal of conscience to the Soviet Union published as an advertisement in The Times Jan. 14.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- David J. McDonald compared his election opponent today to Barry Goldwater. Mr. McDonald the president of the United Steelworkers of America, said that his rival, I.W. Abel, and Mr. Goldwater both wanted to go back to the "good old days."

Two of the oldest textile companies in the nation -- West Point Manufacturing Company and Pepperell Manufacturing Company -- are planning to merge in a transaction involving more than $110 million in stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- John T. Connor, President Johnson's first Cabinet appointee, won Senate confirmation today to become Secretary of Commerce.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 15 -- President Johnson is attempting to revitalize the Cabinet as a dynamic and major instrument of Government, according to informed sources.

ONE of the earliest purveyors of golden oak, Herb Brooks Discoveries, has just moved to larger quarters at 350 Bleecker Street, across the way from the former shop. Although the attics of America have probably not yet been entirely stripped of turn-of-the-century furniture and bibelots, Mr. Brooks had re cently decided to investigate Europe as an additional source for late Victorian furniture.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Cornell scored 26 points in the last 10 minutes of the first half tonight for a 40-31 lead and went on to beat Penn, 76 -- 65.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Players of the Philadelphia Eagles have been asked by Jerry Wolman, the team's owner, to jump the National Football League Players Association and form a company union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Senate Republicans approved today committee assignments that permitted South Carolina's Strom Thurmond to keep at least some of the seniority power he had gained as a Democrat.

DETROIT, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Both management and labor in the auto industry hailed as good news tonight the announcement of a treaty between the United States and Canada eliminating tariffs on autos and parts.
The stock market chugged uphill yesterday to close in the thin air at the top of the grade.

HOUSTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) -- The American Football League refused today to restrict the signing of college players before their eligibility runs out. The league demanded a joint meeting among the pro leagues and the National Collegiate Athletic Association as the only solution to the problem.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 15 (UPI) -- Wes Ellis, a cross-handed putter from West Caldwell, N.J., moved into the second-round lead of the $35,000 San Diego open golf tournament today with a 36-hole score of 131 -- 11 under par for the distance.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Ambassador to the United States got what he wanted -- a model of a covered wagon.
TRENTON, Jan. 15 -- Overwhelming support for reapportioning the Legislature on the basis of Congressional districts instead of county lines was evinced at a public hearing at the Capitol here today.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 15 -- Premier Levi Eshkol said today that war or peace in the Middle East depended on whether the Arab states implemented plans to deprive Israel of her "just share" of water from the Jordan River.

ROME -- A fact that strikes diplomats with experience in Communist China is that Peking, although continuing its violent anti-American propaganda, seems to have ceased referring to the United States as a "paper tiger." WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Government accountants said today the Navy had waisted more than $1 million in buying outdated radar sets for fighter planes.

MARATHON, Fla. -- The trailer parks and camping grounds from one end of the Keys to the other are beginning to fill up. This influx of campers is a welcome sight to both state park officials and the operators of the dozen or more private camping grounds in the Keys.

CLEWISTON, Fla. -- The decrease in traffic on U.S. 27, which passes through this Lake Okeechobee town, has been felt here since opening of Interstate 75 last summer. National and state achievements in boating will be given recognition at the Chicago National Boat, Travel and Outdoors Show. The show will be held March 6 through 14 at McCormick Place.
An experimental all-weather track has been put in use for horses in winter training at Roosevelt Raceway. Designed by Paul (Tex) Tankersley, the new three-eighths mile strip was recently completed.

MILAN, Italy -- When Milan's first subway line began operating last November, the inhabitants of this congested city in a hurry greeted the event with a mixture of pride, irritation and the customary Italian flair for improvised experiments.

HOLLYWOOD A YOUNG man named Richard Zanuck quietly celebrated his 30th birthday the other day. This event normally would be of scant interest to anyone, except for the fact that young Zanuck happens to head one of Hollywood's most important studios, 20th Century Fox.

In January 1960, a task force (the term was then still a novelty in governmental jargon) presented a plan for Federal aid to education to President-elect John F. Kennedy. The document broke so sharply with prior school aid proposals that it was considered wishful thinking by many Washington pragmatists.

NINETEEN SIXTY-FOUR is the year Carol Burnett will probably want to forget. It started out so well, too, with Carol signed for a Broadway musical and a television revue, our ended somewhat dramatically with a taxi accident that put Carol in a neck brace. She had to stop dancing. She had to quit her musical. She had to begin worrying about the angry people threatening her with legal suits.

The North American Yacht Racing Union and this country's International 5.5-Meter Class Association will have their annual meetings in the New York Yacht Club on Wednesday. Both are expected to be of particular importance to racing yachtsmen.

OSLO -- The world's oldest and largest ski museum may have to find new quarters soon. Situated at the foot of the famous Holmenjollen Ski Jump outside Oslo, its collection is expanding faster than room can be found to exhibit it.

The inboard-outboard marine engine, introduced in the late nineteen-fifties by Volvo, has effected a change in the variety and total number of small inboard boats as reflected in the show. Scores of craft from 14 to 31 feet are equipped with that type of stern-drive power plant. They range from 60 to 450 horsepower.

In these days when first novels belong to the twenties or thereabout, give a thought this morning to a writer whose first novel will be published midway between his 74th and 75th birthdays. He is a distinguished one at that, Marc Connelly, who collaborated with the late George S. Kaufman on plays when the theater was the theater, who won a Pulitzer Prize for "The Green Pastures."

Permanent homes for 550 abandoned Negro babies have been found by a private adoption agency in a project that has rescued the infants from hospital wards and reduced the city's cost of supporting each child from $30 to $5.30 a day.

MILTON, N.J. -- In an era when the experienced skier thinks nothing of undertaking a long-distance trip to northern Adirondack or Green Mountain outposts, thousands of new recruits to the sport continue to derive plenty of enjoyment from tackling the modest slopes situated within a 90-minute drive of midtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Republican party is not a very interesting invalid because it is disposed to believe in the old fallacy that a change of doctors will remove the causes of its condition. But, being an invalid, it is getting the usual attention. That is why so much newspaper space and air-time is being given to bulletins from the sick-room as old doctors are fired and new doctors are hired.

NEWARK, Jan. 16 -- A proposed master plan for the orderly growth of Newark in the next 20 to 30 years was made public today by the Central Planning Board and the Division of City Planning. It is the first of such scope since the master plan of 1947 was proposed.

WADDINGTON, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The big northern pike fixed a baleful eye on the humans peering eagerly down at him through the hole in the ice. A MAN who is active on Broadway and respected for his acumen was speculating the other day on trends in the theater. He thought that the vogue for British imports was near the end of its course He wondered whether the popularity of sex comedies was not ripe for a downturn.

The Great Lakes bulk cargo fleet hauled 192 million short tons of cargo last year, chalking up its fifth best season. The fleet also established six individual commodity records, it was reported last week by the Lake Carriers' Association.

THE Joan Sutherland school of singing has issued its latest text, a handsome two-disk album for London Records called The Age of Bel Canto (A 4257; stereo OSA 1257). Unlike an earlier album called "The Art of The Prima Donna," also for London, in which she sang alone, on these disks she is joined by two masters of the style, Marilyn Horne, the mezzo-soprano, and Richard Conrad, tenor.

Undefeated New York City Community College won its 14th straight game yesterday, routing Westchester Community College, 126 -- 72, on the winner's court in Brooklyn. Wally Goodwin and Ken Hall each scored 24 points for the Bees who made 52 of 81 field goal attempts for a 64 per cent average.

Comprising paintings, sculpture and miscellaneous artifacts it amounts to a cream-skimming of the private possessions of members of the New York Bar and is being shown in aid of indigent persons requiring legal help.

This delicately seasoned meat pie is excellent for either luncheon or supper.

Pookie Adams is a crazy mixed-up kid, but she's not the sort of bird that would hatch her eggs in anyone else's nest.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia, President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike of Ceylon publicly appealed today to President Sukarno of Indonesia "to reconsider your decision to withdraw from the United Nations."
LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Thousands of bettors collected money today on a horse that finished last because of an error in reporting the result to Britain's 15,000 betting shops.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- New York State lost its Republican seat on the House Ways and Means Committee today in another setback for the newly chosen House minority leader, Representative Gerald R. Ford Jr. of Michigan.
The American Stock Exchange and a brokerage concern have offered to settle a $5 million damage suit brought by the trustees of the Swan-Finch Oil Corporation for $450,000.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- A British expedition has found a 500-mile-long Roman road in the Sahara.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan.19 -- The lights in the Celebrity Room's Venetian glass chandeliers flashed on and off nearly 50 times last night before Frank J. Hale managed to get three-fourths of the opening-night audience back into his adjoining Royal Poinciana Playhouse for the third and final act of "Beekman Place." Only then did the impresario finally sit down to his own four-course dinner.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- After a succession of three male presidents, Sarah Lawrence College -- a school for women -- named a woman today to be its new president.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Construction of the Rutgers Medical School at a cost of more than $16 million is expected to begin this year, the university announced today. Completion is planned for 1967.

The State Commission of Investigation voted unanimously yesterday to investigate Mayor Wagner's charges that an offer -- tantamount to a bribe -- was made by the Democratic state chairman to win votes in the Senate leadership fight at Albany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Soviet Union apparently violated the treaty curbing nuclear tests when a large underground explosion last week released radioactivity that was carried beyond the Soviet boundaries, the Atomic Energy Commission said today.

The head of the striking long-shore union expressed confidence yesterday that a second vote -- to be held tomorrow -- on the proposed new contract, would be affirmative and that 24,000 New York dock workers would have a new agreement.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Members on both sides of the House of Commons charged today that American aircraft manufacturers had tried to discredit British manufacturers in an attempt to sell more American planes.
VIENNA, Jan. 19 -- A photocopy of a receipted bill for rope used by Nazis on Sept. 1, 1942, to hang the 12-man Jewish council of Lvov has been delivered to prosecutors at Stuttgart, Germany.

The Metropolitan Opera returned Wagner's "Der Fliegende Hollander" to its repertory last night in a performance that made one conscious of its year's absence. Early Wagner though it may be -- the composer had not yet shaken off influences of Weber and Meyerbeer -- it is nevertheless strongly dramatic, and that was its effect on this occasion.

Efforts to end the Welfare Department strike have broken down because of the strikers' demand that Mayor Wagner give them a commitment he has no legal right to give: a promise of immunity from the fines and other penalties theoretically made mandatory by the Condon-Wadlin Law.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- Simultaneous attacks on the French Government's economic power were launched today by labor and business.
Dr. Calvin E. Gross, the Superintendent of Schools, was cautioned yesterday against undue haste in proceeding with his plans to reorganize the city's high schools.
TRENTON, Jan. 19 -- Marion West Higgins, who last Tuesday became the first woman Speaker of the State's Assembly, was sworn in today as New Jersey's first woman Acting Governor.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Sid Luckman, Otto Graham and Bob Waterfield, three former National Football League quarterbacks who led their teams to world championships, were among seven players named today to the pro football Hall of Fame.
The bullish tone on the American Stock Exchange subsided yesterday after 14 consecutive sessions of price advances.
" A classic bind -- unexpectedly low income, excessively high outgo --" is the way a banker diagnosed the financial plight of the World's Fair yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce called today for repeal of what it termed "the current hodge-podge of discriminatory excuse taxes."
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 20 -- Sir Winston Churchill is holding his own in his struggle for life.

Henry Winston, a national Communist party leader, announced yesterday he had dropped his $1 million suit against the Federal Government for negligence that he said had caused him to go blind while a Federal prisoner.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- An Israeli spokesman described today as "ridiculous" news reports from Lebanon that a secret Arab force had carried out a raid in Israel and killed 12 Israelis.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1964. The preliminary annual report was released yesterday and is subject to final audit.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Gov. Robert E. Smylie of Idaho, after conferences with his party's top spokesmen in Congress, said today he foresaw a Republican national leadership conference in the early summer or late spring.
City Council President Paul R. Screvane mapped for the city budget authorities yesterday a campaign against poverty that would cost $87.9 million in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A group of Democratic Senators introduced a bill today to increase the price support for domestic wheat to 100 per cent of parity -- the standard for measuring farm prices declared by law to be fair to farmers in relation to their costs.
PHOENIX, Ariz. -- There is no gauge to measure the influence of one nation's cuisine on another, but it is certainly true that Mexico has made the greatest imprint on the Arizona kitchen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy is reported to be disappointed over what he feels was Mayor Wagner's failure to keep their agreement to resolve the Democratic legislative leadership crisis with a secret ballot.
THE second annual Decoy Contest will be held at Babylon, L.I., on March 21, according to Walter Berg, the president of the Great South Bay Waterfowlers Association.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- "I am very feminine, but I am not a feminist," the diminutive woman says, smoothing the skirt of her aqua wool suit.

HAVANA, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Cuban Government said today that a United States-made B-26 bomber that came from the north and "retired with a northern heading" staged a raid on sugar-producing Pinar del Rio Province Sunday.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it would adopt new zone schedules on Feb. 1 for some of its Harlem Division evening rushhour commuter trains.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- New York and Connecticut have tentatively agreed on a joint plan to save commuter service on the New Haven Railroad.

SCHRUNS, Austria, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Marielle Goitschel of France, the Olympic gold medalist and winner of the Kandahar Trophy last week, won the Golden Keys women's slalom race today in a blinding snowstorm.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A nylon cord was found in a jet engine of an Air Force tanker plane that crashed here Saturday and killed 30 persons. But the head of an investigating board said it was too early to say if the cord contributed to the crash.
ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that the state would drastically alter its approach to the construction of mental hospitals.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 15 -- A debate that promises to have far-reaching effects on the practice of Communism in Eastern Europe is taking form in three countries.
DOVER, Del., Jan. 19 -- Charles L. Terry Jr., former Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, was sworn in today as Governor of Delaware.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) -- Sledge won a close battle with Viking Spirit today in the $10,000 County Fair Purse at Santa Anita.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Britain appealed to the Soviet Union today to make a voluntary contribution and thus "give the lead" to extricate the United Nations from the crisis over unpaid assessments.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The National Theater has another undoubted triumph on its books with Arthur Miller's "The Crucible," which opened at the Old Vic tonight in a stunning production by Sir Laurence Olivier.
Two more Mafia leaders were taken yesterday before the special Federal grand jury investigating the disappearance of Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, underworld figure.

WARSAW, Jan. 19 -- A troop train laden with German soldiers and equipment comes whirling around the bend. Suddenly there is an explosion and the train is wrecked. Polish guerrillas rush out and kill the few surviving Germans.
STRASBOURG, France, Jan. 19 -- Economic growth in Europe will be substantially less in 1965 than in 1964, according to a forecast today by the European Economic Community's chief economist.

Another detail in one of the most intriguing and terrible episodes of English history has just come to light with the discovery of Anne Mowbray's coffin and skeleton in a subterranean chamber of the old nunnery of St. Clare in Stepney, not far from the Tower of London.

BOWIE, MD., Jan. 19 (AP) -- John J. Roe's Tilmar, a candidate for stakes to be run later in the meeting, missed tying the track record by only one second in the seventh race today when he ran six furlongs in 1:10 2-5.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 19 -- Project Gemini, the nation's next major manned space venture, moved forward today when the launching vehicle and an unmanned spacecraft performed almost flawlessly in a critical suborbital shot down the Atlantic Test Range.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th President of the United States, will begin his first elected term in the office when he is sworn in at noon tomorrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Nearly $25 million in income tax liens today tied up the Bay area property of Harry S. Stonehill, the international businessman, and his partner, Robert P. Brooks.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 19 -- A comparatively little-known area of late 19th-century French painting is interestingly explored in a major exhibition opening on Thursday at the Yale University Art Gallery, Entitled "Neoimpressionists and Nabis in the Collection of Arthur G. Altschul," it concentrates on the work of the advance guard in Paris between the decline of impressionism and the rise of the fauves, that is, during the 20 years from 1885 to 1905.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Hubert H. Humphrey bounced about town today, only hours away from what he called "a new job rating."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has had a heart attack, described by his doctors as "mild," the agency announced today.

CLIFFWOOD, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Glowing, red-hot Chug-A-Mugs destined to hold cold Rheingold beer popped out of batteries of automated molds at the rate of 140 a minute here today as the American Can Company put its newest glass plant into production.

Emile Griffith, who successfully defended his welterweight title twice in 1964, was named yesterday Ring Magazine's fighter of the year.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Cassius Clay has a $17,000 red-and-white bus. It is one of his three most prized possessions (the others are his wife and his religion, says a friend). Today, Clay drove the bus, filled with newspapermen, photographers and two buckets and a mop, into a ditch as he misjudged the width of a two-lane road.
The five leading New York City commercial bankers who resigned from the financial advisory committee of the World's Fair Corporation have taken an extreme but effective means of protest.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 19 (AP) -- A Communist led crowd of several thousand marched on the Presidential Palace today, demanding the dismissal of a Cabinet Minister it blamed for the high cost of living.

Robert Moses, president of the World's Fair Corporation, denounced yesterday as "false" charges of financial secrecy at the fair. The charges had been made by George S. JOE LYNCH of Georgetown University, has a "good chance of running in the Wanamaker Mile in the Millrose Games," according to his coach, Steve Benedek. The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a drop of 989,496 shares in the short-interest position on the exchange in the last month. Although historically the short-interest position decreases between mid-December and mid-January, the drop for the month is the biggest in the last year.

The First National City Bank, which already operates seven branches in Africa, will acquire a minority interest in 34 more banking offices under terms of an agreement announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The Yankee infielder, Phil Linz, was fined last season for his harmonica-playing, but the Boston Red Sox crooner, Tony Conigliaro expects to be paid handsomely for his offseason appearances as a singer.
Plans for a 48-story office skyscraper, the largest to be built on the West Side since the war, were announced yesterday by the Bowery Savings Bank.
DUSSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 20 -- Heinar Kipphardt's play "In der Sache J. Robert Oppenheimer ("The Oppenheimer Case") is to be played in English in London and New York this year.
The top staff officer of the American Bankers Association recommended yesterday that the legal link between gold and the domestic money supply "be relaxed," but "not removed."

Radio station WMCA submitted two affidavits to the United States District Court here yesterday in support of its contention that the state's Assembly and Senate districts were gerrymandered in the four Republican reapportionment plans.

Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol found 19 leaders of the Welfare Department strike guilty of criminal contempt yesterday for flouting his order that they end the walkout. He sentenced three of them to 30 days in jail and fined them $250 each.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson today became the first President's wife in history to hold the Bible while her husband took the oath of office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Johnson's Inauguration was a dramatization of the American Dream. It was all there, "bigger and better" than ever before: The poor boy, the country boy at the pinnacle of the world; the lovely wife holding the Bible for the oath; the eternal American combination of religion and politics; and above all, the optimism of America transmitted by a manmade satellite in the sky to a distracted and pessimistic world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The heaviest concentration of security forces ever assembled in the nation's capital was mobilized today to insure the safety of the President and Vice President and to control the record Inaugural crowds.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's Inaugural Address in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Hundreds of Texans came to Washington for the inauguration of Lyndon B. Johnson "on faith" -- without invitations, tickets, or credentials other than money. They were rewarded today when the man they call "our boy" became President of the United States in his own right.
There will not be enough silver in the long run to satisfy both industrial and coinage needs at the present rate of demand.

Relatively few people have heard of Maurice Pate, but scores of millions of children in well over 100 countries have been fed and clothed because he lived. His measure of greatness was not fame, from which he shrank, although he was famous among those connected with relief work anywhere in the world.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- President Johnson's inauguration today is expected to cost about $2.1 million, almost $500,000 more than the inauguration of President Kennedy in 1961.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Esthetically speaking, Presidential Inaugurations have begun to go the way of the Hollywood biblical epic. Both are afflicted by the national passion for overproducing the simplest of dramas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Members of Congress acclaimed President Johnson's first Inaugural Address today as a fitting statement of the country's abiding principles, aspirations and goals. Republicans and Democrats agreed that the President had sketched, in appropriately broad and nonpartisan terms, the lofty objectives behind which all patriotic Americans should unite.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Fred A. Young has decided to resign as Republican state chairman.

The boycott of Public School 617 in Brooklyn is an act of unpardonable irresponsibility. The Rev. Milton A. Galamison, who organized the action, cannot plead ignorance of the human and educational harm he has done in asking 136 students -- many of them emotionally disturbed, some retarded and others chronic truants and discipline cases -- to stay out of school.
Government bonds again held the spotlight yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, where prices were generally up in moderate trading.
ROME, Jan. 20 -- Barocco attempted last night to stab through the tough-skinned world of haute couture.
" Tiny Alice" is a mystery play. Everyone feels he must see it in order to talk about it. Finally, one month after its opening, even Edward Albee is talking.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- While President Johnson held center stage tonight Republicans gathered in the wings for their own party.

A luncheon and fashion show next Thursday at the Terrace Room at the Plaza will aid the Thrift Shop of the Girls Club of New York. Miss Mary Alice Rice is producing the show, called "Around the World in Style."

SCHRUNS, Austria, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Marielle Goitschel, a 19-year-old student from Val d'Isere, France, gained her second victory in the three-day Golden Keys women's ski races today when she beat all rivals by more than one second in the giant slalom.

The Fairfield County Commuters Association, expressing fears that the New Haven Railroad's commuter service to New York was in danger of collapse, said yesterday that it had begun a study of alternative transportation.
Treasury bond prices continued to advance yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Benedetto, Croce, the Italian philosopher and politician, once said: "Politics, like economics, has its own laws, independent of morals."

MIAMI, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Ogden Phipps's Open Hearing, ridden by Braulio Baeza, scored an easy victory in the second division of the Jasmine Stakes at Hialeah Park today before a crowd of 17,389 and paid $62.20 for $2.

THOSE were true Men of Distinction who were elected this week to the Pro Football Hall of Fame at Canton, Ohio. Of all the various sports pantheons this one is the most snobbish and most exclusive, perhaps too much so. Yet seven scintillating stars of yesteryear presented such impeccable credentials that they have been named to join the 24 men already in the shrine.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Timo Makinen of Finland and his teammate, Paul Easter, were officially declared the winners of the long-distance time-endurance section of the Monte Carlo auto rally today, although the final check cost them an apparently perfect record in penalty points.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 20 -- A system for machine tools that embodies automatic controls without the costly numerical-control system was put on display today by the Bullard Company. What the system does, in effect, is to use the numerical-control concept to build a template -- a guiding device for machine tools -- that incorporates all the programing a client's engineering staff wants to build into it.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 20 -- Germany has suddenly soared into the front ranks as an international supplier of private capital. Foreign fund raising in Europe last year surpassed $600 million.

MADRID, Jan. 20 -- Eighteen young Basque nationalists went on trial before the Tribunal of Public Order here today on charges of illegal association and propaganda. A 19th defendant was being tried in absentia.

The Commissioner of Markets, Albert S. Pacetta, agreed yesterday to provide representatives of the West Fourteenth Street meat merchants with copies of a report suggestiing the sprawling market be relocated in the Hunts Point area of the Bronx.

The United Parents Associations called on Mayor Wagner in a letter yesterday to make available for school construction $50 million more than had been proposed. The group argued that this amount could "safely and prudently" be released from the city's unemcumbered debt margin for borrowing.

A least one unnamed member of the Mafia underworld is involved in a conspiracy in which horse meat has been sold to the public under counterfeit labels, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office reported yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority sold $25 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Alex Quaison-Sackey, President of the General Assembly, and the Secretary General, U Thant, have drawn up a plan that they hope will end the threat of a confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union over the latter's voting rights in the Assembly.

A very small bottle containing, among other ingredients, a few drops of "bull's blood," gave rise yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, to a charge that the Government was seeking to gain control of the $2 5-billion-a-year cosmetics industry.
WARSAW, Jan. 20 -- The Warsaw Pact's Political Advisory Committee ended a two-day meeting here today, but there was no official word on the results.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Twenty-three per cent of junior and senior high school students questioned in a recent study in Michigan admitted drinking some alcoholic beverage at least occasionally and 92 per cent said they had tasted alcohol at some time.

SELMA, Ala., Jan. 20 -- A rift in the white community over Sheriff James G. Clark's militant actions in dealing with Negroes attempting to register as voters broke into the open today while the sheriff was arresting 150 applicants on a charge of unlawful assembly.

Olin J. Stephens, a noted designer of notable yachts, was awarded the Nathaniel G. Herreshoff Trophy last night at the annual dinner of the North American Yacht Racing Union. The union, a national organization with 3,160 members, gives the award each year to the person adjuged to have made a major contribution to the sport of yachting.

The Department of Hospitals ordered Howard Park General Hospital in Queens yesterday to clear out all of its more than 85 patients by Feb. 11. New admissions have already been halted at the 225-bed, privately owned institution at Cross Bay Boulevard and Belt Parkway, Howard Beach.

President Johnson's Inaugural Address was an eloquent and moving statement. Although no single phrase is likely to prove memorable, the President achieved a powerful effect by developing a great theme -- the implications of rapid scientific and technological change -- in terms of human society's struggle for the enduring political goals of justice, liberty, and union.

Urban renewal for the Morningside Heights area, long sought by planning and civic groups, was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. Board of Estimate approval will be required for final sanction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The State Department had no immediate comment today on the report that West Germany, in cooperation with other European countries, was shipping $80 million worth of modern arms to Israel.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20 -- A scheme under which coin collectors are said to have been defrauded of millions of dollars for undelivered, Mexican coins has been discovered here.
I cannot agree with the reasoning of your Jan. 4 editorial on the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The Pacific Coast Stock Exchange's board of governors, rather than its general membership, will answer the hot-potato question of whether to admit a subsidiary of a mutual-fund management company as a member.
EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 20 (AP) -- Billie Sol Estes, the former Pecos, Tex., financier, had a jail breakfast of cold cereal and hot coffee today and mopped his cell along with three other prisoners.

In three ways we seem to be treating the Congo in traditional fashion. We assimilate it largely into the cold war; we treat it primarily as a problem of governmental stability; and we act pragmatically to concentrate on the issue that seems most pressing at the moment.

Carol Channing, star of "Hello, Dolly?" since the musical opened on Nov. 18, 1963, has agreed to extend her contract until June 1, 1967. A spokesman for David Merrick, the producer, said it was believed to be the longest commitment a star has had with a producer.
CARDIFF, Wales, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Brian Curvis of Wales outpointed Vince Shomo of New York in a 10-round bout tonight.
Stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange generally edged down yesterday in moderate dealings.

On Dec. 7 in Jamestown, N.Y., Robert F. Kennedy declared that he would remain neutral in the contest between Assemblymen Stanley Steingut and Anthony J. Travia for Speaker of the Assembly. A day later, in Utica during an upstate tour, he deplored factional fighting among rival Democratic leaders in the state and said it "wasn't important who the leaders are in the State Senate and Assembly."
The Transit Authority may install a horn with a distinctive tone or a light-signaling device on 190 new buses to alert the police in the event of trouble.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Lord Moran of Manton, the frail old gentleman who is Sir Winston Churchill's personal physician, is more than just a doctor to his famous patient. The two have enjoyed each other's company and straightforward talk for a lifetime.
TORONTO, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Dick Duff's second-period goal gave the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before 14,357 fans.
Chester Schwimmer, favored by Governor Rockefeller and the top Republican state leadership, withdrew last night from the race for party leader in Queens.

An outstanding week of scoring and rebounding for Tom Hamm of King's College has earned the 6-foot-3-inch center a berth on this week's All-East College Division (small colleges) team of the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

If the fashion industry has a bright new look, it may well be because an increasing number of young people are finding careers in it. Unfortunately, however, not enough young persons are entering the industry and jobs, depending upon the season, are going begging.

The nation's electric power production rose 5.4 per cent in the week ended Jan. 16, from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Jacnot Stable's Hempen fought off a closing challenge by Isle of Greece today and won by a nose in the $24,150 San Miguel Stakes for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

Governor Rockefeller's proposals for what amounts to a two-year moratorium on Blue Cross and Blue Shield rate increases will come as a boon to the ten million New Yorkers covered by these insurance plans. But it would be delusive to pretend that the proposals represent any basic check on the mounting hospital costs that have sent rates up so precipitously in recent years.

The Beatrice Foods Company, Chicago processor of dairy and convenience foods, will enter the chemical field through the proposed acquisition of a closely-held group of companies in Peabody, Mass., for about $16.9 million in stock.

TWO musical visitors introduced themselves to New York last night. John Pritchard, the British conductor, appeared in Carnegie Hall's International Festival of Visiting Orchestras with the Pittsburgh Symphony.
The British pound declined 6 points to $2.7916 in moderately active trading on the foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 -- Premier Tran Van Huong presented a reorganized Cabinet today after overcoming the reluctance of leading military men to enter the Government.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics almost blew a 12-point half-time lead but came on strong in the last quarter tonight to beat the Baltimore Bullets, 131 -- 105, for their 15th straight National Basketball Association victory.
The stock market's week-long trek to historic highs halted yesterday. A slim majority of prices showed slight declines in heavy trading.
TRENTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The New Jersey Racing Commission announced today that the state's revenue from the 1964 racing season was $28.5 million, an increase of $1.3 million over the 1963 figures.
Erich Leinsdorf, conducting the Boston Symphony, and Isaac Stern played a Beethoven Violin Concerto at Philharmonic Hail last night that, for two movements, was highly atypical.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 20 (AP) Murray Stable's Burlington drew off quickly in the final sixteenth of a mile to take today's featured eighth race at Bowie, the Inaugural Purse.

More than 30 wholesale buyers will bid today for the $400,000 retail fur inventory of the Neiman-Marcus Company, Dallas, which was flown up to New York following the store's $5 million fire last month.
PARIS, Jan. 20 -- France and West Germany agreed today on new initiatives toward reunification of Germany and political unity in the European Common Market.
DETROIT, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Royals held the Detroit Pistons scoreless in the final five minutes tonight and won a National Basketball Association contest going away, 102-90.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Leading United Nations figures met here tonight at a reception to mark publication of a book on current world problems dedicated to the late Secretary General, Dag Hammarskjold.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- London's critics were divided, but not seriously today over the merits of the film version of "My Fair Lady." The headline in The Times of London said, "Not Quite So Gay As It Might Have Been."
BARTLETT, N.H., Jan. 20 -- Phil Robertson, that old pro among ski-area operators, who built and introduced America's first T-bar lift in 1935, is about to introduce a new system of lift ticket sales.

IN the Caro-Kann Defense -- 1 P-K4, P-QB3 -- it is assumed that Black is satisfied to seek advantage in long-range positional considerations. A startling exception is the game between Nikolai Bakulin and David Bronstein in the current Soviet championship at Kiev.
A visitor to the National Motor Boat Show can buy a gleaming $3,000 yacht for nothing down and $57.50 a month -- if he can afford it.
Reorganization of the airplane division of the Boeing Company into two new divisions was announced yesterday by William M. Alien president.

Five management-backed directors of the Washington Heights Federal Savings and Loan Association were reelected yesterday in an annual meeting punctuated by angry arguments between several shareholders and the chairman.
Three Olympic champions were matched yesterday for the women's 60-yard dash in the Millrose Games next Thursday night. The track meet will be the first of five this winter at Madison Square Garden.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 20 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri said today that the world nuclear menace could be met by stopping the "proliferation" of atomic weapons, extending the treaty on nuclear testing to include underground explosions and banning nuclear weapons altogether.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- On a bleak, snow-topped hillside above the Potomac, a silent cluster of visitors chose to pay their respects to the 35th President today while the 36th was being inaugurated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A few minutes before noon today, Hubert Horatio Humphrey -- his right hand upraised and his left hand on an old Bible belonging to his wife's family -- intoned after Speaker John W. McCormack, "So help me God," and the nation had a Vice President for the first time since Nov. 22, 1963.

THIS year marks the 20th anniversary of the death of Robert Frederick Foster, who, for 60 years, had been one of the great figures in whist and bridge. He was a world authority on card games and his "Foster's Complete Hoyle was placed in the time capsule at the 1939 New York World's Fair.
A flurry of rumors involving Mexico's ability to meet her international sugar commitments caused some erratic price swings yesterday in world sugar futures.
A Public Service bus became a makeshift delivery room near the Lincoln Tunnel yesterday morning.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Six of the nation's leading aluminum companies have been named in an antitrust suit filed in the United States District Court here.
BONN Jan. 20 -- West Germany has begun, in cooperation with other European countries, to deliver $80 million in modern arms to Israel.
Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" will be given by the Metropolitan Opera tonight at 8, with Gerard Souzay making his Metropolitan Opera debut as Count Almaviva.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Four British couturiers agreed on one message in their spring-summer collections shown today. With varying degrees of intensity, they were all committed to fuller coats and skirts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A resumption of the Senate Rules Committee's investigation in the Robert G. Baker case has been postponed for at least a week. The sessions had tentatively been scheduled for next week.
OTTAWA -- Canadian business closed 1964 under the shadow of a record volume of major business legislation piled up by the longest and slowest-paced Parliament in the nation's history.

TORONTO -- Economic growth continued at a record rate across this land of vast potential in 1964, from the forests of British Columbia to the fishing waters off Newfoundland, from the prairies with their oil, wheat and cattle, to the industrial cities of Ontario and Quebec.
SELMA, Ala., Jan. 21 (UPI) -- The city police made their first arrests today in four days of racial demonstrations.

In replying to criticism of the financial position of the World's Fair, Robert Moses reveals that he has lost none of his penchant for invective or his skill at verbal fencing. The trouble is that by following these tactics under present circumstances he is accomplishing nothing at all for the fair.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 21 (AP) -- David Merrick, Broadway producer, applied today to the Nevada Gaming Commission for authority to invest in a Las Vegas hotel casino, the commission said.
REGINA, Sask. -- With Premier Ross Thatcher, a new private-enterprise captain, at the helm, Saskatchewan sails into the new year on a buoyant economy.
The World's Fair Corporation, despite the resignation of five members of its finance committee, faces no immediate financial crisis, a fair official said yesterday.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- The increasing demand for electric power, paced by rising industrialization and rapid suburban development, is being met by a series of hydroelectric installations in the central plateau.

An increase of 2,010,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 205,854,000 barrels, compared with 203,844,000 a week earlier and 196,894,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The State Department said today that the embassy clerk accused in the assassination of Premier Ngendandumwe had been hired "on the basis of excellent references, and following the customary check with local authorities."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara says revolutionary changes "have been driven into the bedrock" of the giant military establishment and will remain after him.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 21 -- Four Air Force Academy cadets voluntarily resigned today while an investigation continued into reports of cheating on examinations.
TORONTO -- Money markets in Canada have weathered strong external pressures and, for once, broken through the fear of diminished help from the United States.
Thousands of lives could be saved yearly in the United States by a vaccine against certain types of bacteria that cause pneumonia, a specialist said here yesterday.

MANILA, Friday, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- Hundreds of university students massed in front of the United States Embassy here today, yelling, "We want Blair" and waving anti-American placards. William McCormick Blair Jr. is the United States Ambassador to the Philippines.
A 15-year-old girl plunged to her death last night from a building on East 79th Street near Fifth Avenue, the police reported.
Production and consumption of newsprint set records in the United States and North America last year, an analysis of figures from producers and users disclosed yesterday.

BELIEVING that other parents of prep-school youngsters find sending regular, moderately priced packages to their children a chore, two enterprising couples have formed a company called AcHar to perform the service in cooperation with Charles Co., specialists in fancy groceries and gift packages.
DETROIT, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Marcel Pronovost scored his first goal of the season and Roger Crozier posted his fourth shutout tonight as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Secretary of the Army Stephen Aries and Thomas C. Mann, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, will leave Wednesday for a week of exploratory discussions in four Latin-American countries on the building of a sea-level canal from the Atlantic to the Pacific.
ATHENS, Jan. 21 -- Stavros Niarchos was reported today to have plans to become the owner of the world's first nuclear-powered merchant fleet.

SELMA, Ala., Jan. 21 -- The Dallas County Board of Registrars issued a public statement today suggesting that there was more involved in demonstrations in front of the courthouse than the desire of 150 Negroes to register and vote.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- The possibility of a crisis in municipal assessing policies in Massachusetts has been raised by a recent decision by the State Supreme Judicial Court.
CARACAS, Venezuela -- From the remote jungles of the south to the handsome boulevards of this capital city, Venezuelans have lined up to be immunized against poliomyelitis.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- When Yoshihiro Inayama, president of Japan's Yawata Iron and Steel Company, visited Canada recently at the head of a 23-man economic mission, he had a picturesque phrase with which to describe his goal.

" SHADOW'D GROUND," which was given its premiere by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater last night, is not like anything else in the company's repertory.

PANAMA -- Considering how anti-American riots staged by extremists a year ago disrupted some sectors of the economy, most business indicators showed 1964 to have been a relatively good business year for Panama after all.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that his sole motive in accusing the Democratic state chairman of attempted bribery was to prevent the use of money to settle the leadership fight in the Legislature.

The 15th anniversary Animal Kingdom Ball for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was held in the ballroom, Trianon Room and the Rotunda of the Sheraton-East last night.

ROME, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Pope Paul VI's private chapel in the Vatican has been completely redone along modern lines. Patriarch Athenagoras, the Orthodox leader, is depicted in a sculptured bronze altar panel.

TRENTON, Jan. 21 -- An outbreak of Type-A influenza in scattered parts of central and north Jersey was reported today by Dr. Roscoe P. Kandel, State Health Commissioner. He said his office was checking on the extent of the outbreak.
BALBOA, Canal Zone -- President Johnson's announcement that the United States would seek to cut a sea-level canal in Panama or a nearby country came as no surprise to Panama Canal executives.
MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 21 -- The advice offered today to down-country, ski-starved patrons by innkeepers and resort owners in the southern precincts of the Green Mountains was "come and get it."

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 21 -- The zoning board has rejected a proposal by Lord Taylor to build a $3 million branch store on the outskirts of the city because, the board said, the store might jeopardize a downtown redevelopment project that is just getting under way.
ASUNCION, Paraguay -- This South American Island of economic stability enjoyed one of its best years in 1964. Almost all economic indicators closed at record levels.
A 23-year-old man was stabbed to death and two women were wounded last night in the Harlem office of the leftist Progressive Labor Movement.

A $20 million plan to preserve the New Haven Railroad's New York commuter service was made public yesterday. The proposal was announced by Governor Rockefeller, Gov. John N. Dempsey of Connecticut and Edwin G. Michaelian, Westchester County Executive.
OTTAWA -- While the official outlook for the Canadian economy is for "another good year," the Government will take no chances. It intends to move aggressively for an expanding economy.

MADRID, Jan. 21 -- The Old World quarrels and maneuvers of the pretenders to the Spanish throne took a new twist today when the Carlist branch of the Bourbon family restated its claims. Carlism is an ultraconservative force in Spain.

VANCOUVER, B.C. -- In the far north of British Columbia, in one of the emptiest areas in the world, a tree decorated with bright ribbons was raised recently above a vast collection of conveyors and earth-moving equipment.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 -- The Allegheny Observatory will be closed, Dr. Edward H. Litchfield, chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh, said today.
