RIO DE JANEIRO--Latin America is not likely to find answers to all of its economic problems this year, but some realistic programs in key countries may set a bright example.

Florence Knoll Bassett, who has been described as the single most powerful figure in the field of modern design, is giving up her job as director of design for Knoll Associates, Inc., in order to have more time for private life. Her husband is Harry Hood Bassett, who has cattle ranches in Florida and is president of the First National Bank in Miami.

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 22 -- Sir Winston Churchill, who suffered a stroke a week ago, has not weakened further since he was described on Wednesday to be at a very low ebb.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic -- For the first time since the end of the 31-year dictatorship of Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, there are signs of progress in this Caribbean country.
The Republic Steel Corporation reported yesterday that profits in 1964 soared 30.2 per cent from the 1963 level. Sales set a record.
PARAMARIBO, Surinam -- Vast hydroelectric projects and mineral discoveries were the bright spots on the economic scene in this tidy country last year.

Isiah Brunson, former chairman of the Brooklyn chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, yesterday paid a fine of $150 for disorderly conduct in 1963. Arnold Goldwag, former CORE member, paid a fine of $100.

MIAMI, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Premier Fidel Castro asserted tonight that he had full control of Soviet anti-aircraft missiles in Cuba capable of "hitting any plane, day or night." The Premier threatened to use the missiles against United States reconnaissance planes. The remarks reiterated previous warnings by Mr. Castro.
QUITO, Ecuador -- Stability is marking Ecuador's economy. Central Bank reserves rose during the year, trade was nearly balanced and, consequently, the sucre remained firm.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 -- United States policies in South Vietnam came under new criticism today from Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh, commander of the armed forces, and from a leader of Buddhist resistance to the Government.

MONTREAL -- All roads that will lead to the World's Fair here in 1967 are designed to accommodate not only visitors to the exhibition, but also the expected vast increase in traffic to the area's business establishment.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 -- Emperor Hirohito exhorted the Diet (Parliament) today to work harder toward the new national goal of re-establishing the position of international trust that Japan forfeited in the events leading to World War II and her disastrous defeat.
Two groups of Harlem tenants sat in at City Hall yesterday to protest a lack of heat and hot water in their tenements.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- Greater stability for the average Venezuelan was the outstanding economic feature of the year 1964, according to a consensus of experts here. It was a good year for the economy, and the experts believe that the favorable trend will continue in 1965.
The sharp demand for copper and the major rise in its price last fall is reflected in the favorable 1964 results of three companies issued yesterday.
WINDSOR, Ont. -- Optimism is sweeping Canadian automotive centers in the wake of the Canadian-American agreement for controlled free trade in auto products signed last Saturday.
A series of international exchange concerts will begin at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday at 8:30 P.M. with a recital by Renee Morisset and Victor Bouchard, husband and wife piano team from Canada.
BUJUMBURA, Burundi, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A Watusi refugee employed by the United States Embassy as a clerk has confessed to the assassination of Premier Pierre Ngendandumwe, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to make the District of Columbia a model area that would "exemplify the best" of The Great Society. He acknowledged that the District had a long way to go.
The Alabama State Highway Authority sold $15 million of revenue bonds yesterday to an investment banking syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A panel of the National Academy of Sciences proposed today a "vigorous" 10-year investigation of the earth's interior, "where the huge forces that shape the face of the earth are born."
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 22 -- The Labor Government, on its 97th day in office, suffered severe setbacks yesterday in two by-elections.
WARSAW, Friday, Jan. 22 -- The Communist Warsaw Pact powers said today that the establishment of a nuclear force by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would compel them to take countermeasures.
The annual award for the most ingenious real estate transaction of the year has been given to a broker who managed to put an indoor tennis club on a roof.

Tentative plans have been made to build a major annex to the Port Authority bus terminal on a 60,000-squuare-foot plot occupying the west block-front of Eighth Avenue from 41st to 42d Street, connecting with the main terminal in the block to the souuth.
PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The Government said today that it had issued orders to insure that essential services would not be deprived of electric power during a strike next week.

Jamaica, the Caribbean island republic that gained independence from Britain less than three years ago, forged ahead in 1964 in its effort to industrialize and improve its competitiveness in world trade.
LA PAZ, Bolivia -- Having ended the 13-year rule of their most controversial Government, Bolivians are asking themselves what the cost of revolution was and whether it was worth paying.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- A group of University of California professors asked a judge today to dismiss charges against 770 demonstrators -- 590 of them students -- arrested Dec. 3 for a sit-in at Sproul Hall, the administration building.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- A Mini Cooper driven by Timo Makinen of Finland and Paul Easter of England won the Monte Carlo rally today despite road conditions described as the worst ever.

A technical violation of the limited nuclear test-ban treaty was committed by the Soviet Union when radioactivity from the recent major Soviet underground nuclear explosion passed beyond the boundaries of the U.S.S.R. It is likely that the violation was unintentional, a consequence more of Soviet inexperience with underground explosions than of intent to ignore the treaty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- President Johnson was urged today by the New York Congressional delegation to review the proposed closing of three V.A. facilities in the state.
RALEIGH, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Luther H. Hodges, who resigned as Secretary of Commerce earlier this week, was elected chairman of the multi-million-dollar North Carolina Research Triangle Foundation today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Dick Weber of St. Louis threatened to make a runaway of the American Division in the $100,000 All-Star bowling tournament tonight by surging 352 pins ahead of his old teammate and doubles partner, Ray Bluth, also of St. Louis.

Eight proposals for the construction of a marina and middle-income housing on city land bordering the Hudson River in the Washington Heights-Inwood section of Manhattan are being considered by city agencies.

Contributions are continuing to flow into the 53d Neediest Cases Fund. In the first five days of this week, $4,480.04 was received from 118 donors. Accompanying the gifts were several notes apologizing for delays in contributing.

TEHERAN, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Iranian police said today that Bokharaii had admitted shooting Premier Mansour and added that documents revealing the motive had been discovered. The police did not say what the motive was.
The President should be commended for urging Congress to extend the life of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. [Editorial, Jan. 16.].

The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen said last night that it was starting a drive to take over the membership of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, one of the country's oldest labor unions.
BUENOS AIRES -- A little over a year ago, Dr. Arturo U. Illia assumed the Presidency of Argentina practically as a receiver in bankruptcy, both political and financial.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica -- Even before the full year was accounted for, Costa Rica knew that her newly gained membership in the Central American Common Market was of benefit to her economy.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- The sea of coffee upon which Brazil's economy floats was almost drained by severe drought, frost and inflation early last year. Nevertheless the country is having one of its best coffee export seasons in a decade.

Latin America continues to be a battleground for two rival methods of economic development. The outcome is still in doubt, but those who favor the "monetarist" approach are gaining ground against the "structuralists."
The American Stock Exchange ran into flurries of profit taking that produced a mixed list at the close.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Jan. 21 (UPI) -- The United Press International carried dispatches from Waukegan on Dec. 31, Jan. 1 and Jan. 2 in which the three American Bishops of the Serbian Orthodox Church of America and Canada were described erroneously as having been named by President Tito of Yugoslavia.
HAMILTON, Bermuda -- The economy of this mid-Atlantic island, heavily dependent on the tourist trade, has maintained slow progress.
JUAREZ, Mexico, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Anthony Quinn was granted a divorce today from his wife of 27 years, the choreographer Katherine DeMille.
" You have to play the demon prosecutor at times."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Indonesia formally withdrew from the United Nations tonight, leaving the organization with 114 members.

The three-judge Federal Statutory Court considering four Republican reapportionment plans for New York State declined yesterday to consider any challenge to them on the ground of gerrymandering.

From Stonewall Manitoba to Red Deer in the Alberta foothills, curling rocks click and brooms whish as farmers relax in the warm afterglow of the best year they ever had.

Raymond Rubin, attorney for a Harlem woman who won a $46,500 libel judgment against Representative Adam Clayton Powell, has asked the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to extradite the Representative.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras -- Despite worrisome and extremely costly insect invasions, Honduras had a better than average economic year. An upswing late in 1963 continued into the first quarter of 1964. The tempo of the second quarter was relatively quiet, but activity began picking up at mid-year.
Gerard Souzay made his Metropolitan Opera debut in less than optimum circumstances last night as the Count in Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro."
The American Mining Congress took issue yesterday with an outlook report on silver issued Wednesday by Handy Harman, precious metals refiner.

Two television executives, a professor of drama, a bank vice president and a woman civic leader are planning the establishment of a professional year-round, non-profit theater in Queens by next fall.
The Hebrew Institute of University Heights, 1835 University Avenue, the Bronx, announced yesterday the appointment of Rabbi Maurice Lamm as its spiritual leader.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- There was a growing belief among delegates today that a showdown vote on arrears for United Nations peacekeeping operations would be avoided.
VIENNA, Jan. 22 -- Leonard Bernstein will conduct a new production of Verdi's "Falstaff" for the Vienna State Opera and a concert by the Vienna Philharmonic at the Musikverein in March, 1966.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A decision by Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz that underprivileged youths enrolled in the Neighborhood Youth Corps must be paid the Federal minimum wage of $1.25 an hour is causing a number of local poverty groups to reconsider their support of the program.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Jan. 22 (UPI)--Seven of the 18 men indicted in connection with the slaying of three civil rights workers have asked dismissal of the charges against them. They say the Federal Government has no jurisdiction in the case.

The British pound remained steady in moderately active trading on the foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.7915, down 1 point.

Seven new members of the citizens' advisory committee of the Housing and Redevelopment Board were appointed yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The appointments bring the membership of the committee to 24.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Senate suspended its rules today to let its new presiding officer, Vice President Humphrey, make an address from the chair -- but only for three minutes.
Foreign-language films without subtitles are a flourishing entertainment fixture in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The Government announced today that 199 Southern colleges, including the University of Mississippi, had promised to comply with the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Patrick Gordon Walker resigned as Foreign Secretary today in the wake of his surprise defeat yesterday in the Leyton by-election.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 22 (AP) -- John Fraser of Australia, a former Wimbledon semi-finalist, and Juan Gisbert of Spain won opening-round men's singles matches in the Australian tennis championship today.
BONN, Jan. 22 -- A spokesman denied today that the West German Government had had a role in initiating a new investigation of the magazine publisher Rudolf Augstein on suspicion of treason.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Ray C. Bliss, long one of the Republican party's most celebrated professional politicians, today was unanimously elected chairman of the Republican National Committee, effective April 1.
The strike of Welfare Department workers passed through its 19th day yesterday with no sign of a break in the stalemate.
GRAND CANYON, Ariz. -- There has been much speculation recently that the tourist industry in the United States will increase many times in coming years.
Fifty years ago this Monday, Alexander Graham Bell realized a dream -- the transcontinental telephone conversation.

ROME, Jan. 22 -- No one can make pants quite like the Italians. There isn't one influential couturier, as this spring's collections came to an end, that hasn't had a fling with floppy pajamas or the divided skirt.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Champagne Tony Lema went to the front today in his bid to repeat as winner of the $84,500 Bing Crosby golf tournament. He scored a six-under-par 65 for a 136 at the halfway mark.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (UPI) -- The University of Pennsylvania, which dismissed its losing football coach, John Stiegman, last month, began a manpower hunt today for student-athletes in a bid for its fair share of victories in sports.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- Indonesia's letter of formal withdrawal from the United Nations was being "carefully studied" today by the world organization.
The Howard Hughes interests have lost their fight to have Northeast Airlines accept $15 million from Eastern and National Airlines in exchange for Northeast's Florida route.
Justice Vincent D. Damiani of the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that he could not enforce a temporary injunction to halt a four-day-old school boycott, which was extended to a second school.
The stock market signed off the week on a positive note yesterday following two days of trendless trading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Johnson's program of school aid received an A-plus from the Democrats and only light paddlings from the Republicans as it started its long course through Congress today.

Government bond prices continued their gradual, steady ascent yesterday, capping an advance that has lasted three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The State Department expressed concern today about an apparent North Vietnamese military build-up in central and southern Laos.

Leaders of the striking welfare unions asserted yesterday that despite the imprisonment of three of their officials the strikers would remain off their jobs until they won an "honorable settlement."

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 23 -- President Arturo U. Illia sounded an urgent warning today for the Latin-American nations to take a "firm and decisive stand" against all movements that advocate subversion and terrorism as a political weapon.

WARSAW, Jan. 23 -- They arrived in specially outfitted trains the way the czars and emperors might have at the turn of the century. They met at a hall here built during the days of imperial Russian rule where the Russian viceroy stayed and where Polish patriots protested Russian rule.
BONN -- A growing number of West Germans are up to their necks in hot water -- to the boundless gratification of appliance manufacturers.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 -- A Tibetan monk who escaped last September from the monastery of the Panchen Lama declared here today that the Lama's life was in danger from the Chinese Communists.
LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 24 -- Sir Winston Churchill is dead.

TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. -- "It isn't the Alps. It isn't the Rockies. It isn't even the Catskills. But it's ours." This was the sentiment expressed recently by a skier arriving here after a 239-mile motor trip from Detroit -- almost all of it over superhighways.

KATHRIN PERUTZ'S second novel, "A House on the Sound," is written with economy and style; once again, we are made aware of the resources of a most talented writer. Miss Perutz is only 25; (her first novel, "The Garden," was published when she was 21).

APHRASE heard often around Minneapolis's Center Opera Company is "opera without elephants." The two-year-old company, which gave Carl Orff's "Die Kluge" last weekend and this, sprouted from the fertile soil of the Walker Art Center, and its productions are held in the $2,250,000 Tyrone Guthrie Theater.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- The Philadelphia 76ers, stifling a late Boston rally, broke the Celtics' 16-game winning streak, 104 -- 100, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

In one of those peculiar ironies of our time the complex of installations at Oak Ridge, Tenn., that made the fuel for the first atomic bombs and has produced nuclear weapons ever since, is now shifting its emphasis to the preservation of life.

Our higher courts have spurned it. Psychologists have debunked it. Civil libertarians have denounced it. Journalists have exposed it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Supreme Court this week again had to deal with the critical line between free expression and public order.

" Royal Flush," an incoming musical with Kaye Ballard and Mickey Deems heading the cast, will close for repairs after tomorrow night's performance in Philadelphia. The show, which was written by Jay Thompson and Robert Schlitt, opened there Wednesday night.

The largest collection of American paintings ever to be offered at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, will be auctioned on Wednesday. The pictures by artists from Gilbert Stuart to works of the present, will come up for sale in two sessions, at 1:45 P.M. and at 8 P.M.
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 23 -- Canberra, long scorned by Australians as a stuffy little bureaucratic backwater in the middle of nowhere, is beginning to confound its detractors.

In an otherwise admirable Inaugural Address, President Johnson spoke only briefly of this country's role in world affairs. Earlier he referred to foreign policy in his State of the Union message almost entirely in generalities. By his lack of emphasis, Mr. Johnson may have contributed in a way that he did not intend to the developing national debate over the character and scope of America's responsibility in the world.

IN a low-ceilinged, triangular wedge of a room one creaky flight of stairs up from Seventh Avenue and two floors above the Village Vanguard, a group of self-proclaimed jazz "revolutionaries" have set up a weekend showcase for their wares.
MONTREAL, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The first-place Montreal Canadiens defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 -- 1, tonight for their fourth straight victory with Gump Worsley in goal.

THE New York Botanical Garden will stage its annual house plant show today through March 28 in the Main Conservatory. Potted plants will be exhibited on wall dividers and window sills. Bottle and dish gardens will also be shown.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23 -- Dr. Nicholas Wagman, director of the Allegheny Observatory since 1941, plans an all-out effort to keep it in operation.
My paintings are like my children -- never home," complained a well-known collector the other day, wistfully seeing three of his Rauschenbergs off on an extended museum tour.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 23 -- A research project in mental health embracing eight Fairfield County communities has been started here. Known as the Southwestern Connecticut Mental Health Planning Project, the program will serve Greenwich, Stamford, Darien, Norwalk, Westport, Weston, Wilton and New Canaan.

It was a crowded week. It began in a holiday atmosphere, reached a high point with the drama and solemnity of the Inaugural ceremony, saw President Johnson buckle down to work as architect of the Great Society, and ended on a note of concern as he was taken to the hospital with a respiratory infection.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Johnson, who ponders deeply on what is fitting to the occasion, chose the quiet approach to important pronouncements on his Inaugural Day. He can make the rafters ring when he wants to. But on Wednesday he summoned the American people to the creation of the Great Society in low tones and with impassive facial expression.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Ben Schwartzwalder, the football coach at Syracuse University, has been awarded a new, five-year contract, Athletic Director James H. Decker announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Ray C. Bliss, the new Republican National Chairman, said today that he intended to operate as "a realistic politician." He declared that he would not "waste time" on intraparty feuds over ideology or projects that were not almost certain to produce results at the polls.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Baltimore Bullets defea ted the St. Louis Hawks, 106-97, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

The gas industry has no plans to let the electric utilities run away with the lighting business. The latest development is a new sign from the Arkla Air Conditioning Company of Little Rock, Ark., that is aimed directly at the commercial outdoor-lighting field.
Hungary's economic plan for 1965 calls for a sharp slowdown in the rate of industrial growth as compared with the gain made in 1964.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Arvid Pardo is a rare diplomat. The first permanent representative here of Malta, which won independence from Britain last Sept. 21, he has spent all of his nearly 51 years outside his country except for brief visits there.
PITTSBURGH, Jan 23 (AP) -- Coach Buddy Parker signed today for his ninth season with the Pittsburgh Steelers of the National Football League.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 23 -- In waether appropriate to their avocation, skippers of the Mamaroneck Frostbite Association and of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club frostbite fleet held their annual team match at Indian Harbor today.
TOKYO, Jan. 23 -- Japan is now uncertain whether she will participate in the second conference of Asian and African countries to be held in Algiers, a Government spokesman said yesterday.

DUSSELDORF, Germany -- Heinrich Heine, the most prominent Jewish writer in German literature, may be a source of national pride, but for his native town of Dusseldorf, he is the source of embarrassment.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- A Soviet literary critic was accused today of glossing over the ideological nonconformity of the early novels of Ilya Ehrenburg, now being republished here after having been banned more than 30 years.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- Three months after the fall of Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Chinese-Soviet conflict threatens to erupt again with all its old bitterness. Western specialists here feel that it is only the determined, almost desperate restraint of the new Soviet leaders that prevents an immediate resumption of all-out public polemics.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- President Johnson's proposal for establishing a network of regional centers for the treatment of cancer, heart disease and strokes was endorsed here today by Senator Lister Hill.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 -- George Young of Casa Grande, Ariz., raced to an upset victory over the Olympic 10,000-meter champion, Billy Mills, tonight in the two-mile run of the sixth annual Los Angeles invitational indoor track meet.
Empire State Airlines, which operates a scheduled commuter service between Syracuse and other upstate cities, will begin serving the metropolitan area tomorrow.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Jan. 23 -- The Democratic-controlled Legislature adjourned this week on a technicality. It thereby deprived Gov. Daniel J. Evans, a Republican, of a chance to carry out his announced intention of vetoing a redistricting bill.
EDISON, N.J., Jan. 20 -- In a row of squat, concrete-block buildings that shout their Army origin, earnest young men and women were interviewing job applicants today "by appointment only."
The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday a new program for tennis in New York City's public schools.
Democratic State Chairman William H. McKeon sent telegrams yesterday to the party's 62 county leaders inviting them to a meeting in Albany this afternoon "to discuss urgent political problems."
Department store sales last week rose from levels attained in the similar 1964 week, but declined from volume attained in the prior 1965 week.

Special programs for college students at the top of their classes abound. But Pace College is introducing a new program at its New York City and Westchester campuses to challenge the student with a C-plus average as well.

TOMORROW President Johnson will submit to Congress a fat and complicated document called the Budget, covering the Government's income and outgo for the year beginning July 1. SALONIKA, Greece, Jan 20 -- On a gentle slope just outside this city 180 Greek village boys are learning about hybrid grains, improved livestock breeds and other elements of modern farming. They are students of the American Farm School, an unusual institution in the Balkans, where primitive agricultural methods still hold sway.

DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Unofficial tabulations show that General Motors posted more than 50 per cent of United States car sales in 1964, marking the third consecutive year it has attained that goal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- The Army altered today an earlier statement that the National Guard would be maintained as an all-volunteer force after it absorbs the remaining units of the organized Army Reserves.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Fees for some Federal recreation areas will probably be set soon for the first time and a price established for the new automobile sticker that will provide entry to all areas where there are fees.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Jan. 23 -- British Columbia has many natural lakes, but the biggest in the province will be man-made as a result of the Columbia River and Peace River hydroelectric projects.

THE veteran grand master, Paul Keres of the Soviet Union, won the Hastings, England, Christmas Congress. This triumph, by a score of eight out of a possible nine in the 10-man round robin, was no runaway.

NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 23 -- Italy is engaged in a long-term war on poverty that, comparatively, reduces President Johnson's action in the same field to a skirmish. Naples is in the front line.

ATLANTA, Jan. 23 -- A hometown banquet honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., which provoked behind - the - scenes controversy in Atlanta business circles when it was proposed, has won overwhelming public endorsement.

FREDERICK BUECHNER'S previous novel, "The Return of Ansel Gibbs," was skillful, perceptive, convincing. CONSTANTINE, Algeria, Jan. 16 -- A Protestant-sponsored reforestation compaign is being pressed in Eastern Algeria with the aim of enabling the nation to live off "her own forests in 10 years."

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- In his campaign last fall Harold Wilson promised to give Britain, if elected, "100 days of dynamic action." It was a deliberate borrowing of style and phrase from the politician he so admired, John F. Kennedy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23 -- Scholars who deplore the use of computers in the humanities have been accused at a conference here of "a species of anti-intellectualism" and a "sentimental attachment to the 19th-century" methods.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 23 -- Vice President Humphrey predicted today that President Johnson would make a speedy recovery.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- Paolo Emilio Taviani, the Minister of the Interior, has declared war against pinball machines and slot machines.
WASHLNGTON, Jan. 23 -- Fashion has rarely been more cruel to girls than it is right now. It is sad watching them struggle to cope with the dangerous-woman costume that style has clamped upon them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Johnson's pulse is probably steadier today than Washington's. The people here have absolutely no reason to doubt that the President was popped into the Bethesda Medical Center in the middle of the night mainly as a precautionary measure, but they are jittery just the same.

THE official 1964 mintage figures are in. The Philadelphia and Denver Mints together produced nearly 202 million Kennedy half dollars, far surpassing the previous annual peak for half dollar production of 92.3 million, in 1963.

The boys at Harvard last week upheld the doctrine of male supremacy when they denied Miss Faye Levine's right to list her name on the ballot in the election of senior class marshals. Miss Levine, a 20-year-old Radcliffe senior from Peekskill, N.Y., was the first undergraduate girl to try to run for this highly esteemed office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson, with a severe cold herself, was admitted to the Naval Hospital at Bethesda this afternoon.

A chilly mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain brought treacherous driving and walking conditions to the metropolitan area yesterday.

The Persian Gulf promises to be the scene of the world's most important oil hunt this year. Despite the abundance of oil supplies in the free world, five important oil groups have obtained rights to exploit the petroleum resources in an area of some 10,000 square miles off the coast of Iran.

TO THE EDITOR: I MUST spring to the defense of the Pennsylvania Railroad. I have no doubt that "the coaches were absolutely filthy and the condition of the toilets was revolting," but, at the same time, Mrs. Edward Korn says [Jan. 10], "We usually drive, but, because of the season, we thought it would be wiser and more comfortable to take the train."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 -- The San Francisco National Bank, which opened two and a half years ago with a capital of $4.5 million, was declared insolvent last night by James J. Saxon, United States Controller of the Currency.
HINTS of wonderful things being done by Zoltan Kodaly with music education have been coming out of the composer's native Hungary for years.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., Jan. 23 -- Atlantis II, the oceanographic research vessel, has embarked on a 50,000-mile cruise around the world.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 23 -- A study of the St. Lawrence Seaway's impact on nine states indicates that shipping lines have been lax about beating the bushes for new business.

THE "Today" show, an early morning news and feature smorgasbord that was panned by critics, shunned by advertisers and troubled by ratings, is quietly celebrating its 13th anniversary this month -- a triumph that undoubtedly disillusions skeptics of sunrise or for that matter sundown television programming.

Newspaper public relations and promotion will be discussed by 28 executives at a two-week seminar beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute of Columbia University. It is only the second seminar on this subject to be held in the institute's 19-year history.
Swedish shipyards last year turned out a record total of new merchant tonnage and delivered 74 vessels totaling 1,018,344 tons.

Bill McClellon of DeWitt Clinton set a national interscholastic high jump record of 6 feet 10 1/4 inches yesterday in the ninth annual St. Francis Prep track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

The University of Rhode Island study that found trading stamps raised food prices has been attacked by the Sperry Hutchinson Company, biggest concern in the field, as having "no foundation in reality."
BERLIN, Jan. 23 (Reuters) -- The East German Skating Union today said the United States consulate in West Berlin had refused to grant visas to members of an East German skating team.

PECOS, Texas, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Walter E. Heller Company, a Chicago lending concern was told by a jury last night that it could not collect $1.3 million in mortgages involved in the Billie Sol Estes case. But at the same time the finance company defeated a $4 million damage claim.

WITH one exception, the dog breeds that led the popularity parade in 1963 were those that ranked in the first 10 again in 1964. Poodles again are unchallenged in first place. The registration figures were issued by the American Kennel Club last week.

LEAFING though some recent books on Shakespeare, I was saddened to find so many people playing the dreary game of deducing the writer's biography from his work. Any writer whose life-story could be so deduced, it seems to me, would by definition be a second-rate artist, since it is his business to use his imagination, to put himself in other people's places and understand their lives, not just to record his own.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 23 -- Iranians are still speculating why a youth tried Thursday to kill Premier Hassan Ali Mansour, who was reported today to be making good progress in recovering from his wounds.

" Lulu" is Albany jargon coined by the late Gov. Alfred E. Smith to denote a flat allowance "in lieu of itemized expenses." Each of the state's 208 legislators gets a $1,000 lulu in addition to his $10,000 annual salary, and some major committee chairmen receive special lulus running as high as $16,000 a year -- as determined by the majority leaders.

Jonel Perlea, the 64-year-old Rumanian conductor who was deprived of the use of his right arm several years ago by a heart attack and a stroke, led 50 members of the Manhattan Orchestra yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Army's powerful swimming team had little trouble today in downing Cornell, 66 -- 29, in a dual meet here.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation has announced that about $14 million of its 6 per cent subordinated sinking fund debentures due in 1984, including some with warrants attached, and the 4 1/2, per cent convertible debentures due in 1970 have been tendered and bought by the company.
The city has decided to make its own emergency repairs on slum buildings and then bill the landlords.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 -- Despite minor problems, the New Tokaido Line, Japan's high-speed Tokyo-Osaka rail line, carried 5,172,102 passengers in its first three months of operation and in most cases delivered them to their destinations in comfort and on time.

ELK MOUNTAIN, Pa. -- For two years now, my friend (who owns a ski shop) has been nagging my wife and me to go skiing. Neither of us ever had been on skis, so for two years we gracefully ducked the invitation. Last week, finally running out of excuses and enticed by glowing reports of friends, we hesitantly accepted an invitation to ski in Pennsylvania.

A certain number of people hold that the late Bertolt Brecht was this century's greatest playwright -- a sweeping statement, nevertheless held. English translations of some of his work already are in print; and starting with the autumn, Random House expects to publish as complete a Brecht as it can -- a couple of volumes this year, more next, until there are perhaps 12 or 15 in all.
Into each National Motor Boat Show a little freezing rain and snow must fall, but this year they forgot to turn it off.

TOM PAXTON: RAMBLING BOY (Elektra EKL-277; stereo EKS-7277). One of the better new-wave folk song writers in a program of his own works. A fusion of country and city elements, a variety of moods and topics, a clear sense of conviction and diction add up to a generally impressive disk.

The amount of academic dishonesty in American colleges and universities is "grossly underestimated" by students, student body presidents and deans, according to a nationwide survey of more than 600 deans and about 6,000 students in 99 institutions across the country.

Perhaps we lay Catholics should speak out about the tiresome and damaging myth repeated by Arthur Miller ("Our Guilt for the World's Evil," Jan. 13), namely, that the Roman Catholic Church had placed the guilt of the Crucifixion of Christ on the Jews alone (hence their persecution), and has recently lifted this to spread it over mankind. Rather the church has spoken in ecumenical spirit to clarify its teaching for the misinformed.

TO THE EDITOR: A simple solution to the problems and perils of the yellow traffic signal would be to blink the green light for a few seconds before the change to red. This would enable the motorist at the corner to get across while the light is still green, and would give warning to following motorists that the light is about to change.

With his Budget Message Monday and Economic Report Thursday, President Johnson will unveil much of his economic program. Interest in the size of the budget, the amount of a proposed excise-tax cut and the forecast of the gross national product has obscured other key questions that may be answered.

Ambrose Lightship -- the Atlantic approach beacon to the Port of New York -- is about to be moved again in the Coast Guard's continuing search for the best location at which to replace it with a fixed structure.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Orlando Cepeda, a leading slugger for the San Francisco Giants for six years, returned his signed 1965 contract today.
FIVE Manhattan galleries are currently offering three one-man and two group exhibitions of photography. The displays cover a wide range of themes.

A city official is studying the employe-training methods of private companies, public agencies and unions to develop a program to prepare workers for better jobs.
A capsule containing cyanide has been found in the jacket pocket of the 19-year-old student who died of poisoning Thursday in George Washington High School in upper Manhattan.

ONE should not be too hard on this little book. Its aim is modest: to tell a story (or two stories) of how Hitler's Vengeance Weapons (V-1 and V-2) failed to change the course of World War II and how subsequently American Intelligence officers raced to capture V-2 plans and scientists for our own rocket and space satellite programs.

OF all the provinces of learning, history maintains the most loosely defined and ill-defended boundaries. There is no bother about passports or customs, and there has never been any language barrier. As an intellectual community, historians have always lived in an open society.

A MEDALLIC memento of last Wednesday's Presidential inauguration is available to collectors. A limited, serially numbered issue has been struck in silver and there is also a limited, unnumbered issue in bronze.
Music of the Western Hemisphere was played by the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon in a stimulating concert saluting the Alliance for Progress.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. -- The biggest crowds of the Florida winter season are attracted by events such as the Orange Bowl festivities in Miami, the Gasparilla parade in Tampa and the automobile races here in Daytona Beach.

" IN England they call me the 'Greek-born British director,'" Michael Cacoyannis, the director-producer-screen writer of "Zorba the Greek" recently said here. "I say no, I lived in England for 13 years, but I couldn't get a chance to do a film there.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Rutgers University, which more than 80 years ago helped establish the county agricultural agent system, is experimenting with a similar program involving urban areas.

WITH the Sportsmen's Vacation and Travel Show at the Coliseum less than a month away, the event's bugle-blarer is keeping his announcement machine spinning with disclosures of features that winter-bound, hardy outdoorsmen may anticipate.
MADRID, Jan. 23 -- The Spanish Government has decided to broaden cultural and economic exchanges with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries in Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Assistant Secretary of State William P. Bundy said today that "significant numbers" of trained North Vietnamese soldiers had for the first time been infiltrating into South Vietnam to support the Communist guerrillas.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Gov. George W. Romney of Michigan warned today that "no nation, and no people, can survive as islands of prosperity and plenty in a world that hungers and is filled with envy."

We don't suppose Chief Justice Warren could be persuaded to investigate the Robert Whitehead case. No disrespect intended; but the victim, again, is not only a man but also our reputation for freedom. It is ironical that this assassination should happen at a time when even the commissars are beginning to understand that it is best to leave the theater alone.
ANNOUNCEMENTS of new courses include practical instruction both for the beginner and the advanced student of photography. Course subjects include black-and-white, color and movies.

In its 176 years, the United States has been without a Vice President 16 times because of death, resignation or succession. Often it made little difference. Most Vice Presidents have had few duties and minimal authority. Thomas Jefferson said of the post when he assumed it under President John Adams, "It will give me philosophic evenings in the winter and rural days in the summer."
BRUSSELS, Jan. 23 -- George S. Moore, president of the First National City Bank of New York, appealed today for "a new collective effort to make the New York World's Fair a success."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 23 -- An obscure ward politician is believed to have caused more pain and embarrassment for President Mohammad Ayub Khan in the last week than all the leaders of Pakistan's political Opposition combined.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The chairman of the Labor party, Ray Gunter, said tonight that British workers would have to get over "selfishness" and get down to work if Britain's economy was to grow.
Retail activity quickened last week from the pace of the corresponding 1964, week. However, volume declined from the prior 1965 week.

PHOTOGRAPHERS are a marvelous breed, driven to their difficult art by compulsions as potent as those driving explorers and missionaries and gold seekers. As historians they have been of tremendous value to us since the Civil War. Beyond that, the big, glass-plate cameras of men like William Henry Jackson and L.S. Huffman helped win the West, for their stereopticon views were immensely popular and encouraged millions to move beyond the Missouri.
NEPTUNE, N.J., Jan. 23 (AP) -- A masked gunman shot and wounded a young woman in an isolated section of Neptune early today.

The "power grab" of professional college coaches to gain control of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen failed to materialize yesterday as the organization's president, Jack Sulger, led the 92d annual convention through a quiet, routine meeting at the New York Athletic Club.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Roger Dion, who has been leaping from slopes in New Hampshire ever since he was old enough to carry skis, topped the season's best field today to win the New York State Class A crown.
BONN, Jan. 22 (Reuters) -- The 5,400-ton training vessel Deutschland is to leave Kiel Tuesday for the first round-the-world voyage of a West German warship since the end of World War II.

MONTCLAIR, N.J. Jan. 23 -- Armed with charm, determination and a satirical coloring booklet, about 200 members of the New Jersey League of Women Voters will march on the State Capitol Monday to press for a state income tax.
Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, said last week that great strides had been made in making the port competitive.

FRESH flowers predominate in arrangements in Florida, especially during the winter. Favorites are camellias, which reach their peak of bloom during January and grow in almost every garden in the central and northern sections of the state.
A Brooklyn community that has been quietly integrating for 50 years disproves the theory that Negro families usually drive out the whites.

TO THE EDITOR: It has always been a problem as to what action the driver should take "when the yellow flashes." It depends on speed, alertness, proximity to the traffic signal, reaction and response time of the driver, and even emotional attitude.
The lamp business has spawned a little-known but important $700 million industry -- lighting fixtures.

In her letter to The Times published Jan. 17 Shirley Levitan objects to Senator Bayh's proposed constitutional amendment concerning Presidential succession. She notes that the amendment renders succession subject to nomination by the President and approval by Congress, and observes that this process would "inevitably require time" and "in an age of nuclear threat the country cannot afford such a luxury."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Richard M. Nixon, of all people, has put his finger squarely on what President Johnson sought to do -- and probably succeeded in doing -- in his State of the Union message and Inaugural address.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 23 -- A cautious movement is under way to legalize the sale of contraceptives and the dissemination of information about them in Minnesota. A leader of the State Medical Association proposed today that a special Legislative committee be formed to study the whole field of sexual behavior, including contraception.

THE town of Mayberry, purely nonexistant to a cynic but which is real to a fan of "The Andy Griffith Show," is about to lose another solid citizen. Last year it was Gomer Pyle who went away to get his own show on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

RICHMOND, Jan. 23 -- A constitutional test of Virginia laws that make it a crime for a white person to marry a Negro will begin here next week. The case is regarded as certain to go to the United States Supreme Court and may become a landmark.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23 -- Rain and gale winds took their toll of the nation's finest golfers today as the third-round leader in the Bing Crosby tournament became Rocky Thompson.

TO THE EDITOR: It is always refreshing to read of a member of a public regulatory agency, such as Chairman Alan S. Boyd of the Civil Aeronautics Board, giving detailed attention to the important needs of the traveling public, such as were reported in your Jan. 3 issue.

TO THE EDITOR: Last August, we had the unfortunate experience of booking passage for three on the liner Riviera, which did not sail because of financial problems. We booked passage through a travel agency that we believe to be responsible; to date, we have not received any refund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Liberal Democrats in the House of Representatives are exchanging congratulations on the revival of a party rule that some regard as a potential lever for modification of the seniority system.
LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Arthur Miller paid a fleeting visit here today to see one of his old plays, "The Crucible," and to arrange the production of a new one, "Incident at Vichy."
All the major stock averages broke through the ceiling of their previous highs early last week but then eased downward when the power of January's reinvestment buying stalled.

Current favorites, such as the twist, the watusi and the frug, took second place to hardy perennials like the polka, the oberek and the mazur at the Polonaise Ball at the Sheraton-East last night. The ninth annual event for the benefit of Polish Mutual Assistance was limited to about 400 persons so that there would be plenty of space for dancing in the hotel's ballroom.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A special conference on intellectual freedom sponsored by the American Library Association heard reports today that censorship pressures are increasing in the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan.23 -- Efforts continued today to find a compromise formula for settling the thorny issue of United Nations financing without a confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The gradual concentration of political leadership in Western Europe around the towering figure of President de Gaulle halted suddenly and unexpectedly -- and perhaps momentarily -- this week.
HARTFORD, Jan. 23 -- Two high-ranking Democrats are expected to get Superior Court appointments within the next few months.
FIRST-DAY dates for five United States 1965 stamps and one postal card were announced last week by Postmaster General John A. Gronouski.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 22 -- Gen. Mustafa al-Barzani, leader of the Kurdish revolutionary movement in northern Iraq, has appealed to "friendly countries" and the United Nations "to prevent another war and to resolve our national question peacefully and justly."
SELMA, Ala., Jan. 23 (UPI) -- A Federal judge ordered Sheriff James G. Clark today to quit interfering with Negro voter applicants, and warned that "violence on either side will not be tolerated."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 -- In the hinterland of the primitive kingdom of Laos, the United States has become deeply involved in a twilight war with the Asian Communists. United States jet fighter plances, loaded with bombs and rockets, are flying concealed missions to interdict the clandestine flow of men and supplies from North Vietnam to Communist revolutionary movements in South Vietnam and Laos.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 21 -- Half the eligible non-British settlers, roughly 250,000, who have come to Australia in this country's large scale post-war immigration program have failed to become Australian citizens.
Twenty-eight outstanding sports figures were honored last night at the 14th annual Bill Corum Memorial Awards Dinner of the Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The United States transferred to West Germany today the personnel file of a former German prisoner of war, symbolizing the coming transfer of hundreds of thousands of similar files.
There is grief throughout the world for Sir Winston Churchill. He was the true symbol of courage to the Free World.
Proponents of the long-sought and long-resisted Lower Manhattan Expressway expect Mayor Wagner to give his final approval soon to the $110-million project, which he nearly buried two years ago.
The Ford Foundation's $2.5 million grant to the Pittsburgh public schools to improve education in that city is a fine demonstration of constructive use of foundation money.

STARK and terrifying desert landscapes are the setting for this novel of flight and sudden death in eighth-century Islam. Abderahman, a last surviving member of the family of the deposed Ommiad caliphs, flees Damascus on a white mare of almost superequine speed and endurance -- the real heroine of the book.

THE "Bridge World" match last weekend between the Traditionalists and the Scientists was both exciting and memorable. However, it is doubtful whether it achieved its intended purpose of demonstrating that top-level bridge can be played effectively without a multiplicity of conventional bidding understandings.
Starting this year, the City Rent and Rehabilitation Administration will grant rent increases to building owners who modernize incinerators or central heating systems.
VIENNA, Jan. 23 -- Simon Wiesenthal, who has won fame here as a private nemesis of Nazi evildoers, has just concluded a letter-writing campaign against them.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 23 -- Larry Lembo tied the Navy Field House basketball record today with 24 points, but Manhattan dropped a 75-70 decision.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 -- A conservation study commission has described San Francisco Bay as this region's greatest asset and called for positive steps to save it from "destruction'' through haphazard filling operations.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 23 -- Haiti is being taken over piecemeal by foreign promoters who have received extraordinary concessions from President Francois Duvalier, according to charges in the current issue of Ralliement, a Haitian leftist review.

THE Soviet-American cultural exchange program, Peter Pan division, recently got into high gear with a three-week, whirlwind excursion through New York City and nearby parts, by two bright, photogenic moppets from Moscow. The cost -- approximately $30,000 -- was borne by ABC-TV's children's show "Discovery," which Hopes to draw an audience of around 10 million with "Yuri and Irena Discover America."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Billie Jean Moffit of Long Beach, Calif., and Mrs. Carole Caldwell Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, the two stars who gave the United States second place in the recent Federation Cup women's tennis matches, turned in straight-set victories today in the second round of the Australian championships.

ARTIFICIAL flowers have gained widespread popularity in recent years for flowers and foliage now have an unbelievable lifelike texture and look. Though they lack the fragrance and freshness of growing plants, their permanence and variety are a boon to the busy housewife, and to those who have no access to freshly cut garden flowers and foliage.

A controversial treatment for a disease that kills 25,000 infants in the United States each year is being tested by 500 physicians across the nation, the pathologist who devised the treatment said here yesterday.
January white sales, clearances and promotions have succeeded in keeping retail volume humming. They are also providing the money with which merchants can make their spring and Easter commitments.
Four Winds Travel, Inc., announced last week that it would schedule 32 rail cruises between April 17 and the end of October.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Within hours of President Johnson's hospitalization early today, the United States Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md., was turned into a major communications center.

TO THE EDITOR: With three to five million skiers paying up to $7 a day for lift tickets, it is obvious that skiing is now as much a business as professional baseball. A baseball fan paying admission is entitled to security that his seat will not collapse or that the stands will not fall on him. Similarly, skiers and their families are entitled to some minimum protections from the ski-area operators.

A record of $1,111,000,000 of new life insurance was sold by the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company during 1964, O. Kelley Anderson, president, reported last week. The total was 11 per cent above that for 1963.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- President Johnson, on the advice of his doctor, is taking cough medicine that tastes and looks just like the old-fashioned remedy it is -- the "Brown Mixture" known to several generations of Americans.

In August nine young composers who were commissioned by the Fromm Foundation to write music for a Contemporary American Music Festival, gathered at the Berkshire Music Center in Lenox, Mass. LIMA, Peru -- An American, newly arrived in Lima, might be excused if he found himself confused when glancing out his hotel window at the Plaza San Martin, the equivalent of New York's Times Square.

An assistant vice president of one of the large New York City banks is betting that Government bond prices will turn up sharply within the next 12 months or so. He is putting several thousand dollars of his own money where his mouth is.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan 23 (AP) -- Representative Gerald R. Ford Jr., the House Republican leader, predicted today that the Democrats' overwhelming voting advantage in Congress would "really plague them as much as it will help them" during the current session.

EUGENE KAYDEN'S translation of Pushkin's "Eugene Onegin," the masterpiece of Russia's greatest 19th-century poet, is the seventh version to appear in English and the third in the last couple of years. Unlike the previous translators, Mr. Kayden may be regarded as a professional for he has devoted a long lifetime to rendering hundreds of pages of Russian verse.

ONE Saturday afternoon a few weeks ago a young South Vietnamese man with a suitcase set out walking south along the main coastal highway, Route No. 1, from the district town of Duc Pho. He had taken a battered bus from the provincial capital of Quangngai despite the warnings of the American military team there that his way was "too dangerous."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Johnson wore neither a hat nor a topcoat throughout the inauguration festivities here this week. For a mail with a history of bronchiectasis, a chest specialist said today, it probably was a mistake.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that his two Senate investigating bodies had disclosed income tax cheating and other Federal tax losses aggregating more than $29 million in the last 10 years.
KITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 23 -- Austrian-born Ludwig Leitner, now a German citizen, won the downhill race in the Hahenkamm ski meet today.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Nancy Roth defeated Mrs. Peter Dye of Indianapolis in a sudden-death playoff today to move into the final against Mrs. Marlene Streit in the Doherty women's amateur golf championship.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- A 24-year-old University of Michigan graduate has been the talk of ham-radio air waves around the world in the last few months. He is believed to be the first American short-wave amateur to operate out of the Soviet Union.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 23 -- A rebel force struck across the Congo River today from the former French Congo and captured the village of Nkolo, 200 miles north of Leopoldville.
ATLANTA -- In a small town in southern Georgia the other day, a Negro tourist stopped at a hamburger stand on U.S. 301, the main route between New York and Florida.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 23 (UPI) -- Michigan built a 51-38 half-time margin, then went on to crush Purdue, 103 -- 84, today.

The Cunard Line reported last week that a total of 183,012 passengers had sailed on its ships in 1964 across the Atlantic and on cruises.

NAHA, Okinawa. Jan. 15 -- Okinawa's sugar farmers, already hurt by a drop of prices in 1964, are facing an even more dismal new year. The Japanese Government has turned down their request to re-evaluate its sugar-purchasing policies.
