AMERICANS are always the last to discover America. That, at any rate, is the siren song sung by a thousand new books a year. In the two fine examples before us today, stimulating efforts are made to lighten our darkness, dispel our insularity, and redress our plain forgetfulness. Do they succeed? Yes.
Your paper has highlighted the controversy pro and con regarding the Lower Manhattan Expressway.
AN automatic air-conditioner that is said to be quieter than most room units now available was introduced yesterday by Amana Refrigeration, Inc.
Some of the salesmen whose fingers ring the doorbells and whose feet jam the doors of American homes are here this week to do some buying of their own.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Something should be said about Sir Winston Churchill's refusal to be imprisoned in his own wardrobe, for he was the last politician of any consequence with the courage to dress as he pleased.
DETROIT, Jan. 25 (AP) -- United States auto makers were moving today toward a second successive 800,000-plus production month as they headed into the final work days of January.
A new method of charging tuition, which is intended to encourage students "not to dawdle" on their graduate degrees, was announced yesterday by the Graduate Faculties of Columbia University.
Mary Martin will be seen in "Hello, Dolly!" in Tokyo, Moscow and Hong Kong under the auspices of the State Department. She will have the role played here by Carol Channing.

President Johnson's new budget is generally realistic and forward-looking. It reaffirms the departure from the traditional and artificial ritual that called for a tidy balance of expenditures and receipts. Instead, it shows a deliberate deficit, resulting from a combination of excise tax reductions and increases in spending, particularly in the civilian sector.
NOTTINGHAM, England, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Two stars of the England soccer team -- Peter Swan and Tony Kay -- were found guilty by a jury today of having conspired to fix a match.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices was unchanged at 101.0 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Jan. 19, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices of farm products and processed foods advanced, while industrial commodities declined.

The hope that the heavy tax levied on the nation's commerce by the Atlantic and Gulf dock strike would be quickly ended by union ratification of a master agreement in the Port of New York has now evaporated. The great bulk of operations remain shut down in this port. The same paralysis blocks ship loading in Boston and Norfolk, both of which were quick to fall in line on the New York pattern.
The possibility of including the Ford Rotunda and the United States Pavilion at part of the city's permanent Science Museum was discussed yesterday at a meeting in the World's Fair Terrace Club.

THE United States Military Academy, given a 4.0 rating as a place to train potential Army officers, was given a much lower rating yesterday for the development and production of a good basketball team.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 25 -- No one was to blame for the series of explosions that destroyed 10 aircraft, including nine T-28 fighter-bombers, yesterday at Vientiane's military airport, an inquiry has found.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 25 -- Thousands of students demonstrated today in Tamil-speaking Madras, a state in south India, against a law that will make Hindi, the language of the north, the sole "official language" of the Indian Union.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Johnson disclosed today that he planned to ask Congress to reduce excise taxes this year by $1.75 billion, a cut that is somewhat smaller than had generally been expected.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals let stand today a lower court's temporary restraining order blocking a strike by three shopcraft unions against the nation's railroads.
Nervous trading first ran up prices in soybean futures to contract highs yesterday, then beat them down by as much as 3 3/4 cents a bushel from the day's best levels on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The Interfaith Health Association announced yesterday that it had purchased the financially troubled, 225-bed Howard Park General Hospital in Howard Beach, Queens, and would seek to continue its operation temporarily as a profit-making institution.

Tempers flared and a woman stockholder was ejected yesterday from a stormy special shareholders meeting of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., called to vote on a two-for-one split of the utility's common stock.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Carole Caldwell Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, the United States' third-ranked woman tennis player, nursed an injured leg through two easy matches today and earned a place in the quarter-finals of the Australian tennis championships.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 25 -- The National Rural Electric Cooperative Association accused 106 of the nation's largest private power companies today of overcharging their customers by $3.4 billion in the seven years ended 1962.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Following are the texts of President Johnson's Budget Message and of a Budget analysis of Federal activities, photographically reproduced, as presented to Congress today:

Directors of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the company's common stock. They also raised the quarterly dividend on the present common stock to 65 cents a share from 60 cents, payable March 15 to stockholders of record Feb. 26.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to review a decision that property owners in the area of the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport in Washington State were entitled to damages on their claims that noise by jet planes destroyed normal usefulness of their homes.

The sixth consecutive year of record profits was achieved in 1964 by the Union Oil Company of California which is now in its 75th year, Fred L. Hartley, president, reported yesterday in a preliminary annual statement.

In regard to The Times Jan. 19 editorial "Border Politics in Bonn" it is undoubtedly true that given the present pattern of world power relationships and the current policy position of the Soviet Union, "few, if any, informed West Germans have any illusions about the possibility of recovering the area east of the Oder-Neisse line. . . ."

Teachers snatched leaflets from the hands of students yesterday as the Rev. Milton A. Galamison's organization moved to close another "600" school on the fifth day of a boycott of the schools for disturbed children.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Johnson asked Congress today for $20 million to push research on high-speed rail transportation between Washington, New York and Boston -- the so-called Northeast Corridor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- George Wilson, who quit recently as head coach of the Detroit Lions, joined the Washington Redskins today as chief strategist for the Redskins' offense.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -The Treasury bill rate moved in different directions for three-month and six-month bills at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 25 -- Last month a third-year cadet at the Air Force Academy stole a key to a locker in which examination papers were stored and then recruited 10 other cadets to help sell them.

With some of the trappings of a James Bond thriller, the Raytheon Company of Lexington, Mass., and Amana Refrigeration, Inc., of Amana, Iowa, disclosed yesterday a plan for Amana to become a subsidiary of Raytheon. The deal will involve in excess of $10 million.
In the spring, a homemaker's fancy turns to fancies -- fancy towels, fancy linens, fancy bedspreads and other accouterment of the domestic scene.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 -- Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, a former major in Fidel Castro's army who became a prominent anti-Castro exile leader, has been captured trying to enter Cuba, the Havana radio said tonight.
Members of the New York County Medical Society adopted as official policy last night a report stating that doctors have the right to maintain addicts on drugs under very exceptional circumstances.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Minnesota rallied in the second half tonight to defeat Purdue, 85 -- 81, in a Big Ten basketball game.
BANMETHUOT, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 -- American Special Forces officers here believe they have averted another uprising by mountain tribesmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Mutual funds and other investment companies will be required, beginning this year, to make public extensive new information about their operations under a rule adopted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a worker may not sue his former employer for severance pay in state court if he has not made an effort first to invoke the grievance procedure in his union's contract.
LENINGRAD, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet fur industry gave evidence today of its growing strength in the world market at the opening of the Leningrad International Fur Auction.
Kuhn, Loeb Co., the investment banking house, announced yesterday the election of Henry C. Bevers, Paul D. Kaplan and Richard C. Solow as vice presidents. All are career executives with the company.
The Police Department called in Sol Gelb, a prominent criminal lawyer, yesterday to prosecute one of its detectives in a departmental trial. It is believed to be the first time this has been done.

MARGARET RUTHERFORD, looking very much like a Queen Mother in search of a misplaced throne, lolled imperiously in the back seat of a Rolls-Royce and announced as it whisked passed Stonehenge that she was traveling deeper and deeper into the West Country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Associate Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court has suggested to attorneys for Billie Sol Estes that they submit to the United States Circuit Court in New Orleans a request that he be released on bail.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- The United Nations General Assembly adjourned its morning meeting today in honor of Sir Winston Churchill, whom the Secretary General, U Thant, called "one of the great men of this or any other age."

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The House of Commons said farewell today to the greatest of its own. Sir Winston Churchill was eulogized on both sides of the chamber where he spent more than 60 years of his political life. It was a simple occasion, brief -- and moving in its affection.
The steel industry continued last week to maintain production at 25 per cent above the 1964 level.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A proposal for a sweeping reorganization of the Labor Department'se manpower administration cleared a major obstacle today.

WHEN the snows and sleets of winter are at hand, the average boy's propensity for getting half-frozen without really trying calls for all the ingenuity a mother can muster to keep one jump ahead of the ubiquitous winter colds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- President Johnson's budget sent to Congress today calls for an increase of 26,680 employes in the next fiscal year, starting July 1. They would bring the Government payroll to 2,495,680 persons.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The family of Edwin M. Green filed an appeal today, seeking $1.5 million in damages from a cigarette manufacturer for the lung-cancer death of Mr. Green.
Prices steadied generally on the London Stock Exchange yesterday after profit taking reduced early gains.

THE behavior patterns of the New Breed, the refreshingly different fans who support the New York Mets, are no more predictable than were those of their Ebbets Field predecessors, the possessive and intensely loyal Brooklyn Dodger partisans. Both groups had an unswerving devotion to their own, and every outsider was regarded as the enemy.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation said tonight that an international audience of hundreds of millions might be able to witness the highlights of the state funeral of Sir Winston Churchill on Saturday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 25 -- Abram Fischer, a leading Johannesburg lawyer who has been appearing in court both professionally and as a defendant charged under the Suppression of Communism Act, has gone into hiding.

The licenses of two real estate agents were revoked and those of four brokers were suspended for two weeks in an alleged scheme that fraudulently induced the Veterans Administration to guarantee a $19,500 mortgage loan on a house it had previously rejected as ineligible.
A modest improvement in this country's international payments situation in 1965 was predicted yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council in its 14th annual analysis of the balance of payments.
Sixteen more leaders of the 22-day-old welfare strike were jailed last night after they declined to pay fines of $250 each for refusing to obey a court order to end the walkout.
Three hours was too long for Jesse Gray, Harlem rent strike leader, to wait to see Mayor Wagner at City Hall yesterday. So Mr. Gray and 14 persons with him walked out on the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A $500 million reduction in the Federal farm budget was proposed by President Johnson today but, as in recent years, the savings could be illusory. A large part of the cut hinges on legislation that he will ask Congress to enact.
Stringent ticket regulations promulgated by License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo to abolish scalping and kickbacks to theater personnel will go into effect March 1 instead of next Monday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- California's first $4 billion budget was sent to the Legislature today by Gov. Edmund G. Brown.
ROME, Jan. 25 -- Pope Paul VI today named 27 new Cardinals, including the Most Rev. Lawrence Joseph Shehan, Archbishop of Baltimore, and three prelates from Communist countries.
The snow and sleet that turned the city into a kind of frozen daiquiri over the weekend became just so much dirty water and slush yesterday.
Chief Wahoo McDaniel is on the warpath again.
ROME, Jan. 25 -- While many of Pope Paul's appointments today reflected the needs of the church in various countries, the Pontiff elevated at least one cardinal from a deeply personal motivation.
PARIS, Jan. 25 -- France's Official Journal today published the name of Carlo Ponti, the Italian-born film producer, among a list of newly naturalized French citizens.
ATLANTA -- Integration has touched off an economic revolution in the black ghettos of the South, for nothing has been quicker than the desegregation of the Negro's dollar.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Congressional sponsors and the American Bar Association began today an intensive campaign for early ratification of a constitutional amendment to deal with Presidential disability and vacancies in the Vice Presidency.

The KLM Building at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 49th Street has been bought by the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of Milwaukee for $4.4 million. The 12-story structure was sold by the Henry Phipps estates, the owner since its construction 40 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Soviet Union informed the United States today through its Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, that it excluded the possibility of a violation of the treaty for a limited test ban in its underground nuclear test Jan. 15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Johnson included $350 million today in his budget for merchant marine operations by two Federal maritime agencies for the fiscal year 1966, which begins July 1.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The budget's emphasis on health, education and welfare programs is clearly reflected in the President's estimates of research and development spending for the coming year.
CAIRO, Jan. 25 -- The United Arab Republic is increasing its pressure on West Germany to cease arms shipments to Israel and to refrain from extending diplomatic recognition to her this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The House Ways and Means Committee put the hospital care bill on the express track today.

BONN, Jan. 25 -- A team of Krupp company executives and technicians flew to Warsaw today to work out details of a planned collaboration between the world's largest privately owned concern and the state-run Polish industry.
Three anti-Castro Cubans were indicted by a Queens grand jury yesterday on charges growing out of the firing of a bazooka toward the United Nations on Dec. 11.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 25 -- Premier Moise Tshombe has banned a Leopoldville newspaper that opposed his Government.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- The Lawn Tennis Association of Australia said today it would not conduct an investigation into the reported payment of $500 expense money to the Wimbledon tennis champion, Maria Bueno of Brazil.
The directors of the Metropolitan Opera Guild will give a dinner the evening of Feb. 3 at the Metropolitan Opera Club before the premiere of the new production of "Salome."
A stakes schedule for 1965 of 114 races carrying a value of $4,582,500 in added money was announced yesterday by the New York Racing Association.

MADRAS, India., Jan. 25 ---- The Home Minister, Gulzarilal Nanda, told the people of Kerala today that if the "leftist" Communists were elected to the state Assembly in the elections March 4 they would not be allowed to function.
SELMA, Ala., Jan. 25 -- A large Negro woman stepped out of the voter registration line today and punched Sheriff James G. Clark in the face.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- "The orchestra," as they say here when they are not talking about "the university" or "the railroad," played a concert for the 108th anniversary of the Academy of Music Saturday night, and 3,000 of the faithful were there.

The vast over-the-counter market, encompassing those issues not traded on organized exchanges, may not attract as much attention as does the trading of listed securities, but it can turn in a more spectacular performance.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for the easy-to-prepare main dish.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Steve Leo Jr., Joe Nechamkin's Maryland-bred colt, ran six furlongs in 1:12 and won the $10,000 Collington Purse on a muddy track today at Bowie.
HARTFORD, Jan. 25 -- A bipartisan meeting of state legislative and political leaders adopted today a schedule for the special session of the General Assembly that will open Feb. 2.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Waldemar Farm's Good Trouble led from start to finish today and defeated the more highly regarded Eurasian, Flag Raiser and First Family in the fifth race at Hialeah.

The election of Nathan H. Wentworth as vice chairman was announced yesterday by the Continental Insurance Companies, a group of 10 property and casualty insurance companies with assets approaching $2 billion.
The Philadelphia Orchestra will play at Philharmonic Hall at 8:30 tonight. Eugene Ormandy will conduct, with Alfred Brendel, pianist, and Joseph De Pasquale, violist, as soloists.
The stock market took in stride yesterday the hospitalization of President Johnson over the weekend and his budget message to Congress.

One real danger to the public interest in the Democratic leadership deadlock that has immobilized the State Legislature for nearly three weeks is that insistence on a face-saving compromise will result in acceptance of a second-class man in either the Senate or the Assembly. This possibility is implicit in any deal between the pro-Kennedy and the pro-Wagner blocs.
The City of Dallas, Tex., sold yesterday $15 million of waterworks and sanitary sewer revenue bonds to an underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Drexel Co.
Joe Namath had the operation.
Herbert Blau and Jules Irving, founders and co-producing directors of the San Francisco Actors Workshop, have been named co-directors of the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater.

The failure of two national banks last weekend points up two continuing problems confronting state and Federal bank supervisors. The more fundamental problem concerns certificates of deposit. In both failures -- the San Francisco National Bank, with deposits of $37.6 million, and the Brighton (Colo.) National Bank, with deposits of $2.2 million -- the banks had secured large amounts of deposits by the sale of certificates.

The joint 1965 fund-raising campaign of Planned Parenthood -- World Population and Planned Parenthood of Manhattan and the Bronx will open with a luncheon Monday in the Grand Ballroom of the Sheraton-East.
More than 300 works by noted artists will be placed on sale at Lord Taylor Westchester on Thursday for the benefit of WNDT, Channel 13, the educational television station.
Net income, before special credits, of the Chicago and North Western Railway in 1964 and in the final quarter declined from 1963 levels, Ben W. Heineman, chairman, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Senate investigators working on the case of Robert G. Baker have begun a study of contracts with the Sweetwater Development Corporation of Dallas regarding a pilot saline water conversion plant now under construction at Wrightsville Beach, N.C., informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- President Johnson put it simply in his Budget Message: Let's clean up the auto and tincan junkyards along the country's highways and put the scrap to work.
The Cleveland Browns and the Baltimore Colts yesterday collected the largest player shares in the 32-year history of the National Football League championship game.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (Comtelboro) -- In the closing months of 1964 there were signs of resumed growth in British exports, the Board of Trade has reported.
The tallest building in the world became a traffic hazard yesterday.
A private agency for better housing has concluded that criminal prosecution of housing code violators, as presently pursued by the city, is not an effective weapon against slums.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 27 -- The military leaders of South Vietnam ousted the civilian Government of Premier Tran Van Huong today.
The Texas Water Development Board sold $15 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago.
A realignment on the top executive level of the National Lead Company was announced yesterday.

A program designed to avoid "complacency, duplication, bureaucracy and waste" in the city's campaign against educational poverty was begun at Gracie Mansion yesterday with a promise of full support from Mayor Wagner.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Providence College romped to a 73-56 victory over Rhode Island tonight and remained the nation's only major unbeaten college basketball team.

Despite protests from persons who want to preserve the Savoy Plaza Hotel, the General Motors Company yesterday filed plans with the city's Department of Buildings to replace the landmark with an office building.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- President Johnson approved today granting routes to Alaska to two European airlines, Royal Netherlands KLM and West Germany's Lufthansa.
The interaction of fashion, culture and leisure is the newest force in retailing, according to one of America's most seasoned merchants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The new Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States pledged his "moral support" today to the Great Society program of his fellow Texan, President Johnson.

Sixteen leaders of the Welfare Department strike have chosen to go to jail rather than pay fines for contempt of a court order to end their walkout. They join three other unionists already imprisoned. Their purpose is to dramatize their fight against the Condon-Wadlin Act and the mandatory penalties it imposes for civil service strikes.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Jan. 26 -- One suspect in the Philadelphia, Miss., civil rights murders is planning to plead either guilty or no contest, while a second has repudiated his confession, a Federal Court was told here today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Billie Jean Moffitt and Mrs. Carole Caldwell Graebner, two of the top players in the United States, scored easy doubles victories in the Australian tennis championships today. But Australian Davis Cup stars dominated the action.
INTEREST in needlepoint is the highest it has been since Queen Victoria deemed it a worthy and homely pursuit.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- The Soviet Union ordered today the expulsion of Richard F. Stolz, 39-year-old first secretary at the United States Embassy, on charges of espionage.

MONTREAL, (Canadian Press) Jan. 26 -- Soviet shipping land diplomatic officials announced yesterday that the first trans-Atlantic passenger service between Canada and the Soviet Union would start at the beginning of the 1966 navigation season.

August Heckscher, executive director of the 20th Century Fund and former White House Consultant on the Arts, will address the Architectural League of New York tomorrow. There will be a reception at 6 P.M., dinner at 7:15 and the program at 8:30.
Negotiations between the United Steelworkers and two major can companies were recessed abruptly yesterday amid recriminations between union factions.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reversed today by a 4-3 vote contempt proceedings brought against United States Attorney Robert Hauberg of Jackson, Miss.
A prominent steamship industry executive paid tribute last night to the foreign freight forwarding industry for its efforts in promoting and stimulating international trade.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 26 -- After the completion tomorrow of the 1965 Pure Oil Performance Trials, drivers and crews of the Auto Racing Club of America will take over the garages and workshops at Daytona International Speedway.

BONN, Jan. 26 -- Hans Walter Zech Nenntwich, a 48-year-old convicted war criminal, was sentenced today to 10 months in prison for bribery and instigation to jailbreak. Zech-Nenntwich escaped from prison last April and fled to the United Arab Republic. He gave himself up in August.

In another of their excursions into the distant past, musically speaking, Paul Boepple and his Dessoff Choirs presented music by Ludwig Senfl in Town Hall last night. A native of Zurich, the composer spent most of his career in Vienna and various German cities during the first half of the 16th century, and his music was much admired by Martin Luther.

The first live television broadcast of Sir Winston Churchill's body lying in state in Westminster Hall in London is scheduled to be presented here at 9:22 A.M. today. The American Broadcasting Company, Columbia Broadcasting System and National Broadcasting Company said they would carry the program.

TOKYO, Jan. 26 -- A fact-finding and conciliation mission of the International Labor Organization apparently has failed to find a solution for a long standing impasse between the Japanese Government and leftwing labor unions.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that the major appropriation increases he would recommend in his 1965-66 budget would total $598 million.

There are the grave food shortages, the threat of China's nuclear bombs, the conflict over Kashmir, the arguments over a national economic plan, the divisions in the ruling Congress party and many others. Yet it is unhappily typical that the most exciting and excitable development in India today is the violent protest in Madras Province against the introduction of Hindi as the official language.

BY general acclamation, summertime is salad time. But just as too many cold foods can pall in hot weather, so can too many hot foods in winter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged today that the United States Steel Corporation and three other large companies violated antitrust laws in acquiring various cement and concrete producing companies.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 26 -- Tourists and magazine readers know the Southwest as a land of bright sunshine, breath-taking scenery and a wealth of natural resources feeding an endless boom in everything from oil to agriculture and real estate.
The New York Knickerbockers left town two weeks ago on a losing note. They returned last night on the same note.
After 13 years, the bronze statue of Jose Marti, the Cuban liberator and writer, will finally rise next month on its long empty pedestal at the southern end of Central Park.

The new military take-over in South Vietnam is the latest of a series of Government crises that have beset the war-torn nation since the overthrow and death of President Ngo Dinh Diem in November, 1963. It appeared to mark the end of the two-month-old civilian Government of Premier Tran Van Huong, in the wake of violent Buddhist opposition.

When Simon B. Blumenthal arrived at work at 9:40 A.M. yesterday, he found a basket of 60 white carnations waiting for him on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange. "Right then," he recalled later, "I knew something was up."

To use a golfing analogy, it may be relatively easy to hit the right spot with four shots gradually increasing in accuracy; but it is quite another to have to hole out in one.
There was little excitement on the American Stock Exchange yesterday with prices moving up irregularly as the trading pace slackened.
Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division urged the city yesterday to stop treating chronic drunks as "human refuse" to be swept off the streets and into jails.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Johnson, who entered the Naval Hospital at Bethesda, Md., with a cold three and a half days ago, returned to the White House today.

Roger M. Blough has criticized as excessive the attention given to recent steel price increases, declaring that there "has been practically no change in the average price of steel during the past six years."

An auction of manuscripts and books in a Madison Avenue gallery proved to be of unusual interest yesterday because of its historical range: It was, in effect, a survey of world literature from Babylon to Washington.
A syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., won the distinction yesterday as underwriters for the first public financing by a private company set up to generate atomic power.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The House voted today to stop sales of surplus food to the United Arab Republic.

GEORGE A. VICAS, whose program on the Kremlin was one of television's more impressive accomplishments, applied his talents last night to a filmed documentary on the French Revolution over the network of the National Broadcasting Company.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Candy Spots showed today that his recent comeback in a sprint race was no fluke by easily capturing the mile and one-sixteenth $25,000 added San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 (AP) -- An official of a maritime group predicted today that ship pilots would reject a controversial proposal to change traffic regulations on the Great Lakes.

Herbert L. Seegal has been elected a director or R.H. Macy Co. and also has been named chief executive of Bamberger's, New Jersey division of the Mary company, Jack I. Straus chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

The comments of Brooks Atkinson published Jan. 19, on "a streak of bigotry" in the Eitani case in Israel, were not merely in questionable taste but displayed an uncharacteristic lack of understanding of a difficult situation and of Jewish religious law and observance.

Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation raised the quarterly dividend by 25 cents yesterday to $1.50 a share on 35,048,259 shares of common stock outstanding. It is payable March 10 to some 266,666 stockholders of record Feb. 5.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Johnson's budget has resolved doubts that may have existed about the President's commitment to the "new" economic policy begun under President Kennedy. He favors it.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- The United States appealed to the small powers today to uphold the right of the General Assembly to impose mandatory assessments for peace-keeping forces.
Following is a listing of some of the principal improvements for the 1965 season of the World's Fair as outlined yesterday for the directors and members of the fair corporation:

ROME, Jan. 26 -- Pope Paul VI acted today to fill vacancies in the Roman Curia, the administrative body of the Catholic Church, brought about by the appointment of 27 new Cardinals announced yesterday.

Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that "we are losing the war in Vietnam." He added, "If our strategy is not changed, we will be thrown out in a matter of months -- certainly within the year."

In a landmark 2-to-1 decision, the United States Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday that mass demonstrators arrested while protesting denial of equal rights are not entitled to a Federal Court trial on state charges.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 26 (UPI) -- The University of Virginia named George Blackburn, the football team's coach on offense, as head coach today. He succeeds Bill Elias, who resigned to take over as head coach at the United States Naval Academy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- William C. Foster, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, had a rough time today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Senator Jack E. Bronston, who has been the front-running candidate for Senate majority leader, has concluded that he no longer has any real chance of election.
A regulation permitting Federal savings and loan association to make loans for urban renewal projects has been approved by the board of the federal Home Loan Bank.

Fifth Avenue, the grande dame of the city's well-dressed boulevards, got another accessory yesterday -- a newly designed, bronze-colored lamppost with twin mercury-vapor lamps and a built-in flagpole.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 26 -- Robert Stevenson of New Haven, Conn., a 42-year-old graduate of Yale and Harvard Law School, became an Iranian citizen today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Senator J.W. Fulbright proposed legislation today aimed at curbing the influence of foreign agents and lobbyists on United States foreign-policy decisions.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 26 -- A Municipal Court judge denied "in the interest of justice" today a petition signed by 244 faculty members of the University of California. It requested dismissal of all charges against more than 700 defendants arrested in sit-in demonstrations on the Berkeley campus late last year.

HOUSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Manuel Gonzalez, third ranked welterweight, advanced his chances for a shot at the world championship tonight with a narrow decision over the champion, Emile Griffith, in a non-title 10-round fight.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Jan. 26 -- Finance ministers of the European Economic Community predicted today that monetary union among the member nations, while "eminently desirable," would not become a reality for at least five years.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- With the opening last night of the Boston Ballet's first subscription season, this city became the fourth on the Eastern Seaboard to have its own professional ballet company, performing on a regular schedule.
The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation has cut off supplies of several of its brands of liquor to R.H. Macy Co. for selling them below the fair-traded price.

SAIGON, Wednesday, Jan. 27 -- Renewed violence swept South Vietnam's major cities yesterday, and a 17-year-old girl burned herself to death in support of Buddhist demands for the resignation of Premier Tran Van Huong.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits urged today that major Senate debates be televised. He also proposed installation of a public address system in the Senate Chamber.

A $70 million renewal project for a 15-block area of the Bronx that would include low-income and moderate-income housing and rehabilitation of some buildings on the site was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 -- Harry A. Stuhldreher, the quarterback of the famous Four Horsemen of Notre Dame, died today in West Penn Hospital. He was 63 years old.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 26 -- The winner of a three-month countywide Queen of Hearts contest will be chosen on Saturday at the first annual Queen of Hearts Ball. The ball, in the Georgian Room of the Garden City Hotel, will benefit the Nassau Heart Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Senator John J. Williams, the Delaware Republican who initiated the investigation of Robert G. Baker 15 months ago, said today that Representative Emanuel Celler, Brooklyn Democrat, split a legal fee with Mr. Baker's law firm in 1961.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26 -- Yale probably will hire a new football coach before the week is out, DeLaney Kiphuth said today. Kiphuth, the director of athletics, explained he had reactivated a seven-man screening committee that had made a thorough study and search for a coach two years ago following the resignation of Jordan Olivar.
The stock market managed yesterday to close with narrow gains in heavy trading after following a zigzag route all day.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- The loss of the two co-producing directors of the Actor's Workshop here to the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater was lamented today as "the worst possible" cultural blow San Francisco could have received.
TRENTON, Jan. 26 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes outlined today plans for a 3,000-acre multipurpose park five miles east of Trenton.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- A Wall Street lawyer told a group of British businessmen today that one way they could increase their sales in the American market was by fighting American trade barrier's "in the press, in the courts, and in the legislatures."

DETROIT, Jan. 26 -- The General Services Administration, the Government's purchasing agent, published today in the Federal Register a list of 17 safety features that it would like to see included in the new automobiles it buys.
A system in which buoys moored in the ocean will send weather data almost instantaneously to almost any point on earth is being developed by the United States Weather Bureau.

In 1962, when I was 20, I wrote The Times opposing suggestions to raise New York State's minimum drinking age. I argued that most people my age drank only in moderation and should not be punished because a few could not restrain themselves.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 26 -- A 22-year-old south Indian burned himself to death in the city of Madras today as a protest against the adoption of Hindi as the sole official language in India.

CONDUCTORS are beginning to investigate the lesser-played Haydn symphonies. There are more than a hundred Haydn symphonies, but for years conductors were content to live with a half dozen or so. We had the "Military," the "London," the "Surprise," over and over again.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The Defense Ministry announced today that it was scrapping Britain's entire fleet of Valiant bombers because their structure had been weakened by metal fatigue.

WARSAW, Jan. 26 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, has joined in this country's protest against a 20-year statute of limitations on trials of Nazi war criminals. The statute goes into force May 8 unless modified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy today named Walter J. Sheridan, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent and Justice Department investigator, as a special assistant on his staff. He will head the Senator's office in Syracuse, N.Y.
Now that Borough President Edward R. Dudley has taken his place on the bench, I want to speak out for the designation, as his successor, of Deputy Borough President Earl Brown.

ON the 25th anniversary of the Army-Notre Dame football game of 1924 four grayish-haired men assembled in New York for a private dinner party in honor of Grantland Rice, then the beloved dean of the sports-writing profession. It was an unusual gesture of appreciation and gratitude because the hosts were the fabled Four Horsemen of Notre Dame, a backfield that had been given the glow of immortality by the poetic pen of the imaginative Granny.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Jan. 26 -- The Air Force Academy has threatened resigning cadets with severe penalties if they discuss the academy's cheating scandal.

IN HIS new novel, Frederick Buechner has left the palaces of the mighty and the machinery of politics he pictured in "The Return of Ansel Gibbs." He has turned now to the tree-lined precincts of a small New England town and to concerns of the spirit: the nature of prayer, the virtue of suffering, the "truth" of God and His gift to man.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Thirty-one-year-old Gerard Pipart was the man of the hour on the second day of the French haute couture collections, and the bet is that he will keep that position even when the giants of high fashion show later this week.
A special three-man Federal Court upheld yesterday the basic Republican plan for the legislative reapportionment of New York State.
The British pound gained slightly in moderately active trading on the foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Its closing quotation was $2.7926, up 1 point from the Monday level.

Mrs. Marilyn Jean Fraser, a 25-year-old blonde described by Federal Government lawyers as a prostitute, denied yesterday allegations that she had been taken to the Hudson County jail to have sexual relations with a prisoner.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- America's proposed supersonic airliner is about to undergo the most critical review since a program to develop it began 19 months ago.
A controversial bill broadening the jurisdiction of the Traffic Department's Meter Maids was passed yesterday by the City Council. The vote was 26 to 7.
ATLANTA, Jan. 26 -- The quail is more to the South than just a game bird. It is, in a small, earthy sort of way, typical of a way of life, and a good one.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- United States District Judge Richard Austin ruled here today that the Zenith Radio Corporation is entitled to $48,716,616 damages from Hazeltine Corporation, a designer and licenser of electronic systems.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- The American Medical Association has opened its "national educational" campaign against medical care for the aged under Social Security.
Prices of soybeans for future delivery were whipsawed yesterday by rumors that turned out to be well founded.

AT a crowded news conferece in Washington yesterday, the Right Rev. John Elbridge Hines spoke smilingly of a "disaster" that had occurred last October in St. Louis. The disaster, it turned out, was his election as the 22d Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Johnson today named Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey to be chairman of the National Advisory Council of the Peace Corps, and directed him to convene a national conference of Peace Corps volunteers who have finished their term of service.
NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 26 -- A wife has appealed to Senator Robert F. Kennedy for assistance in her determined running skirmish with the Marine Corps over the right to remain overseas with her husband.

A crew member of the freighter Smith Voyager told Coast Guard investigators here yesterday that he could see "some daylight" through several watertight doors while the vessel was on her doomed voyage from Houston to the East.
A NEW designer, Charles (Chuck) Howard, made his debut on Seventh Avenue yesterday with a collection of summer clothes that are young, swinging and easy to move around in.
The manager of a Bronx catering concern, in a hurry to get rid of a nervous gunman, helped the bandit find the company's cash during a holdup yesterday.
TRENTON, Jan. 26 -- Oh, the farmer and the sportsman should be friends!
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- We are obviously going to have some lovely arguments on our way to the Great Society over how to employ our people.

" Winston Churchill: An Intimate Biography," by Violet Bonham Carter, daughter of Lord Asquith and a leader in the Liberal Party, will be published by Harcourt, Brace World in late March or early April.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Gov. William W. Scranton today urged adoption of his record $1,261,000,000 budget to "further speed Pennsylvania along the road to progress and prosperity."

ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The site for the 1965 meeting of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States was changed today from Memphis to Montreat, N.C., because of what was described as a racial controversy at the Memphis Second Presbyterian Church.
United States Government bond prices fell slightly yesterday. The decline was the first in a month to include most of the 63 outstanding Treasury issues.
Can a small advertising agency from the Middle West find happiness? Do the big big-city agencies have all the fun? And all the accounts?
The issuance of the first export license for the sale of soybeans to the Soviet Union was announced yesterday afternoon by the Department of Commerce and the Continental Grain Company.
The operators of the United States Government-owned Savannah, the world's first nuclear-propelled merchant ship, announced yesterday that Turkey had refused to be host to the $53 million vessel.
THE burgeoning interest in art nouveau in the last decade has bean registered in spiraling prices but not in the furnishings shown in department store room settings.

The nation is less troubled today, because one man is out of his sickbed and back at his desk. President Johnson left the hospital two days sooner than his doctors had first recommended, but for him this probably constituted self-restraint.

The volume of merchant shipping under construction throughout the world decreased slightly during the last quarter of 1964 from the record peacetime level set at the end of last September. This was reported here yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.
Mayor Wagner told 150 of the leading bankers of the nation yesterday that the city's economy was bright and early "on the upswing."

Since a suit is a suit no matter how you photograph it, Edward M. Meyers Associates, Inc., decided they had to come up with a provocative idea for Haspel Brothers, producers of summer clothing. Well, some 200 years ago a protege of the Marquise de Pompadour became controller general of France.

EAST HILLS. L.I., Jan. 26 -- Two armed men escaped with about $12,000 in jewelry today after gaining entry by a subterfuge and handcuffing four persons in the home of a vice president of the Harry Winston, Inc., jewelry concern.

New York's middle-income housing program has been endangered by a "totally inadequate" 10 per cent increase in architects' fees, the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects charged yesterday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 26 -- The five Opposition parties that joined forces to back Miss Fatima Jinnah in her unsuccessful campaign for the Presidency of Pakistan decided tonight to maintain their alliance a little longer and work jointly to win seats in the national and provincial assemblies.
Proctor Gamble Company the leading soap and detergent producer, was one of a few companies reporting earnings yesterday that failed to show a significant increase in profits.
Stockholders of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company approved yesterday a proposed 50 per cent stock dividend.

A gala champagne opening of an exhibition of paintings by leading contemporary Spanish artists will take place on the evening of Feb. 9 at the World House Galleries, 987 Madison Avenue, to benefit Just One Break (J.O.B.). The show will continue through Feb. 13.
MIAMI. Jan. 26 (AP) -- Out of Pocket ran down favored Glass House in the final stride today to win the seventh race at Hialeah and score his fourth straight victory.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Republicans and Democrats alike declared here tonight that a Federal Court's approval of a Republican plan for legislative reapportionment was a victory for their party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today the first case to reach it raising the issue of whether the Justice Department may sue a state in an effort to knock down discriminatory barriers to Negroes who want to register to vote.

Herbert Hill, labor secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called yesterday for the abolition of the system under which he said "union hiring halls" were used as the sole source of labor recruitment in the building construction industry.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Jan. 26 -- Premier Moise Tshombe announced today that he would go to Brussels tomorrow for long-delayed talks with the Belgian Government.

Robert Moses, president of the World's Fair Corporation, said yesterday that "if I know anything about the fair's finances," the city would not get back any of the $24 million it advanced for permanent improvements in making the fair site ready.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Billy Walker of Britain knocked out Charlie Powell of San Diego with a right to the jaw after 2 minutes 32 seconds of the second round tonight, in a scheduled 10-round bout at the Olympia.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 26 (UPI) -- Dr. John Emery, the pilot of the No. 2 Canadian bobsled, was injured today when his sled crashed during a practice run for the four-man world championship this weekend.

The Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation reported yesterday record 1964 net earnings of $7,373,081, or $2.55 a share. This compared with $4,845,000 or $1.69 a share, in 1963, after adjusting for a 100 per cent stock dividend in 1964.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Treasury auctioned $1 billion of one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 3.945 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Council of Chief State School Officers will offer the first major opposition within the educational community to President Johnson's $1.25 billion school aid bill.
A new minimum contract granting copyright ownership to writers of popular songs, in addition to other conditions, has been drafted for negotiation with United States music publishers.
A Brooklyn gambler and two other men were arrested yesterday when the police raided a lavishly furnished apartment in a building at Manhattan Beach.

Lillian Gish will portray the nurse in "Romeo and Juliet" at the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Conn. It will be the first bill of the student series on March 8 and will usher in the regular season on June 19.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Jan. 26 -- Jimmy Arthur has a tanned and leathery face, seasoned by too many years of helping other people train harness horses. For 26 of those years he has helped Del Miller reign as the Squire of Meadowland and acquire more money than you can shake a buggy whip at.

Six Olympic athletes from foreign nations arrived yesterday to compete in tomorrow night's Millrose Games and other indoor track meets.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 26 -- The advance in technology is forcing the nation's rural electric cooperatives to find new and larger sources of capital, Norman M. Clapp, Administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration, said here today.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 26 -- Premier Hassan Ali Mansour of Iran died tonight, five days after he was struck down by two bullets from an assassin's pistol. He was 41 years old.

Governor Rockefeller has been at some pains in recent weeks to prepare the people of New York State for the shock of increased taxation. WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, introduced a bill today to raise the ceiling on the number of veterans' hospital beds from 125,000 to 130,000.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday that estimated consolidated net income for 1964 reached a record of $395 million, or $3.81 a share on the capital stock outstanding.

Strikes and other factors were blamed yesterday for the drop in net income last year of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company. Income fell to $34,122,737 from $39,306,664 in 1963, the annual report disclosed.

Visitors to a new exhibition of primitive art, opening today at the American Museum of Natural History, will find many of the objects mysterious as well as engrossing. They will be in accord with experts in the field, who still have much to learn about the artifacts' meaning and use.

SAMMY RESHEVSKY of Spring Valley, New York, is, at 53, the oldest grand master in active competition. He started his professional career at the age of 7, staging simultaneous exhibitions at leading clubs, and he has never lost his zest for these mass demonstrations.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Bernard Marmaduke FitzAlan Howard, 16th Duke of Norfolk, Earl of Arundel, Earl Marshal and Hereditary Marshal and Chief Butler of England, believes that, if the aristocracy is to lead in Britain, it must work hard and well at the jobs it under takes.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings rose 44.5 per cent in 1964 from the 1963 level, hitting a seven-year high.
ROME, Jan. 27 -- Pope Paul VI told an audience today that the expansion of the College of Cardinals, from 76 to 103, corresponded to the growing "proportions" of the Roman Catholic Church.
Prices of most issues advanced on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and the trading pace quickened.

The consolidated net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (Near Jersey) for 1964 were estimated yesterday by M.J. Rathbone, chairman and chief executive officer, at $1.05 billion, or $4.87 a share, on the average of 215,538,204 shares outstanding.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Carole Caldwell Graebner and Billie Jean Moffitt advanced to the semi-finals of the women's doubles in the Australian tennis championships today.
NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 27 -- The First Army will retain its designation when its headquarters are shifted, sometime this year, from Governors Island, N.Y., to Second Army Headquarters at Fort Meade, Md.

BONN, Jan. 28 -- In a move to cut the flow of "hot" money into the country, the West German Bundestag (lower house) voted today to impose a 25 per cent tax on interest paid to foreign holders of fixed-interest stock market securities.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan halted further proceedings in Supreme Court yesterday on an indictment that had charged George Whitmore Jr. with murdering two East Side career girls.
Kansas City, Mo., sold $7,837,000 of bonds yesterday to an underwriting group led by the Bank of America.

NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 27 -- Mrs. Nathaniel N. Reich, an American housewife fighting Marine Corps efforts to evict her from Okinawa, received support today from an unexpected source -- men and women from Army and Air Force units here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- President Johnson today selected Douglas MacArthur 2d, United States Ambassador to Belgium, to be Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Relations.

Watching the Inaugural Parade I had more of a feeling of locality, of the extent of this country, of its multitude of communities than I had ever had before. The passing of the President and the Vice President, who come from opposite boundaries of the country, the procession of the Governors, each usually followed by a band and a float from his state, made a deep impression.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) -- William Haggin Perry's Jacinto, a son of Bold Ruler, equalled the track record of 1:20 3-5 for seven furlongs today and won the $10,000 Long Beach purse at Santa Anita.

Selma, Ala., is currently the center of the long struggle to make the right to vote a reality for Negroes in the Deep South. Under the leadership of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, the Negroes there have organized an intensive drive to register.

THE campaign to prepare United States skiers for top international Alpine competition seems to be making great strides. Bob Beattie, the Olympic coach, remains convinced that the United States will soon become a power in the sport's downhill phases.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Residents of one of this city's most fashionable sections have established a window-watching organization of "crime wardens" to help curb a wave of robberies and burglaries.
JOHN DONNE, a poet very influential in our century, lived three centuries ago. The aptness of his tragic sense of life does not diminish. His bell still tolls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A six-year search for the best site at which to drill a hole through the earth's crust ended today with the selection of a spot in the Pacific Ocean 100 miles north-northeast of Maui in the Hawaiian Islands.

The New York City Opera will borrow Kurt Kasznar from the cast of the Broadway comedy, "Barefoot in the Park" for six appearances as Mack the Knife in "The Threepenny Opera" this spring. The company is doing the Weill opera in its original German under the title "Die Dreigroschenoper."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The White House said today that President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey had agreed on the procedures Mr. Humphrey should follow in assuming the powers of the Presidency if Mr. Johnson became incapacitated.

The timetable is slowing down for a controversial package plan under consideration by the New York Stock Exchange. The general membership probably won't get to vote on proposed changes in fees and commissions until this spring -- at the earliest.

STUTTGART. Germany, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- The widow of a former SS (Elite Guard) officer today won her long struggle to have her husband honored for the secret role he played in fighting against the Nazi murder of the Jews.

Long after the invention of the cigar -- but shortly after the nomination of Warren G. Harding in 1920 in Chicago's Blackstone Hotel -- there began to spread throughout the United States some ugly rumors about the existence of "smoke-filled rooms."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The players Harry Stuhldreher led as the Notre Dame quarterback in the early nineteen-twenties, when the "Four Horsemen" galloped the road to football glory, will attend his funeral here Saturday.

The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that it was negotiating for United States television rights to a special Briaish drama show on which prominent performers appear in excerpts from outstanding plays.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Two submarine crewmen perished today in a general alarm fire that swept a three-story frame apartment building.
The roster of distinguished guests was no less glittering than the exhibition of fine jewelry at the sixth Diamond Ball last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States lost $95 million worth of gold in December, bringing the loss for the year to $125 million, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
The new foreign aid program is getting off to a poor start, emphasized by Senator Fulbright's withdrawal from his normal function as floor manager of the Administration bill.
George Meany is trying to help mediate the 24-day-old Welfare Department strike.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 27 -- Another south Indian, the second in 48 hours, burned himself to death today in protest against the establishment of Hindi, the tongue of north India, as the official language of this vast, diverse republic.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Jan. 27 -- Thirty more Air Force Academy cadets have resigned in the academy's cheating scandal, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- An Administration official said today that the illegal traffic in pep pills and tranquilizers had become so lucrative that racketeers were entering the business.
TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- The State Reapportionment Commission agreed tonight to disagree on methods for redrawing New Jersey's 15 Congressional Districts and reapportioning its Legislature.
TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- New Jersey may establish a clearing house of information about out-of-state colleges to enable average, but qualified, high school graduates to continue their education.

Much has been said against creativity in advertising recently, particularly against what has been called creativity for creativity's sake. And the criticism has come from executives of some of the larger and more successful agencies.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the Lawrence American Field Warehousing Corporation was liable for losses taken by six warehouse receipt holders in the soybean-oil swindle. Tile action was taken even though the company had no direct control over the Bayonne, N.J., tank farm involved in the swindle.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 27 -- Four men were arrested by the Nassau County Police today and charged with the robbery of $20,000 in jewelry yesterday from the home of a vice president of the Harry Winston, Inc., jewelry concern and the theft of $31,000 in jewelry and cash from a Kings Point home last Dec. 4.
A LITTLE something for everybody is what it appears they've tried to cram into "Dear Brigitte," the comedy that opened at Loew's State and other theaters yesterday.

ATLANTA, Jan. 27 -- Jack Crockford, the assistant director of field operations for the Georgia Game and Fish Commission, took time the other day to outline some of the prospects and problems of hunting and fishing here.
AFTER a long career as a novelist James Hanley, British author, wrote his first play. "Say Nothing," which opened last night at Jan Hus House, turns out, not surprisingly, to be novelistic.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 27 -- Forty times in the last 11 years mobs on four continents have attacked United States Information Agency libraries and cultural centers, burning books and smashing furniture and exhibits. Scores of lesser incidents, such as the breaking of a window, have also been recorded.
LOS ANGELES Jan. 27 -- A Brooklyn-born novelist named Martin Dibner has been traveling through California's cities and towns for several months on a sort of cultural odyssey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Following is the text of the statement released by President Kennedy on Aug. 10, 1961, describing the disability agreement between him and Vice President Johnson that forms the basis for the new disability agreement between President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The House Ways and Means Committee started work today on the Administration's program of health care for the aged with favorable action all but assured.
The directors of the Union Carbide Corporation voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend to $1 a share from 90 cents and proposed a two-for-one stock split.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Representative Emanuel Celler and one of his law partners, Murray C. Spett, held a joint news conference today to disclaim any impropriety by their firm in having shared a legal fee with Robert G. Baker's firm in 1962 after Mr. Baker had referred a client to them.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- The difference between driving good horses and bad horses, according to Ralph Baldwin, is a heart attack.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation showed a sharp recovery in earnings last year, with profits rising 60.3 per cent over 1963.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission approved today the sale of a Louisiana television station to a Texas company partly controlled by the trustees of the Presidential family's broadcast holdings.

The appointment of W.H. Conzen as senior vice president in charge of domestic operations of the Schering Corporation was announced yesterday by Francis C. Brown, chairman and president of the pharmaceutical-products company.
Indoor track returns to Madison Square Garden tonight with a three-ring circus of Olympic athletes from here and abroad.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 -- A panel of three Federal judges rejected today a March, 1963, order of the Interstate Commerce Commission that would have cost 56 Western railroads an estimated $45 million to $50 million a year in freight revenues.

The owners of Israel's flagship were accused yesterday of operating the 25,339-ton luxury liner Shalom with "careless, incompetent and inattentive" personnel who were responsible for a collision that cost the lives of 19 seamen.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Capt. William S. Busik completed his tour of duty as athletic director of the United States Naval Academy today and was replaced by Capt. Alan R. Cameron.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission was accused by one of its commissioners today of intruding unconstitutionally into the field of religion.

An increase of 4,545,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks for the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 210,399,000 barrels, compared with 205,854,000 a week earlier and 198,943,000 a year ago.
The city was urged yesterday by the Citizens Union to move swiftly in enacting a pending City Council bill calling for strict regulation of the taxicab industry.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Jan. 27 -- The Opposition accused Premier Moise Tshombe' Government today of repression and intimidation designed to prevent free participation in the March elections.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Johnson said this evening that he would not fly to London for the funeral of Sir Winston Churchill.

The Xerox Corporation realized a 68 per cent increase in earnings last year on a 52 per cent gain in revenues, Joseph C. Wilson, president, noted yesterday in reporting the best results in its 58-year-history.

ONE might suppose that record for trans-atlantic crossings motivated by international bridge encounters would be held by one of the great Italian world champions. Pietro Forquet and Giorgio Belladonna, perhaps the brightest stars of the Blue Team, have made five round trips in the course of winning their seven world titles.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The Republicans in the State Senate delivered this ultimatum today to the Democratic majority: Settle your leadership squabble soon, or we'll settle it for you.

" The Addict in the Streets," a book in which youngsters involved with narcotics tell their own stories, will be published by Grove Press on Feb. 19. The book is based on tape recordings made over a seven-year period by Ralph Tefferteller, associate director of the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side of New York City.

The Ford Foundation gave a financial transfusion yesterday to WNDT, the educational television station. The sum was not disclosed, but Devereux C. Josephs, a member of the station's board of trustees, said that the amount was sufficient to meet operating expenses until June 30.
The stock market had good news for most investors yesterday as three stocks rose for every two that lagged in heavy trading.

MONTREAL, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Two goals by Jean Guy Talbot late in the third Period broke up what had been a brilliant defensive struggle tonight and gave the league-leading Montreal Canadiens a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.
It is a pleasure to read in your columns that citizens of goodwill have risen to the occasion to save architectural landmarks from the too-eager hands of builders of unneeded "luxury" housing.

RICHMOND, Jan. 27 -- A three-judge Federal court postponed a decision today in a case involving marriage between whites and Negroes. At stake is a Virginia statute that forbids racially mixed marriages.
Three persons who helped arrest criminal suspects or assisted policemen in difficult situations were honored yesterday at a ceremony at Police Headquarters.

One of tile city's valuable proving grounds for composers was open for business last night as Max Pollikoff's Music in Our Time began its ninth season at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The fact that Andrew S. (he asks to remain anonymous) has canceled plans to vacation on Antigua next month is of no importance to the public, but his reasons for doing so cast interesting light on the trials of middleclass living.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli sector), Jan. 27 -- The Knesset (Parliament) rejected today Opposition motions for a debate on the citizenship status of Mrs. Rina Eitani, a member of the town council of Upper Nazareth.

A lease has been signed by the New American Library of World Literature, Inc., for 33,500 square feet of office space in the new 45-story J.C. Penney Building at 1301 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) between 52d and 53d Streets.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, top carrier in its industry, reported yesterday systemwide consolidated earnings of $52,309,000 for 1961, the best showing in eight years. Last year's net income was more than double the 1963 figure of $24,054,000.

Giuseppe DI Stefano, the Italian tenor, came back to the Metropolitan Opera last night after an absence of eight seasons. He chose to appear as Hoffmann in Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann," a role that he had not previously sung.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- An attorney for the United Mine Workers of America told the Supreme Court today that the Sherman Antitrust Act did not prevent a union from bargaining for higher wages even if less efficient producers were forced out of business.

An official of the ship line that operated the ill-fated American freighter Smith Voyager conceded yesterday that the 10,720-ton vessel was overloaded and unseaworthy on five voyages to India before she sank in the Atlantic on Dec. 27.

The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that beginning Feb. 1 the Manufacturers National Bank of Detroit,' the trustee under the company's savings and stock investment program for salaried employes, will acquire substantially all of its requirements of Ford common stock for the program by purchasing shares of Ford Class A stock from the Ford Foundation.
The former fur inventory of the Neiman-Marcus Company, Dallas, will be put on sale Monday, Feb. 8, in the basement fur department of William Filene's Sons, the Boston specialty store.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The Government announced today new measures to help British companies sell more overseas as part of its efforts in defending the pound.

LIVE television pictures from Westminster Hall, where Sir Winston Churchill will lie in state until Saturday morning, were received in the United States yesterday morning with excellent clarity and detail.
CAMP PLEI ME, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 -- In the two months since it arrived, the Special Forces team at Plei Me, 18 miles from the Cambodian border, has killed one Vietcong' soldier.

Mrs. Lytle Hull, who has devoted herself to the cause of the New York City Center of Music and Drama since its inception, was honored last night at the New York State Theater by the Friends of City Center. She is vice president and an incorporator of the center.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The state's Republicans began to prepare today for the party upheaval that may result from yesterday's reapportionment decision by a Federal Court in Manhattan.

The New York Telephone Company, which is controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, announced yesterday the appointment of William G. Sharwell as personnel vice president. Mr. Sharwell had been general manager for the Westechester area.
Four-year-olds are not the only ones learning from the pre-kindergarten programs operating in 34 of the city's public schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Johnson moved swiftly today to offset the reverse that he suffered yesterday when the House voted 204 to 177 to halt further sales of surplus food to the United Arab Republic.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. 27 -- The General Assembly recessed today until Monday to give delegates more time for consultations on the crisis over unpaid assessments for United Nations peace-keeping forces.

EUGENE ORMANDY, conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra last night at Carnegie Hall, found himself on congenial ground in a program of music by Viennese composers. For at least part the evening, the Philadelphia has never sounded better to these ears, namely, in Schubert's great C major symphony, the Seventh.

The Quinton Company, a consumer-products division of Merck Co., announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Harry J. Robinson as president and director of research. He had been director of the Merck Institute for Therapeutic Research.

GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- The United States switched tactics today in hopes of sparking the long and stubborn negotiations on international trade in farm products. Its principal adversary -- the European Common Market -- showed no immediate sign of budging.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Government charged today that the Dominican Republic was involved in military operations against Cuba. It also accused the United States and Puerto Rico of complicity in aggression plans against Cuba.
MONTREAL, Jan. 27 -- One of the oldest currently performed ballets for which the original choreography has been preserved almost intact is Auguste Bournonville's "La Sylphide," which dates from 1836.
PHOENIX, Ariz. -- The good people of Arizona can set a splendid table, and two exponents of the art are the William La Follettes, who live in the Paradise Valley region here.
PARIS, Jan. 27 -- Waistlines are loose and easy, white evening gloves are longer and jackets are down to the hips in one new collection here.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- The Soviet Union is apparently turning to the United States for a supply of soybeans obtained in the past from Communist China.
