The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- George Sauer Jr., an end whose pass-catching contributed to two of the University of Texas's nine victories last fall, said today he planned to sign with the New York Jets even though he had a year of eligibility left with the Longhorns.

CANADIAN pure-bred dog activity was described as resembling that in the United States, but on a smaller scale and with sharp differences, by two Canadians at the most recent meeting of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club at Luchow's Restaurant.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- The Soviet leadership is believed to have turned down an appeal by leaders of the Communist party of Britain for a postponement of the preparatory conference of Communist parties due to start here March 1.

The decision of the three-man Federal court still fails to put legislative reapportionment in this state on a satisfactory basis. Plan A, which tile court accepted, remains a cynical and offensive piece of political manipulation. The fight to overturn it must go on.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- After almost a week during which the press was unable to discover whether a Presidential disability arrangement between Mr. Johnson and Vice President Humphrey existed in any definite form, an answer was supplied today by the White House press secretary.
The 72-year-old owner of an East Harlem hardware store was stabbed to death yesterday in a robbery.
George F. Kennan, career diplomat, historian and commentator on the Communist world, was elected president of the National Institute of Arts and Letters yesterday.

A permanent memorial to Gen. Douglas MacArthur -- a plaza named for him -- was dedicated yesterday near the United Nations. His widow helped dedicate the new Gen. Douglas MacArthur Plaza, a block-long street between 48th and 49th Streets paralleling the East River Drive and in front of the new United Nations Plaza building.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- The General Assembly met in special session today to hear 27 speakers extol the life and work of Sir Winston Churchill, one of the founding fathers of the United Nations.

J. Raymond Jones, Manhattan Democratic leader, charged yesterday that the state Democratic chairman had offered a judgeship for Assemblyman Anthony J. Travia as part of a "package" to end the contest over the party's legislative leadership.

Arthur J: Olsen, reporting from Bonn in your Jan. 21 issue that the West German Government had authorized delivery of modern arms to Israel which were paid for by the German Government, explained that the Government considers it "has a moral obligation to contribute to the security of the Jewish state."
MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Old Hat came on fast in the final yards to win the $31,400 Columbiana Handicap today before 20,158 at Hialeah Park. Tosmah, the 3-5 favorite, finished sixth in the field of 10.
WASHINGTON. Jan. 27 -- A bill to pump nearly $1.1 billion in economic aid into the 11 - state Appalachia region cleared committee today and beaded for floor action in the Senate tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Administration appeared inclined today toward acceptance of the new military-dominated Government in Saigon as the only political course open to South Vietnam or the United States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- The United States intends to explore the moon, not just visit it, President Johnson said today.
The British pound dropped 7 points to $2.7919 in moderately active trading in foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Jan 27 -- Neshoba County Sheriff Lawrence A. Rainey and 16 other men pleaded not guilty today to indictments charging them with conspiracy in the murder of three civil rights workers last June 21.
Stock prices dipped slightly in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
A company well known in the space field but new to rocket manufacture will produce the rocket engine that is scheduled to land the first American astronauts on the moon.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Negro leaders made an unsuccessful attempt to see Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. today to protest the fatal shooting of a young Negro prisoner by a sheriff's deputy here last week.

THE distance between Hollywood and Acapulco is not very great, but while Darryl Zanuck presides over a huge movie enterprise his daughter Darrylin spends her days in a tiny dress shop in the Acapulco Hilton.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Sir Winston Churchill lies in state in the great hall at Westminster, the vast dank, ancient chamber where much of Britain's history has unfolded.

Soybean futures prices traded at or near the daily permissible limit of 10 cents a bushel yesterday before closing with gains of 1.5 to 7.5 cents. All but the two most distant deliveries set contract highs.

THE lonesomest man in the Olympic Village before the start of the Tokyo festival last October was an obscure distance runner by the name of Billy Mills. He never had won a major championship and his career was so lacking in distinction that only the other American distance runners were even aware of his existence.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 27 -- A college's petition to establish its main campus here has been rejected on the grounds that the school would disturb the peace and tranquility of the community, increase taxes and raise the crime rate.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 27 -- Research designed to produce an effective method of spotting drugged horses before they get to the post is being conducted at Roosevelt Raceway.

A strike that would have closed 90 per cent of the public parking garages in Manhattan and the Bronx was averted yesterday when union and management agreed "in the public interest" to submit all issues to binding arbitration.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 27-Anthony (the Frog) Frangipani was arrested late today on a 25-count indictment returned earlier by a grand jury investigating loan shark operations in Suffolk County.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A Brooklyn Democrat chided New York City school officials today for not insisting on a larger share of the Administration's proposed aid to schools in low-income areas.
The appointment of Raymond G. Fisher as vice president of the Central Metal division of the Continental Can Company was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration has asked for funds for three new hospitals and money to plan for four more buildings in the budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 27 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi entrusted the Premiership of Iran today to Amir Abbas Hoveida, Finance Minister in the Cabinet of Premier Hassan Ali Mansour who died last night.
Jesse C. Bogue, financial editor of United Press International, was elected president of the New York Financial Writers Association yesterday to serve for the year ending next Jan. 1.

MARLBORO, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Floyd Patterson, who is putting the finishing touches on his training for his 12-round bout with George Chuvalo of Toronto in Madison Square Garden Monday night, was declared "a superb physical specimen'' today by Dr. Edwin Campbell of the New York State Athletic Commission.

WILL Roosevelt Raceway's reindeer, bear and trained cd raccoons outdraw Oscar and Silvia, Island Garden's two 50-pound octopuses? Will the trout bite faster at the Raceway or at the Garden? And who will win the seven-day Caribbean cruise for two aboard a luxury liner?

TWO clubs, the Henry C. Parker and the Bronx Westchester Associates, are jointly sponsoring a tournament at the Sheraton-Atlantic Hotel this week-end. The schedule is: Tomorrow, Open Pairs; Sunday, Mixed Pairs.
A predominantly white organization that is supporting the current school boycotts charged yesterday that city and school officials were acting "irresponsibly" in the dispute over integration.
The Dow-Jones industrial average finally did it yesterday -- closed above 900 for the first time in history -- and the cheers sounded sedately in brokerage board rooms across the nation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A comprehensive program of medical care for the aged, financed mainly by Federal appropriations, was proposed today by leading House Republicans.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Jan. 26 -- Fox hunting on the North Shore of Nassau County is beset by the problems of suburban sprawl, roads and drainpipes.
CAIRO. Jan. 28 -- The Arab Boycott Office said today that it was blacklisting Sophia Loren after she defied Arab warnings against her participation in a film on the 1948 Palestine war.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 -- East Germany-West German talks on permits for West Berliners to cross the Berlin wall were interrupted today amid indications that the Communists might want to renege on an agreement providing for family visits at Easter and Whitsuntide.

Putnam's will publish on March 15 "Great Destiny," a 720-page book of autobiographical extracts from the writings and speeches of Winston Churchill. The experiences, adventures and achievements of the British leader over 60 years are described in quotations chosen and arranged by F.W. Heath.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Five electric companies unveiled today a $225-million plan to build a giant power generating plant on rich coal beds near Johnstown and extra-high-voltage lines to send electricity into several eastern states.

GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- President Johnson's proposal to reduce the Government's official gold requirements, set forth in his economic message today, has nearly unanimous endorsement among financial authorities in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Senator John J. Williams suggested in the Senate today that Representative Emanuel Celler, Brooklyn Democrat, "not muddy the waters with a lot of denials of something that has never been said."
Rollie Sheldon and Hal Reniff, two right-handers who won 11 games between them last season, returned their 1965 contracts yesterday to the New York Yankees.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Johnson asked Congress today to propose a constitutional amendment covering Presidential disability and the filling of a vacancy in the office of Vice President.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 28 -- Gen. Alberto Ruiz Novoa today blamed what he called "a palace intrigue" for his ouster yesterday as War Minister.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Johnson told Congress today that the nation could look forward to "another year of sustained and healthy economic growth."
City College will begin a $40 million expansion program next year that will enable it to accept more than 1,000 freshmen now turned away for lack of space.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 28 -- Miss Lorraine Hansberry, the playwright, who died in New York on Jan. 12, left part of her $115,000 estate to the civil rights cause.
LISBON, Jan. 28 -- The Government of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar charged today that the Communist party was trying to infiltrate the armed forces through university groups.
A special meeting of directors of the Pure Oil Company has been called for today to consider merger proposals that the company has received in the last several months.
DES MOLNES. Iowa, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- A power failure blocked out a 600-mile-wide belt in five Middle Western states in the winter's coldest weather.
Legal action aimed at forcing the City Council to elect a borough president of Manhattan was started in the State Supreme Court yesterday.
TRENTON, Jan. 28 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes denounced today the attempt by the Legislature to redraw Congressional districts in conjunction with legislative reapportionment.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Red Hay scored two goals and picked up two assists tonight to pace a 6-2 victory for the Chicago Black Hawks over the Boston Bruins. The Hawks thus moved back to within 2 points of Montreal, the National Hockey League leader.

President Johnson's economic report reflects the confidence that comes from four years of steady economic expansion. Evidently free of doubt that the present momentum can be sustained, Mr. Johnson predicts a continued rise in 1965 and he expresses the conviction that a recession can be permanently avoided.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- Sergel V. Mikhalkov, one of the Soviet Union's most successful writers, was elected today to head the important Moscow unit of the Soviet Writers Union.

In a Jan. 21 editorial entitled "The Kennedy Role" The Times has suggested to Robert F. Kennedy that he make clear that he is not, in fact, interested in the outcome of the Albany struggle and that he urge the party chairmen to allow a free vote on the matter.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange closed irregularly higher yesterday in the most active trading this month.
The shipping industry in New York appealed to President Johnson yesterday to intervene in the 18-day-old dock strike has choked off foreign trade in ports from Maine to Texas.
PROVIDENCE, R.I, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Bill Blair's two foul shots with 20 seconds remaining in the game gave unbeaten Providence a 77-76 basketball victory tonight over St. Bonaventure.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Veterans organizations denounced today plans to close 11 veterans hospitals and four rest homes, but defended the acting Veterans Administrator, William J. Driver.

TORONTO, Jan. 28 -- Rolf Hochhuth's controversial drama about Pope Pius XII, "The Deputy," is enjoying a successful run here.

ATLANTA, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Southeastern Conference one of the nation's best re cruiting grounds for professional football players, voted today to have nothing to do with the American Football League.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Fifteen million American children, one-fourth of all those in the nation, live in poverty, the President's Council of Economic Advisers estimated today.
An East Harlem factory that employs 800 persons threatened to move out of the city yesterday in the face of opposition by residents of the area to its expansion plans.

The Children's Health Service will receive the proceeds of a champagne breakfast in the Park Avenue Room of Saks Fifth Avenue Feb. 9. Mrs. Tucker Ridder will direct the function, at which spring fashions will be shown.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Physicians and drug manufacturers joined pharmacists today in supporting a bill to curb bootlegging of depressant and stimulant drugs.
The stock market cracked the 900 barrier yesterday in heavy trading that carried 649 issues ahead while 459 slipped.
Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York, trade association for 1,000 member concerns, announced yesterday the appointment of Paul L. Noble as president.

Your Jan. 13 editorial "Focus on Education" seems to imply that only the Roman Catholics -- among religious groups -- are interested in seeing some form of aid given to parochial schools on the part of the Federal Government.
A group of heatless Manhattan tenants discovered yesterday that while perhaps "you can't beat City Hall," you can dicker with it -- and get some heat in the bargain.

Directors of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation raised the quarterly dividend yesterday to 35 cents from 30 cents a share for its 73.500 stockholders. It is payable March 1 to stock of record Feb. 11.
A $1.5 million complex for the manufacture of chemicals will be built by I.C.I. (Organics), Inc., on a 2.5-acre plot in Bayonne, N.J., purchased from the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 28 -- Secretary of the Air Force Eugene M. Zuckert has convened a special committee to investigate the Air Force Academy, including its athletic programs and its cadet honor system.

William H. McKeon, Democratic State Chairman, said under oath yesterday that the charges of bribery leveled against him by Mayor Wagner in the legislative leadership fight were "a vicious, contemptible lie."
SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 28 (UPI) -- The battle over control of the Sunshine Mining Company goes into Federal District Court here tomorrow.
IN recognition of the growing teen-age market, Macy's will open a section of rooms Monday devoted specifically to the furnishings needs of young people.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Marc Bohan's spring collection for Christian Dior reminds the world what the French haute couture can achieve. It is the best work Bohan has ever done.
Music for the Restoration Theater, the first in a series of three concerts of music of the English baroque, will be given tonight at Hunter College Playhouse at 8:30. Robert Mandell will conduct.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 28 -- Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri spoke words of appeasement today to south Indian antagonists of Hindi, the newly established sole official language of India.
EDMONTON, Alberta, Jan. 28 -- Three United States jet fighter-bombers were dynamited at a servicing plant here early today after a security guard was shot and killed.
The Howard Park General Hospital went out of business yesterday and its new owner, the Interfaith Health Association, decided it would not sack to continue as a proprietary or profit-institution.
Thomas J. Deegan Jr., chairman of the executive committee of the World's Fair Corporation, has withdrawn his public relations company from the fair's operation.
PLEI DO LIM, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 -- Many American soldiers sent to South Vietnam as military advisers have found their greatest satisfaction in setting up a kind of peace corps in the villages.
The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System have chartered jet planes to fly video tapes here tomorrow of Sir Winston Churchill's funeral in London.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Following are excerpts from President Johnson's Economic Report to Congress:
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 28 -- Four judges issued orders today against a planned racial demonstration tomorrow at the County Courthouse.
PARIS, Jan. 28 -- Forty-eight hours of walkouts in the public services brought a strike today of gas and electric power workers that was little noticed.

Jim Bunning of the Philadelphia Phillies was named the winner of the Van Heusen Outstanding Achievement Award yesterday for the perfect game he pitched against the New York Mets in Shea Stadium last June.
Commercial artists of the city may be relieved to know that their profession is now fine art as far as the Zoning Law and its interpretation are concerned.

SELMA, Ala., Jan. 28 -- Negro leaders asked a Federal judge today to order Sheriff James G. Clark to show cause why he should not be held in contempt for arresting persons in the Dallas County voter-registration line.
MIAMI, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Buda, making her first start in three months, scored a nose victory over Sparkling Siren today in the six-furlong seventh race at Hialeah.

The Leon Gillis family and their homemade covered wagon came off the liner Statendam yesterday, full of quiet admiration for the Poles, the Czechs and the Russians. The six of them including 10-year-old George and the three girls, 13 to 18, lived in each of the three countries for seven "glorious, friendly and informative" weeks.
BUDAPEST, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Laszlo Papp, the European middleweight champion, confirmed today thatthe Hungarian Government had ordered him to quit fighting at the height of a brilliant boxing career.
Mayor Wagner appointed a blue-ribbon Citizens Task Force yesterday in an effort to settle the 25-day-old Welfare Department strike.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Johnson formally proposed to Congress today that part of the statutory requirement for a 25 per cent gold cover for the nation's money supply be repealed.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The Soviet Government has drafted far-reaching reforms of the agriculture-wage structure under which farmers would be paid for actual production rather than for work performed.
S.H. Kress Company, variety-chain subsidiary of Genesco, Inc., will shortly have a new managing director drawn from the ranks of the parent company.
The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest producer of aluminum, reported yesterday a 18.9 per cent increase in earnings last year on a 6.6 per cent gain in sales.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The Soviet press warned today that an influenza epidemic now in its third week in Leningrad threatened to spread to other parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Jan. 23 was above the volume in the corresponding week of 1964. Total freight rail carloadings during the same period registered a decrease.

Neil Simon's incoming comedy. "The Odd Couple," starring Art Carney and Walter Matthau, will charge the highest top price asked for any straight play thus far this season. Orchestra tickets from Monday through Saturday nights will be $7.50 at the Plymouth, where the play will open March 10.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Assemblyman Hyman Mintz of Sullivan County was admitted to Albany Medical Center Hospital early today and placed under the care of a cardiologist.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- A commemorative medal will be struck for Sir Winston Churchill, the first by the royal medalists since David Lloyd George was similarly honored in 1917.
Communist China has stepped up the pace of its foreign policy activities this month.

THE busiest weekend of the season for skiing -- both for spectators and participants -- is anticipated today because new powder has given the North Country its best mantle of snow since early last spring.
Robert Moses has dashed any lingering hopes that New York City may have entertained about getting back the $24 million it spent in preparing the site for the World's Fair.
The police have obtained about 200 tapes containing conversations of Richard Robles, the 22-year-old narcotics addict charged on Tuesday with the killing of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert in 1963.

A Center for Urban Education to help solve "big city" problems, such as integration and community relations, will be established in New York City under at charter granted yesterday by the State Board of Regents.
The Government can do much to restore a positive balance of trade for the domestic textile industry, Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, asserted last night.
Joe Foss, the commissioner of the American Football League, attacked yesterday colleges that put players under "undue pressure" to continue in school "merely for the sake of their athletic ability."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Administration declared today that Ambassador Maxwell D. Taylor had the "full confidence" of President Johnson and would remain at his post in South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had found penicillin contamination in some drugs. It is taking steps to prevent possible harmful reactions in persons allergie to the antibiotic.
HONG KONG, Jan. 28 -- Indonesia associated herself with Communist China on a wide range of political questions in a joint statement issued in Peking today.

As a member of the House of Representatives Veterans Affairs Committee and chairman of the House ad hoc committee on hospitals and facilities, I have been a leader in the fight to keep Castle Point Veterans Hospital, as well as other veterans' hospitals and facilities, from being closed.
Contracts for new construction continued to advance in December, the F.W. Dodge Company reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- Soviet-bloc nations announced today that they would keep Karoly Csatorday of Hungary in the race against Dr. German Zea of Colombia for chairman of the General Assembly's Political Committee.
The Ford Foundation warned yesterday that viewers and community institutions must contribute more generously to educational broadcasting if noncommercial television is to survive.
The Southern Pacific Company made more money for its stockholders last year than any railroad ever has, according to industry records.

The Uris Buildings Corporation has entered into partnerships to develop two sites in Atlanta, one a 140-acre tract for garden apartments and commercial facilities and the other a 40-acre garden-apartment group.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A bill aimed at curbing production of tobacco by abandoning acreage controls was presented to the Senate today.
Harry Karlin, the district's dean of college soccer coaches, was honored yesterday with members of the first all-Metropolitan intercollegiate soccer team.
The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday the biggest annual profit ever registered by any company in the United States.

Bayside Federal Savings and Loan Association, Queens, the only thrift institution in New York City to reduce its interest rate at the turn of the year, reported yesterday that its savings declined by less than $2 million in January.
BEERSHEBA, Israel -- Since Israel is cultivating patches and corners of the great Negev, the hard news concerns irrigation, winter wheat, afforestation, mining, road building desalination.

PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga., Jan. 28 -- This visitor to Georgia for quail shooting knows when he's associating with big leaguers. It's not hard to tell. The first couple of flushed bobwhites shows the quality of the company.

As the holder of a responsible office in the civil service of the constitutional administration of the Republic of Cyprus, I feel I must comment on your Jan. 22 editorial in which you say that "Turkish Cypriotes boycotted Parliament and the Government.

New corporate securities offered offered for cash in 1964 totaled a record $13.4 billion, according to a report published yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. The total, the commission noted, excluded investment company shares.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 28 -- Following two deaths this month attributed by the police to the unavailability of doctors, the Union County prosecutor has begun a survey to find out how often emergency patients are unable to get fast medical treatment.
Prices advanced on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, with steel and motor issues pacing the industrial list. Oil and gold shares also increased price.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- About 30 Federal officials, headed by Vice President Humphrey, promised today firm but not hasty enforcement of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation began operation yesterday of a Subscriber Data Processing Center in Garden City, L.I. Company officials said this was the first such center in the world.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 28 -- Surging oil revenues notwithstanding, the immediate problem facing the Government of Amir Abbas Hoveida, the new Premier, is financial survival.
The elevation of Nicholas Katzenbach to the post of Attorney General reflects credit on the President as well as on his appointee.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- President Johnson told leaders of the nation's rural electric power industry here today that "electric cooperatives must have the opportunity to share fully" in the new technologies of the power industry.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Respected, a daughter of Round Table, raced to a two-length victory today at Santa Anita in the $32,450 Santa Ynez Stakes for 3-year-old fillies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Representative John V. Lindsay has opened the door to the possibility of his running for mayor of New York -- or, at least, he has left it ajar.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Queen Elizabeth paid an extraordinary tribute tonight to the greatest commoner of the age.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- It is helpful if the Attorney General of the United States happens to be a legal scholar, but it is absolutely essential that he know where all the political booby traps are planted.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Jan. 28 -- The Board of Education has tentatively set March 30 for a referendum on a bond issue to build a new high school. It would be the second in less than four months. The voters defeated a $3.8 million issue for the same purpose last Dec. 17.

The decision of Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, to consider medical care for the aged without a time-wasting new round of public hearings is a major step forward.

THE sight of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne playing opposite each other was its own reward in last night's television revival of Emmet Lavery's. unashamedly sentimental drama, "The Magnificent Yankee."
United Air Lines, Inc., reported yesterday record 1964 earnings, revenues and volume of traffic. The airline also disclosed plans to sell about $66 million of convertible debentures.
Treasury bond prices continued to slip yesterday, extending a minor decline for the fourth consecutive day.

Bad luck and good luck figured in the Thanksgiving Day collision of the Israeli luxury liner Shalom and the Norwegian tanker Stolt Dagali according to testimony in a pretrial examination begun here yesterday in three law suits arising from the accident.
CHICAGO, Jan, 28 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. celebrated its 10th year in retailing today and the man who made it possible held one of his rare news conferences to tell about it.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 28 -- The 12 tribes of the Old Testament have been replaced in modern Zion by two loose and somewhat antagonistic communities. Therein lies the story of racial discrimination in Israel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Johnson ended months of speculation today by naming Nicholas deB. Katzenbach as Attorney General. Mr. Katzenbach had been Acting Attorney General since last September, when Robert F. Kennedy resigned to run for the Senate from New York.

ARTHUR ALLYN, the owner of the Chicago White Sox, is a slightly different kind of maverick from Charlie Finley, the proprietor of the Kansas City Athletics. Allyn talks a lot more sense. He already has shown enough imagination and independence to be rather nettlesome to the two men who run the baseball business, Walter O'Malley of the Dodgers and Del Webb of the Yankees.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Fred (Butch) Baird, Jack McGowan, George Archer, Jack Montgomery and Gardner Dickinson shared the first-load lead today in the $57,500 Lucky International golf tournament.

Box holders have been announced for the first performance of the new production of Richard Strauss's "Salome" at the Metropolitan Opera House Wednesday. The Metropolitan Opera Guild is sponsoring the event for the benefit of the Production Fund of the Metropolitan Opera Association.
Business loans by 14 leading New York City banks have risen by $1.46 billion since mid-1964, more than double the advance of $629 million in the period a year ago.

A friendly audience, a good many of whom knew one another personally, went to the first concert last night in a series of three the Contemporary Music Society is putting on in the small auditorium of the Guggenheim Museum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate passed today a new program for combating water pollution throughout the nation. The vote was 68 to 8.

James Jones, author of "From Here to Eternity" and other best-selling novels, has contracted with Delacorte Press to write several books for a guaranteed price which is estimated in publishing circles to be between $700,000 and $1,000,000. Dell Publishing Company, a paperbach concern, owns Delacorte.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan 28 -- The president of the defunct San Francisco National Bank was reported to have heavy commitments to pay losses at gambling casinos in Las Vegas.
Federal prisoners in the Hudson County Jail in Jersey City enjoyed most of the comforts of home -- if they paid, according to evidence before a Federal grand jury here.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The United States team made some changes today in its line-up for the world four-man bobsled championship this weekend but still failed to catch Vic Emery of Canada.
The Dayton, Ohio, City School District sold $15.3 million of bonds yesterday to an underwriting syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Lehman Brothers and Blyth Co., Inc.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Jan. 28 -- The green barn is so massive that Claudia Howe seems to be much tinier than her 5 feet 2 inches. It looks more like an airplane hangar and Claudia becomes dwarfed by this old wooden building as she tends her two horses at Ben White Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The President's Council of Economic Advisers believes that more attention should be paid to the recent pattern of "conglomerate" mergers. In which a company in one product line takes over another in a wholly different area.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Emanuel R. Piore to the new post of vice president and chief scientist.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Following is the text of President Johnson's message to Congress requesting a constitutional amendment to deal with problems related to Presidential disability and incapacity:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- About 57,000 United States servicemen have served in South Vietnam in three years of major United States involvement there, the Pentagon reported today. More than 360 have died, and more than 1,550 have been wounded.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Great Lakes shipmasters adopted a resolution today opposing any changes in the pilot, rules on the Great Lakes.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- Pennsylvania publishers and editors announced today the formation of a Freedom of Information Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Federal budget and the Economic Message which President Johnson has submitted to Congress are sublimations of two philosophies of government, each entwined with the other. In combination they are a full Executive commitment to the concept of the Welfare State and the "New Economics."

City College is about to go from Collegiate Gothic to Collegiate Concrete in a modern master plan for its uptown campus that is a sample demonstration of some of the most progressive principles of today's architecture and design.
The British pound rose sharply in fairly active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Sterling for delivery today closed at $2.7928, up 9 points from Wednesday's final quotation.
CAPE KENNEDY, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- A construction workers' walkout, the fifth in less than a year, halted key work at the space center here today.
CAIRO, Jan. 28 -- The official state visit of East Germany's President, Walter Ulbricht, to Cairo Feb. 26 will put the United Arab Republic's diplomatic ties with West Germany to a severe test.

A steel girder 60 feet long, weighing 35 tons and dwarfing the workmen who clambered over it was swung delicately into place atop a pair of slender columns at a construction site just off Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- House hearing on the Administration bill on aid to education turned into a kind of ecumenical chorale today as Roman Catholic and Protestant spokesmen joined in praise of the measure.

BONN. Jan. 28 -- Every January an independent opinion research agency puts this question to a cross-section of German adults: What is the most important problem that West Germany should be dealing with today?
The inevitable profit taking that follows a sharp price rise left soybean futures irregular at the close yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- An increase in earnings of Swift Co. is expected this fiscal year despite a dip in the first two months, stockholders were told at the annual meeting today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union warned today that its navy was carefully monitoring the movement of United States Polaris submarines and was capable of destroying them with nuclear missiles.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Government has been named in five suits totaling $1,725,000 as the result of a Slick Airways crash two years ago that killed four men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The uncertain fate awaiting the Administration's $3.4 billion foreign aid request was further complicated today by a demand of Senator Wayne Morse that Congress overhaul the policy of that program as well as the Food for Peace plan.
The program presented at Kaufmann Concert Hall last night by the Jose Molina Bailes Espanoles showed what can happen to Spanish dance when it strays too far into show business.

LATROBE, Pa., Jan. 28 -- The birth control problem will remain a divisive factor in Roman Catholic-Jewish relations for some time to come despite a high degree of accord in other areas such as racial justice, religious liberty and civic morality, according to a prominent Catholic sociologist.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 28 -- Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo, heading a 20-man negotiating team, arrived here from Leopoldville today to straighten out his country's financial problems with Belgium.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 28 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department, in a move to make United States wheat competitive in the overseas market, knocked 10 cents off the world price of hard red winter wheat today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Alan S. Boyd, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, warned the world's airlines to lower international fares or the sovereign governments of the world would do it for them.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 - The Labor Department announced today that the median wage increase provided by all major wage settlements last year was 3.2 per cent, or about 9 cents an hour.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The President's Council of Economic Advisers warned today that absorbtion of teen-agers into high productivity jobs was the greatest test facing the nation's general economic and manpower politics.
Sam Perry, the fastest indoor sprinter in the Bronx, has become the fastest indoor sprinter in competition anywhere.

Zino Francescatti has probably played the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto more times than he would care to remember, but last night with the New York Philharmonic he played it with such freshness of spirit and persuasiveness that it was a revelation.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Billie Jean Moffitt of Long Beach, Calif., moved into the singles semi-finals of the Australian tennis championships at Kooyong today, but her Federation Cup teammate, Mrs. Carole Caldwell Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, lost her quarter-final match.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Sandra Post of Ontario and Margaret Jones of Covington, Ky., upset a team of tournament golfers today in the opening round of the international four-ball tournament.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported yesterday in a preliminary statement that net income last year fell to $471 million, or $10.03 a share of common stock, from $472 million, or $10.05 a share, the year before.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The state accused the city of Troy today of turning the Hudson River near here into a cesspool.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday Jan. 29 -- A struggle for political power began yesterday between Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh, the South Vietnamese military commander, and Thich Tri Quang, the activist Buddhist leader.
The discothtque, the system by which dance music is provided in nightclubs through elaborate record players, has made an appearance at the Stork Club and, from all indications, is there to stay.
Standing-room tickets will go on sale today for Monday's heavyweight fight at Madison Square Garden between Floyd Patterson, the former world champion, and George Chuvalo of Canada.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- President Johnson named today a 10-man panel to make recommendations to him on Government civilian and military pay.
THE fifth and last of the Beethoven concerts conducted in Carnegie Hall by Herbert von Karajan, with the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, came to its climax last night with the Ninth Symphony.
The builders of machine tools -- machines used to make machinery that makes many types of products -- set a variety of records in 1964.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- President Johnson picked 14 persons from labor, industry, education and other fields today to become a National Advisory Council in the anti-poverty program.
The tradition of outdoor symphony concerts at Lewisohn Stadium, which have been held every summer since 1918, may end in 1967 as a result of City College's expansion program.
TRENTON, Jan. 28 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes and officials of the State Highway Authority unveiled plans today for a $1,650,000 cultural center.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Frank Lane said today he would like to purchase the Boston Red Sox or "any major league franchise.''

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Vice President Humphrey complained here this week that there were more fight promoters around Washington than around Madison Square Garden. He observed sadly that somebody was always trying to promote a fight between the White House and Congress or between other elements in the Government, and he recommended instead that everybody join in the one big happy consensus for the good of the country.

James Ruderman and Nicholas Farkas, consulting engineers specializing in building design, will conduct a panel discussion on "Structural Systems for High-Rise Buildings," before the structures group of the Metropolitan section of the American Society of Civil Engineers at the United Engineering Center, 345 East 47th Street. The meeting will be held Wednesday at 7:15 P.M.

EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 28 (UPI) -- A deputy United States marshal and a sheriff took Billie Sol Estes today from the El Paso County Jail to Dallas-600 miles to the east -- by automobile for a hearing on charges of filing false financial reports.

ALTHOUGH "A View From the Bridge" has not the size of tragedy that Arthur Miller probably intended it to have, it remains a play of fiery, primitive passions. WASHINGTON, Jan 28 (AP) -- Living costs edged up one-tenth of 1 per cent in December, 'rounding out a year of what the Labor Department described today as a "moderate advance" in prices.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 28 -- New Jersey hopes to acquire at least 32,000 acres this year under its Green Acres program and add nearly $10 million in Federal grants to the $80 million state and local project fund.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- A special bar committee investigating the Oklahoma Supreme Court reported today that it had "discovered collateral evidence" indicating "professional laxity and perhaps professional misconduct."

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Iowa upset the University of California, Los Angeles, 87 -- 82, tonight and Loyola stunned Wichita, 93 -- 92, in overtime in a Chicago Stadium college basketball double-header.
A black-headed grosbeak, a Western species rarely seen in the East, has been reported feeding the past two days in Elberon, N.J., near Asbury Park.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The threatened loss of 700 jobs has persuaded union rubber workers to approve a 25-cent hourly wage cut if the United States Rubber Company agrees to stay here for at least five years.

TRENTON, Jan. 29 -- The Federal Office of Education was asked today to allocate $5,942,738 to eight private colleges and one publicly supported college in New Jersey under the Higher Education Facilities Act of 1964.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A bill intended to encourage the orderly reduction of the Government's multibillion dollar defense stockpiles advanced a step in the Senate today.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- France's highest military authority, Gen. Charles Ailleret, chief of staff of the armed forces, has declared that an alliance cannot always "meet the defense needs of the countries composing it." S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday that the authority would spend $4,775,000 to accommodate the expansion of one of its major clients.
MONTREAL, Jan. 29 -- The Canadian pulp and paper industry, the largest single economic force in this country, has embarked on an unusual three-year $800-million expansion program.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange continued yesterday to respond to favorable corporate news and advanced in active trading.

ROME, Jan. 29 -- The Italian Cabinet gave its initial approval today to a five-year economic plan aimed at creating a "modern, dynamic democratic state."

CAIRO, Jan. 29 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser, who just a month ago was telling the United States to "jump in the lake" with its economic assistance, is following a policy of restraint now that the United States Congress is considering cutting off aid to the United Arab Republic.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today a $3.48 billion budget that included a 2 per cent statewide sales tax.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 29 (AP) -- The nearest thing to a riot by fans developed at Bowie Race Course today after the track veterinarian ordered Caterpillar scratched from the sixth race about two minutes before post time.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Following is the timetable for the order of service at the funeral of Sir Winston Churchill. The time is five hours later than New York time.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- The world champion, Vic Emory, and his Canadian teammates were favored today to capture the world four-man bobsled championship, which starts tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- In its battle against the synthetic fiber makers, the cotton industry has turned to the inventor. The National Cotton Council received a patent this week for a special kind of trouser cuff.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Lawrence F. O'Brien, a top aide of President Kennedy and now President Johnson's legislative liaison man, said tonight that some friends have urged him to consider running for office in his home state of Massachusetts.

Milton C. Mumford, chairman and president of the Lever Brothers Company, and John Robert Fluor, president of the Fluor Corporation, Ltd., were elected yesterday to the board of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation. F.O. Boylon and Otis D. Hallin, senior vice presidents of the San Francisco manufacturer of paper products, also were named directors.
Mrs. Geneva Fox, a short, motherly woman, briskly herded four children across an inter-racial picket line yesterday as the school boycott was extended to Junior High School 99, in East Harlem.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Billie Jean Moffitt of Long Beach, Calif., and Robyn Ebbern of Australia turned in the biggest upset of the Australian tennis championship today by eliminating second-seeded Maria Bueno of Brazil and Norma Baylon of Argentina, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, in the semi-finals of the women's doubles.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Reynaldo Garza today sentenced Paul Amos Sandblom, a bankrupt financier, to 15 years in prison on 24 counts of defrauding investors in get-rich-quick schemes.
The stock market was like a car in deep snow yesterday. It spun its wheels furiously, but advanced very little.

OCONOMOWOC, Wis., Jan. 29 (UPI) -- Dick Wurster and Jeanne Omelenchuk ignored 10-below-zero temperatures today to take opening-round leads in the three-day North American Olympic speed-skating championships.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller proved once again today that the state is just like an average family -- but on a far grander scale. He asked the Legislature for $58.7 million with which to make ends meet.
A five-alarm fire raced through six three-story buildings in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn last night forcing the evacuation of 15 families.

I recently read with dismay a letter from George H. Hobson Jr., protesting what he terms an "encroachment upon his privacy." This refers to his definition of piped-in music as a travesty on the idea of entertainment -- causing, in his words, a "deadening of our senses and dulling our minds."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The first strong opposition to the Administration's $1.25 billion school-aid bill touched off a party dispute at a House hearing today.

Franco Corelli sang his first Don Alvaro in Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" in his season's debut with the Metropolitan Opera last night. The tenor was his usual big, handsome self, and he sang with his usual big, handsome voice, bringing down the house after his Act II aria "O tu che in seno agli angeli."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Standing Committee of Correspondents unanimously elected as its chairman today Robert N. Branson of Federated Publications, with newspapers in Michigan, Indiana and Idaho.

GENEVA, Jan. 29 -- Business and labor officials of eight West European countries -- including Britain -- insisted today that the British Government start cutting its three-month -old tax surcharge on imports "within a matter of weeks." Representatives of two nations even suggested possible retaliation.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29 -- The pinnacle of power on which stands Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran is lonelier today than ever before.

Sam Perry, the world's new fastest human indoors, isn't even sure he will be around for the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Maritime Administration rejected today a request from the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company for a 90-day extension on its application for Government insurance on the construction of three nuclear-powered ships.
A jet fighter with a specially designed wing has been flying in and out of a California air base trailing scientifically important little tornadoes.

TORONTO, Jan. 29 -- Bill Crothers, who seems to run every night and win, ran again tonight and won. His 600-yard victory in the Telegram-Maple Leaf Games was especially happy because he lives in the Toronto suburbs and everyone in Maple Leaf Gardens seemed to be rooting for him.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- If there is anything to be termed a traditional Arizona restaurant menu, it consists of a shrimp cocktail and a choice of three steaks -- New York cut, top sirloin or filet mignon; a choice of broiled chicken, grilled lamb chops and roast prime ribs of beef; an offering of lobster tails, and the dish that is currently "in," a combination plate of broiled lobster tails and filet mignon.
PARIS, Jan. 29 -- President de Gaulle's Government today forbade the use of France's greatest military shrine for Gen. Maxime Weygand's funeral.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 29 -- A former Minister of Agriculture and the leader of an opposition party have been arrested and accused of having plotted to establish an Indonesian-sponsored Malaysian Government in exile.

City College looked normal yesterday. Its Gothic walls were gloomy and the winds were icier than in most parts of the city. Students, huddled in the cafeteria, were all business as they plotted courses for the new semester.

If it is dour and glowering the ground hog will not see his shadow and winter's worst will be over.

Phillips, a recognized authority for a generation, admitted privately on many occasions that slavery was a barbaric institution, but refused to use certain valuable materials in his researches and generally omitted reference to the darker shadows of the institution in his writings.

Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons announced yesterday plans for a $2 million renovation and expansion to modernize its teaching laboratories and lecture rooms by the summer of 1966. The school may also increase its enrollment slightly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A variety of post-inaugural ailments put a few Senators and House members in Government hospitals, along with President Johnson, but none of them enjoyed Mr. Johnson's rate of $1.09 a day.
ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller went on television today to explain his $3,488,000,000 budget in terms familiar to people whose annual budgets are a lot closer to $3,488.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 -- Communist East Germany expects a record Western participation at its Jubilee Industrial Fair at Leipzig this year. Some 9,000 exhibitors from 70 countries are to show their goods from Feb. 28 to March 9.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Administration secretly gave permission to the West German Government for the recent transfer of a number of American-made tanks to Israel, officials disclosed today.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Hundreds of thousands who watched Sir Winston Churchill's funeral today said farewell to their own bright and desperate yesterdays.

Stores have completed the bulk of their early spring buying, resident buying offices report. Much of the spring merchandise sold to date has been for cruise-wear departments. Orders for such goods will increase again later this year.

LEADING executives of the South American Travel Organization have embarked on a 16-city tour of the United States in order to tell more than 2,500 travel agents that recently lowered air fares, improved and new hotel facilities and a general friendliness by the natives are making South America the next "in" place to visit.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 30 -- More than $40 million has been set aside in Governor Rockefeller's new budget to improve the facilities of the Long Island State Park Commission.

Less than a century ago a Marie Curie or a Rutherford, gifted with insight and genius, could conduct comparatively simple experiments alone and make major discoveries. Today the "easy" things have largely been done. If one wishes to look more penetratingly into the vastness above, into the earthshaking mysteries below or into the strange world of the atom, he must form a team and obtain equipment that often is extraordinarily expensive.
ROME, Jan. 30 -- Pope Paul VI renewed today his appeal for Roman Catholic unity and hinted that the Ecumenical Council would deal with Communism in its fourth and last session next fall.

JAMES LEIGH, a 35-year-old English teacher at San Francisco State College, apparently has endured hell. His first novel, "What Can You Do?" testifies to the ultimate anguish of those who instruct the young. Like the radiologist whose experiments with X-rays finally give him cancer, Mr. Leigh has contracted the blight of a special kind of adolescence.

The Telemann Society crossed 57th Street last night to give a program of Telemann's music at Judson Hall. The society consists roughly of Theodora and Richard Schulze, Kenneth Weaver and John Dennison, and its office is a room in the Carnegie Hall building.
The Socony Mobil Oil Company, which operates more than 90 tankers, will begin today to make a major contribution toward less oil pollution.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Cuba was reported today to be striving for a closer alignment with Asian countries in Communist China's sphere of influence.
Welfare Department workers voted last night to end their 28-day-old walkout and to return to work today.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- A Gurkha patrol and Indonesian troops waged a fierce battle yesterday in the defense jungle area of Sarawak, a military spokesman said today.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen agreed today to stop fighting the repeal of state laws that require full train crews.
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Andre Courreges -- the controversial couturier who put women into pants suits, white hoots and above-the-knee dresses -- has not softened any of his bold, basic ideas.

I congratulate you on publishing the much needed popular discussion on modern mathematics and its trend [Times Jan. 25]. The article is informative and raises certain questions in one's mind; but a few additional remarks may be helpful.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain, held in check in the first half, scored 17 points in the third period today to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 127-122 victory over the Cincinnati Royals in a National Basketball Association game.
Bachs Co., Inc., a leading member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, begins business today as a corporation after operating as a partnership for the last 86 years.
LUDLOW, Vt., Jan. 31 -- The Amateur Ski Club of New York won the 27th Metropolitan New York Ski Council's interclub championship today in a two-day competition at Okemo Mountain.
Edward Bowes of the New York Athletic Club won a 5.31-mile Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union road race, walked a quarter of a mile and won an 8.04-mile Met A.A.U. race yesterday in the West Bronx.

The Johnson Administration's economic policy-makers can claim a pretty sure touch in domestic affairs, but they appear hesitant and fumbling in their efforts to reduce the deficit in the nation's transactions with the rest of the world. In his new economic report, President Johnson promised an improvement in the nation's international payments, which poses a test for the policy-makers -- and for the domestic economy.
HAMPTON, Va. -- The Tactical Air Command, until five years ago the stepchild of the services, has expanded to a force of about 136,000 men and 1,800 aircraft.
PARIS, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Ozo, the French trotting mare owned by Roger Massue, won today the $100,000 Grand Prix d'Amerique, Europe's top harness race.

MANILA, Monday, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- A United States airman, Larry D. Cole of Marshall, Mich., will stand trial by general court martial for the slaying of a Philippine youth, Clark Air Base authorities announced today.
YONKERS, Jan. 31 -- More than 300 members of Gamblers Anonymous and their spouses left the Westchester Town House here this afternoon after a two-day conference on their problems.
Your Jan. 12 editorial advocating an anti-smoking campaign should be heeded by members of Congress.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has long held that his job is more than merely investigating and prosecuting criminals, that it also entails an obligation to protect the innocent.
Msgr. Francis X. Duffy emphasized the character and effect of the sacrament of confirmation at the 10 A.M. solemn mass yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
VIENTIANE, Monday, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- A group of army officers seized a radio station here last night and announced that they had staged a coup d'etat.

The president of the metropolitan area Blue Cross said yesterday that if Governor Rockefeller's plan to forestall rate increases was put into effect, Blue Cross would have to "reduce benefits or go out of business" by Dec. 31, 1966.
The leader of 12,000 licensed ship engineers charged yesterday that the Maritime Administration was "dedicated to mischief designed simply to engage management and labor in useless conflict."
The mountain had a peak, after all.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31 -- The campaign to elect half of the Chamber of Deputies is to open this week in an oppressive, humid summer heat.

WINNER of the $10,000 Harper Prize for 1965, "P.S. Wilkinson" is the story of a Yale man, Phillip Sadler Wilkinson, who enters the Army, lands in Korea, is released, fights a number of civilian battles and is called back into service during the Berlin crisis.

The appointment of Bruce A. Gimbel as chairman of the $2 million drive of the New York City division of the American Cancer Society .was announced yesterday. Mr. Gimbel is President of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. The campaign, which will run through the year, will help fight cancer through education, service for patients and research.

MEGEVE, France, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Jean-Claude Killy of France solidified today his reputation as the most consistent of Europe's Alpine skiers by winning the special slalom and combined in the Emile Allais Cup.

THE hopes of the Columbia Broadcasting System to compete with the National Broadcasting Company's "Bonanza'' appear no brighter today than before. The latest entrant in the Sunday evening period at 9 o'clock, entitled "For the People," started as an old-fashioned and ridiculous series on the adventures of an assistant district attorney.
BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- "It was an interesting experience," said Bill Crothers, "but I'm looking forward to resting today."
The nation's economy is off to a strong start in 1965 with expectations for a good year ahead. That is the finding of the latest monthly survey by the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A 10-year-old girl severely burned in the Indianapolis Coliseum explosion of 1963 is this year's National Easter Seal Child of the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults.
Forty-five national Negro leaders declared yesterday that their civil rights strategy for 1965 would emphasize voter registration and political action.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Captain Edward Molyneux straightened his beige tie and then walked calmly into a cream-colored salon today to watch the first collection he has done in 14 years.

THE considerable increase in complaints received this year by the Consumer Fraud and Protection Bureau of the New York State Department of Law may be due more to increased public awareness than to an actual increase in fraudulent practices, according to Assistant Attorney General Barnett Levy, head of the bureau.

An official of the United States Chamber of Commerce charged yesterday that the taxpayer's right to decide on new public works projects was being diluted by increased Federal subsidies to state and local governments.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Kentucky's sparkling defense led the Wildcats to a 96-64 victory over the Georgia Bulldogs tonight at Memorial Coliseum.

The Administration's compromise plan to eliminate the gold backing for Federal Reserve deposits while preserving it for Federal Reserve currency is a halfway measure that makes little sense. The Administration evidently thinks that it can relax some of the restraints imposed by gold without losing the support of those who regard gold as the true measure of wealth and the ultimate enforcer of discipline; but it is simply bowing to the Goldfinger syndrome.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court overturned today the conviction of two Negroes on a charge of trespass for refusing to leave the entrance of the Plantation Restaurant, Enfield, N.C., in a 1963 racial demonstration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The United States Supreme Court upheld today a ruling by a three-judge Federal District Court requiring New York State to elect a new Legislature this fall.

LAKE PROVIDENCE, La., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Four East Carroll Parish officers have been arrested on charges of beating Negro prisoners, records filed in the Federal district court at Shreveport showed today.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- New expressions of confidence in Britain's short-term economic future and a pledge that her hotly controversial tariff surcharge soon would be reduced were made tonight at a banquet for overseas bankers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Fred Hutchinson, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds who died of cancer after the 1964 season, was named tonight as the nation's most courageous athlete of 1964 by the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 1 -A Valentine Polo Ball is being planned here for Saturday, Feb. 13. to help build a community hospital. Zoning of the site has been approved by the city commission, and groundbreaking ceremonies are scheduled for the spring.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin's trip to Hanoi appeared imminent tonight as the Soviet press published new charges of United States "violation" of North Vietnam territory.
The Red Cross here collected 8,771 pints of blood last month. This compared with 8,648 pints last December and 8,614 pints in January, 1954.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- George (Birdie) Tebbetts, the manager of the Cleveland Indians who suffered a heart attack 10 months ago, received the American Heart Association's Heart of the Year Award today.
The United States' balance of payments remained the chief concern of the bond market yesterday.

The assessed value of taxable real estate in New York City has risen to a record high of $31,377,694,465, according to a tentative estimate of property assessments for the fiscal year 1965-66. This is an increase of 5.5 per cent over the current fiscal year's total of $29,752,740,109.
Sam Spiegel, one of the film industry's few remaining big-time producers, called a big-league press conference yesterday to tell the world that he is back in business.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- A strike by service and maintenance employes at Lawrence Hospital here has had repercussions in at least one doctor-patient relationship.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- A Republican assemblyman pitched a tent on the snow-covered lawn of the State Capitol this morning and said it was his office.

On the heels of record earnings, directors of the General Motors Corporation voted yesterday to raise the dividend on its common stock to 75 cents a share from 65 cents a share paid in recent quarters.

David M. Baldwin, president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, real estate management and brokerage concern, will address the New Jersey chapter of the Institute of Real Estate Management on Thursday. The meeting, which will begin at 6 P.M., will be held at 744 Broad Street Club in Newark.

Net earnings of the Phillips Petroleum Company last year rose to a record of $115,018,000, or $3.44 a share, the company reported yesterday. This compared with net income of $113,900,000, or $3.40 a share in 1963.
Financial interests from Los Angeles and San Francisco are expected to be unsuccessful again in their bid to join the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court accepted today a second appeal involving the constitutionality of a 1962 law requiring the Post Office Department to destroy Communist propaganda mail from abroad unless an addressee requests delivery.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Murray C. Fuerst, a lawyer who has worked for this city for the last 28 years, became the new City Manager today with the endorsement of most political leaders, but with the criticism of a few civic groups.

MIAMI -- When Henry M. Flagler was developing Palm Beach in 1894, he said it was for his elegant friends, and that West Palm Beach across Lake Worth was for their servants. Two years later, he ran his railroad south, and Miami was incorporated without either his blessing or his curse.
The American Tobacco Company registered the biggest sales and earnings in its 60-year history in 1964, lifted by a record fourth-quarter.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Giants traded Billy O'Dell, left-handed pitcher, to the Milwaukee Braves today for Ed Bailey, a left-handed-hitting catcher.

The election of Edward J. Maude as president of the Union Square Savings Bank was announced yesterday. Mr. Maude, former treasurer of the Greenwich Savings Bank, apparently is first in line to succeed Randolph H. Brownell, who has moved up to the chairmanship after 19 years as president.

BOWIE Md., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Three winners in the four twin-double races at Bowie Race Course today were enough for three ticket holders to take home $20,461.20 apiece as no one called the turn on Tam Lea's victory in the seventh race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Two members of President Johnson's Cabinet were confined to bed today with respiratory ailments. Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara had a moderate case of viral pneumonia and Secretary of State Dean Rusk had a cold.
SEATTLE, Feb. 1 -- Stuart Vaughan has been signed for another two years as artistic director of the Seattle Repertory Theater.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Sandy Wilson's new musical, "Divorce Me, Darting," opened at the Globe Theater this evening after being postponed from last Thursday out of respect for Sir Winston Churchill.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 1 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation will be able to continue close surveillance of Momo Salvatore (Sam) Giancana, reputed head of the Chicago underworld, as a result of a Supreme Court action today.
The Board of Estimate received from Mayor Wagner yesterday his $650,981,004 capital budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Circuit Judge O.H. Barnett told the Neshoba County grand jury today that it could do nothing about the slaying of three civil rights workers until the Justice Department turned over its evidence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A Senate subcommittee paved the way today for a constitutional amendment providing for continuity of Federal executive power in event of Presidential disability and for filling the office of Vice President when ever a vacancy occurs.
Local housing authorities plan to sell $117,480,000 of bonds on March 3, the Public Housing Administration announced yesterday.

Melina Mercouri, the Greek actress who gained prominence here in the motion picture "Never on Sunday," will be the guide for an hour-long filmed tour of Greece to be televised in color by the American Broadcasting Company at 9 P.M. on May 3.
Profit taking reduced early gains yesterday on the London Stock Exchange and the list was steady at the close.
WARSAW, Feb. 1 -- A Communist youth newspaper accused Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, today of "primitive demagoguery."
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Feb. 1 -- The steamy air of Kuala Lumpur was shattered tonight by wave after wave of small explosions.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- The Rockland County Sewer Commission tonight authorized its chairman. Supervisor Paul F. Mundt of Clarkstown, to sign a contract for the controversial county trunk-sewer system.

President Johnson urged long-shore leaders yesterday to ease the effects of the 22-day strike that has tied up shipping from Maine to Texas by sending their men back to work at some ports where settlements had been reached.
PARIS, Feb. 1-- Mayor Gaston Defferre of Marseilles, Socialist candidate for the French Presidency, was in political trouble in his hometown today after the Communists won over some of his followers.

Judges for the National Book Awards have named leading contenders for the annual $1,000 prizes. Richard Gilman, R.W.B. Lewis and Bernard Malamud listed the following fiction works: "The Rector of Justin," by Louis Auchincloss; "Herzog," by Saul Bellow; "Second Skin," by John Hawkes; "The Martyred," by Richard E. Kim; "To an Early Grave," by Wallace Markfield; "The Defense," by Vladimir Nabokov, and "Short Friday," by Isaac Bashevis Singer.
An uncompleted seven-story motel on Ditmars Boulevard and 22d Road in Queens has been sold to the Holiday Inns of America for $500,000.

A damage suit opened in Brooklyn Federal court yesterday that could produce the first court ruling on the issue of the Government's liability in connection with the airliner collision here four years ago.

THEY moved to the Grand Concourse from East Harlem or the side streets in the Bronx. The avenue was wide and spacious and lined with trees, and for many it was a reminder of the boulevards and promenades of Europe, from where they immigrated.
WOODBURY, L.I., Feb. 1 -- The Waldemar Medical Research Foundation indicated today that it would have to cease operations in three months if more funds were not obtained.
WASHINGTON Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The Senate rejected today a move to postpone for 30 days a vote on the nomination of William J. Driver as Veterans Administrator. It agreed to vote tomorrow.
At one of the most crowded swearing-in ceremonies held at City Hall in recent years, Mayor Wagner administered the oath of office yesterday to John V. Connorton as Deputy Mayor-City Administrator.
TOKYO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Nankai Hawks succeeded today in getting Masanori Murakami to sign a contract to pitch for the Japanese team during the 1965 season.
BONN, Feb. 1 -- A young West German university student was recently asked to describe the changes the Americans had brought to her country.

CAIRO, Feb. 1 -- Ambassador Lucius D. Battle met with President' Nasser tonight to outline the Adminisration's efforts to continue American food shipments to Egypt and to discuss the future of the aid program.

Harry Gallatin, coach of the New York Knickerbockers, and Red Auerbach, coach of the Boston Celtics insulted one another and one another's teams yesterday as a feud between the two continued. The verbal battle came less than 24 hours after the coaches nearly came to blows during a National Basketball Association game at the Boston Garden Sunday night.
The establishment of a federation of all licensed merchant marine officers on United States-flag ships to resolve problems common to all six officer unions was proposed here yesterday.

In baseball, as on Broadway, the show must go on. Because major league baseball teams fly so much, and planes sometimes crash, the American League has its 11-year-old Disaster Plan and the National League, as of yesterday, its Emergency Team Replacement Plan.
Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol agreed yesterday to release 19 jailed leaders of the Welfare Department strike as more than 5,000 workers ended their 28-day walkout and returned to work.
An Iranian exile was awarded $104,316 yesterday for fire damage to his Fifth Avenue apartment, its furnishings and his clothing which included 392 suits.
United States steel production rose 1.1 per cent in the week ended Saturday to the highest weekly level in five years.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, announced today the appointment of Prof. Robert L. Geddes as dean of the School of Architecture, a new position.
The school boycott was extended yesterday to Junior High School 136, an all-girls school in Harlem.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., and American Airlines, Inc., each announced yeterday the election of a new vice president.

Prices of cocoa for future delivery declined the daily limit of 1 cent a pound at the close of trading yesterday. All deliveries closed at contract lows. Cash quotations tumbled 1.25 cents on major grades.
Francis E. Rivers, former New York City Civil Court judge, has been elected president of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., the fund's board of directors announced yesterday.
Despite stay-at-home weather and ice-and-snow-covered sidewalks, more than 150 lower-Manhattan residents turned out last night for the city's first community hearing on a proposed capital budget.
The loudest noise this year in the foreign-car market may not be the roar of the engines but the sound of advertising money being plunked down.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The History Makers have lost no time in acclaiming Sir Winston Churchill "The Mall of the Century." For those of us who are as yet only in the summer of life, it is disheartening to see the award passed out at a time when the century still has nearly 35 years to run.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 1 -- Charlie Boylan's jump shot with three seconds left gave Catholic University a 57-55 upset victory over Seton Hall here tonight.
