While optimistic steel-industry observers express little fear of the after-effects of inventory build-ups, there are reports that a prime customer, the automobile industry, is looking abroad for supplies.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 1 -- A plan to establish birth-control clinics here under the Federal antipoverty program has again become the target of criticism from Roman Catholics and some doctors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Senate passed the Administration's $1.1 billion Appalachia bill today after opening the way for possible inclusion of New York State in the program.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 1 -- Nine more cadets have resigned from the Air Force Academy as a result of the examination cheating scandal, it was announced today. This brought the total of resignations to 102.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- The General Assembly took another recess today to avoid a showdown between the United States and the Soviet Union on the question of unpaid assessments. This time, however, the recess will also be used to prepare to break off the Assembly session if the deadlock on funds continues.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused again today to rule on Government effort to desegregate public schools near military installations.

Fredric March and Florence Eldridge will be the first husband-and-wife acting team to go abroad under the auspices of the State Department's division of cultural presentations. Their itinerary, covering a dozen bookings will begin April 4 in Cairo and end May 13 in Naples.

OTTAWA, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Mitchell Sharp, Canada's Minister of Trade and Commerce, said today that the slashing of international wheat prices last week was "relatively orderly" and lashed out at his political foes for making what he called "completely false and irresponsible" statements about the wheat situation.

Efforts by the State Investigation Commission to subpoena financial records of Robert W. Seavey. a lawyer for a 1960 city-aided housing project in which Democratic leader J. Raymond Jones had been interested, were resisted yesterday as "roving, searching and oppressive."
" THE ORDWAYS" is a rowdy ballad of a book, told as if sung to a modern guitar, humorous, tragic and wayward, reaching deeply for its material into the American past.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Britain's highest court cleared the way today for mass Government distribution of drugs imported at low cost from abroad. The ruling was made against the wishes of the patent-holders.

Assignment of a specified percentage of the nation's oil imports for transportation on United States-flag tankers would be a "betrayal of the country's leadership towards trade liberalization," President Johnson's Maritime Advisory Committee was told yesterday in a statement submitted to it.

An expansion of its staff to enable the City Council to discharge its increased powers efficiently under the new City Charter was recommended yesterday by a study group headed by the Council President, Paul R. Screvane.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Margaret Smith won her sixth straight Australian singles championship today when Maria Bueno of Brazil collapsed with a leg cramp in the third set and was forced to default. The scores were 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 5 -- 2.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. William W. Scranton, wife of the Pennsylvania Governor, marched into the Capitol pressroom today and posted a statement in a controversy over new drapes in the Governor's reception room.
SELMA, Ala., Feb. 1 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and more than 770 other Negroes were arrested today while demonstrating against Alabama's voter-registration requirements.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- The House Armed Services Committee organized under new management today and served notice on the Pentagon that it did not intend to be pushed around.
A three-judge Federal court in Brooklyn refused yesterday to intervene in a dispute over how Suffolk County ought to be governed.
GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- The Swiss television audience was able tonight to view the first showing of a program that had been banned by Government edict for 11 years.

VERONA, Italy, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The feuding Montagues and Capulets are at it again in the city of Romeo and Juliet, and the United States Army's Southern European Task Force has been caught in the crossfire.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers announced today they had acquired Billy McGill, a former Utah star. The price was not disclosed.
IT has been told in legend that Hannibal used vinegar to dissolve the rocks as he crossed the Alps. Hippocrates is said to have believed in the medicinal uses of vinegar.

THE Judson Dance Theater is presenting James Waring and Dance Company in three performances at Judson Memorial Church on Washington Square South. The first performance was given last night, and the others will be given tonight and tomorrow night.

STUART, Fla., Feb. 1 -- It takes optimism of a most unusual kind for Floridians to see any good in a cold snap. Let the temperature drift perceptively downward, as it has for a few days, and they see a new Ice Age creeping down on them from the snowy North.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 1 -- A top Ford Motor Company official suggested today that demand for new automobiles was so strong that the industry could sell about 8.5 million domestically built cars in 1965.
PEKING, Jan. 20 -- Among young Chinese, a new heresy is gaining ground.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Anthony J. Celebrezze, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, urged Congress today today to approve a $250 million program that would strengthen existing education projects, he said, and plow new ground in the field of higher education.

Morris Gold, an upstate Republican leader, pleaded guilty yesterday in Supreme Court to perjury and admitted that he had given $100,000 in cash to Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz six years ago in Miami Beach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The House Banking Committee, with unusual speed and little controversy, approved today the Administration's request for partial repeal of the gold backing for United States money.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Supreme Court rifled today that the state of an owner's last known address should have the power to take his intangible personal property when the rightful owner cannot be located.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- Ron Clarke of Australia broke his own world 5,000-meter record tonight during the Western Springs track meet. His time of 13 minutes 33.6 seconds was one second better than his still pending mark set at Hobart, Tasmania, on Jan. 16.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 1 -- Emperor Haile Selassie and thousands of his subjects welcomed Queen Elizabeth II of Britain today for a state visit to this ancient African kingdom. Elizabeth flew from London on a four-engine jet for the first formal call on Ethiopia by any British monarch.
" Would you change anything if you fought him again?" was the question put to George Chuvalo in his Madison Square Garden dressing room last night -- after he lost to Floyd Patterson.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The United States nuclear submarine Seadragon arrived at the southern port of Sasebo early today, and 600 Socialists and Communists massed in Sasebo's main square to protest the four-day visit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The White House announced today that President Johnson was sending McGeorge Bundy, his special assistant for international security affairs, to Saigon for consultations on the situation in South Vietnam.
BONN, Feb. 1 -- West Germany called its Ambassador home from the United Arab Republic today to report on Bonn's worsening relations with Cairo.
The rally that began on the American Stock Exchange late in December faltered again yesterday as stocks generally declined in moderate trading.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Bob McIntyre socred 25 points and pulled down 15 rebounds tonight as St. John's University overcame a 10-point deficit midway through the second-half and defeated Loyola University of Chicago, 92 -- 87.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to let President Johnson complete a surplus food sales agreement with the United Arab Republic if he finds it in the national interest.

MIAMI, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Jumping Brook Farm's Hi-Hasty resoundingly ended a string of victories by the favorites at Hialeah today when he scored by three lengths in the seventh race and paid $84 for $2. Favorites had won the first six races.
The stock market generated little excitement yesterday as traders waited to see if General Motors would split its stock.
American Metal Climax, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement involving almost $1 billion to sell iron ore through an Australian affiliate to Japanese steel producers.
The regional concept was a popular idea in the 1930's when Congress established the Tennessee Valley Authority, but in the decades that have intervened it has not made much headway.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Manufacturers' inventories rose by about 1 per cent in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1, (AP) -- The tactics taught to Communist guerrillas in South Vietnam to shoot down United States planes are being countered successfully by saturation, rocket and machine-gun firing plus a bit of deception military experts said today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 1 -- The Communist party is attempting a comeback in the Middle East, especially in Syria and Iraq.
Sales of area department stores in January barely budged from the corresponding level a year earlier, according to a survey compiled yesterday by The New York Times.

THE Hot Stove League always reaches a conversational peak during the annual soiree of the Baseball Writers Association at this time of year. After the dinner and show of the New York chapter the other night the boys were still batting the conversational ball around into the wee hours of yesterday morning.
Tokyo has sent Yoshijl Matsuura, a Japanese city planner, to watch New York City grow.
The Temple University Concert Choir sang last night at Town Hall and showed that it is a reasonably trained group capable of a pleasing range of expression.
CAPE KENNEDY, Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Union leaders ended a walkout today that had halted $200 million in space construction for three days.
The directors of the New England Electric System announced yesterday a subscription price of $26.25 a share for the utility holding company's offering of 698,227 additional shares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- While associates in the Air Force praise him as a strong general with a deep Air Force tradition, there is little doubt that Gen. John Paul McConnell represents a new trend in the military high command.

The British pound rose sharply yesterday in fairly active trading in foreign exchange markets here. The currency, climbing 21 points to $2.7948 for delivery today, had its best day since last June. A point is one-hundredth of a cent.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Nearly everyone on Capitol Hill was talking about a settlement of the legislative leadership deadlock today, but no one seemed to know when it would come about.
Galey Lord, a fabric-producing mill, will use some "in" advertising in The New Yorker, designed to appeal to fashion trend setters. Six socialites have had their portraits painted by Henry Koehler.

WASHINGTON Feb. 1 -- President Johnson announced today a job development program in service and related fields to do something about the paradox in which jobs are going begging while four million people are unemployed.
THE appointment of Mrs. Dorothy Whyte Cotton as editor, of Parents Magazine will be announced today by George J. Hecht, publisher.
The election of Dr. Timothy J. O'Driscoll, director general of the Irish Tourist Board, as president of the 21-nation European Travel Commission was announced here yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- It was appropriate that Alix Gres's collection came right after the one shown this morning by Captain Edward Molyneux. Both were leaders of the haute couture in the nineteen-thirties.
Ethan A. Hitchcock, Axel G. Rosin and Mrs. Edward R. Wardwell were elected to the board of directors of the New York Philharmonic at a recent board meeting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Two Southern Representatives called today for the House Committee on Un-American Activities to investigate the Ku Klux Klan.
Bertram M. Beck, a 46-year-old social worker with extensive experience in combating juvenile delinquency, was appointed yesterday as executive director of New York's Mobilization for Youth program.

THE biggest individual championship tournament held anywhere in the world is the New England regional event held annually in January. John J. Hunt, of Bridgeport, Conn., emerged the winner from the field of 576 players this year.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to $91,925,670,929. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

His best punches bouncing off a seemingly iron skull, his body punished in continual clinches, Floyd Patterson hung doggedly through 12 brutal rounds last night at Madison Square Garden to win a unanimous decision from George Chuvalo.

Total sales for the notions industry for 1964 are close to a record of $1.5 billion, a rise of 10 per cent above the year before, David S. Colin, president of the National Notion Association, said yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Christian A. Herter, President Johnson's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations, conferred all day today with European Common Market leaders to obtain more favorable trade terms for the sale of American farm products.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Sir Winston Churchill's last words to his family were, "I am bored with it all."
CORVALLIS, Ore., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Dee Andros, 40-year-old coach at Idaho, was picked today to succeed Tommy Prothro as head football coach at Oregon State.
Mitchell N. Daroff, a vice president of Botany Industries, Inc., was elected yesterday to the board of the textile and apparel manufacturer.

The Department of Commerce recommendation to Congress that the size and weight limitations imposed on trucks using the Interstate Highway System be substantially increased makes a mockery of our much-publicized drives for greater traffic safety.
A wind-whipped snowfall began here shortly before 3 P.M. yesterday causing hazardous driving conditions and rush-hour traffic delays.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 1 -- Premier George Papandreou of Greece flew here today for a four-day official visit to Yugoslavia in what can be described as a new era of good feeling in the Balkans.
LAREDO, Tex., Feb. 1 (UPI) -- Telephone operators here went on strike today in a dispute over whether they should be paid extra to talk in English and Spanish.
NEW HAVEN Feb. 1 -- Students at Yale University have won the right to have their girl friends visit dormitories daily.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Former Premier Edgar Faure of France said tonight that financial difficulties and "procedural casuistries" were threatening the existence of the United Nations even though it is more vigorous and more successful than the League of Nations.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A memorial trust that will provide travel fellowships to persons in the United States and all parts of the British Commonwealth was started today to honor the memory of Sir Winston Churchill.
Fashion and finance -- until recently there seemed to be no two worlds more incompatible.

A dispute over script changes between the producers and authors of "Kelly," a musical scheduled to open on Broadway on Saturday, was ordered placed in the hands of an arbitration panel yesterday by a State Supreme Court Justice.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Evans Products Company reported today that sales and earnings in 1964 reached record levels.

Iran's effort to catch up and come to grips with the modern world continues to bring it tragedy and misery, typified by the wanton, stupid assassination of Premier Hassan Ali Mansour by a young religious fanatic. It is a tribute to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi that he is not allowing this tragedy, or the reactionary opposition of the nationalists and the even worse obscurantism of the Shia clergy, to stop his program of modernization.

The Rev. John Courtney Murray, one of the leading theologians at the Ecumenical Council, said last night that he was confident a strong council statement on religious liberty would be approved this year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Johnson, apparently rid of his Cold, bestowed new honors and acclaim today on Gen. Curtis E. LeMay.

Mrs. Lynn Chuvalo, wife of George Chuvalo, the Canadian heavyweight, and mother of his four Children -- all boys -- leaned against the wall and sobbed uncontrollably outside his dressing room at Madison Square Garden last night.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 1 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors reversed itself today and voted $400,000 in aid for the New Haven Railroad. The vote was 35 -- 6. Last September the board rejected a somewhat similar plan by 26 -- 16.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 -- Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo and Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium began negotiations today toward settling the financial disputes between their countries.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 1 -- An international Orthodox agency with headquarters in New York and London will be established next month for coordinating the cultural and religious activities of Jewish communities throughout the world.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The political truce that lasted through Sir Winston Churchill's illness, death and funeral came to a noisy end today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) United States Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon maintained silence today on the tangled affairs of the closed San Francisco National Bank.

Mrs. Rae Kitain, a short, stout, intense landlady who had trouble keeping superintendents, was found stabbed to death early yesterday, a bread knife protruding from her neck. She was found in her basement apartment office at 126 West 74th Street.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Democratic legislators said today they would examine Governor Rockefeller's $3.48 billion budget exhaustively to see where cuts could be made and additional taxation lightened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Of the payments in local currency made by Egypt to the United States Government for shipments of surplus foodstuffs, 85 percent is in effect returned as a gift. What the Egyptian Government does with this gift in current circumstances was precisely stated in a Cairo dispatch to this newspaper under date of Jan. 2:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- More than 400 persons attended the Snow Ball here yesterday. It was the first big charity benefit of the season and was held in the Celebrity Room at the Royal Poinciana Playhouse.

The indictment of a man and wife for first degree murder in the shotgun slaying of a Bronx electronics engineer in front of his home last Aug. 2 was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William Lyman.
TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes presented to the Legislature today a record $646,829,749 budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad's fourth quarter and full year's results in 1964 were seriously affected by the cost of retroactive wage and fringe benefits won by the rail unions in November and December.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The White House announced today that President Johnson had accepted the resignation of Richard M. Scammon as director of the Bureau of the Census.
Oren Root, former State Superintendent of Banks, joined the Irving Trust Company yesterday as a senior vice president and counsel.

ATLANTA, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Attorneys defending Lester G. Maddox in a contempt of court action contended today that he had refused to serve Negroes at his restaurant because of political belief, not because of racial origin.
ALL right, all right professor, who really did bulid Stonehenge and why?
REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy -- What should be done about a 70-year-old woman from Maysville, Ky., stranded in poverty and failing health in the remote Calabrian hills?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a contention that part of the District of Columbia vagrancy law is unconstitutional because it is too vague.

The One William Street Fund, which became the world's biggest "no load" fund last July by eliminating its sales charges, managed to reduce its ratio of redemptions to sales in the second half of 1964, its annual report showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Treasury bill rate rose slightly this week to the highest level since March, 1960, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Feb. 1 -- A 31-year-old housewife, who said she had never picked a lock in her life, opened four pairs of handcuffs with a hairpin this morning to free herself and three other persons.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 1 -- Ten persons were arrested last night in the Liaquatabad area of Karachi in connection with the Jan. 4 political riots here, it was reported today.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 1 -- A brief and apparently unsuccessful military coup d'etat was regarded by some sources today as an attempt by Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, a rightist leader, to regain his power in the army.

TRENTON, Feb. 1 -- The Legislature canceled today, its traditional winter recess in an effort to expedite an agreement on legislative reapportionment and Congressional redistricting.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, First Secretary of the Communist party, and Nikolai V. Podgorny, widely assumed to be the second most powerful man in the Soviet party hierarchy have spent three days in secret talks with Hungarian Communist leaders in Budapest.

While a light snow was falling outside, Leopold Stokowski was conducting the American Symphony Orchestra in Stravinsky's "The Rite of Spring" in Carnegie Hall last night. This was the concluding work in the program, which began with another piece springlike in spirit if not in name, Brahms's Serenade No. 1 in D. Schubert's "Unfinished" Symphony was the intermediate composition played.

Mayor Wagner has again confirmed his intention to run for a fourth four-year term. He had said as much last August, but his remark that he "most likely" will be a candidate suggests that his mind is fully made up.
A swarm of scalpers and those looking to be scalped gathered around Madison Square Garden last night.

The New York Knickerbockers accomplished two things last night. First, they gave Coach Harry Gallatin his first victory at Madison Square Garden after four defeats. Second, they demonstrated their superiority over a National Basketball Association rival -- something that seldom has happened.
The awarding and reoffering yesterday of the Texas Electric Service Company's $16 million first mortgage bonds reflected a resistance to higher interest rates on new issues, despite a slow market.
The futures market in Maine potatoes underwent another day of general selling yesterday and closed with prices down 3 to 16 cents a hundredweight.
The Nathan Hale Life Insurance Company of New York announced yesterday that it had received its life-insurance license from the State Insurance Department.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Gold and convertible currency reserves of the sterling area continued to fall last month, but by a lesser sum than at the height of the sterling crisis.
Edwin Posner, who guided the American Stock Exchange through its darkest hours, will step down next Monday as chairman after serving three successive one-year terms.
In an unusual occurrence a City Councilman demanded the censure of a colleague last night on the Council floor.

MIAMI, Feb. 2 -- Joe Duplin of Cambridge, Mass., regained the lead today in the Star Class Bacardi Cup series by winning the third race on Biscayne Bay as small-craft warnings flew. He has 82 points after finishing first and ninth in previous races.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Official and public neglect of education has opened an important breakthrough for organized labor among school teachers, it was said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Government auditors said today that the Government could save a lot of money if it stopped providing false teeth for patients at veterans hospital who had such ailments as deafness or "inflammation of the big toe of the right foot."

Andy Robustelli, who recently resigned as defensive coach of the football Giants, joined the baseball Yankees yesterday as the director of a new physical conditioning program to be conducted during spring training.
Nine new directors have been named to the board of the General Aniline and Film Corporation as the company moves close to a public sale of its stock.

The official Soviet report on economic performance last year poses even more puzzles than usual.

The National Automatic Merchandising Association said yesterday that it would be opposed to any change in the silver content of United States coins because of the resultant physical problems in converting vending machines.

The New York Times merits public gratitude for its Jan. 12 editorial "Smoking Loses Ground" and for the news' coverage accorded the life-and-death problem of smoking and health in the same issue and on other occasions.

City College started slowly, caught fire and then coasted to an 83-54 victory over the Hunter College basketball team last night at the Beavers' Wingate gymnasium.

HARTFORD, Feb. 2 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey called on Connecticut's General Assembly today to expand state aid to education, tighten civil rights laws, increase housing for the elderly and accelerate urban-renewal projects.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- Frol R. Kozlov, who once was regarded as Nikita S. Khrushchev's heir apparent, was given a state funeral in Red Square today by practically the entire Soviet leadership. Former Premier Khrushchev was not among the mourners.

In your Jan. 23 editorial on the subject of the mayorality of the City of New York mention was made of my proposal to draft Senator Kenneth B. Keating to run for Mayor. Your objection seems to be that it would subject him to the charge of carpetbagging, an argument he justifiably used against Massachusetts' Robert F. Kennedy.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Cars for three big races scheduled in the next two weeks at the Daytona International Speedway began arriving today. John Marcum's Midwestern big league group, the Auto Racing Club of America, brought in close to 50 entries for its 250-miler, to be held here on Sunday.
The Continental Can Company, Inc., took he profit crown away last year from the American Can Company which still leads the container industry in sales, according to reports issued yesterday.
MONTCLAIR, N.J. Feb. 2 -- Negro leaders in this community were critical today of the Board of Education's failure to elevate Mrs. Bessie Marsh from vice president to president.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz announced today that youth opportunity centers would be established in 13 more city areas in 10 states under the antipoverty program.
Another crack has appeared in that sturdy relic of the advertising business -- the commission system of compensation for agencies' services.

John P.R. Budlong became president of the New American Library of World Literature, Inc., yesterday. He succeeds Kurt Enoch, president since 1948 when he and Victor Weybright, chairman and chief editor, formed the concern.

The world's largest high-pressure oxygen chamber was unveiled yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. The $800,000 tank, which weighs 37 tons, can help to force up to 30 times as much oxygen as normal into the blood of patients.
Treasury bond prices turned upward yesterday, ending a downward drift that had lasted more than a week.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 2 -- Officials of Nassau County were warned today that they must face up to a growing problem of narcotics addiction among teen-agers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it was concerned over the effect that in-flight movies and other travel entertainment might have on airline fares.
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, St. Paul, Minn., turned in the best annual sales and earnings last ear in its 62-year history.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The building trades unions and the construction industry agreed today on a new plan for setting jurisdictional disputes.
The election of Thomas J. Murrin as manufacturing vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation was announced yesterday by D.C. Burnham, president.

Hyman G. Mintz, Sullivan County Republican leader who is chairman of the Assembly's Excise Committee, has been named in court as the recipient of $100,000 in cash in a plot involving a race track license. The accusation was made by an acknowledged perjurer.

A Russian tanker dropped anchor in New York Harbor last night after the United States Government granted the ship emergency clearance to pick up provisions and water. The tanker, the 12,000-ton Lyepaya, radioed from near Ambrose Light about 10 o'clock Monday night that she needed fresh water and additional food after being blfffeted by storms on the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- I.W. Abel, who is trying to unseat David J. McDonald as president of the United Steelworkers of America, put forward today two proposals that he said would lessen the chances of strikes in the steel industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Mrs. Esther Peterson, the President's special assistant for consumer affairs, finally spoke her piece today to the Advertising Federation of America.

THE theory that one can be too clever at the bridge table would be supported, out of his personal experience, by Ned Gardner; the proprietor of the Forest Hills Bridge Club. This is the oldest rubber bridge club in Long Island and was founded by him in 1946.

Charles Ufford of Harvard and Steve Vehslage of the Racquet and Tennis Club, seeded No. 1 and 2. respectively, advanced to the second round of the Metropolitan Class A squash racquets championship yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 2 -- The state police met with telephone company officials today to map strategy in combating thefts from public telephones along the Merritt Parkway and Connecticut Turnpike. Such thefts have caused a loss of about $5,000 in the last six months.
Three men helped the police catch a robbery suspect yesterday after he allegedly picked a woman's pocketbook on a subway train.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- The 15th annual luncheon, bridge party and fashion show benefiting the Westchester Heart Association will be held on Feb. 12 at the Scarsdale Golf Club here.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- Twenty-one miners were killed today by a gas explosion in a coal pit near Lens, in the northeastern corner of France. There were no survivors.

Bill (Red) Johansen, the Rovers' 36-year-old center, was named player-coach for the remainder of the season yesterday and Coach Steve Brklacich was assigned to the post of coordinator of scouts for the Rangers in the Province of Ontario.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 2 -- The Chrysler Corporation, in an effort to quiet mounting criticism from its automobile dealers over the amount of money new dealers have to put up to get started, has made what it considers to be a major change in its policy of financing new dealerships.

Don Schollander, the winner of four Olympic swimming gold medals and still a babe in arms by most sports standards, was named the 1964 winner of the James E. Sullivan Award yesterday as the nation's outstanding amateur athlete.
Gifts to the 53d Appeal for the Neediest Cases continued to climb toward the $700,000 mark as recent contributions totaling $1,969.88 were received from 104 additional donors.

Personnel of Fort Monmouth, N.J., will give blood to the Red Cross today. Employes of downtown banks here will donate at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street. ATLANTA, Feb. 2 (UPI) -- Lester G. Maddox, depicted as a man who has grossed $130,000 selling segregationist souvenirs, swore in Federal court today that he would die before serving an integrationist at his restaurant.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- The Actor's Workshop, fighting for survival after losing a dozen veteran actors to New York's Lincoln Center Repertory Theater, appealed directly to San Francisco's city fathers today for financial aid.

A nationally known consultant to private and governmental pension plans took exception yesterday to recommendations on pensions made last Saturday by a Presidential committee of high Government officials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Short-take-off aircraft that might make the nation's 13 regional airlines self-sufficient are almost ready for development, a top space agency official said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Atomic Energy Commission is considering an additional cutback in the production of enriched uranium for atomic weapons, commission officials disclosed today.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission voted today to eliminate the twin double at the state's three one-mile tracks, beginning with tomorrow's program at Bowie Race Course.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Greyhound Corporation announced today that agreement had been reached in principle with representatives of Yellowstone Park Company stockholders for the acquisition of all their stock in exchange for common stock of Greyhound.

The Chicago Black Hawks, trailing the first-place Montreal Canadiens by 2 points, face the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. The National League Hockey game is slated to start at 7:30 P.M.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Efforts to end the protracted tug of war over legislative leadership broke down this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Charges that criminals have been gaining control of banks and may have been responsible for some recent bank failures were made today in both the House and Senate.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The London Philharmonic Orchestra, faced with financial disaster five years ago, announced today that it had erased a deficit of $112,000 and faced its future with optimism.

Solomon Sheer, deputy director of the city Board of Standards and Appeals, will address the Peter Minuit Post, the real estate unit of the American Legion, on Feb. 18, on the City's zoning resolution. WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Government stepped up pressure today on segments of the construction industry in Cleveland to eliminate racial discrimination in their apprenticeship programs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, has offered to help settle the controversy over the counting of ballots in the recent election of the International Union of Electrical Workers.

Theater in the Street will start its fourth summer season in July with an expanded schedule of performances, twice as many as last year, in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.
Controller Abraham D. Beame subpoenaed the World's Fair's books yesterday and the fair said it would move to have the subpoena quashed.

The special stockholders meeting yesterday of the Columbia Pictures Corporation ran as long as some of the company's major film productions. The 3-hour-long feature concerned discussions of the company's dividends.

Stocks on the American Stock Exchange yesterday generally edged downward as the trading pace eased.

AUTHOR of two novels, Curtis Harnack brings a novelist's eye and a practiced pen to his account of a year's stay in Iran at the University of Tabriz. He also brings an admirable point of view. He is neither a superior westerner nor a wide-eyed romantic. He mentions difficulties in food, sanitation and problems of hygiene in passing, but he does not raise to a plane of metaphysics what is a matter of personal discomfort.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Rev. William H. DuBay, a Roman Catholic priest, has spoken out again against James Francis Cardinal McIntyre and has been reprimanded anew, a source close to Father DuBay said today.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Assemblyman Hyman E. Mintz, named this week in a bribery scandal involving the Finger Lakes Race Track, was discharged today from Albany Medical Center Hospital, where he had been under treatment for a heart ailment.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 3 -- Mississippi's largest organization of businessmen declared here today that the state must "adjust" to the Civil Rights Act, restore interracial communications and extend voting rights impartially.
General Aniline and Film Corporation has a new board of directors. This was announced officially yesterday after the board meeting.
The Southern Natural Gas Company announced yesterday four changes in its top management.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association has decided to make an extensive study of the relationship between a free press and fair trials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Council of the Organization of American States today scheduled a long-delayed conference of the hemisphere's foreign ministers for May 20 in Rio de Janeiro.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Rear Adm. Draper L. Kauffman, a veteran of the French Army and the British Navy in World War II, was named today to become superintendent of the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md.
American Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a $33,457,000 profit, equal to $3.95 a share, for 1964. This compared with the carrier's 1963 earnings of $19,703,000, or $2.35 a share.
A dissident group of stockholders has won control of the Sunshine Mining Company in Spokane, Wash.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Paul C. Meyer, 25 years old, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to obtaining 15 United States passports through fraud and delivering them to Soviet agents in East Berlin.

A retired first-grade detective who held 13 citations, including the Police Department's Medal of Honor, its highest award, was arrested yesterday on charges of extortion, grand larceny and impersonating a policeman.

SINCE all dog breeds are not the same in physical characteristics or mental reactions, they must be judged with Understanding in obedience competition, said John S. Ward of Arlington, Va. He is a Government employe in Washington whose dog interests include judging obedience trials and conducting a training class in Alexandria, Va. "

The financial crisis building up among this country's educational television stations has been dramatized by the near-bankruptcy of WNDT -- a danger now temporarily averted by an emergency Ford Foundation grant of $500,000. But the Foundation has warned that it cannot assume indefinitely the burden of guaranteeing the financial base of educational television in this and other cities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Sentiment is mounting in New York Congressional circles to divorce the proposed Consolidated Edison power plant on the Hudson River from legislation to preserve the scenic character of the river.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized four trunk airlines -- American, National, Northeast and Trans World -- to reduce fares on certain routes where they compete with Eastern Air Lines.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- An investigation has begun to determine whether the White House is getting dirty too fast.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A 34-year-old Army veteran, paralyzed since he underwent a lung operation in a Veterans Administration hospital in 1959, today was awarded $650,211 in a medical malpractice judgment against the Federal Government.
The Anaconda Company, one of the world's leading producers of copper, yesterday announced sizable increases in its net profits and income from operations for 1964.
The municipal bond industry's second largest new offering of the year, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's $54 million public improvement bond issue came to market yesterday and was quickly sold out.
The New York Bank for Savings plans to build a 27-story apartment house next to its main office at Third Avenue and 72d Street, utilizing the same Colonial design.
The nation's electric power production rose 9 per cent in the week ended Jan. 30 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
The Soviet tanker Liepaja, anchored off South Brooklyn in Gravesend Bay, took on meat, vegetables and potatoes yesterday as crewmen made engine repairs.

The New York University swimming team defeated Fordham yesterday, 52 -- 43, at N.Y.U.'s Quigley Pool in the Bronx. The Violets took first place in seven of the 11 events as they captured their second victory of the season. They have three losses.
Fruits and vegetables valued by importers at a million dollars are spoiling on ships here as a result of the dock strike, traders said yesterday.

McCrory Corporation reported yesterday a doubling of its earnings in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, 1965 and a cash position in excess of $20 million that would allow it and its affiliated companies to make a $50 million to $100 million acquisition.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Regulations to speed the improvement of new drug labeling and manufacturing procedures were announced today by the Food and Drug Administration.
The New York Philharmonic will play at Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30. Thomas Schippers will conduct, with Regine Crespin, soprano, as soloist.
The operator of a Broadway ticket service and his son pleaded guilty yesterday in Criminal Court to charges of ticket scalping.
MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin is to leave tomorrow morning for Hanoi, North Vietnam, apparently by way of Peking.

In his otherwise objective letter published Jan. 28 Morris Amchan comes to a wrong conclusion when he says: "Imagine what would happen if the fear of prosecution is removed and Martin Bormann or S.S. General Heinrich Mueller, Eichmann's boss, reappears.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 3 -- Paced by a senior, Don Switzer, and a sophomore, Roy Benson, the Dartmouth track team defeated Boston University, 63 -- 41, today. Switzer won both the weight throw and tile shot-put, while Benson contributed victories for the Indians in the one-mile and 1,000-yard run.

With the appointment of Bertram M. Beck as its executive director, Mobilization for Youth has taken an important step forward in its attack on juvenile delinquency and poverty. Mr. Beck is a highly respected figure in the field of social work. He will bring to the embattled agency vigor, imagination and warm human sympathies, tempered by sound judgment and broad experience.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The American delegation on the executive board of the International Coffee Organization will fight the 5 per cent reduction in world coffee-export quotas sought by producing nations, conference sources said today.

" Bardot M.P.?" by A.P. Herbert, will come from Doubleday on Feb. 12. Sir Alan, Member of Parliament, author, plavright and poet, has turned out a collection of 25 mythical legal cases. The one that provides the title for his book concerns the election of Brigitte Bardot, the French film star, to Parliament after Britain has joined the European Common Market, or Community.

Fourteen television shows now on the Columbia Broadcasting System network may not continue next season, judging by a tentative schedule drawn up by C.B.S. and circulated in the industry yesterday. Initial planning is subject to many changes before the schedule is officially completed, but it was obvious that C.B.S. had in mind a major turnover in programs for the 1965-66 season.

NASHVILLE, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- LeRoy Collins, director of the Community Relations Service, said tonight that results of the Civil Rights Act so far had been better than many of its proponents had expected.
Shares of D. Kaltman Co. held the spotlight yesterday in a generally stronger market on the American Stock Exchange.
BONN, Feb. 3 -- Hermann Krumey, a wartime member of Adolf Eichmann's command, was sentenced to five years at hard labor today for having assisted in the murder of 300,000 Hungarian Jews.
Fifth-graders at three public schools in the Bronx are finding out that snow is good for something besides sledding, building snow men, making snowballs and shoveling.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Senate voted today to block two Administration economy moves involving veterans' hospitals and agricultural research.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey assured the United States Chamber of Commerce today that the Johnson Administration had confidence in business, but declared it was "terribly important that businessmen themselves have confidence in business."
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 3 -- In their locker room before the game, the Providence College players will relax by listening to taped jazz.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The nation's unemployment rate for January will show a drop for the second month in a row. The rate will go from 5 per cent to 4.8.
The new stroke-play format for the 1965 United States Amateur golf championship is being favorably received, according to surveys on the United States Golf Association's action of last Saturday.
Governor Rockefeller's special investigator, Herman T. Stichman, is conducting an investigation of the city's enforcement of fire, health and safety laws relating to housing.
Seven single records and 28 record albums have won the 1964 Gold Record Awards presented by the Record Industry Association of America.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 3 -- Australia has neither sought nor received any new United States commitment under the ANZUS pact in connection with her decision to send combat troops to Malaysian Borneo. She would nevertheless expect United States assistance under the treaty if serious hostilities with Indonesia resulted.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland told the Senate today that Communist forces inside and outside the United States "are pressing for a Negro revolution in this country."
Ellen Faull, a soprano with the New York City Opera, gave a recital of German music last night at Town Hall, all lieder except for a group of Bach arias at the start.

TOKYO, Feb. 3 -- Japan's export trade made noteworthy gains during 1964, but "more closely woven" export-promotion measures are necessary to maintain this rate of expansion and insure steady and stable markets abroad.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Frank Beard, who was gravely ill with encephalitis less than a year ago, fired a six-under-par 66 today to take the first-round lead in the 90-hole $100,000 Bob Hope golf classic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Huge, specially modified aerial tankers, loaded with electronic gear, were in their fifth year today of an extraordinary patrol that began at the height of the country's "missile gap" fears.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Three teen-age "goof ball" addicts were "laughing fit to die" as they pumped 11 bullets into a 66-year-old express clerk in a robbery-slaying that netted them $11, the admitted triggerman said today.
NEWARK, Feb. 3 -- "I always believed my father, but I wanted him to have his medal in his hand." 13-year-old Ellen Rader explained today. And that's why she wrote to President Johnson.

Joseph Papp, founder and producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, said yesterday that he had received a pledge of $200,000 to operate a 299-seat year-round repertory theater, starting next season. Mr. Papp declined to identify the donor, the site of the Off Broadway theater or its name until arrangements for the gift are complete.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3 -- The United States Military Assistance Command reported today that South Vietnamese troops killed 2,210 Vietcong guerrillas in January, described as the most successful month of Government military operations to date.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A crash that wiped out a family of five near Alliance, Neb., last March 26 was caused by the pilot's loss of control in adverse weather conditions, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.

The case of a 40-year-old New York State dairy farmer saddled with $42,000 of debt was considered yesterday by a seminar of 50 bank examiners, six bankers and two college professors. The farmer in the hypothetical case was given the name Adam Smith in an apparent tongue-in-cheek reference to the British economist.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- American society forges upward through ever more burdensome levels of plenty. A while back there was the two-car family. Then came the two-house family. Now, just over the horizon, comes the two-family family.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A plan for reorganization of the Labor Department's Manpower Administration is running into opposition.

TOKYO, Feb. 3 -- A continuing strike by almost the entire student body at one of Japan's leading universities has focused national attention on the economic plight of private educational institutions here.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 3 -- The Danikils, a mainly nomadic people in Northeastern Ethiopia, saw Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, today.
Mayor Wagner was reported last night to have had no hand in the developments at Albany leading to the nomination by the Republicans of Joseph Zaretzki for Senate majority leader.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The establishment of an administrative counsel of the Congress -- a sort of complaint desk for the public -- was proposed today by Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, and Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin.

Personally, I find it difficult to accept new taxes, or the excuses made for them, simply because I have very little confidence in our city and state administrations. Still, if there must be new taxes is it necessary for them to be such unimaginative ones?
BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- A West German company has offered to sell East Germany heavy electrical equipment worth nearly $3 million for resale to the United Arab Republic.

The Rev. Milton A. Galamison was given a suspended sentence of 10 days in the Workhouse or a $250 fine or both, on charges arising from the school boycott he is leading. He also announced extension of the movement to nine more junior high schools.

William S. Morris, the giant killer of the municipal bond business of 1961 who dissolved his partnership in 1963 after one of his financial coups turned sour, has incorporated and is selling stock in his concern.
The appointment of Allen Austill as dean of the New School for Social Research, was announced yesterday by Dr. John R. Everett, president of the institution.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 3 -- Brown snapped Dartmouth's 10-game winning streak and gained first place in the Ivy Hockey League by defeating the Indians, 4-2, at Meehan Auditorium tonight.
CLIFTON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The Clifton Teachers Association voted today to end a boycott of extracurricular activities that was entering its third week.
A last minute burst of trader enthusiasm gave an otherwise mixed market a positive finish yesterday.
BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain and Hal Greer led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 116-95 victory over the New York Knicks tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- Store buyers who saw Hubert de Givenchy's spring collection today made calm, contented comments about it. Their reactions are the first available report because Givenchy traditionally excludes the press until a month after he shows to buyers.

The British pound declined slightly in quiet trading on the foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.7945, a drop of 6 points from Tuesday. The quotation for Friday sterling ranged from $2.7946 to $2.7948.
The Frank G. Shattuck Company has leased 15,000 square feet at 417 Fifth Avenue, at 38th Street, for a Schraffts restaurant, the 34th in the metropolitan New York area.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 3 -- Francois Mergen, professor of forest genetics, has been named dean of the Yale University School of Forestry. He will succeed George A. Garratt, who will retire after 20 years in that post.
A Mississippi water district that failed in December to get any acceptable bids from Wall Street investment bankers for $24.65 million of bonds succeeded in selling the securities yesterday.
BOWIE Md., Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Senator B., an 18-1 shot who ran last for the first half of the race, rallied in the stretch today and won the $6,000 feature at Bowie by a length.
The Liggett Myers Tobacco Company increased its earnings last year by 6.2 per cent above those of 1963 despite a sales decline.
The third consecutive day of heavy selling slashed Maine potato futures prices by 14 to 21 cents a hundredweight yesterday on the active spring contracts.
Mayor Wagner announced plans yesterday to make Manhattan General Hospital the city's treatment and research center for narcotics addiction.
The fifth annual dance of the Blue Hill Troupe will be given on Feb. 12 in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East to benefit the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.
California's Director of Employment, Albert B. Tieburg, recently stated that we do not have a shortage of domestic workers in our state who can and will do farm work if given a chance.
ROME, Feb. 3 -- The reorganization of the Christian Democratic party leadership and a strongly worded denunciation of Communism were unanimously approved tonight by the party's National Council.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 (UPI) -- Rocky Colavito signed his 1965 contract with the Cleveland Indians today for an amount estimated to be $55,000.

A 57,000-square-foot plot at the corner of North Franklin and Kellum Streets in Hempstead, L.I., has been acquired by Goodrich Associates, builders, for construction of a headquarters building to be leased to John's Bargain Stores, a 400-unit chain of variety outlets.
America's traditional system of free collective bargaining cannot meet many of the complex problems facing the labor movement, speakers at an industrial relations seminar agreed yesterday.
All the evils of the textile industry do not revolve around imports, Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, asserted yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 3 -- President Sukarno asserted today that the Indonesian and Chinese Communist revolutions shared the aim of defeating Western "imperialism" and that a joining of the movements would bring stability to Asia.
WESTPORT, Conn. Feb. 3 -- A town committee investigating the reported use of narcotics by Westport youngsters has found that teen-age drinking is a greater problem.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Jimmy Walker directed unbeaten Providence to a 72 -- 70 victory over DePaul tonight.
New York University's fencing team defeated Cornell, 17 -- 10, yesterday at the Violets' School of Education gym.
The election of John L. Gibbons as a director of the North American Life Assurance Company, Toronto, was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Feb. 4 -- Masanori Murakami, a left-handed pitcher known to his American teammates as "Mashi," has been the unintentional cause of a deep reassessment here of baseball relations between the United States and Japan.
MOSCOW Feb. 4 -- The Soviet press and radio gave immediate publicity today to President Johnson's statement that he had reason to believe that the Kremlin would welcome a visit by him to Moscow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- "I may have made a mistake," President Johnson said today as he reviewed his reasons for not asking Vice President Humphrey to represent him at the Winston Churchill's funeral.
Alirio Diaz, a Venezuelan classical guitarist who was last heard in Town Hall in January 1963, gave a recital last night in the same auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- In one of his most strongly worded denunciations of racial discrimination, President Johnson deplored today the infringement of voting rights in Alabama and pledged vigorous legal action.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Three hold-out shopcraft unions and the nation's railroads settled their protracted wage dispute today.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The New York State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of the 381 candidates who passed the bar examination held last Dec. 1 and 2.
ANCHORAGE, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Fear gave way to relief today for thousands of coastal residents on both sides of the Pacific who spent much of the night waiting for tidal waves that never came.

MAHWAH, N.J., Feb. 4 -- A 15-year master plan to enable this wooded Ramapo Valley township to escape "urban sprawl" while undergoing an explosive growth in population was presented to the public at a hearing here tonight by Leo Ckrazinski, chairman of the planning board.
Management changes were announced yesterday by three banks in the New York area.
Alfred deF. Licato, a former deputy commissioner of the State Liquor Authority who pleaded guilty to taking bribes, was sentenced yesterday to serve a year in jail.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4 -- Peter N. Landerman, a California student who was released from a Soviet jail today after serving 16 months of a three-year sentence growing out of a traffic accident, looked lean but healthy at a news conference in the United States Embassy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Committee for Economic Development urged the Senate Banking Committee today to remove the 25 per cent gold-backing requirement on both Federal Reserve Bank deposits and currency.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A record traffic accident toll of 47,800 lives and $8.2 billion in economic losses last year was reported by the National Safety Council today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- A special investigating committee on Oman's claims to independence has reported to the General Assembly that agitation in the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman is "a serious international problem" caused by foreign intervention.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- President del Gaulle made proposals today for reform of the United Nations, the reunification of Germany and changes in the world monetary system -- proposals that challenge United States policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The United States was reported today to be preparing to withdraw its Ambassador to Tanzania, William Leonhart, in reprisal for the expulsion of two American Embassy officials last month.
William C. Fletcher's rebuttal [letter published Jan. 30] of The Times' Jan. 18 news article "Soviet Said to Ease Christianity Stand" may be correct in detail but is certainly incorrect in emphasis.

Governor Rockefeller declined yesterday to order a state investigation of the case of George Whitmore Jr., who has recanted confessions to an East Side double murder, a Brooklyn murder and an attempted rape.
Interests associated with Webb Knapp, Inc., have acquired a 63 per cent share of the fee ownership in the property situated at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and 57th Street.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 4 -- A 52-year-old sewing machine stands on the balcony of the Island Garden during the Marine Recreation Boat Show.
MAPLE PARK, Ill., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Greyhound, the snow-white gelding who was the Man o' War of harness racing, died in his sleep today at the age of 33 -- comparable to 132 years for a human being.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Treasury denounced today the proposal of President de Gaulle for a return to a full gold standard in international finance.
It was "a great market" last month, much greater than was indicated by the 3 per cent rise in the Dow-Jones industrial average, a Wall Street analyst asserts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Walter W. Jenkins, former White House aide whose name has figured in the investigation of Robert G. Baker, did not answer a subpoena to appear before the Senate Rules Committee today.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller and two of his top political aides led the Republican intervention in the Assembly that culminated tonight in the election of Anthony J. Travia, a Democrat, as Speaker.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 -- Within minutes after McGeorge Bundy landed in Saigon this morning, he was asked if his journey was related to the visit of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union to North Vietnam.

TWO of the visiting experts at the American Bridge Association tournament held here last weekend under the auspices of the Henry C. Parker and Bronx-Westchester Clubs were Roscoe Rigmaiden and Luis Pietri of Philadelphia.

MELVILLE, L.I. Feb. 4 -- Leonard W. Hall of Locust Valley, former national chairman of the Republican party, was named chairman of the Nassau-Suffolk Regional Planning Board at its organization meeting here today.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 4 -- A prominent American diplomat lashed out today at the rising tide of European nationalism, linking it to a similar trend in the United States.
The British pound gained appreciably in quiet trading of foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2.7955, up 10 points from Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board gave the Flying Tiger line permission today to put into effect between Chicago and California the same type of reduced bulk-cargo rates it now offers between New York and California.
Josef Krips will return to the New York Philharmonic as guest conductor next week for a four-week engagement. Mr. Krips had conducted the orchestra for six weeks this season.
Camille Henry, the little man who was always there, is gone.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A bill to extend the fisheries loan program, from next June 30, to June 30, 1975, was introduced today by Sen. Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee.

The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) has expanded its space at 673 First Avenue, the former United Parcel Building at the northwest corner of 38th Street, by taking an additional floor of 34,000 square feet.

MIAMI, Feb. 4 -- With her jockey seizing every strategic advantage, Taunoa managed to win the feature race on today's Hialeah program. The rider, Mike Venezia of Brooklyn, exhibited the skill and daring that enabled him to become one of the most popular riders at Aqueduct last year as he kept Taunoa at the head of the pack virtually all the way to score by a nose over the favored Wild Note.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- An Agena rocket of the type that has put more than 60 per cent of this nation's satellites into orbit was presented to the Smithsonian Institution today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Johnson declared today that the Administration was determined to continue its policy of "helping the people of South Vietnam preserve their freedom."
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 4 -- The Scarsdale Public Library will join the Westchester County library system tomorrow to share in the system's $380,000 a year in state aid.
The Yale Express System, Inc., announced yesterday that it would report a loss for 1964, after having announced a net income of $904,318, or 42 cents a share, for the first nine months of the year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Customs duties on all goods imported into the Soviet Union from the developing countries of Asia, Africa and Latin America have been abolished as of last Jan. 1, Secretary General U Thant was informed today in a communication from the Soviet representative, Nikolai T. Fedorenko.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The Conservatives comfortably held the constituency of Altrincham and Sale in northwestern England in a by-election today.

Although West 84th Street was once called "the worst block in New York," a 21-year-old New York University student named Thomas Abercrombie moved there last month because he had read that all was now changed -- it had become a "model block."

A.J.P. Taylor, the British historian who contended in "The Origins of the Second World War" that diplomatic stupidity and not Hitler's deliberate plan set off the conflict, has written a book about the First World War, "Politics in Wartime." Athenenum will publish it late this month.
THE third, last and biggest of the new works presented by the New York City Ballet in this winter season at the New York State Theater had its premiere last night.

LAST night's concert by the New York Philharmonic was refreshing. In a season when the cry seems to be "Give us this day our daily Beethoven," Thomas Schippers took the orchestra into one or two musical byways. Ravel's "Sheherazade," for example, is not really an unknown piece.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Despite Senate resistance and many protests from the affected communities, President Johnson stood fast today on the decision to close veterans' facilities in 12 states.
The 11 basic steel companies are not prepared to grant wage and benefit improvements greater than 2 per cent to the United Steelworkers of America this year, according to informed industry sources.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- President Charles de Gaulle advocated today the return of the world's money system to the gold standard -- a system that would, in France's view, subject all countries to better monetary discipline and reduce the dominant power of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- No matter how you read it -- down the column or across the page -- President Johnson has his foreign policy problems. Seldom in recent months have there been so many confusing and conflicting reports in the Washington diplomatic corps about American policy in the Atlantic and Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from President Johnson's Farm Message to Congress today:
SELMA, Ala., Feb. 4 -- A Federal judge issued today an order to make it easier for Negroes to register to vote in Dallas County.

TOKYO Feb. 4 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communist leader Mao Tse-tung has told an American journalist that the Vietcong will win the war in South Vietnam with their own power, a Japanese newspaper said today.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The Government disclosed tonight that it would tighten the Commonwealth Immigration Laws. Two years ago, before it came to power, the Labor party opposed the adoption of those laws, which are a focus of controversy over racial prejudice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Four soldiers today saved a high official of the Atomic Energy Commission who had plunged 90 feet off the Key Bridge into the ice-covered Potomac River at Georgetown.

NEAR-ZERO temperatures in much of the snow country has kept skiing covers intact as area operators and inn-keepers prepare for another major invasion of recreational runners this weekend. Adding to the busy picture will be two important two-day competitions in different sections of New England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation believes it should be allowed to refuse to insure the deposits of new national banks. It also seeks "a better method" for keeping an eye on how national banks are operating.
BONN, Feb. 4 -- Several hundred Turkish workers rolled out their prayer rugs in Cologne Cathedral last night in the first Moslem service ever to be held in a Roman Catholic church in Germany.
MOSCOW, Feb. 4 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev was accused today of "harebrained scheming" in military strategy.

The only water-supply boat in the harbor, the 100-foot-long Aqua, was idling at her home berth at 30th Street, Brooklyn, late Wednesday night when she was called to supply fresh water to the "near-dry" Soviet tanker Liepaja, according to a Coast Guard officer.
Plaid cotton madras from India has acquired status among teen-agers and the staid country-club set in recent years. To appeal to both groups, Altman's has installed a Madras Shop on its third floor.
M'GUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., Feb. 4 -- A former B-17, bombardier received today the Distinguished Flying Cross that he was awarded more than 20 years ago.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The drive to pit economic sinew against racial extremists continued today with the Mississippi Manufacturers Association siding against the extremists.

BELGRADE, Feb. 4 -- The four-day official visit of the Greek Premier, George Papandreou, ended on a friendly note today with agreement between Athens and Belgrade on an elastic formula for solution of the Cyprus crisis.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 4 -- Bob Gifford and Art Rudolph, undefeated sophomores, led the Hofstra wrestling team to a 19-10 victory over Massachusetts Institute of Technology today. It was Hofstra's seventh victory in eight dual meets.
Chock full o' Nuts confirmed rumors yesterday that Jerome S. Neuman, president of the Jos. Martinson Co., coffee roasters, would become its president effective Feb. 23.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Ken Boyer, the National League's most valuable player who smashed a grand-slam home run for a 4-3 victory over the New York Yankees in the World Series, signed his contract tonight with the St. Louis Cardinals for an amount reported to be $65,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Consumer installment credit increased by $560 million in December, the largest rise in nearly a year.
Members of Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America will begin voting today in a referendum that could have far-reaching effects on the graphic arts industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Johnson reacted coolly today to President de Gaulle's proposal for a five-power conference, including Communist China, to resolve the difficulties of the United Nations.

DE PERE, Wis., Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Edward M. Du Quaine, a special master, recommended yesterday that the Kohler Company be required to pay millions of dollars in back pay to workers who went on strike against the plumbingware company in Kohler, Wis., from 1954 to 1960.

AS far as Anthony John Travia can see, the only drawback to being Speaker of the Assembly, the post to which he was elected yesterday, is that he will have to sit still in his high-backed red leather chair behind his noble mahogany desk on the rostrum and remain silent while other voices crackle in debate on the floor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- American automobile manufacturers have agreed to provide speedometers with more accurate mileage readings, the National Bureau of Standards said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved unanimously today a constitutional amendment to establish procedures for dealing with Presidential disability and keeping the office of Vice President filled.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Streit of Font Hills, Ont., gained the semi-finals of the women's championship of Palm Beach today by defeating two opponents with the best golf of the tournament on the Breakers Golf Course.

ARFON, Feb.4 (AP) -- Art Arfons, who drove his Green Monster at a speed of 536.71 miles an hour on the Bonneville, Utah, Salt Flats last October, received word today that his performance had been accepted as a world land speed record for jet-powered cars.

REGINA, Sask., Feb. 3 -- This prairie province of Canada began a Diamond Jubilee this week to commemorate Saskatchewan's admission to the Confederation in 1905. Regina, the capital, is honoring its history and its pioneers.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- The two weeks of the haute couture showings are always frenzied. Buyers and reporters attack their assignments as if they were competitors in a track meet.

She has made her biggest reputation to date as a coloratura mezzo-soprano, but this time she avoided, for the most part, the showy end of the repertory. Aside from the Purcell "Alleluia" and the two big arias from "La Cenerentola," this was a program of the art song.
The shipping industry has again urged President Johnson to act in the 27-day-old longshore strike, which it described as "senseless, suicidal and unjustified."
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Bermuda Industrial Union continued its strike against the Bermuda Electrical Company today. Sympathy walkouts threatened to paralyze the island.

Justice Edward Thompson ruled in Queens Supreme Court yesterday that Alvin Mitchell's confession in the killing of a 15-year-old girl had been properly obtained by the police and could be offered as evidence in his forthcoming second trial.

The sonata series at Grace Lainey Rogers Auditorium is distinguished by its uncommon pairings of artists. Mayor Wagner appointed John V. Connorton, his deputy, yesterday to head a special panel that will study what steps can be taken to streamline Welfare Department practices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Beautifying cities with flowers, trees and lighting was discussed today at the seventh of Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson's luncheons for "women doers."

Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall was honored yesterday by the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society for "outstanding leadership" in the field of scenic conservation.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON England, Feb. 5 -- At the Royal Shakespeare Theater here tonight, the touring section of the Royal Ballet gave the world premiere of Norman Morrice's arresting "The Tribute."

One of the leading "in" figures of instrumental music, Julian Bream, gave a recital of guitar and lute music last night at Town Hall. A commemorative film on the career of Sir Winston Churchill, produced by Britain's J. Arthur Rank Organization, will have its America premiere today at the Exeter Street Theater, Boston.

Joe Namath, who underwent surgery on his right knee 12 days ago, will be released from Lenox Hill Hospital today, much to his gratification. Maj. Gen. Robert H. Warren, Superintendent of the Air Force Academy, was entirely correct in giving "full support" to the Academy's cadet honor code, which declares that a cadet will not lie, cheat or steal, and will not tolerate others who do.

Washington emphasizes that the United States "does not strive to expand the war."

In weekend stealth the vulture-like work of destroying another New York landmark has begun. Wrecking crews are busy tearing down the Brokaw Mansion at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, and lovers of beauty can indulge once again in the macabre pleasure of attending a demolition-watching. The despoilers were so eager to get this lovely building down that they were delighted to pay premium rates to the workmen for their weekend toil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The military operations in Vietnam over the weekend have increased the tension in the cold war, but so far there is no reason to believe that the conflict will get out of control.

The New York Civil Liberties Union started a drive yesterday to stop the practice by many employers of asking prospective employes whether they have been arrested.

A defendant in the alleged $50,000 parking-meter bribe plot suggested yesterday possible prejudice by State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich. The justice sharply rejected the charge and refused to disqualify himself from presiding at the long-pending trial.

Brohi of Pakistan said in a lecture here tonight.
The eight City Councilmen from Manhattan were summoned by Mayor Wagner yesterday to meet in City Hall at 11 A.M. on Feb. 16 to elect a Borough President of Manhattan.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- This is not a town where people speak wistfully of snows of yesteryears, but they go on at length about yesteryear's barbecues, when outdoor cooking was a practical necessity rather than a social event.

Sweden's top hockey player has a weekly television show, hockey sticks bear his name, and his picture graces cartons of milk. But Sven (Tumba) Johansson, the player, is an amateur who earns $50,000 a year.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 8 -- The original manuscript of "The Heroic Adventures of M. Boudin" by William Makepeace Thackeray, translated from his "somewhat inaccurate French," as the author put it, has been acquired by Syracuse University.

I recently witnessed a mass purse-snatching on the subway by six youths, ranging in age from 19 to 22 years. The way in which it was carried out brought terror to every passenger, and I am still in a mild state of shock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Communications Workers of America is preparing to attack the community wage policy followed by the Bell Telephone System.

ATHENS, Feb. 8 -- Formal contacts between the Eastern Orthodox Church and the Roman Catholic Church will be resumed soon for the first time since 1438, when an abortive attempt was made to heal the breach between the two.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. (UPI) -- The state legislatures have begun to send to Congress demands for a constitutional amendment to overturn the Supreme Court's "one man, one vote" decision of last June on legislative districts.

Brumbaugh, executive vice president and treasurer of Time, Inc., and Don Taylor, president of the Metropolitan New York Printing Industries.
