JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 8 -- Foreign Minister Subandrio said today that the current lull in the Indonesian-Malaysian conflict was a favorable moment for renewing negotiations for a political settlement.
TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes urged the Legislature today to confine its reapportionment efforts to the Senate. He said he saw no justification for reapportionment of the Assembly.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 10 -- Major engagements were reported at two points near the strategic air base at Danang today after a battle 50 miles east of Saigon cost the life of one American and wounded 12 others.

DETROIT, Feb. 9 -- A Federal grand jury indicted Mayor Orville L. Hubbard of suburban Dearborn today on a charge of denying equal protection of the state laws to a man whose home had been attacked by a mob.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Twenty-five French impressionist and postimpressionist paintings were sold tonight for $1,425,750 in one of the largest and most glittering art auctions in Palm Beach history.
To India, so rich in magnificent, ancient temples and vast quantities of sculpture, the collection on exhibition today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art represents a tiny, if important, sampling.
Professional football is doing better than ever at the box office here.
The climate for new issues in the municipal bond market con-with many of the calendar's estimated $40 million in offerings more than half sold, underwriters said.

A sharp break in soybean futures prices sent four deliveries down the daily permissible limit of 10 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. It was the sharpest setback in the commodity in 16 months.
GENEVA, Feb. 9 -- Steel consumption may drop sharply unless steps are taken to improve the properties of the metal, according to a study by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

A year ago last fall, Young Rubicam, Inc., parted company with Bert and Harry Piel and with the beer those amiable comedians sold -- or maybe didn't sell. And as far as beer is concerned, Y. R. has been dry ever since.

Prodigal sons return home from Holy Cross and St. Bonaventure for tonight's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. The Bonnies play Iona in the 7 P.M. opener, with Holy Cross opposing New York University in the second game.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 -- A Wall Street lawyer, Orison S. Marden of Scarsdale, N.Y., was nominated today to head the American Bar Association in 1966-67.
ROME, Feb. 9 -- An unexpected storm left up to a foot of snow in Rome's streets today, paralyzing the normal life of the city.

Eighty city-owned properties were sold at the monthly auction held by the Department of Real Estate yesterday at the Statler Hilton Hotel. The parcels were sold for a total of $1,298,755. The total minimum, or "upset," price of the 80 parcels was $963,500.

CATANIA, Sicily, Feb. 8 -- Nearly three-fourths of the new industry established in Sicily in 10 years of intensive development effort is concentrated in the 35 miles of seacoast between this busy commercial port and the ancient city of Syracuse to the south.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI) -- About 3,000 members of United Steelworkers locals in Puerto Rico were prevented from voting in the union election today because they received bundles of campaign literature instead of ballots, a union official reported.
The Republic Steel Corporation announced plans yesterday to build a $75 million cold strip roiling mill and related facilities at the company's Cleveland plant.
Charges of unfair labor practices have been filed against the International Longshoremen's Association by New York employers.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 9 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led a march against Negro voter apathy here today and apathy won.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Feb. 9 -- Sightseers came from near and far today, most of them with binoculars, in a futile attempt to view the salvage operation of the Eastern Air Lines DC-7B that plunged into the sea about six miles south of here.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- A bill was introduced in the State Senate today calling for the formation of a temporary state commission to study and make recommendations on New York's laws on divorce, annulments, separations and "matrimonial actions generally."

Hans Schmidt-Isserstedt, the German conductor who has been heard here just once before, in 1961, returned last night with the Philadelphia Orchestra in one of that group's regular visits to Philharmonic Hail. He was, once again, straightforward, knowledgeable, steady as a rock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Acting Attorney General Nicholas deB, Katzenbach called today for quick approval of a constitutional amendment that would permit the Vice President to take over the duties of a disabled President.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 -- A sweeping critique that was interpreted by some observers as a strong hint of the way the nation's merchant marine policies should be revised was delivered here today by Nicholas Johnson, the Federal Maritime Administrator.
The eight City Councilmen from Manhattan will in a few days elect a successor to Edward R. Dudley as president of the borough.
Immediate salary increases and fringe benefits totaling $18 million were assured for 42,500 uniformed policemen, firemen and correction officers yesterday by the City Council.

THE National Broadcasting Company's "White Paper" series turned the spotlight last night on miscarriages of justice that had sent innocent men to prison, including defective practices of police and prosecutors that led to denials of elementary rights to the accused.
By the end of 1965, New York will have 2,310,324 trees in its streets and parks, or about one tree for every four inhabitants.
DUBLIN, Feb. 9 -- Terence M. O'Neill, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, visited Dublin today to return the call of Prime Minister Sean F. Lemass to Belfast last month.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Thirty-five days after convening, the Legislature completed its organizational chores this afternoon and adjourned until Monday.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- The 11 countries that put together an emergency package of credits to save the British pound last November have agreed informally to renew the measure intact before it starts to expire two weeks from now.
LOGAN, UTAH, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Wayne Estes, Utah State basketball star, was electrocuted in a freakish accident last night, only two hours after setting a school scoring record.

A $3.5 million mortgage has been obtained for the Imperial Square office building in Hempstead, L.I. The loan was arranged for 20 years at 5 1/2 per cent interest by Hubbard, Westervelt Mottelay of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- High Administration sources explained today that President Johnson had not foreclosed Federal participation in development of the lower Hudson River as a national scenic waterway.
The sea yielded bodies and debris but no clue yesterday to the cause of the crash of an Eastern Air Lines plane off Jones Beach early Monday night. Eighty-four persons died in the crash.
Governor Rockefeller went before the state's town leaders yesterday to ask support for his proposals to increase aid to education and to eliminate pollution of the waters.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, just retired as the Air Force Chief of Staff, is listed among the distinguished group expected here for next Sunday's 500-mile stock-car race.

" Sally and Sam," a romantic comedy series about a young couple in Manhattan, is tentatively scheduled for its debut next fail on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. According to initial planning, the show will be presented from 9:30 to 10 P.M. each Monday with Cynthia Pepper and Gary Lockwood in the principal roles.

Vitriol without a chaser was the drink for 123 Village Vanguard customers who paid $1.50 each Monday night to hear a panel chat on art and politics. The audience, liberals all and most of them white, sat in a daze while LeRoi Jones, playwright, and Archie Shepp, jazz musician, both Negroes, pronounced them guilty of racial injustice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The House approved today the Administration's bill to repeal the requirement for a 25 per cent gold backing for Federal Reserve deposits. The roll-call vote was 300 to 82, with Republicans helping to pass the measure.
Mr. and Mrs. Eugene McDermott have donated $200,000 to Southern Methodist University for the establishment of the Margo Jones Memorial Theater in Dallas.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 9 (AP) -- A new trial was ordered today for Harlis Miller, a 35-year-old handyman serving a life sentence for the rape-slaying of a Westport matron.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Johnson met this afternoon with a group of Congressional leaders to discuss measures he is considering to decrease the balance of payments deficit.
VIENNA, Feb. 9 -- The official Czechoslovak press agency, Ceteka, distributed today a denial that the detention of the Most Rev. Josef Beran at Radvanov, near Mlada Vozice, amounted to imprisonment.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Britain will send two Cabinet Ministers to Rhodesia for 10 days this month to sound out the African colony's views on independence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, gave the Senate today information indicating that Representative Emanuel Celler's New York law firm had violated professional ethics in splitting a $10.000 legal fee with Robert G. Baker.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Malcolm X, an American black nationalist leader, was refused entry by France today. He returned here and said defiantly, "I never go to any place where I am not wanted."

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Feb. 9 -- The Government is seeking to block the publication of a book on the Lavon affair written by an Israeli journalist at the request of former Premier David Ben-Gurion.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Mary Ann Eisel, 18-year-old defending champion from St. Louis, had the most difficult opener of the leading players today in the national women's indoor tennis championships.

The letter of two history instructors at City College (published Feb. 5) suggests a conflict between a dramatic expansion of higher educational opportunities for Negroes, Puerto Ricans and others, and the maintenance of quality education.

Ever since it became known that the fourth quarter of 1964 had seen a serious deterioration in the nation's balance of payments, the Administration has been sending up a bewildering series of trial balloons about its intentions. They are proving a poor substitute for action.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 9 -- A United States business leader declared here today that "Communism plus cost accounting equals capitalism." He said the "highwater mark of Communism, as an economic philosophy, is past" and even the idea of a mixed economy has begun "to ebb."

ABOARD THE COAST GUARD CUTTER MACKINAC off Jones Beach, Feb. 9 -- Beneath a crimson half-moon, the sea shimmered in an eerie apricot hue as Coast Guardsmen picked up the wreckage of the Eastern Air Lines plane that crashed last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright proposed today that $1 billion worth of nonconvertible foreign currencies owned by the United States be used to establish private binational educational foundations abroad.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 -- This was a day for heroes at Saigon Airport, Nine dead American soldiers were honored and their bodies sent home. On the other side of the field crowds and a brass band welcomed the South Vietnamese pilots who bombed Communist North Vietnam yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States has adopted policy of greater flexibility in any future retaliatory strikes against North Vietnam, officials reported today.
Cardinal Spellman will receive the Humanitarian Award of the Reform Jewish Appeal at a dinner next month.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 10 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin announced in Hanoi today that agreement had been reached on measures to strengthen North Vietnam's defense potential, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

The Hudson, one of the most majestic of America's rivers, flows to the Sea through a valley that is being increasingly ravaged. The long fight to block the despoliation of Storm King Mountain by a Consolidated Edison power plant is now in the hands of the Federal Power Commission in Washington. At the very least, the battle has served the useful purpose of arousing public indignation over the trend.
TAMPA, Fla. -- The two gray jet fighters with glistening white undersides looked like prowling sharks as they swept in, low and close together, lazily nearing the speed of sound.
PARIS, Feb. 9 -- Capt. Edward Molyneux has decided to accept private customers in his newly opened fashion house here although he had originally dismissed the prospect.
THE Moscow Art was Chekhov's theater, and he was its playwright. The mutual affinity persists.
The battle between Macy's and National Distillers and Chemical Corporation over the sale of liquor by Macy's at cut-rate prices was waged on two fronts yesterday.

NOGALES, Mexico -- The border towns between the United States and Mexico are such an earthy mixture of the friendly, the garish and the rude that they must count among the last outposts where a visitor would anticipate a restaurant of quality and substance.

HONG KONG, Feb. 9 -- The Government of Hong Kong has asked the Bank of England to ship here by air-freight a supply of sterling bank notes. The request came in the face of a critical shortage of local currency following a heavy run on a number of Chinese barks.

MIAMI, Feb. 9 -- Hail to All gave a thrilling demonstration of stretch running to win the feature event on today's program. Coming "out of nowhere" in the closing phase, Mrs. Ben Cohen's Florida-bred scored by a half-length over Flag Raiser with Good Trouble third.
Samuel H. Woolley, president and chief executive officer of the Bank of New York, told a brief and informal gathering of stockholders yesterday he "looked for a year of improvement."
After 11 years of close supervision of its daily life the Port of New York is still not ready yet to conduct its own operations, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor said here yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- A convocation of world leaders to discuss the requirements for word peace and cooperation will open in the General Assembly Hall Feb. 17 with an address by Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey.
REA Express and Seven Arts Productions have joined in a project to bring sound and sight entertainment to bus, train and plane passenger.

In the ornate lamp-lit trial room at Police Headquarters, the testimony yesterday was about a 22-year-old detective, praised for "devotion to duty," who had worked three hours overtime to solve a murder and caught a suspect.
Butler Aviation Co., Inc., a privately owned concern, said yesterday that it had acquired a "substantial stock interest" in the Hazeltine Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- This may not be a bad time to take a hard look at the nature and mathematics of the war in Vietnam.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Britain is expected to seek a new loan from the International Monetary Fund some time this spring, probably after the April budget, to refinance shortterm emergency credits from 11 nations.
Three firemen were injured yesterday in a two-alarm fire in a three-story building in lower Manhattan. Traffic in the area was disrupted for an hour as 90 firemen fought the blaze.

Michael W. McCarthy, who started in the grocery business and now is head of the world's biggest brokerage concern, offered some free advice yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange on its package plan for raising fees.
NEWARK, Feb. 9 -- The Newark City Council unanimously approved today a municipal budget of $78,371,448 for 1965, a reduction of more than $1,373,000 from the 1964 figure.

IN HIS introduction to a forthcoming anthology, "To Catch a Spy," Eric Ambler suggests that a definition of a spy story might be "a story in which the central character is a secret agent of one sort or another." But he quickly points out that by this definition a number of celebrated tales of espionage, among them his own, would not qualify as spy stories and could not have been included in his anthology.
Stock prices were firm in selective trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

BONN -- When one asks 89-year-old Konrad Adenauer who was the greatest man he ever knew, the former Chancellor hands from his desk a signed snapshot of Foster Dulles. "There," says Adenauer. "He thought clearly.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 -- The National Lutheran Council has approved the initiation of formal ecumenical discussions with representatives of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Johnson and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. discussed today broad new guarantees sought by Dr. King to secure the right to vote for Negroes.
The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday operating revenues of $196,104,000 for 1964, compared with $182,533,000 a year earlier.

" We Jews and Jesus," by Dr. Samuel Sandmel of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, will be published by Oxford University Press on March 11. In his conclusion, he writes: "For almost eighteen centuries Judaism and Christianity faced each other as enemies.

Nassau County's three towns -- Hempstead, North Hempstead and Oyster Bay -- announced jointly yesterday that they would adopt the state's Suburban Town Law "to promote administrative and financial efficiency." Twenty-six other towns in the state already have adopted the law, enacted in Albany three years ago.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Communist China warned the United States today that the Johnson Administration will not be able to control "the time, place and scale of the war" in South Vietnam if it expands the war in Vietnam.
A midtown druggist on trial on a charge of supplying barbiturates to teen-agers in the Flushing-Jamaica section of Queens was freed yesterday by a three-judge Criminal Court.

Now that President Johnson's Medicare plan is coming up for action by Confess, it is important for the public to realize that it does not provide for payment of physicians' fees nor for drugs used outside the hospital.
Colgate University surprised Columbia with a blistering display of shooting and won a 67-62 decision over the Lions last night at the Columbia gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A bill to authorize the Coast Guard to spend $109,250,000 on vessels, aircraft and additional facilities was introduced in the Senate today.
BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The co-favorites, Boston University and Boston College, scored 5-4 overtime victories last night in the opening round of the 13th annual Beanpot hockey tourney.
The printers' union broke off collective bargaining talks with the Publishers Association of New York yesterday and declared that negotiations for a new working contract were deadlocked.

The largest utility issue of the year, Southern California Edison Company's $60 million first and refunding mortgage bonds, were awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by First Boston Corp. and Dean Witter Co.
A new non-woven material made of continuous polyester fiber has been developed by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

DAYTON BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Three drivers, including the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing 1964 rookie of the year, Doug Cooper of Gastonia, N.C., qualified today for the Daytona 500, to be held Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The United States sold $1 billion worth of military equipment to Britain and Australia today, most of it warplanes for Britain.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 9 -- The European Common Market opened today a new series of key trade negotiations with Nigeria, black Africa's most affluent nation.
TEANECK, N.J., Feb. 9 -- The advocates of integration won a decisive victory tonight over the supporters of a neighborhood school system.

TOKYO, Feb. 9 -- Japan appealed to the United States today for an exemption from the broadened application of the interest-equalization tax that officials here expect to be announced soon by the United States.

Acting Borough President Earl Brown and a group of Manhattan Councilmen agreed yesterday to ask Mayor Wagner to restore or add to his executive capital budget 14 items proposed at recent community meetings.

The National Association of Home Builders will conduct a three-day course in Omaha, Neb., on management and construction techniques. The course will begin March 4 and will be limited to the first 150 applicants.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Traudl Hecher of Austria won the women's giant slalom in the five-nation European Alpine Cup ski meet today.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market recovered yesterday and more than made up the losses incurred Monday when prices declined on news of the crisis in Vietnam.

When the last phases of the marathon battle over featherbedding in train crews were settled at the White House in April, President Johnson expressed hope that the railroads were entering a period of enduring labor-management peace. Dozens of strike threats have erupted since then, but the track at last seems clear for fulfillment of the President's forecast.
Robert V. Roosa, who has just completed four years as an Under Secretary of the Treasury, took a look into the future yesterday and saw some things that may pose problems for his successor.
MONTREAL, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- By the time the ailing Bobby Hull returns to the Chicago Black Hawk line-up the National Hockey League record of 50 goals which he shares, may be out of his reach.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Feb. 9 -- Western diplomats are working for the resumption of disarmament negotiations in Geneva by the middle of March. They see a growing urgency for measures to prevent the further spread of nuclear weapons.
The Sheepshead Bay piers may be lighted by the city to thwart midwinter marauders who have damaged Brooklyn's sport fishing fleet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Federal recognition of the historic character of the Bowne House in Flushing, Queens, was proposed today by New York's two Senators, Jacob K. Javits and Robert F. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Dr. Luther L. Terry, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, said tonight there were grounds for hope that a brigade of killing and crippling diseases could be eliminated from America "well before 1985."

Barry Kramer, New York University's All-America basketball star of two years ago, became a New York Knickerbocker yesterday. He will make his first appearance as a Knick here Saturday against the Boston Celtics.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- Britain announced today a pledge of $11.75 million for United Nations development and technical-assistance work, an increase of $1.75 million over her last contribution.
Eastern's Flight 663 left Kennedy International Airport last night with at least three passengers who said they were glad they were leaving New York a day late.
WASHINGTON, Feb 9 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon believes that the use of tax-free municipal bonds to finance industrial development has become too widespread and ought to be stopped.
Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" will be given by the Metropolitan Opera tonight at 8.

Richie Guerin and Harry Gallatin, one-time teammates as Knicks and more recently player and coach on the Hawks, met as rival coaches at Madison Square Garden last night and the victory went to Guerin in thought-provoking manner.
The stock market, which was shaken to a decline Monday by the tremors of the Vietnam crisis, marched back uphill yesterday to where it had started from before the selloff.

FLAMINGO, Fla., Feb. 9 -- After visiting the northern part of Everglades National Park the other day, this visitor came down the road toward Flamingo for some fishing. As the car went past West Lake, two things were seen out of the corner of an eye.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9 -- The Government of Argentina was understood today to be convinced that the United States was stalling aid disbursements to this country as a maneuver to force a settlement with American oil companies whose contracts were canceled last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- With a major report pending on the feasibility of abandoning the military draft, voluntary enlistments in the armed forces have declined sharply.
The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, San Francisco, reported yesterday sales of $662,242,000 for 1964, the highest in its 94-year history and up 7 per cent from volume of $616,394,000 the year before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- John T. Connor, the new Secretary of Commerce, hopes to establish closer relations with, the Business Council, an organization of top corporate executives that had strong differences with Mr. Connor's predecessor, Luther H. Hodges.

SAIGON, Feb. 9 (UPI) -- The first planeloads of American wives and children left South Vietnam today as ordered by President Johnson. A total of 1.819 dependents of American servicemen and civilians will be flown out over 10 days.
Four vice presidents of Needham, Harper Steers, Inc., have been elected directors of the agency, according to an announcement yesterday by William E. Steers, chairman.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Happy Hairston, a rookie, broke the game wide open in the last quarter tonight as the Cincinnati Royals beat Boston, 134 -- 121, in a National Basketball Association game.

The annual Russian Mi-Careme Dinner Dance for the benefit of war invalids and needy members of the Association of Former Imperial Russian Cavalry and Horse Artillery will be held on Feb. 25 at the St. Regis Roof.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 9 (UPI) -- Bill Melchionni made five free throw conversions in the final two minutes of play tonight to help Villanova to a 52-43 victory over St. John's at the Villanova Field House.

IF any skeptics still remain from those who could not understand how the Cleveland Browns could have routed the Baltimore Colts in the championship play-off late last December, they need trouble their empty heads no longer. The evidence of Brownie superiority is at hand, and it is so convincing that even the most bemused expert has to admit that the better team got precisely what it was entitled to get.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Governor Rockefeller appealed to the Legislature today to take immediate action on his plan to save the commuter service of the New Haven Railroad.

Four officials of the Continental Can Company were among the 84 persons killed Monday night in the Eastern Airlines crash. They were going to Richmond to begin an inspection tour of the company's plants in the South.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 9 -- The Louisville Board of Aldermen approved an ordinance tonight prohibiting racial discrimination in employment practices.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 9 -- The Bermuda Industrial Union tonight asked all strikers in Bermuda who have left their jobs in sympathy with a stoppage by electrical workers to return to work tomorrow.

WARSAW, Feb. 9 -- The trains from the country generally arrive in the early morning. Consequently, the lines of country people begin forming outside the United States Embassy about 6 A.M. There the people wait patiently, in their Sunday best, often with packed lunches and dinners, until the embassy opens at 8 A.M.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The Minister of Aviation, Roy Jenkins, told the House of Commons today that Britain could no longer go it, alone in the development of new weapons systems.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- The Soviet Union has redeployed its troops in East Germany, moving them from areas close to the East-West German frontier to positions inside the country where they can operate in depth.
Treasury and corporate bond prices held steady yesterday as the market awaited President Johnson's balance of payments message.

Whitey Ford and Al Downing, two of baseball s best left-handed pitchers and half the regular starting staff of the New York Yankees, will be making more money than ever in 1965 despite certain difficulties in 1964, and they hope to repay the club in victories.

The designation of John P. De Santis as acting president and chief executive officer of the Federation Bank and Trust Company was announced by directors yesterday after their regular monthly meeting. Your editorial [Feb. 28] on the German war trials seems based more on a spirit of petty vindictiveness than of meaningful justice. The German people cannot forget the Nazi period, nor can there be anything constructive in prolonging this national expiation.

To the Editor: The Times is to be congratulated for its excellent news story by Charles Mohr (Feb. 8) in which are exposed some of the fallacies behind Secretary McNamara's official defense of our most recent series of air attacks on North Vietnam.

Eleven children 12 years of age or younger lost their lives in fires in this city during the first 20 days of this year, compared with eight during the entire month of January, 1964, according to the Greater New York Safety Council.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt charged today that loose management and inept investing practices by the New York Higher Education Corporation were costing the state hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.

EL OBEID, the Sudan, Feb. 10 (Reuters) -- Mounted policemen spurred their horses into a thick crowd today and lashed out with whips to push it back only a few feet from Britain's Queen Elizabeth II, bringing momentary panic while sheiks and tribesmen paraded.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The passport of Jacques Nevard, correspondent of The New York Times in Pakistan, was returned today by the Karachi police on the order of the West Pakistan High Court after Mr. Nevard put up a surety of about $2,000.

The Union Free School District No. 4 in the town of Huntington, N.Y., awarded $6,059,000 of bonds yesterday to an underwriting group led by the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company and Spencer Trask Co.
Beekman-Downtown Hospital, which traces its development in lower Manhattan from a tiny building and two horse-drawn ambulances, is seeking funds for a $9 million expansion program.
James B. Carey, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, told members of the union's executive board yesterday that he opposed a merger with the United Automobile Workers.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Following is the text of a letter written by United States Senator Robert F. Kennedy to the Democratic leaders of the Legislature. Copies were sent to Joseph Zaretzki of Manhattan, the Temporary President of the Senate (majority leader), and to Anthony J. Travia of Brooklyn, the Assembly Speaker. They were received here this morning.
A possible new witness in the second murder trial of Alvin L. Mitchell may put him near the scene of the crime on the night of the fatal stabbing of Barbara Kralik, a 15-year-old Queens schoolgirl.
ROME, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A White Paper containing documents on relations between the Vatican and Nazi Germany is nearing publication, Vatican officials said tonight.

SELMA, Ala., Feb. 10 -- Sheriff James G. Clark and a group of deputies with night sticks and electric cattle prods led 165 Negro demonstrators, all children and teen-agers, on a forced march into the Dallas County countryside today.

A rather brash and driving Lucia, flecked with energy, was heard at the Metropolitan Opera last night. The production afforded Met fans their first hearing this season of Roberta Peters in the title role and Ettore Bastianini as Ashton.

The reorganization of 267 Brooklyn elementary and junior high schools into 54 "educational complexes," or clusters, was proposed yesterday by a consultant to the Board of Education to help correct racial imbalance in the borough's schools.

Three 90-minute dramas based on the United Nations, which were to be televised this season as part of a series of five, have been postponed until next fall. The first was presented Dec. 28 and the second ("Who Has Seen the Wind?") will be televised Feb. 19 by the American Broadcasting Company.
The Consolidated Aluminum Corporation announced yesterday price increases ranging from 1 to 4 cents a pound for most of its aluminum sheet products. The higher prices are effective immediately.

Any attempt to use gold alone as the basis for international credit "would seem to insure world deflation on a catastrophic scale," United States Ambassador Adlai E. Stevenson told 1,200 bankers here yesterday.

S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., increased its profits four-fold in the six months ended Jan. 23, and predicted operating earnings of $1.5 million for the full fiscal year, compared with a small loss a year ago.

To the Editor: The whole unsettling episode involving George Whitmore's alleged confession of the murder of two young women and his subsequent clearance, by the District Attorney's office demands a full investigation and complete disclosure as to the manner in which the police elicited the confession. [Editorial Jan. 30.]
The World's Fair Corporation agreed yesterday afternoon to go along with the fair's exhibitors in setting up a "comprehensive" program for the 1965 season.
The city's breweries agreed yesterday to integrate Negroes and Puerto Ricans into the industry's permanent work force.
The City Planning Commission "strongly urged" the Board of Estimate and City Council yesterday to reject Mayor Wagner's proposal for a parking garage under Madison Square Park.

A 28-year-old man was convicted yesterday in Criminal Court, Brooklyn, for handing out anonymous political leaflets in last fall's campaign. The New York Civil Liberties Union announced immediately its intention to appeal the decision as unconstitutiona.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York believes that the nation's economy got off to a very strong start this year.
The New York University basketball team, poised and polished, defeated scrappy Holy Cross 84 -- 73, last night in a brilliantly played finale of a collegiate double-header at Madison Square Garden.
TEAM contests spread over a period of several months are becoming increasingly popular, and the Greater New York Bridge Association is considering scheduling such an event for next winter.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Women and a few men carrying placards picketed the White House today demanding a negotiated peace in Vietnam.
BONN, Feb. 10 -- The Social Democratic Opposition accused President de Gaulle in Parliament today of trying to drive the United States out of Europe.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Ken Wharram scored twice tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-2 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game. It was the Hawks' fourth victory in their last five games.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Controller Arthur Levitt proposed today appointment of a bipartisan state commission to formulate long-range plans for operation of the Long Island Rail Road.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The House today swiftly passed and sent to the Senate a bill to cover the expenses of servicemen's dependents evacuated from hazardous areas. The measure was made retroactive to cover families who were rushed out of South Vietnam last weekend.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., in 1964 realized the highest sales and earnings in its 37-year history. These were supported by fourth-quarter results, which exceeded any quarter on record.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- A top Democratic spokesman on fiscal matters predicted today that the Legislature would enact a revenue and spending program without a state sales tax.

A state supreme court jury in the Bronx awarded $120,000 today to the widow of a clothing manufacturer who was killed May 10, 1961, in a fire escape accident while he inspected a newly rented factory in Peekskill.

IT'S enough to break an author's heart -- in the case of "Diamond Orchid," two authors' hearts. They document their story with a multiplicity of details about their heroine's life, and their play perversely remains lifeless.
It was coming-out day in the data processing industry yesterday as both Honeywell, Inc., and the International Business Machines Corporation announced new computer systems.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- The General Assembly approved plans today for a $7 million new home for the United Nations International School. It would be built within the United Nations enclave on the East River.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Physicians who helped to draft President Johnson's plan for a national effort to combat heart disease, cancer and stroke called today for a larger start than the Administration has proposed.
Eight clergymen were arrested early last night for conducting a sit-in at the Board of Education offices of Dr. Calvin E. Gross, Superintendent of Schools.

HARTFORD, Feb. 10 -- A survey by the bureau of research of the State Board of Education has found that a majority of school superintendents in the state believe there has been a big increase in teen-age drinking in the last 10 years.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The Government may appeal a Federal court's ruling that jurors should not be sent home overnight while they are deliberating a felony case.
LONGVIEW, Wash., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The captain of a Philippine freighter whose crewmen walked off Monday accusing him of tyranny gave up his command last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A bill requiring Congressional districts to be compact and nearly equal in population was approved today by a House Judiciary subcommittee.

Ralph Berger, who was convicted in December of conspiracy to pay a bribe to obtain a liquor license for the Playboy Club and a Second Avenue cafe, was ordered yesterday to answer questions by a grand jury that is continuing an investigation into scandals involving the State Liquor Authority.
The nation's electric power production rose 12.3 per cent in the week ended Feb. 6 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- A Republican Congressman, saying that Mr. Jenkins was well enough to attend Washington parties, accused Democrats today of favoritism in not forcing the former White House aide to testify.

MIAMI, Feb. 10 -- What a Treat, George D. Widener's home-bred filly, took the lead at the turn and managed to fight off a closing bid by Vassar Grad to win the $35,400 Mimosa Stakes today. The crowd "liked" What a Treat so much that she returned only $3.20 for $2 after doing the 1 1/8 miles in 1:53 1-5.
The Johnson Administration's new program for stemming the outflow of funds abroad will have positive results, but many authorities doubt that they will be positive enough.
New York State's unique law stipulating adultery as sole grounds for divorce has withstood revision since 1787.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 9 -- Terence Rattigan, embarking on his 30th year as a playwright and screenwriter, disclosed yesterday that he would write the screenplay for a British-Soviet motion picture to be financed by the Soviet Government and by British film interests.

The slugging match in Vietnam continues; the war escalates; the danger grows; the goal of peace recedes. Just in one day -- yesterday -- many Americans were killed when an enlisted men's barracks was blown up by Vietcong terrorists, while in the north, in a pitched battle that began on Monday, Vietcong guerrillas wiped out five companies of South Vietnamese troops.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 -- United States troops at Pleiku have increased the number of their guard posts to avoid a repetition of the Vietcong infiltration that inflicted heavy losses on United States soldiers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Congress yielded today to President Johnson's appeal for a free hand to use surplus food shipments to the United Arab Republic as an instrument of United States foreign policy.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 10 (UPI) -- Barry Goldwater found his luck still running the wrong way today.

The Henry Street Settlement, which has led social protests on the Lower East Side since 1893, found itself on the other side of a picket line yesterday as about 90 of its 100 employes struck in a dispute over union membership.
The Balance of Payments Message had little impact on trading in the nation's stock and bond markets yesterday.

" Burke Marshall, former Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department, has been offered the job as Dean of the Yale Law School by Kingman Brewster Jr., president of the university.
NEWARK, Feb. 10 -- The Essex County prosecutor moved today to set aside the conviction of a man who has already served 18 months for a robbery he did not commit.

The County Trust Company of White Plains, N.Y., with 52 banking offices in Westchester, Rockland and Putnam counties, is planning to expand its banking interests to Sullivan and Orange counties under terms of a merge proposal announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Governor Rockefeller started at the top today in trying to persuade the Federal Government to give New York State millions of dollars of new financial aid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Johnson called on American business and banking today for a broad new voluntary effort to cut down their lending and investing abroad to eliminate the deficit in the nation's international payments.
ROME, Feb. 10 -- Pope Paul VI promoted three monsignors and a priest today to the rank of titular bishop less than two weeks before they and 23 other prelates will be created cardinals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -The Government told major banks and corporations today that it would scrutinize closely and often their loans and investments overseas.
A father and son who pleaded guilty last Wednesday to ticket scalping paid fines totaling $1,250 in Criminal Court yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- "The commercial banking system has never been in such strong condition." James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, asserted here today.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- President de Gaulle appealed again today for the end of foreign intervention and a negotiated peace in South Vietnam.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union is in the midst of a campaign for higher manufacturing standards and more attractive designs in industry.

HAVANA, Feb. 10 -- Communist Cuba's exclusion from an international baseball competition in Colombia has unleashed a huricane of protests here in which politic and sports mix against a background of nationalism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The sound of Vietcong explosives at Quinhon echoed through Washington today and posed for President Johnson one of the sharpest dilemmas of his Administration.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -Britain dispatched more warships and troops to Southeast Asia today to bolster Malaysia's defenses in its conflict with Indonesia.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 11 -- The Government announced last night that Premier Kosygin would fly to Pyongyang, capital of North Korea, today on the invitation of the North Korean Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- By standing firm on his program to eliminate certain conspicuously wasteful operations by the Veterans Administration and the Department of Agriculture, President Johnson overcame two of the most powerful lobbies in this country.
A blind woman who had charged that she was refused service in a restaurant because she was accompanied by her guide dog, withdrew her complaint yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 10 -- It was "unions" day at Bethlehem Steel Corporation's shipyard here as the Seamar the fourth of six large, fast C-4 troopships being converted into cargo carriers for Calmar Steamship Corporation was christened today.

The $30-million-a-year bridal-gown industry is turning to sociology to cure its sales head-aches.

There is no longer any excuse for the 4,000,000 or more cases of measles that develop yearly among American children, a specialist said here yesterday.
The radar aboard the Israeli luxury liner Shalom did not perform normally during the quarter hour before the liner collided with a Norwegian tanker, the liner's second mate said here yesterday.
The New York Retail, Wholesale sale and Department Store Union opened a legal battle yesterday to force the state to raise the minimum wage paid to 177,000 workers in the retail trades.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 10 -- The office of the Public Prosecutor in Belgrade has ordered an injunction against sale of a literary monthly on the charge that it insulted the honor" of the Soviet Union, it was announced today.

The nip-and-tuck nature of the election contest in the giant United Steelworkers of America almost certainly means that the outcome will be enshrouded in litigation for many months. Whether David J. WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, now commander of the United States Pacific Fleet, was named Supreme Allied Commander in the Atlantic today.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 -- Steelworkers bolting through the pre-dawn January cold and darkness after working the third shift in the heat of open-hearth furnaces were startled to see a group of the union's leaders standing at the plant gate.

The election of Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz as chairman of the board of directors of the newly established International Synagogue at the Kennedy International Airport, sponsored by the New York Board of Rabbis, was announced yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 10 -- Beginning in the spring, all Greenwich residents who will be 65 years of age or older by next Sept. 15 are to be granted free use of the community's three beaches, ferry service to one of the beaches, lockers and bathhouses, tennis courts and the new municipal golf course.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union extended its campaign against Trofim D. Lysenko's discredited biological theories today to the Academy of Agricultural Sciences.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 10 -- Mississippi's attorney general gave the United States Civil Rights Commission assurances here today that state leaders were trying to cope with the civil rights issue, "free from demagoguery."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, reported today there was virtual assurance that congress would authorize a study of the possibility of keeping the Great Lakes open for year-round shipping.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- European impatience with the continuing deficit in the United States' international payments was only partially satisfied by President Johnson's new program to wipe it out.

DETROIT, Feb. 10 -- Three leading automobile companies, responding to growing concern about auto safety, today announced plans to install rear seat belts in their new cars.
Bankers and businessmen reacted cautiously, though generally favorably, to President Johnson's Balance of Payments Message to Congress yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 10 -William J. Strawbridge Jr. of Pocantico Hills, a son-in-law of Governor Rockefeller, was elected president of the Urban League of Westchester County tonight by the directors. He succeeds Walter H. Liebman of Rye.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Johnson's nomination of Nicholas deB. Katzenbach to be Attorney General.

THE discussion of community antenna television systems on last night's installment of "Broadcasting Forum" was an amusing example of a professional in courtroom appearances stealing the show.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The New York World's Fair has financial troubles mainly because it is grossly overbuilt and poorly managed, according to the man who directed the successful world's fair in Seattle.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Lawyers for Schenley Industries, Inc., will seek an emergency hearing before the United States Court of Appeals tomorrow in their bid to proceed with a stock purchase offer that was scheduled to expire at 3 P.M. tomorrow.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 11 -- Vietcong terrorists last night blew up a four-story building housing American enlisted men in the coastal city of Quinhon, 207 miles northeast of Saigon.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, one of the Soviet Union's top World War II military commanders, emerged today from the obscurity to which former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev consigned him in 1957.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 1; (AP) -- Mrs. Carol Hanks Aucamp arrived late by plane from St. Louis, but went on to win two matches today and reach the quarter-finals of the National Women's indoor tennis championships at the Longwood covered courts.
The American Football League pledged yesterday not to sign college players to professional contracts until after the final games -- including bowl games -- of their "senior" seasons.

William E. Hutton, senior partner of W.E. Hutton Co., 14 Wall Street, has been named treasurer of the Music Theater of Lincoln Center, Inc. He succeeds Robert J. Hoguet Jr., now president of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Retail sales dipped by 1 per cent in January following a 5 per cent spurt in December, the Commerce Department reported today.
A DEFT way for a woman to annihilate an adversary is to remark with seeming candor, "She has no taste."

Leaders of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, approved a budget of more than $600,000, yesterday to carry out special projects in medical research, nursing and vocational education in Israel.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- The General Assembly held a 35-minute nonvoting session today and put off major decisions until Tuesday.

OTTAWA, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Finance Minister Walter L. Gordon said today that President Johnson's balance-of-payments measures presented Canada with no special difficulties but that Canada would not be left entirely untouched.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 -- The Armed Forces Council, which seized Government power Jan. 27, decided today to set up a "war cabinet."

HONG KONG, Feb. 10 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union flew to Peking after a warm farewell in Hanoi today. He was accorded the same lukewarm reception that the Chinese Communists gave him last Friday on a stopover on his way to North Vietnam.
Fog and heavy seas hampered the hunt yesterday for the fuselage of the Eastern Air Lines plane that plunged into the Atlantic Ocean off Jones Beach Monday night with a loss of 84 lives.
THREE young playwrights touched on the impossibilities of human communication at the Cherry Lane Theater last night and made the point, sometimes far too impressively.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 10 -- Premier Levi Eshkol disclosed tonight that the army's Hawk ground-to-air missiles were about to become operational at their defensive stations in Israel.
Stock prices retreated yesterday when news that the Communists had blown up a United States Army billet in South Vietnam touched off a wave of selling.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Administration opened its Capitol Hill drive today for a new immigration law, with Senate sponsors of the bill protesting that "scarecrows and red herrings" had been raised against it.

Alexander H. Cohen was named yesterday by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to produce the film version of "Baker Street," the musical based on the Sir Arthur Conan Doyle stories about Sherlock Holmes. Mr. Cohen's stage presentation will open next Tuesday night at the Broadway Theater.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Efforts by the United States to trim its balance-of-payments deficit were looked on with sympathy by the British, who have recently been trying to do the same thing.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- The French Cabinet was told today that the country's programs for military and civilian use of atomic energy were proceeding on schedule.
BANGKOK, Thailand. Feb. 10 -- More than 50 persons have been arrested in the last week in Thailand's northeastern provinces on suspicion of being Communist agents.

JACKELINE (JACKIE) DEVLIN, the 9-year-old daughter of Arthur Devlin, has become a ski jumper. The personable 60-pounder, her long, brown hair streaming behind her, achusses down the in-run on Lake Placid's 40-meter hill whenever conditions are suitable.

" Buddhism or Communism." by Ernst Benz, will be published by Doubleday on March 12. The author is professor of church and dogmatic history and director of the Ecumenical Institute at the University of Marburg, Germany.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -The deficit in the United States balance of international payments was $1.445 billion in the final quarter of 1964, the Commerce Department announced today.

TOKYO, Feb. 10 -- The top officials of the Tokyo Stock Exchange expressed confidence today that the drastic corrective measures taken to halt a long slump in the market were at last proving effective.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Johnson summoned the National Security Council today to discuss new Communist military successes against American and South Vietnamese troops, but gave no hint whether the United States would respond.
BONN, Feb. 10 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard has ordered a temporary halt in West German arms deliveries to Israel, qualified sources said tonight.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 10 -- Chris Reddington, a 6-foot-5-inch junior from Baldwin, L.I., scored 36 points today to break the field house record of 34 set by Rudy Milkey of Columbia in 1958 in leading Navy's basketball team to a convincing 94-75 victory over Long Island University.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- Richard M. Nixon renewed tonight his demand that President Johnson pour America's might from the air and sea on bases and lines that supply Communist forces in South Vietnam.

An increase of 2,033,000 barrels in the nation's stocks of gasoline in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend total supplies were 215,946,000 barrels, compared with 213,913,000 a week earlier and 203,132,000 a year ago.

The Federal Maritime Commission has been asked to investigate the agreements of two powerful steamship conferences whose practices are said to siphon Far East traffic from Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports for handling through West Coast ports.

Two tower floors totaling 10,400 square feet have been leased in the 32-story Saturday Evening Post Building at 641 Lexington Avenue at 54th Street.

The Explorers Club dedicated its new quarters last night as several hundred members toured the five-and-a-half-story Tudor-styled building at 46 East 70th Street. The club, which is more than 60 years old, was at 10 West 72d Street for three decades.

The New York Athletic Club indoor track and field meet will be staged at Madison Square Garden tonight with Valery Brumel in the high jump and Igor Ter-Ovanesyan out of the broad jump. In fact, there won't even be a men's broad jump.
The Parke-Bernet Galleries, the auction house that was acquired by Sotheby's of London in 1964, will lower its commissions for the sale of paintings, drawings and sculpture starting May 1.

DETROIT, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The New York Knickerbockers beat the Cincinnati Royals tonight for the first time since November, 1963. Tom Gola scored 4 points and Johnny Green 6 in overtime for a 115-112 victory in the first game of a National Basketball Association double-header.

The National Dairy Products Corporation achieved an 18.1 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 4.4 per cent last year, according to a preliminary statement of J. Huber Wetenhall, president.

The New York Philharmonic will play at Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30. Josef Krips will conduct, with John Wummer, flutist; John Corigliano, violinist, and Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichordist, as soloists.

The directors of the standard Oil Company (Ohio) declared the regular quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share on the common stock at a meeting held yesterday in Cleveland. The dividend is payable on March 10, to stockholders of record of Feb. 19.

SNOW conditions were rated "far from perfect" yesterday as officials of the Dartmouth Carnival put the finishing touches to the tournament layouts that will occupy center stage during the Big Green's 49th winter sports extravaganza.

The first public objections from the leadership of organized labor were raised yesterday against the proposed merger of the United Automobile Workers and the International Union of Electrical Workers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits is seriously considering running for Mayor of New York City.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing officials ruled today that race cars in 1966 might have any kind of fancy engines as long as the stripped assemblies cost no more than $1,000.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Bert Yancey, Frank Beard and Al Geiberger shared what appeared to be the second-round lead today in the $67,500 Phoenix open golf tournament.
The Transit Authority has added a weapon in its war against crime in the subways.
Never underestimate the power of a man when it comes to buying his own ties.
If children of United States parents are brought up in the tropics they are likely to be shorter and slighter than if they were brought up at home, a study suggests.
LISBON, Feb. 12 -- A Portuguese drama about an 18thcentury wine war has been banned here, apparently because of a too enthusiastic public reaction.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Ira Livingston's spring ran dry last fall and, needing water, he drilled a well. The well hasn't produced any water yet, but it has produced enough natural gas so that it could be many years before the Livingstons pay another gas bill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A Federal advisory body has split bitterly over issues of high public policy concerning the development of the rich oil shale reserves on public lands in Western states.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- Pro-Communist Pathet Lao forces have begun a new offensive in Samneua Province and are threatening the right-wing area headquarters at Hua Muong, a spokesman for the Laotian Armys' high command said today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI) -- The long-awaited 1965 appearance of Gun Bow takes place tomorrow at Santa Anita in the $50,000 added San Antonio Handicap as his first step towards horse-of-the-year honors.

A Roman Catholic organization filed a brief with the United States Supreme Court yesterday asking that a Connecticut law that makes it a crime to use any contraceptive device or drug be ruled unconstitutional.

A bidders' battle for the building occupied by the Washington Square Galleries, a five-story art emporium that opened last June with a splash and recently folded without a ripple, has reportedly been won by New York University.

A red, pink and white decor provided the setting in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East last night for the Blue Hill Troupe's fifth annual dance, a benefit for the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Administration left undefined today its intentions about further air attacks against North Vietnam, but they were the subject of a continuing debate behind the scenes.
Stocks declined on a broad front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
A man living in a $165-a-month apartment furnished with only two cots and a television set mounted on a suitcase was arrested here yesterday and charged with attempted robbery.

The lawyer for the woman suing Representative Adam Clayton Powell for defamation of character told the police yesterday that a notebook with names of about 125 informants in the case had been stolen from his office during the night.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Despite the dampening effect of a 15 per cent surcharge on imports, the pendulum of international trade once again swung against Britain in January, Government figures showed today.

Frenchmen, it seems, have added lately a new sauce to their already ingeniously concocted traffic tangles. Now when things get out of hand in the streets the drivers get out their gall and, non-Gallic, fight. The phenomenon has gained such headway that the afternoon newspaper France-Soir has had a campaign running to discourage pugilism between bickering motorists.
NEWARK, Feb. 12 -- The state police chased a car hurtling at speeds of up to 110 miles an hour through heavy fog banks on the New Jersey Turnpike today before stopping the driver after a 70-mile run.
Yehuda Guttman, a pianist who has been absent from the midtown concert scene for seven years, played last night at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The United States and Britain announced today agreement on a 10-year cooperative research program for developing an advanced type of atomic power plant that produces more nuclear fuel than it consumes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee is awaiting the outcome of a preliminary inquiry before deciding whether to investigate the Ku Klux Klan.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 12 -- Columbia's basketball team took command early in the second half tonight and defeated Brown, 65 -- 59, in an Ivy League game.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Johnson named Thomas C. Mann today to be Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

WASHINGTON Feb 12 -- The Federal Reserve Board is giving serious consideration to asking Congress to authorize a graduated scale for banks' reserve requirements based on demand (checking) deposit totals.
Federal Judge John F. Dooling declined to sign a writ yesterday to free the Rev. Milton A. Galamison, leader of the school boycott, from a city jail.
Eastern Europe is showing greatly increased interest in building atomic power stations to help overcome the area's deficit in conventional fuels as sources of power, diplomatic sources report.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12 -- The Yale swimming team defeated Colgate, 65 -- 30, tonight to stretch its consecutive dual-meet victory streak to 34.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 12 -- These days sunshine has sneaked up on Bogota, a grayish city that tends to distrust sunshine and prefers the familiar overcast. The newspapers are already printing short items darkly noting that sunny days mean cold nights and a water shortage.

Louis Rodriguez of the dancing feet and the pitter-pat punches won a unanimous 10-round decision last night from Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, whose great muscles sometimes seem to get in the way of one another.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 12 -- A $17 million summer program to give preschool children from disadvantaged areas a head start on their education was outlined here today by representatives of the Office of Economic Opportunity.
Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman" will be given today by the Metropolitan Opera at 2 P.M. and Puccini's "Tosca" tonight at 8.
Soybean futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade when commission-house selling met with only slight buying interest. Most grains also showed declines.

Brazil has finally joined other Latin-American countries that have signed investment-guarantee programs with the United States. When the Brazilian agreement is ratified, private American investors will be protected against revolution, expropriation, nonconvertibility and other such risks.
HONG KONG, Feb. 12 -- A virulent "Hate America" campaign spread throughout Communist China today. Millions of people pledged support for North Vietnam's "Struggle against United States aggression."

A 26-minute color movie displaying the charms of the New York World's Fair as seen on a tour of the grounds and buildings made during the height of activities last summer was previewed this week and will soon be available to theaters, airlines (with in-flight movies), clubs and schools and, later, to television stations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 -- The Vietcong responded today to bombing raids on North Vietnam with a call for stronger attacks against United States forces, to compel them to "pay more blood debts."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- An Optical-steering system for automobiles and trucks, invented by two Maryland engineers, is designed to follow a highway automatically. Once set on a course, it can keep the car in the same lane, along the straight -away and around curves. So far as the inventors know, theirs is the only automatic system that does not require special cables, signals or markings in the roadway.

Maria Kouba, a shapely, bigvoiced Austrian soprano, made her debut with the Metropolitan Opera last night as Salome in Strauss's opera. She came as close to looking the part as one could wish, and most of her trim body was on view at the end of the celebrated dance.
About 75 members of the Young Americans for Freedom demonstrated in front of the United Nations yesterday to urge increased action to win the war in Vietnam.
DETROIT, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A warrant for the arrest of the Mayor of suburban Dearborn was issued today when he failed to appear in Federal court for arraignment on civil rights charges.

The 26th annual American Music Festival got under way at Town Hall yesterday afternoon with a program that emphasized opera and the conservative wing. The old composers were MacDowell, Griffes and Gottschalk and the contemporary ones were Elie Siegmeister, Harold Farberman and Nicholas Flagello, each of whom conducted a New York premiere.

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (UPI) -- A former National Hockey League referee, Dalton McArthur, backed today his charge that a league official had ordered hint to "call only good penalties to the Rangers" in a game against Boston that affected a playoff berth in 1963.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 12 -- Turkey's international and internal political life is undergoing subtle changes that suggest far-reaching consequences.

Daniel K. Ludwig of Darien, Conn., arrived at his office at 360 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan yesterday morning, completed a deal to sell his 4,117,510 shares of Union Oil Company of California for $46 million more than he paid for it last June, and then went off on an extended vacation.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The chairmen of most of the standing Senate committees were named today by Senate Majority Leader Joseph Zaretzki.

BARGAIN days for airline passengers bound for the Caribbean and South America are over, at least for the time being.
