BONN -- The problem of rejoining Germany's partitioned halves will undoubtedly feature this year's election campaign although it is obvious political speeches won't produce diplomatic results. Particular attention is now being paid to de Gaulle's recent proposal to regard the problem in a European context, to "Europeanize" reunification.

The Catholic curriculum is determined by theologians, who assert supremacy over well-established, highly technical fields like physical science, logic and mathematics. Logic and mathematics as presented at Catholic universities do not include the tremendous advances of the past hundred years in these subjects that have altered them fundamentally.

READERS of Sylvia Ashton-Warner's earlier and uniquely germinal books, "Spinster" and "Teacher," will not be surprised that in her new novel "Bell Call," she is still concerned with education. Once again the geographical center of the book is a school in her native New Zealand.
Air Force engineers have reported photographing a beam of light bounced off an artificial satellite some 950 miles high.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (AP)--Bill Oakes scored 11 straight points at the start of tile second half tonight to pace St. Joseph's of Philadelphia to a 73-59 basketball victory over Temple. The victory was the Hawk's 21st of the year against one loss.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Harvard's powerful track team rolled up a record total of 93 points, more than doubling that of its nearest competitor, as the annual greater Boston collegiate championships closed today.

I was greatly interested in Mrs. Rosanne Frank's letter of Jan. 31, and I want to answer her on the basis of my own experiences. Although I have often used other forms of transportation, both here and all over the world, I prefer the railroad for seeing a place and its people.

A resolution critical of the Police Department for taking disciplinary action against a patrolman accused of rudeness to a foreign diplomat has been introduced in the City Council by Harry J. Donnelly, Brooklyn Councilman at Large.

At the annual Hungarian Piarist Ball on Feb. 26 there will be traditional ceremonies with a waltz by 25 newly presented debutantes and the dancing of the czardas. The gala will occupy not only the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza but also the Terrace, Baroque and Crystal Rooms.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 13 -- Charles Ufford of New York reached the semi-final round of the fourth annual William F. White Memorial Cup squash racquets invitation tournament at the Merion Cricket Club today by defeating Ralph Howe, the national champion from Oyster Bay, L.I., 15 -- 7, 15 -- 8, 13 -- 15, 15 -- 6.

WHEN the curtain goes up this Friday on the Metropolitan Opera's revival of "Wozzeck," a small man will be seen bobbing about in the orchestra pit. His vigorous lunges across the podium and the brisk, nonsense flicks of his baton will give the impression that a young man is conducting.
Four Navy and Coats Guard divers brought up small pieces of metal late yesterday from the wreckage of the Eastern Air Lines DC-7B that plunged into the Atlantic near Jones Inlet, L.I., Monday night.

The Shields Class of 30-foot fiber-glass sloops, raced the last few seasons mostly by students of the United States Merchant Marine Academy and the New York State Maritime College, but loaned occasionally for special events, will operate on a broader basis next season.

France's formal notice that she prefers gold to the dollar and to the pound sterling backs up President de Gaulle's demand for a return to the gold standard. The French say they have no intention of jettisoning the present monetary system. But they do not mind shaking it. Nor do they seem to mind demonstrating the weakness of its key underpinnings, the pound and the dollar.

AN inexpensive, attractive ceiling can be easily put up in a garage or basement where the overhead ceiling joists or rafters are exposed. Consisting of panels of 1/4-inch thick hardboard suspended between the joists, this type of ceiling requires a minimum of careful fitting since the individual panels fit loosely inside a supporting framework of 1x3 lumber.

Best of breed honors at the Bulldog specialty show in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Edison yesterday went to Paul and Dorothy Maddox's Ch. Mim Jim's Buckie Two of Cha Ru. The 2 1/2-year-old male scored over 83 other dogs.

Soviet Premier Kosygin's hurried tour of Communist Asia, now completed, took place under far more explosive conditions than he could possibly have foreseen. In the strained atmosphere created by the Vietcong sneak attack on Pleiku and the American retaliation against North Vietnam, the Soviet leader had to walk a tightrope to woo his hosts while avoiding any excessively perilous Soviet commitment.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Freddie Lorenzen a 30-year-old Elmhurst, Ill., driver, won the seventh annual running of the Daytona Beach stock car race today with an assist from the weather. The scheduled 500-mile event, interrupted twice by rain, ended after 133 laps (332.5 miles) had been run.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Relations between the United States and Tanzania deteriorated sharply today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Rod Funseth, who had never before won a professional golf tournament, shot a brilliant 67 today to win the Phoenix open with a 14-under-par 274.
A FAMILY photograph album for Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, the energetic woman Adlai E. Stevenson once called "the head of the most successful employment agency in America," might include these items:

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Greg Johnson, 7 years old, slept deep in the protection of a cave on Claudius Smith Mountain last night while the police and volunteers searched for him with bloodhounds, helicopters and foot patrols in 12-degree cold.
The case of David Coleman's confession is only one of many that may be reopened, it was indicated yesterday by District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 14 -- India is facing a severe monetary crisis because her foreign exchange reserves have fallen from $235 million a year ago to $157 million at the end of last month.

President Johnson's new proposals for reducing the persistent deficit in the nation's balance of payments represent merely the latest attempt to solve the problem. Still other steps, it is safe to predict, will be forthcoming.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 14 -- Tanzania tonight ordered her Ambassador in Washington to return home amid increasing friction between the East African country and the United States.
Mohawk Airlines intends to have all-turbine aircraft by the end of next year.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Peter Snell of New Zealand set his goal today on one of the few world middle-distance records that has eluded him, Herb Elliott's 1,500-meter mark.
The Rev. Frank M. Southard Smith was instituted yesterday as 18th rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Village of Flatbush, 157 St. Paul's Place, Brooklyn.
TODAY no legendary hero of ancient Greek mythology, poetry and tragic drama is as well-known as Oedipus, King of Thebes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-call in the House during the week ended yesterday:

New York's boast that its subways offer the safest transportation in the world needs revision. Accidents are not the problem; crime is. Danger rides the underground rails in the form of muggers and hoodlums preying on subway passengers. How serious the upsurge in violence has been is reflected in the Transit Authority's disclosure that serious crimes rose by more than 50 per cent last year.

The M.A. Hanna Company had a record net income last year of $16,239,131, or $1.34 a common share, up 9 per cent from $14,787,383, or $1.21 a share earned in 1963, according to the report issued yesterday.

New York's waterfront, normally quiet on Sunday, operated at weekday pace yesterday as 15,047 dock workers turned out to reduce the mountain of cargo accumulated in the 33-day strike that ended Saturday.
Ed Bowes of the New York Athletic Club led from start to finish and won the 4 1/4-mile Road Runners Club of New York Henry E. Isola Memorial run over the Bronx Markets course yesterday.
The Greensboro Generals came to New York, saw Madison Square Garden, and were conquered by the New York Rovers, 5 -- 3, yesterday afternoon before a crowd of 5,618.
The average factory production worker in the New York metropolitan area earned $101.14 a week last year, the United States Department of Labor reported yesterday.

UPPERMOST in the minds of commuters on the New Haven Railroad is the imminent possibility of the end of service. Yet, among those riding the New Haven day by day, there is not much talk to be heard about the danger of becoming defunct.

In Scandinavia's largest department store, Nordiska Kompaniet of Stockholm, one of the most popular items of American make is the Barbie doll, manufactured by Mattel, Ind., and that high-fashion dolls clothing and furniture.
The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority has asked the Legislature for permission to build a $100 million bridge-causeway between Westchester and Nassau counties.

Confusion, overcrowding, unprepared teachers and "lack of direction from central headquarters" were among the charges leveled yesterday by the United Parents Associations against the Board of Education's experimental reorganization program to aid integration.

The Democratic chairman of the State Senate Finance Committee said yesterday the income tax was the fairest tax and offered "the best possibilities for getting large sums" for state budget rises. But he asserted he was "not foreclosing" a sales tax.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 14 -- Stormy weather lies ahead for the European Economic Community, if the Johnson Administration's new balance-of-payments tack is at all effective.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking Committee, called today for full public disclosure of bank ownership to shake out criminal elements. He said hoodlum control of banking was becoming "widespread."
Robert Moses, president of the World's Fair, said yesterday that restoration of the Flushing Meadow park following the 1965 season had priority over the payment of the fair's noteholders.
ROME, Feb. 14 -- The halting of a private performance of "The Deputy" last night provoked a sit-in strike by 15 actors in the troupe today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Dean Burch, the retiring chairman of the Republican National Committee, made it plain today that the conservative faction that former Senator Barry Goldwater represented would fight to mold the Republican party to its views.
SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia -- The young hichhiker said his father was Bulgarian and his mother Greek, but "I am a Macedonian."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration designated today the targets on Mars that are scheduled to be photographed by Mariner 4 next July 14.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- After four months in office, Prime Minister Harold Wilson has still not brought forward a bill to nationalize the steel industry.
APARTMENT dwellers, lacking caves or cellars, are devising ingenious ways of storing their wines in walls, closets or libraries.
DOLGEVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- A small army of rescue workers, including a team of cave experts abandoned their attempts tonight to bring a trapped 23-year-old explorer out of a cave alive.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Alan Paterson and his St. Mary's High team from Greenwich, Conn., took honors at the 4th annual Seton Hall High Eastern Catholic swimming championships tonight.

Lord Taylor, a division of Associated Dry Goods Corporation, announced over the weekend the appointment of Albert J. Utz as senior vice president-for administration and William E. Humphreys as vice president and general operations manager.

The ghost of the late Dutch Schultz, once the beer baron of New York, turned up as a kind of spirit of poetry last night after Sir Tyrone Guthrie and William S. Burroughs had finished two separate performances associated, vaguely, with poetry in the theater.

THE qualifying stage of the 23d National Intercollegiate Bridge Tournament ended yesterday, but the results will not be known until next month. Games were held in 233 colleges, and 16 pairs will qualify on a regional basis for the national final, which will be a face-to-face contest in Chicago on May 8th and 9th.
The independent United Electrical Workers spoke out yesterday against a proposed merger of a rival union with the United Automobile Workers.

ROME, Feb. 14 -- Two representatives of Patriarch Athenagoras I of Constantinople, spiritual leader of Eastern Orthodoxy, arrived in Rome today for discussions of Roman Catholic - Orthodox relations. They. will be recelved by Pope paul VI, probably tomorrow.

Antonio Janigro brought I Solisti di Zagreb to Hunter College Auditorium Saturday night for a program that lacked musical depth but seemed to entertain the capacity audience. There were three Vivaldi pieces, the Concerto in F per Archi, the Concerto in D for cello and orchestra and the Concerto Sacro in C for violin and orchestra.

The city and at least one private group considered buying the three landmark Brokaw mansions on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 79th Street to prevent them from being razed for an apartment house.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- Charlie Pasarell won the annual Philadelphia invitation indoor tennis championship today by defeating Ian Crookenden of New Zealand, 6 -- 8, 11 -- 9, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored four times in the second period, twice while they were playing a man short, to rout the New York Rangers, 6-2, tonight and virtually eliminate the losers from contention for the fourth Stanley Cup playoff position.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Commissioner George K. Wyman of the State Social Welfare Department criticized the Federal Social Security system today in submitting the department's annual report to Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 14 -- In achieving the resignation of the Inonu Government in Turkey yesterday, Suleyman Demirel, the leader of the Justice party, hopes to further his desire to reorient the country's economy toward support of the rising new commercial class.
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Per Ivar Moe, an 18-year-old electrician from Oslo, won the men's world speed-skating championship today with a brilliant performance in the 1,500-meter race.

President Nkrumah has just about read himself and his Government out of the comity of civilized nations. Five persons, including two former Cabinet ministers, have been condemned to death by a court from which Mr. Nkrumah virtually demanded death sentences. The men had had a fair trial after their arrest on suspicion of complicity in the attempted assassination of President Nkrumah in August, 1962.

The recent American air attacks on North Vietnam are unjustified acts of aggression. As The New York Times (Feb. 8) news article by Charles Mohr points out, the targets attacked in North Vietnam could hardly have been involved in the earlier Vietcong raids on American bases in South Vietnam.

Plans for converting a proposed City Housing Authority project on the Lower East Side into a moderate-income cooperative to be called Mararyk Towers have been sent to the City Planning Commission by the Housing and Redevelopment Board.
Tourists to Caribbean resorts are being warned to avoid souvenir booby traps on their shopping expeditions, Joseph P. Kelly, Collector of Customs, announced yesterday.

Since she has been a soprano with the New York Pro Musica and a soloist in the Baroque festivals at Brooklyn College, where she is on the faculty, it was not surprising that Jean Hakes should present an unusual program in her concert in Town Hall last night.
Charles Simmons, author of "Powdered Eggs," has received the William Faulkner Award for a Notable First Novel. The book was published last August by E.P. Dutton Co. and is now in its third printing.
" The same society which receives the rewards of technology must, as a cooperating whole, take responsibility for control. To deal with these new problems will require a new conservation."
Scholars from different disciplines who used to be barely on speaking terms are being introduced to each other by computers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- George P. Larrick, Food and Drug Administration commissioner, announced today the formation of a medical advisory board that would aid the agency in its safety program for drugs and therapeutic devices.

Many of the best terriers in 10 breeds took part in the annual Associated Terrier Clubs' specialty events at the State Armory on West 168th Street yesterday and they proved once more that new good dogs have been challenging for top honors consistently.

Madison Square Garden was only a little noisy below the stairs in mid-afternoon yesterday while a hockey game was in progress upstairs. A decibel count would have given the hockey crowd the decision hands down.
Representative Carl Albert, majority leader of the House, emphasized last night the commitment of the Government to preserve peace in the Middle East.

Maria Wyrzykowska, a mezzo-soprano who was born in the Phillipines, made her Town Hall debut in a varied program yesterday afternoon, A gracious performer who brought much warmth to her songs and arias, she was nevertheless beset by technical problems that hindered a really strong impression.

" The Apprentice Fiction of F. Scott Fitzgerald," a collection of 15 short stories that have never been published before in book form, will be issued by Rutgers University Press on March 15. John Kuehl, a member of the Princeton University English faculty, has written an introduction relating biographical facts to the stories and the stories to Mr. Fitzgerald's later fiction.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 14 Gov. William W. Scranton has persuaded many in his own party that he is not maneuvering for the Presidential nomination in 1968. He has enjoyed no such luck, however, among Democrats.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Johnson gave 40 phones to friends in the Government as Christmas presents.

The executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union declared yesterday that the campaign for human rights and advances in automation and weaponry could produce restrictions of "unprecedented intensity" on individual freedom.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 14 -- About 165 chilled youngsters from 7 to 17 years of age put on a bareback riding performance here today that would have warmed the hearts of old-time cavalrymen.
Supporters of both I.W. Abel and David J. McDonald raised serious questions yesterday about election procedures in the million-member United Steelworkers of America.
The Rev. John Courtney Murray, a Jesuit authority on church-state problems, has been named to receive a Unitarian award for "conspicuous service in the cause of religious liberty."

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The first meeting of the leftist Indochinese Peoples Conference opened here today under banners calling for solidarity, independence and peace. Speakers attacked United States policy in South Vietnam.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- Western diplomatic sources said here today that North Vietnam had given its first sign that it was interested in a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam crisis.
PANAMA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr., of Pocono Manor, Pa., shot a one-under-par 71 today and won the Panama open golf tournament by four strokes over Wes Ellis Jr.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Johnson Administration would like to put the United States merchant marine into Congressional drydock for a thorough and long-postponed overhaul.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Johnson Administration was reliably reported tonight to be preparing a broad statement of its diplomatic and military position in the Vietnam crisis. Informed sources said the statement would be designed to set forth the United states attitude in the light of last week's retaliatory attacks against North Vietnam.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Can 16,000 Chicagoans be wrong? Ask any hockey fan in town and he will tell you "This is the year of the Hawk."

THE cool beauty of metal-based tables with glass tops has caught on with traditionalists and modernists alike. Both groups assert that in a roomful of grained wood furniture such tables give the same psychological relief as a dish of sherbet after a heavy meal.

Paul J. Christiansen led the Concordia College Choir of Moorhead, Minn., last night at Philharmonic Hall in a program of familiar works. As in past appearances here, the 66-voice mixed ensemble was a model of precision and enthusiasm, blending their voices with professional skill.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- The Soviet Union and North Korea made public a joint declaration today that accused the United States of seeking to expand the war in Vietnam.

WOODTOCK, Vt., Feb. 14 -- A competitive skiing rarity in the East -- victory in a major event by a Harvard undergraduate -- was achieved today when Steve Blodgett, a sophomore, captured the Fisk Trophy at Suicide Six.

The Deafness Research Foundation has set up three regional temporal-bone centers. They will coordinate the acquisition and distribution of bequeathed inner-ear structures for a national network of 38 temporal-bone laboratories for ear research.
A theater manager who believes in the art -- and pop art -- influences of television is planning a festival here in May of TV commercials and documentaries.

The first major move to attract private American capital to the Republic of Korea has been made here by the newly formed Korean Industrial Development Agency. With the signing of a long-term lease, the agency will establish offices in Rockefeller Center, at 1270 Avenue of the Americas.

Nearly five weeks ago the Senators from the four states through which the New Haven Railroad runs met with representatives of some of the Governors and of the relevant Federal agencies to discuss the New Haven's problems.

The excitement of starting the city's first bank organized by Negroes and whites is over. The Freedom National Bank is in business at 275 West 125th Street and the 23 men and women on its payroll have settled down to the unglamorous task of making it a going concern.

FREEPORT, the Bahamas -- Big-time legal gambling has arrived here 81 miles off the Florida sands. United States officials are worried that the games are creating yet another outpost for American gangsters.

The skill, flexibility and realism of Czechoslovakia's business executives will decide the fate of the country's economy in the years immediately ahead, the Central Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party has declared.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Feb. 14 -- A proposal to develop the Republic Aviation Corporation airport as a municipally owned general aviation facility and industrial park has been revived.

Mayor Wagner's forces in the Bronx opened a new political attack yesterday on Charles A. Buckley, who responded with a bitter attack on Senate Majority Leader, Joseph Zaretzki, who in turn replied that he did not want to fight anybody.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana Feb. 14 -- The 300,000 Indians among British Guiana's 620,000 inhabitants are being urged by former Premier Cheddi B. Jagan's People's Progressive party to stay away from their jobs tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Beneath the surface silence about Vietnam this weekend, there is an air of anxiety and torment here.
Governor Rockefeller will be urged this week to take an active role in helping to pick the Republican candidate for Mayor.
" What's in a name?" Shakespeare asked a long time ago, and then observed: "That which we call a rose/ by any other name would smell as sweet."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 14 Harry de Leyer, a 37-year-old professional from St. James, L.I., rode Eddie Dutch to the jumper championship, won two hunter classes and saw one of his pupils capture the horsemanship championship today at the February Schooling Show at the Thomas School of Horsemanship.
NEWARK, Feb. 14 -- Hundreds of young men and women, many of whom never worked a day in their lives, have recently become very useful to the city of Newark -- and to themselves.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 14 -- For the second time in 15 months, the major segments of the Puerto Rican economy will sponsor this week an island conference to combat poverty and an unemployment rate that has reached 11 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA Feb 14 -- In a desperately poor section of North Philadelphia, home of thousands of migrants from rural areas, a self-help Negro community project was opened a year ago to train and retrain the unemployed.
Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times received two first-place awards at the annual dinner of the Dog Writers' Association of America at the Statler Hilton Hotel last night.
The fourth soprano to sing the title role of "Tosca" at the Metropolitan Opera this season took over on Saturday night. She was Gabriella Tucci, and she had not sung the part here previously.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 14 -- A right-wing drive to break the grip of Communists and Nasserites in the Sudanese Government ran into new opposition today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Burwell B. Smith, whose paternal grandfather patented the first American washing machine, inadvertently became one of the sights on a tour of elegant homes and gardens here yesterday.

SELMA, Ala., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- More than a thousand Negroes met tonight in preparation for a massive voter registration march tomorrow, amid reports of a secret meeting of local Negroes and white businessmen.

Sharp protests against the treatment of Negroes in New York City were voiced yesterday at a communion breakfast and church service attended by Mrs. George Whitmore at the Antioch Baptist Church 828 Green Avenue, Brooklyn.
BONN, Feb. 14 -- The Hallstein doctrine -- Bonn's diplomatic boycott of East Germany, which backfired on Chancellor Ludwig Erhard last week -- is undergoing a basic review.
A diverting assortment of dance solos and duets was performed yesterday afternoon at the Henry Street Playhouse by Don Redlich and Bernadine Madole.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 14 (AP) -- "I don't want to go," said Mrs. Katherine Westmoreland, casting an unhappy look at her husband, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, commander of United States forces in South Vietnam.
The Navy took command yesterday of operations to salvage the sunken wreckage of an Eastern Air Lines DC-7B six miles off Jones Inlet, L.I.

The trend to computerization may run into trouble, here and there, on Seventh Avenue. Although electronic data processing is clearly the new wave, there is an occasional throwback to manual techniques that will be hard to remove.

THIRTY minutes in the kitchen and a three-course meal on the table -- it sounds like a dream, but it works like a charm, according to Mrs. Bartley Crum. And she should know because she recently produced a 30-minute, three-course meal for the benefit of and before the unbelieving eyes of several friends.

Hearings to study the scarcity of coins in the United States were announced yesterday by Representative Dante E. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, chairman of the legal and monetary affairs subcommittee of the House Committee on Government Operations.
The ambivalence of the United States Government with regard to foreign relations is exemplified once again by the second visit to Japan of an American nuclear-powered submarine.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- A legislative collision between Republicans and Democrats over the Condon-Wadlin Act was assured today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- Soviet economic planners have officially adopted a new measure of industrial output that is designed to deflate the present production index and reflect more realistically the performance of individual plants.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 14 -- President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, the Indian chief of state, voiced thinly veiled criticism of the Indian Government tonight in a speech on the language crisis that has beset his native South India.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Union was described by George F. Kennan tonight as having "everything to lose and very, very little to gain" from further complications in Southeast Asia.

Mark Twain will be the leading character in "Sam," -- from his real name, Samuel Langhorne Clemens -- a musical comedy that is estimated to cost $500,000 to produce. Jerome Alden is responsible for the plot and Maurice Kernerman the music.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk says Washington is going to "press very sharply" for protection of United States embassies abroad.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics turned in a first-class rebounding performance today even without the services of their defensive specialist. Bill Russell, as they whipped the Baltimore Bullets, 126 -- 111.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 14 -- A Jewish taxi driver front London who tore a swastika necklace off the wife of a British Nazi leader, Colin Jordan last month, has decided to settle in Israel to evade harassment by British fascists.
The College Retirement Equities Fund announced over the weekend the appointment of Dr. Roger F. Murray as vice president and economist.

Arts councils in the United States and Canada plan to establish a central headquarters staffed with paid employes before the summer. The office will provide research services for the growing arts council movement, private and public.
PARIS, Feb. 14 -- John Osborne entered the repertory of the Theatre National Populaire in style here tonight when his historical play "Luther" was staged in a new version.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Royals ended a five-game winning streak by the St. Louis Hawks with a 99-92 victory today in a National Basketball Association game.
BATHURST, Gambia, Feb. 14 -- "Dis road, it is too too much," complained a taxi driver in the pidgin that is common throughout English-speaking West Africa.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The Labor Department announced 20 new Neighborhood Youth Corps projects today for 12 states.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 14 -- North Vietnam announced today that it had asked for the withdrawal of International Control Commission observer teams posted on its border with Communist China and at other points.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 14 -- A warm, gusty southeasterly wind and cheerful blasts from hundreds of yachts sent 25 sailing boats off on the grueling 1,200-mile race between Buenos Aires and Rio de Janeiro today.
Armed holdup men robbed and assaulted four taxi drivers early yesterday in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

The moderator of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. said yesterday that he was "quite pleased" with the fact that his denomination had begun a serious re-examination of its theological foundations.

Seven years is too long for a recitalist of William Warfield's caliber to be absent from New York concert halls. The bass-baritone has made stage and orchestral appearances here in that time, but has not given a solo program.

A NERVY comeback in the middle game, after an indifferent start, earned a victory for Arthur Bisguier over Robert Steinmeyer in their English Opening in the current Manhattan Club championship finals.
The New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association has asked the Federal Maritime Commission to take a new approach in the handling of export shipments.
Two Methodist ministers, one from Harlem and one from Park Avenue, switched pulpits yesterday and preached on similar themes.
HAVANA, Feb. 14 -- The regime of Premier Fidel Castro, which maintains that it emancipated Cuba's women, married off many of them today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Regina Heitzer of Austria won the women's individual title tonight at the European figure skating championships.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Sustained prosperity in most industrialized countries brought employment to record levels last year, the International Labor Organization's yearbook for 1964 reported today.
President Johnson's broad Congressional strategy is apparent, but the first month of the 89th Congress has provided few clues as to how well he will succeed with his legislative program.
Ch. Fiddler Fahey struck the right note with Percy Roberts yesterday and Roberts named him best of breed at the Pug Dog Club of America's specialty show in the Statler Hilton Hotel.

A triple-threat Irish setter, a dual-purpose Cordon and the top-winning English for the last three years romped off with the silverware at the combined setter specialty show in the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz reported to President Johnson today that the nation's first Neighborhood Youth Corps, in Newark, had dispelled the idea that the corps was a "make-work concept."

OTTAWA, Feb. 14 -- Another clear sign of an early revival in the Canadian uranium industry is a report that the Federal Government will announce this month the site of another heavy-water plant in western Canada.
Malcolm X, the controversial Black Nationalist leader, and his family escaped injury early yesterday when a firebomb attack wrecked the small brick house in which they lived in East Elmhurst, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- In the long run, there will be no major upheaval in the relationships between the steel industry and the United Steelworkers of America no matter who wins the bitterly contested election for the union's top posts.
Wagner's "Die Walkure" will return to the Metropolitan Opera repertory Feb. 22 as the 20th week of the season gets under way.

Children's Center, a city shelter for the temporary care of neglected and dependent children, is running out of living space because relocation difficulties have made many of its youngsters permanent residents.

THE Postmaster-General of the United States is a bulky, pipe-smoking extrovert who has disproved the adage that if a man speaks his mind frankly he won't get very far in life or in politics. John Austin Gronouski Jr., who was 45 years old last Oct. 26, has been an outspoken partisan Democrat all his adult life.

PERTH, Scotland, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Lady Lansdowne, the former Barbara Stuart Chase of Santa Barbara, Calif., was reported in grave condition in a hospital here today following a shooting accident last Friday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- At 9:16 this morning, Tom Ivener, a cattle feeder from Sioux City. Iowa, sold 30,000 pounds of butchered beef to Ben Levenberg, president of the Diamond Meat Company of Philadelphia, at 38.5 cents a pound for delivery in July.

The National Association of Securities Dealers has begun providing newspapers with the wholesale, or inter-dealer, quotations for the 1,300 actively traded over-the-counter stocks on its national list. The new quotations appear for the first time today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Officials said today that the library building taken over by Indonesia had been leased by the United States from a private individual or concern.
Sketches of a suspect in the slaying of a part-time taxicab driver were distributed yesterday to more than 25 detectives assigned to the case.

A counteroffensive against the rising crime rate in all big cities seems at last to be under way. President Johnson has proposed imaginative new approaches for use in Washington, D.C. Mayor Wagner has ordered the New York police to study new ways of combating crime at the same time that he has authorized more policemen for both general and subway duty.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Florentino Fernandez, a Cuban middleweight, whipped Tommy Caldwell tonight by scoring a technical knockout at 2:34 of the fifth round in in a scheduled 10-round fight at Curtis Hixon Convention Center.
The New York Rovers yesterday promoted Jean Pierre Lafond, their 6-foot-1-inch 192-pound forward, to the St. Paul Rangers of the Central Hockey league.
IT was bitterly cold outside, but it was hard to realize this inside the warm kitchen on West End Avenue where Nettie Ullman was busy baking.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 16 -- The Armed Forces Council announced today the appointment of Dr. Phan Huy Quat as Premier and Phan Khac Suu as Chief of State.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 15 -- What and where is Salisbury? they asked a year ago when it was announced that the national indoor tennis championships would be held here.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Feb. 15 -- William G. Long, dean of men at the University of North Carolina, said today he had written a letter of apology to a Liberian student who complained he was insulted on the campus last Friday.

Two of the ugliest features of American life are automobile junkyards and overhead electric transmission lines. One of the major objectives of the new and more comprehensive conservation policy which President Johnson has proclaimed is to make life in both the cities and the countryside more humane and attractive by striking at these sources of ugliness.

MIAMI, Feb. 15 -- Louis Dexter, who runs his horses at El Comandante in San Juan, Puerto Rico, has a 3-year-old down there that is unusual. Unless he has an air-conditioned stall, he can't run. But, granted air-conditioning, he runs so well that he might even go in the $100,000 Flamingo March 3.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 15 -- The Indonesian Government took control of the United States Information Service library in Jakarta today after four hours of officially sponsored demonstrations protesting air strikes by the United States against North Vietnam.

The West Germans have made an almost incredible mess of the linked issues of arms to Israel and relations with Egypt. As a result, President Nasser has been greatly strengthened; tensions in the already tense Middle East have risen; West German relations with Israel, which had improved so greatly in recent years, have again sunk to a low of bitterness and anger; and Communist East Germany, Bonn's enemy, achieves a triumph.

Directors of the Union Oil Company of California have approved a proposal to proceed with negotiations for a merger with the Pure Oil Company, Fred L. Hartley, president of Union Oil, announced yesterday.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Michigan overcame a 7-point deficit in the final minute of the regulation-game and a 4-point deficit in the last 26 seconds of a first overtime period to defeat Indiana, 96-95, tonight and maintain its perfect Big Ten record.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild announced today that Gene Goltz of The Houston Post was the winner of its Heywood Broun Memorial Award for 1964.
Two major pharmaceutical producers -- the Upjohn Company and the Schering Corporation -- attained record sales and earnings in 1964, according to reports issued yesterday.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb 15 (AP) -- Ticonderoga, 74-foot scratch boat of Robert F. Johnson of Portland, Ore., worked its way up the Florida Keys today in the 403-mile race from St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdale.

I am dismayed by your somewhat one-sided editorial interpretation [Feb. 7] of the recent Kosygin visit to Hanoi. You unequivocally suggest that it was designed to check the Chinese, and that the United States may profit from it by arranging with Moscow for American disengagement from South Vietnam.
About one out of every four children of school age has some kind of eye trouble, according to the Children's Bureau of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

JERICHO, Jordan -- In the parched wasteland between the River Jordan and Jericho, 1,200 feet below sea level, fruit, vegetables, alfalfa, poultry, cows and trees are flourishing -- not to mention 160 boys between the ages of 8 and 12.
Aldens, Inc., Chicago mail-order concern, has leased the seventh floor of the building at 200 Madison Avenue in a deal that involves a total rental of $1.75 million.
MADRAS, India, Feb. 15 -- Anti-Hindi rioters broke into the ancestral home of President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan at Tiruttani yesterday and destroyed the memorial library there.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Lima News and four co-defendants filed an answer today in Federal court denying Federal antitrust charges. They asked for a jury trial.
Coward-McCann, Inc., announced yesterday that it had sold the paperback reprint rights for an unpublished spy novel by John Le Carre (David Cornwell) to Dell Publishing Company, Inc., for $400,000.
TRENTON, Feb. 15 -- The Republican majority in the State Senate agreed tonight on plans for redrawing the state's 15 Congressional Districts and reapportioning the Legislature.
New-car sales, already at a record pace, are accelerating even more.

Clifford Buck, the president of the Amateur Athletic Union, confirmed last night in New York that he would meet with the National Collegiate Athletic Association in an attempt to settle heir dispute over the control of amateur sports.
Steel production in the United States edged up one tenth of 1 per cent in the week ended Saturday.

The excellent impression Edith Peinemann made in her recital debut here three seasons ago was reinforced by her initial appearance locally as an orchestral soloist, made last night in Carnegie Hall with the Cleveland Orchestra.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Talk of the Common Market is in the air again in Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Johnson conferred for more than a half hour tonight with Secretary of State Dean Rusk. Their talk followed a day of contradictory reports as to the Administration's next diplomatic step in the Vietnam crisis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Methamphetamine inhalers, which have been available without restriction for use to relieve nasal congestion, are now restricted to sale by prescription only, the Food and Drug Administration said today.
Operations of the B.F. Goodrich Company resulted last year in a 25.6 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 5.3 per cent, J.W. Keener, president, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan said today three Federal banking agencies had promised full cooperation with a Senate investigation of recent bank failures.
The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York declared yesterday that it would concentrate on the problem of family disorganization this year.

ANDREW A. ROONEY, who last season did the delicate and charming program entitled "An Essay on Doors," returned last night to television with a sequel, "An Essay on Bridges." Its mood was more hurried and it did not have the reflective philosophy of its predecessor, but nonetheless the half-hour was unusual TV, and some of its photography very striking.
Robert Moses' proposal for a bridge-causeway across Long Island Sound between Oyster Bay and Port Chester brought heated opposition yesterday.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 15 -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas rode a pony out of New Mexico's Sandia Mountains tonight after having been trapped in heavy snows on an icy trail for nearly nine hours.
Late selling weakened most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in active trading.

International tellers of the United Steelworkers of America may take days or even weeks to weigh protests and complete official vote tabulations in the close battle for the presidency of the union, it was indicated yesterday.
A stamp of disapproval made its appearance on the local political scene yesterday.
Four rare young seals were flown in to the Coney Island Aquarium from Antarctica yesterday.

ALTHOUGH modesty has not always been one of the more noticeable virtues of brash Bobby Bragan, it is to be doubted that the aggressive manager of the Braves will claim full credit for one recent development in Milwaukee. A determined promotional campaign for the sale of season tickets has moved Bragan into an active role and the result has been a sharp upward turn -- proportionately, anyway.
A bubbling stock market grew defensive in late trading yesterday and closed mixed. While there were 652 advances and only 458 declines, other leading market indicators showed a dropping market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service denied today all arguments by Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania that it was wrong in insisting that his mother's estate owes more than $660,000 in Federal taxes.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 15 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers launched spring training today with the opening of their early cramp at Tigertown.
The constitutionality of the city's proposed water fluoridation program was upheld yesterday by Justice Joseph A. Brust of the State Supreme Court.

A painting by Sir Winston Churchill, possibly the first by the late statesman to come up at public sale in this country, will be auctioned on April 14 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
Mickey Mantle, the well-known life insurance executive, took time out from his business pursuits yesterday to confirm that he had signed another $100,000 contract with the New York Yankees.
Divers searching the wreckage of an Eastern Air Lines DC-7B that crashed a week ago off Long Island recovered more small pieces yesterday.
If the first 100 years are the hardest, then the next century should be a breeze for Abraham Straus.

W.R. Grace Co. is offering its common stock owners subscription rights to $83,469,000 of 4 1/4 per cent convertible debentures, due March 1, 1990, at a rate of $100 principal amount for each 18 shares held, of record of Feb. 11.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Roman Catholics in Britain have reacted mildly to a decision by one of the nation's most popular charities to support birth-control projects in developing countries.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Yields on Treasury bills continued to rise with today's sale of new issues.
NASSAU, the Bahamas -- This British colony has been controlled for generations by its white minority. Today, however, Negroes are pressing for a larger role in public affairs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Cabinet hat on Postmaster General John A. Gronouski's head can lie easy for the next four years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The American Civil Liberties Union protested today a proposed investigation of the Ku Klux Klan and certain other groups by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

Waves of sell orders flooded the soybean futures market of the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The selling, much of it profit taking, stemmed from fears that the settlement of the dock strike would free a huge amount of soybeans that had been kept from the market.
HOUSTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -Space officials disclosed today a flight plan for the first manned Gemini shot.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers said tonight he expected that United States businessmen would cooperate in cutting down the overseas flow of American dollars.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Atomic Energy Commission confirmed today earlier reports that it planned further cutbacks in the production of enriched uranium for atomic weapons.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 -- The head of the General Motors Corporation spoke optimistically today about the 1965 economic outlook and said G.M. probably would spend more for capital improvements in 1966 than the record $1.1 billion it planned to spend this year.
The fourth annual Margo Jones Awards were presented yesterday to Prof. Richard A. Duprey and Villanova University and to Theater '65 and its founders, Edward Albee, Richard Barr and Clinton Wilder.
Four executive appointments to the staff of the American Institute of Architects in Washington, D.C., have been announced by William H. Scheick, the institute's executive director.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Feb. 15 -- Mike Levine, a sophomore guard, scored 17 of his 22 points in the second half to lead C.W. Post College to an 80-59 triumph over Yeshiva University on the victors' court tonight. The Pioneers have a won-lost record of 15 -- 3, while the Mighty Mites are 6 -- 9. Sam Stern was high for Yeshiva with 20 points.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Britons should enjoy themselves more on Sundays, the House of Commons agreed today. The only question was, how much more?

The initial success of the Neighborhood Youth Corps in Newark is an understandable source of gratification to municipal and Federal officials. The 348 school dropouts put to work on special city jobs are showing both enthusiasm and capacity, to the mutual delight of the youngsters and the agencies for which they work. About half of the youths have registered for night courses to make up for their lost education.

Two of the "name" dogs that gained best-of-breed victories yesterday at the opening of the 89th Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden were the whippet, Ch. Courtenay Fleetfoot of Pennyworth, and the Maltese, Ch. Co-Ca-He's Aennchen Toy Dancer.
United States Government bond prices dropped early yesterday and then recovered most of their declines in the last hour and a half of the day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- The Argentine Embassy announced today that an agreement had been reached between the Government of Argentina and the Continental Oil Company and the Marathon Oil Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Johnson sent to Congress today three reports dealing with science and what he called the need "to understand the profound changes which it promises."

Peace reigns at "Fade Out-Fade In," which resumed its interrupted engagement last night at the Mark Hellinger Theater after a 13-week shutdown. The suspension was brought about by a contractual dispute between its star, Carol Burnett, and the management.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 15 -- More than 400 Seaford residents, most of them women and children, protested today plans by Nassau County to build a sewage treatment plant in their community as part of a $335 million sanitary sewer system.

Nicanor Zabaleta gave another one of his impeccable harp recitals last night at Town Hall. As always, the Spanish-born virtuoso played with utmost refinement of taste and remarkable gradation of nuance.

New York State's Democrats still seem much more interested in hashing over their internal fight than in legislating. The time has come for all sides in this Democratic fare-thee-well to stop the wrangling and get down to work. The public has had enough entertainment; now it wants some accomplishment.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 15 -- When residents of Nassau County learned last week that the county's three towns planned to adopt the state's Suburban Town Law their reaction was almost universal: "What is it and what does it mean?"

A strike against the Henry Street Settlement continued for the sixth day yesterday as mediation efforts resumed between representatives of the Lower East Side community center and the union that hopes to speak for the settlement's workers.
The Elgin National Watch Company, which last June had to yield three board seats to a dissident stockholders' group led by A. Phillip Goldsmith, is facing another proxy contest.

PATCHOGUE, L.I. Feb. 15 -- Henry Lorenzen, a court-appointed referr in foreclosure, stood on the steps of Brookhaven Town Hall today and sold a 1,928-acre tract of Long Island woodland for the account of William Zeckendorf's real estate empire.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -The United States will attempt to launch tomorrow the first of three giant folding-wing Pegasus satellites to sample the meteoroid population near the earth.

YONKERS, Feb. 15 -- Yonkers Raceway is ready for Thursday's opening despite the storm last night that left three inches of snow on the protective asphalt-covering of the track today. The snow proved little deterrent to Tex Tankersley and his 24-man crew.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 15 -- Immense plastic and rubber models of a human brain, heart, inner ear and other anatomical parts are being set up on sound stages at 20th Century-Fox's studios this week.
The election of new top executives to run the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the world's largest petroleum organization, was announced yesterday.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Nat King Cole, the velvet-voiced popular singer, died in St. John's Hospital here this morning. He was 45 years old.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Dr. Lucile A. Allen has resigned as dean of women at Stanford University in a controversy over classroom morality.

In the field of public health services, where many new group health, union, voluntary and charitable agencies have been expanding rapidly, New York City, a pioneer in public health, is in danger of being hoist with its own petard.
BOSTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Boston College won a record third consecutive Bean Pot Trophy tonight with a 5-4 triumph over Boston University in a battle of the East's top college hockey teams.
RIO de JANEIRO, Feb. 15 -- A court today declared bankrupt the 36-year-old Panair do Brasil Airline, whose foreign and domestic routes have been canceled by the Government.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- President Johnson increased today his pressure on Congress to make Washington a "great capital city" worthy of the richest nation on earth.

DINAH SHORE invited Harry Belafonte to join her last night in a musical salute to the Peace Corps, and the two .rformers gave viewers tuned to the American Broadcasting Company a remarkably light, easy-going hour of international songs and dances.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 15 -- The two Congos exchanged charges and countercharges today of plots and counterplots.
Mayor Wagner announced plans yesterday to add 1,000 men to the regular police force and 100 to the transit police beginning July 1. Most of the men would be assigned to foot patrol.
SAIGON, Tuesday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Troops smashed anti-Government demonstrations in two northern towns yesterday, killing 15 civilians in one of them.
A New York County grand jury yesterday indicted Richard Robles, a 22-year-old narcotics addict, on charges of murdering Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert in 1963.
Six men were sentenced to prison yesterday for defrauding creditors of a Bronx meat packing concern of $1.3 million after the Mafia had taken control of the company and bankrupted it.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 15 -- The players' union and the rival American Football League will be the subjects of conversation, but probably of little action at the National Football League's annual meeting that opens tomorrow.

BAN THAD, Thailand, Feb. 14 -- Smoke from cooking fires hung lazily over Ban Thad this morning, mingling with the fine dust rising between the rows of crude wooden houses perched on stilts above the littered ground.
SELMA, Ala., Feb. 15 -- About 2,800 Negroes marched on the courthouses of three counties in Alabama's Black Belt today to demand a speed-up in the registration of voters.

MANY consider Tchaikovsky's "Pique Dame," or "The Queen of Spades," to be his finest opera. (Some, though, could advance good arguments in favor of "Eugene Onegin.") In the Soviet Union, and in many European opera houses, it is constantly in the repertory.

MONTREAL, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League, fined 17 players a total of $925 tonight for participating in a free-for-all fight during a Toronto Maple Leaf-Montreal Canadien game last Wednesday.

Gregory Cruz, a 22-year-old former clerk, asserted yesterday that he had been beaten and then shot and wounded critically in fleeing from a detective who did not identify himself and who appeared to be a "madman."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Industrial production continued to rise strongly in January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
DOLGEVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Rescue workers made plans today to drill a shaft into the watery cave where James Mitchell, a 23-year-old cave explorer, was trapped and died over the weekend.
The swift deterioration of United States relations with Tanzania has elements reminiscent of Gilbert and Sullivan, but the prospects opened up are tragic.

Malcolm X charged last night that his home "was bombed by the Black Muslim movement on the orders of Elijah Mohammed," its leader.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The installation of a permanent three-step air-pollution warning system in New York City was urged today as a condition for continuing state aid to the city's air-pollution control program.

An advertising agency and a drug company and its president, charged with the promotion and production of a fraudulent diet pill, were fined $8,500 yesterday after pleading guilty in Manhattan Criminal Court to a series of misdemeanors.
BREST, France, Feb. 15 (AP) -- About 2,000 workers and farmers took advantage of President de Gaulle's visit to naval installations today to demonstrate for higher pay.
RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 15 (AP) -- A wheel and part of a landing gear from a missing single-engine plane were recovered from Raritan Bay today by the Coast Guard.
The Whirlpool Corporation gyrated yesterday with a number of major developments in the operation of its appliance-manufacturing business.

MADRID, Feb. 14 -- Geraldine Chaplin, at 20 the eldest of eight children of Charlie Chaplin and Oona O'Neill, has begun a film career playing the important part of Tonya in David Lean's film of "Dr. Zhivago," which is being shot in Madrid.

De Hirsh Margules, one of Greenwich Village's best known personalities, left an estate valued at more than $100,000. Mr. Margules died Feb. 3 of a heart ailment at the Gracie Square Hospital at the age of 65. His will was flied for probate yesterday in Surrogates' Court.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell has made a $150.40 payment in connection with the defamation-of-character judgment of approximately $262,000 pending against him.

Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson was among dignitaries from the political, diplomatic and motion-picture worlds who attended the premiere last night of George Stevens's "The Greatest Story Ever Told" at the new Warner's Cinerama Theater.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 15 -- The public school superintendent may have to assume new responsibility for children attending private and parochial schools, the resolutions committee of the American Association of School Administrators said here today.

SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia -- What began 20 years ago as a highly self-conscious and rather artificial Macedonian nation-building campaign has now developed into a calm evolution. Involved are about one million people whose sense of identity and cohesiveness grows with every passing year.
Robert Whitehead said yesterday that he was considering instituting a $50,000 suit for breach of contract against the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater.
OTTAWA, Feb. 15 -- The new red-and-white Maple Leaf flag was raised "in the skies over Canada" today.

Benton Bowles, Inc., prides itself on being the mother of presidents -- presidents of other agencies, that is. Yesterday it announced that still another son was leaving home, though this time not for another agency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- It was inevitable that religion would have to yield sooner or later to the national passion for life on the run. The old form of worship involved too much lost motion for a people accustomed to living in a perpetual state of transportation.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Two state officials refused today to produce records that the United States Civil Rights Commission had subpoenaed in regard to racial violence and church burnings in Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Congress has been asked to approve construction of a giant third power plant at Grand Coulee Dam that would nearly treble the generating capacity there to 5.6 million kilowatts, the largest in the world.

Liberal party leaders have made the first move in the 1965 city election campaign by informing Borough President Joseph F. Periconi of the Bronx that he is assured of their nomination again in his bid for re-election.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A heated dispute broke out between the Liberal and National parties today on the eve of elections for a constituent Assembly to draw up a new Constitution for Honduras, which is under military rule.

The news article by Harry Schwartz, your Jan. 26 editorial and the letters evoked by both seem to be taking a familiar direction: "modern math" is failing and the benighted teacher is to blame. I wonder if amid the welter of experts' opinions and analyses a mere teacher may have his say.

BERLIN, Feb. 15 -- Walter Ulbricht, heaping scorn on West Germany for its unsuccessful efforts to have his invitation to Cairo withdrawn, told Bonn to stop "the futile meddling in the internal affairs of the United Arab Republic."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Opposition to the formula the Administration has endorsed for dealing with Presidential disability came today from the Democratic camp in the Senate.
BUDAPEST, Feb. 15 -- The United States is continuing talks with Hungary despite the damage done to the American Legation and to relations between their Governments by rioters here Saturday.
DENVER, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Gerald H. Phipps and Allan R. Phipps agreed to buy control of the Denver Broncos today and said the American Football League team would remain in Denver.
BUSY people who cannot take the time to shop or others who find the activity an intolerable bore might be interested in making their purchases through a professional shopping service.

Educational television station WNDT (Channel 13), which is trying to cope with a major financial crisis, announced yesterday a curtailment of program production activities that will affect at least 13 series of shows.
CAPT. EDWARD MOLYNEUX, the fashion designer who returned to the Paris couture two weeks ago, proved last night he had not been idle during his 15-year retirement.
HONG KONG, Feb. 15 -- Marshal Chen Yi. Foreign Minister of Communist China, called tonight for "concrete action" against the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Is Senator Robert F. Kennedy taking dead political aim at Governor Rockefeller more than a year before the Republican chief executive opens his anticipated re-election campaign?
HONG KONG, Feb. 15 -- Peking expressed approval today of President de Gaulle's recent proposals for reform of the United Nations and for changes in the world monetary system.
A newly formed national, voluntary health agency concerned with epilepsy is completing plans to expand its research and public information programs.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin returned to Moscow today from a 10-day visit to Communist China, North Vietnam and North Korea amid reports that major decisions would be made on Soviet policy on Southeast Asia and the United States.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 15 -- Rising anger against the United States burst into the open today in East Africa. In Kenya, 200 university students marched through Nairobi chanting "Yankee go home."
Industrial issues led an advance on the London Stock yesterday in steady but selective trading.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 15 -- Hua Muong, a Government guerrilla base in Samneua Province, has fallen to a strong Communist force, military sources reported today.

St. John's won the gold medals, but Manhattan won the points as the Metropolitan Intercollegiate indoor track and field championships opened yesterday -- outdoors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Government began an investigation today into a complaint that 12 hospitals in seven Southern states were violating Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Emmerich Danzer completed an Austrian sweep of individual titles at the European figure skating championships today by upsetting the defending champion, Alain Calmat of France, for the men's crown.

LIKE little Eva, its only female character, "The Sweet Enemy" chatters incessantly. The talk covers a wide variety of topics like love, color and the trap that language can be, but it has not been organized into a play.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The Democratic leaders of the Legislature began trimming the salaries of top staff members today. It was the first move in their announced plan to cut $1 million from the legislative budget.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The State Department is investigating the activities of an American-owned aircraft that was found to have a cargo of military equipment when it made an unauthorized landing Feb. 4 on Malta.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -- The Government has decided to cancel an order for one of the five Polaris-missile submarines planned for construction, the Defense Secretary, Denis Healey, announced today.

" Wild Heritage," a book by Sally Carrighar on animal behavior in relation to human behavior, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on March 15. The author has been noted for books on nature since "One Day on Beetle Rock" was published in 1944.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson will visit West Germany from March 6 to 9.

A total of 18,529 longshoremen, a work force about a third larger than that normally employed on the waterfront, worked on 110 New York City piers yesterday to clear a backlog of cargoes piled up during the 33-day strike.
By calling one telephone number yesterday, for the first time, any of the 200 hospitals in the metropolitan area could find out where to get blood in an emergency.

ROME, Feb. 15 -- Italian authorities invoked the Lateran Treaty between the state and the Roman Catholic Church tonight and banned a performance of "The Deputy," but the controversial play went on in a clandestine performance in a Rome bookshop.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The Earl of Cromer, governor of the Bank of England, called tonight for the trimming of Government spending to get Britain's economic house in order at the "earliest reasonable moment."

KENILWORTH, N.J., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Marvin Mathis, a 29-year-old unemployed laborer, was charged with homicide tonight in the death of an insurance agent who was shot and burned here Friday night.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Automobile production lines in the United States roiled at top speed last week, but most were hard pressed to keep up with the sales market.

The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the appointment of Welton H. Hewitt and Tilghman B. Koons as vice presidents. Both are in the international department.
BUFFALO, Feb. 16 -- Leaders of Buffalo's Negro community today hailed the order by Dr. Allen for ending racial imbalance in the city's schools.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 16 (UPI) -- The Florida East Coast Railway gave in today to a Federal court order in the face of a $4,000-a-day fine and took steps to correct four alleged contract violations.
Louis B. Lundborg, a tall, soft-spoken native of Montana who once planned to be a physician, was elected last night as chairman of the Bank of America, San Francisco, the largest bank in the world.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 16 -- Gov. John N. Dempsey presented to the General Assembly today a record package budget of $1,250,500,000 for the next two fiscal years.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 16 -- Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. paid a surprise visit today as the United States Civil Rights Commission began five days of open hearings into charges of racial discrimination in Mississippi voting and law enforcement.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 16 -- National Football League club owners gave their commissioner, Pete Rozelle, the power today to punish any team by taking away from one to all of its draft choices as a penalty for signing college players prematurely.

New York Airways won approval yesterday for helicopter flights in instrument weather. A Federal Aviation Agency certificate granting approval was presented to the line by Oscar Bakke, Eastern Region director, at a ceremony at Newark Airport.

In 20 minutes of judging during which the tension grew progressively until it almost could be tasted, the 4 1/2-year-old silver brindle Scottish terrier, Ch. Carmichael's Fanfare, became best in show in the Westminster Kennel Club competition at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Saying that "we are in sight of the promised land" of a bill on medical care for the aged, President Johnson asked the public today to urge prompt enactment of the measure.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, which is keeping busy these days with such projects as opening its sixth branch in Panama, promises to raise quite a stir soon on Wall Street. This forthcoming move by Chase, the nations largest commercial bank outside of California, involves no new office in the financial district.
THE Royal Shakespeare Company's production of "The Hollow Crown," which opened on Broadway during the 1963 newspaper strike, was brought to television last night in the first of two installments.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Feb. 16 -- Officials of the Town of Oyster Bay and representatives of powerful North Shore civic associations met here today to plan their opposition to the proposed bridge across the Sound.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said today he had "every confidence" that President Johnson would work out a practical solution to the crisis in Vietnam.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 16 -- Ambassador Edwin M. Martin has begun a hurried round of talks with Argentine officials to seek to clear up "misunderstandings" that have arisen over United States aid policies.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The House of Commons decided unanimously today to refer to a committee on privileges a Labor member's allegations to his constituents that some Conservatives had been drunk during debates.
EUGENE ORMANDE, conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, gave a wide-ranging program that satisfied many tastes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Purchase of the Georgetown home of Mrs. John F. Kennedy is being considered by Michael Straight, the novelist.
The New York Newspaper Guild has started negotiating new contracts covering 5,500 news and commercial department employes at six major newspapers in the city.

Manhattan College regained the team title last night in the metropolitan intercollegiate indoor track and field championships. But the honors for the night went to the Germann twins of Seton Hall, two runners built like whippets.
MONROE, H.C., Feb. 16 (AP) -- Solicitor M.G. Boyette said today that he would seek the re-indictment of four persons on charges of kidnapping a white couple in a race riot in Monroe in 1961.
ROME, Wednesday, Feb. 17 -- A bomb blasted a side entrance to Vatican City early today. It caused some damage but no injuries.

" I am one of those people that sociologists, political scientists, educators, novelists and others have referred to during the last 20 years as 'huckters,' 'men in gray flannel suits,' 'Madison Avenue boys' and 'hidden persuaders.'

THE sky on the ceiling at Mainbocher's gilt-mirrored salon is blue and serene. No breeze stirs the painted clouds, and few winds of change disrupt Mainbocher's dream of lovely women. At the end of yesterday's showing of the spring and summer collection, Mary Martin (who had come for a fitting) popped out briefly, all sunny smiles. Miss Martin is, of course, Peter Pan, growing no older -- and yet no younger.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16 -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, in his first statement since his return from a 10-day visit to Asian Communist countries, reiterated today Soviet demands for the withdrawal of American troops and equipment from Indochina.

The Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted unanimously three weeks ago to support Robert Moses' proposal for a bridge-causeway across Long Island Sound between Westchester and Nassau Counties, it became known yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The American Jewish Congress marked its annual "Day in Albany" today by urging Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature to "step up the state's war on poverty by broadening the fight against racial and religious discrimination."

The cost of adapting Paris originals is going up. President Johnson, who has asked American businessmen to cut down their foreign investments, needn't worry about the apparel industry's spending abroad.
Plans for the construction of two new structures, including a $3.5-million science center, were announced yesterday by St. Francis College in Brooklyn.
California sold $100 million of bonds yesterday to finance development of water resources in the state.

SUM SAO, Thailand, Feb. 15 -- The old peasant stood respectfully beside the tree stump on which he had been resting outside the infirmary tent. He raised his heavily tatooed arms to his face and pressed the palms of his hands together in a Buddhist greeting.

A plot by a small group of Negro extremists to blow up the Statue of Liberty, the Liberty Bell and the Washington Monument was broken up yesterday by the New York City police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the help of the Royal Canadian Police.
An irate motorist recently invited Sanitation Commissioner Frank J. Lucia to handle his problem -- a 1957 red Plymouth sedan.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 9 (AP) -- Spectacular outside shooting by Jim Benedict and sharp ball-handling by its backcourt men gave undefeated Providence an 88-72 basketball victory over Rhode Island tonight.

This collection of the more important writings of Clara M. Thompson (1893-1958) is compelling for two reasons. First, it is a deserving tribute to the life and career of one of the great psychoanalytic theorists and innovators of this country. Second, the articles, written in the same direct, unmutilated English that formed her "Psychoanalysis: Evolution and Development" (1950), are models of what scientific writing could and should more often be.
AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 16 -- The University of Massachusetts has selected the site of its new branch in Boston.

In 1917, the Soviet Union opened the practice of law to "all honest persons of either sex who enjoy civil rights." The following year this was abandoned and only members of aI special body of "legal representatives" were permitted to practice for remuneration.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Prime Minister Harold Wilson said today that British entry into the European Common Market was not now "a practical possibility," but he called for new economic "bridges" to the market.
NASSAU, the Bahamas -- A high American official is convinced that underworld money is funneling into secret bank accounts here.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The state ordered the City of Buffalo today to end racial imbalance in its schools, beginning in September.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 16 -- The Princeton University Art Museum has acquired a collection of 83 ancient Chinese ritual bronzes, some of them more than 3200 years old, for exhibition in its new building to be completed next year.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- A ministerial tug of war is under way over the British Government's plans to cut its hotly controversial 15 per cent surcharge on imports.

An American company in the apparel field has joined the campaign to curtail imports from West Germany in protest against its suspension of arms shipments to Israel. The head of the concern predicted that several others would participate.

Vice Premier Pietro Nenni of Italy and Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, a member of India's Parliament, arrived here yesterday to attend a "Peace on Earth" convocation based on an encyclical by the late Pope John XXIII.

The school boycott spread yesterday to Boys High School, a grimy, turreted Victorian structure in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. The move was a departure from the demonstrators' original plans.
The New York Central Railroad awarded yesterday $4.5 million of equipment trust certificates to an investment banking syndicate headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
The seventh annual Medallist Ball sponsored by the Guild of the Long Island College Hospital will be held on March 6 in the Grand Ballroom of the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.
WARSAW, Feb. 16 -- The class was in American literature and the Polish students were well dressed. The lecturer was tall, tweedy and alternated between a pipe and cigarettes.
BONN, Feb. 16 -- The West German Government was reported today to be warning Arab nations not to follow the lead of the United Arab Republic in welcoming Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- The public-relations office of the American Medical Association said today that it was filling requests for seven million pamphlets attacking the Johnson Administration's medicare program.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Bertram L. Podell, Brooklyn Democratic Assemblyman, introduced bills in the Legislature today to prevent "force-fed" confessions and to abolish capital punishment.
The City Council unanimously endorsed yesterday bills before the State Legislature that would permit Councilmen to reapportion Council districts.

The City Planning Commission announced yesterday it would hold a public hearing at City Hall on March 3 on several proposed projects, including a low-income public-housing project, a middle-income cooperative and a Bronx urban-renewal plan.

MONTREAL, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- The National Hockey League governors dismissed today recent accusations concerning the manipulation of the outcome of a hockey game as "unfounded and . . . the product of the malicious distortion of a routine caution."

CINCINNATI, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers withstood a fourth-quarter Baltimore rally tonight and held on for a 106-102 victory over the Bullets in the first game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 16 -- Senator Suat Hayri Urguplu, a political neutral, became Turkey's Premier today.
About 40 Brooklyn youths, including four girls, battled with clubs, tire irons and automobile antennas in a Brooklyn subway station yesterday near the start of the evening rush hour.
LOGAN, Utah, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Wayne Estes, the Utah State University basketball star who died in an accident a week ago, was named today to The Associated Press 1964-65 all-America team.

Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China appeared on American television screens last night in excerpts from an interview filmed on Feb. 2 in Peking with Edgar Snow, a free-lance American journalist who has often reported from China.

The Theodor Heuss Chair in the Social Sciences at the New School for Social Research was dedicated yesterday at a reception at the One Fifth Avenue Hotel. The chair is believed to be the first American professorship supported by a German foundation.

OTTAWA, Feb. 16 -- The Canadian Parliament resumed today its longest session in history to take up a Federal pension plan and other legislation proposed by the Liberal minority Government of Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson.
In a move to prevent overspecialization, Columbia College has placed a limit on the amount of work a student will be allowed to do in his principal field of study.
Southeast Asia cast its shadow over the stock market again yesterday, trimming stock quotations as the day wore on.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The International Union of Electrical Workers rejected today a merger proposal from the United Automobile Workers.
