A number of industrial and service organizations have announced high-level management changes.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 16 -- A jeering mob tore a United States flag to pieces today in neighboring Uganda. The flag was pulled down from the United States Embassy in Kampala in a demonstration against American support of Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo.

Long before the death 10 years ago of Charlie Parker, the jazz saxophonist, legends had grown up around him, legends centering on his narcotics addiction and his sexual exploits as well as his musical triumphs.

The few remaining furnishings in two of the three Brokaw mansions on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 79th Street will be auctioned Friday and Saturday. The houses are being razed to make way for an apartment building.
British scientists have reported an experimental mating of the cells of mice and men.
The Transit Authority announced plans yesterday to construct a subway station on Welfare Island, providing the first direct rapid transit to the island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- The House patched up its internal squabbles long enough today to authorize committee investigations and junkets that are expected to cost $9 million to $10 million in the next two years.
Two shipping lines in strikebound Southern ports have settled with the International Longshoremen's Association and resumed operations.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Wagner wrote his second opera "Das Liebesverbot" (The Ban on Love) at the age of 21. A failure at its first performance, it has seldom been revived since, and tonight's production by the opera group of University College, London, was its first in Britain.
DAYTONA, BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 -- The Daytona stock car racing classic, curtailed from 500 to 322 miles last Sunday by rain was, nevertheless, a financial and artistic success.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 16 -- A taxpayers' injunction suit filed today in Superior Court challenged the constitutionality of a 1963 state law providing for the free loan of textbooks to pupils in private and parochial primary and secondary schools.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday Feb. 17 (AP) -- firing squad executed today a man identified as a Vietcong agitator behind the anti-Government demonstrations Monday in the northern town of Thangbinh.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- With the introduction today of his three crime-prevention bills, the bulk of Governor Rockefeller's program has now been put before the Senate and Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Communist China is preparing for its second nuclear test, apparently in the near future, the State Department said today.

A sharp rise in the nation's supply of frozen french fries caused prices of Maine potato futures to tumble 19 to 31 cents a hundredweight yesterday on the actively traded contracts. The new crop, for November delivery dipped a cent.
Twenty-two Navy divers continued yesterday salvaging of wreckage from an Eastern Air Lines DC-7B that crashed off Jones Beach on Feb. 8, with the loss of all 84 aboard.

The election of Dr. Leslie C. Peacock as a director of Max Factor Co. was announced yesterday by Davis Factor, chairman of the cosmetics producer.

Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" will be given by the Metropolitan Opera tonight at 8.

In the midst of worldwide apprehension about the explosive potentialities of the war in South Vietnam, Ambassador Stevenson conferred yesterday with Secretary General Thant of the United Nations. The immediate speculation was that the United States had at last responded to Mr. Thant's initiative for negotiations to end the Vietnamese conflict, but thus far no one has been able to discover whether this matter, so important to all mankind, was even discussed.
BONN, Feb. 16 -- Erwin Schule, a prosecutor who has supervised the tracking down of Nazi criminals in Germany since 1958, admitted today that he himself joined the Nazi party in 1937.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Britain and France reaffirmed today their intention to go ahead with the plan for a jointly-produced supersonic civil airliner, the Concorde, and said they were discussing a possible British-French "air bus."

BONN -- An encouraging aspect of the new German democracy is its achievement of an essentially bipartisan approach to foreign policy. There are differences in concept of application and in nuance, but basic attitudes of the present Government coalition and Social Democratic opposition are strikingly similar.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Allegheny Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to reject a bus company's attack on special air fares for servicemen.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- The Niagara Falls City Council has sanctioned a proposed franchise for a Houston concern to build a monorail to take visitors to a park near the American falls.

A retail advertising seminar here heard yesterday what ads can do in the quickening retail race. In general, the speakers saw advertising's chief function as that of projecting a store's particular image.
HOBOKEN, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Capt. Kurt Carlsen, hero of the Flying Enterprise saga of 1951, disclosed today that his ship had to fight off Vietcong pirates as he made for Saigon on his latest voyage.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- a state court ruled today that the wife of a liquor salesman who died after a barroom fist-fight over another woman was not entitled to workmen's compensation.

Construction has begun on the first of five 10-story luxury apartment buildings on Clove Road near Clove Lakes Park in Sunnyside, S.I. The apartments will range in size from one-room studios to five-room suites.

MIAMI, Feb. 16 -- A couple of horse players in the crowd of 18,656 at Hialeah today had to be consoled with $55,312 apiece after Windsor Lady took the seventh race on the program. Windsor Lady was the winner of the fourth race of the "twin double," but there were no tickets sold on her in the sequence.

Some of the most recent art finds dug up in this hemisphere and the latest to be identified are on view today in a new exhibition at the Museum of Primitive Art, 15 West 54th Street. The display is called "The Jaguar's Children."

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- The threat of an expanded war in Vietnam has underscored once more the shifting views of conservative and liberal thought in America about the uses of Presidential power to oppose aggression.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest rubber producer and the first in the industry to exceed the $2 billion annual sales mark, also lifted its earnings last year past $100 million, Russell DeYoung, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

Willie Pastrano will defend his light-heavyweight title against Jose Torres on March 30 in Madison Square Garden on the same card in which Emile Griffith will risk his welterweight title against Jose Stable. It will be the Garden's first championship double-header.

Phil Linz, the modest New York Yankee who last August made harmonicas noteworthy and vice versa, received an increase in pay yesterday and a $200 bonus earmarked for music lessons as he signed his 1965 contract.

Much of the commentary about Vietnam on this editorial page has been both telling and somewhat irrelevant. The estate of Mrs. Frank Hague, the widow of the former mayor of Jersey City, was officially appraised here yesterday at $4,517,745.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Reginald Maudling, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, was named the Conservative party's shadow Foreign Secretary today in a major realignment of the Opposition's front bench.
HOUSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- A 25-member surgical team separated today 9-week-old Siamese twin girls who were joined together from collarbone to navel. The four-hour operation seemed to be successful.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Albania threw the General Assembly into turmoil today with a demand that the Assembly take an immediate roll-call vote whether to continue the no-vote procedure it has followed for two and a half months.

Detective John C. Devlin testified yesterday he had shot a 22-year-old clerk three times, wounding him critically, after suffering a blow that made it feel as though "the world had exploded" in his head and a chase in which everything still seemed "dreamlike."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson received today the first Distinguished Volunteer Service Award of the American Heart Association. She promptly gave it away.
THE most recent addition to the growing list of small, dignified and relatively elegant restaurants in Manhattan is the Lafayette, a neat and polished dining room that is generally worthy of regard.
DENVER, Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Four earth tremors shook the Denver area this afternoon.

The National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame has made a substantial gain in its drive to raise $3.5 million for the building of its home at Rutgers University.

" Hemingway: An Old Friend Remembers," by Jed Kiley, will be published by Hawthorn on April 26. The author ran a night club in Paris during the nineteen twenties and was an editor of The Boulevardier, a satiric magazine.
The New York Philharmonic "Promenades" concerts in Lincoln Center will be lengthened from four to five weeks this year. The series will run from June 2 to July 3.

Directors of J. Ray McDermott Co., Inc., raised the quarterly dividend yesterday to 25 cents and also declared an extra dividend of 15 cents on the common stock. Both are payable March 31 to stock of record March 11. The company had paid 20 cents in previous quarters, but no extra was distributed last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Congress was advised by a New York lawyer today not to attempt too much in the way of specifics in writing a constitutional amendment dealing with the disability of the President.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 17 -- South Vietnam turned yesterday to a mostly civilian Cabinet heavily weighted with physicians in an attempt to remedy the nation's serious political ailments. The Cabinet had been approved by the military leaders.

Cornell ran its winning streak to 14 games and increased its lead over Princeton to 1 1/2 games in the Ivy League basketball race with a rally that beat Columbia, 89 -- 80, at University Hall last night before a crowd of 1,500.

BATHURST, Gambia, Feb. 16 -- When Gambia becomes Africa's 36th independent nation just after midnight tomorrow, hundreds of the mud brick houses in Bathurst will bear a fresh coat of white paint. The question is, Where did all the paint come from?

Detectives investigating the fire bombing of the East Elmhurst, Queens, home of Malcolm X said yesterday that a bottle containing gasoline had been found on a dresser.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 16 -- When Rory Calhoun steps into his Rolls-Royce, he starts the motor, the air-conditioner and his stereophonic tape machine in quick succession and then, engulfed in music that comes booming out of four speakers, he heads into the traffic.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 16 -- Manuel Santana of Spain and Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy were beaten tonight in the opening round of the national indoor tennis tournament.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 16 (UPI) -- Rhonda Glenn of Lake Worth, Fla., posted a qualifying round of 76 despite fog and wind today to take the medal by five strokes in the 37th annual women's Florida east coast golf championship.

Two widely separated rivers -- one in Maine and the other in Minnesota -- exemplify the nationwide problem of reconciling the needs for industrial development, for recreation and for unspoiled beauty.
Stock prices were mixed at the close of trading yesterday on the London exchange.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 16 -- Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union be- began trying to organize 4,000 service and maintenance employes today in 26 hospitals of Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Rep. Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of New York, said today he would address the house Thursday on the legal troubles that have led to a $262,000 judgment against him.
The 310-unit Palm Beach Towers, one of Florida's most luxurious apartment-hotels, has been sold for $7 million to the American Realty Trust.

THE Museum of Modern Art's exhibition of recently acquired paintings and sculpture, opening today, can hardly be accused of a narrow-minded attitude toward art. For here. we have 80 works dating from 1909 to 1964 by 66 artists from 12 countries whose styles vary widely, although all can be lumped together as progressive for their particular day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today blamed the pilot for the crash-landing of a Pan American World Airways jet at Kennedy International Airport last April 7.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Circus-loving peers in the House of Lords tonight threw out a bill seeking to end the circus industry on the ground of cruelty to animals.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy went to City Hall yesterday to discuss poverty and ended up pledging support to Mayor Wagner in the Mayor's expected campaign for re-election next fall. The Senator, who has been pictured as locked with Mayor Wagner in a struggle for more power in the Democratic party in the state, arrived at City Hall almost unnoticed at 10:20 A.M. and went directly to the office of City Council President Paul R. Screvane.

ATLANTA, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A Federal Court has been told that 79 Negroes trying to enroll in the ninth grade of a white high school were sent to a Negro high school because they had fourth-grade reading levels.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 16 -- A Swedish woman in Karlstad, western Sweden, has prematurely given birth to six babies, all dead.
O. Roy Chalk, through the International Railways of Central America, of which he is chairman, brought a $507 million antitrust suit yesterday against the United Fruit Company.

Earl Brown's hopes of becoming Manhattan Borough President in his own right were all but dashed yesterday as State Senator Constance Baker Motley was proposed for the post with Mayor Wagner's active support.

The public acclaim that always greets an announcement by Mayor Wagner of an increase in the strength of the police force is convincing evidence that the people of New York want and need better protection. But merely increasing the "authorized quota" of policemen does not automatically and instantly mean more policemen on the streets. The Mayor proposes to increase the quota by 1,000 men on July 1, bringing the total authorization to 27,728.
KENILWORTH, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Two teen-agers held as material witnesses in the murder of a Plainfield insurance agent were released today "until wanted."

STUART, Fla., Feb. 17 -- This sailfish addict expressed curiosity recently about why one such fish would come in without a great deal of trouble, while a seemingly identical fish would fight on with muscles to spare.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A national committee to oppose the John Birch Society and other right-wing groups, organized with some fanfare less than five months ago, has been forced to abandon an ambitious program of "telling the truth" about extremist groups because of lack of funds.

TORONTO, Feb. 17 -- The expanding Canadian Pacific Railway has acquired 670,000 shares of Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., bringing the railroad's interest in the major natural-gas carrier to more than a million shares, or about 13 per cent of the total outstanding.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, Feb. 17 -- The Government radio announced today that three leading officials of the Congo Republic, the former French Congo, had been assassinated, presumably by political enemies.

IT seemed like a revival of the old-fashioned choral festival in Philharmonic Hall last night. Two big 19th-century works were sung by the Schola Cantorum of New York; the stage was jammed to its farthest reaches with singers and orchestral players; the tenors wavered a little on their high notes, and the organ went full blast every now and then.
The majority of Issues on the American Stock Exchange recovered yesterday in fairly active trading after two days of weakness.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Cyril F. Brickfield, 46 years old, chief Benefits Director of the Veterans Administration since March, 1963, was promoted today to be V.A. Deputy Administrator.

M.A. Hittner Sons, one of the oldest concerns in the truck and car-rental business, has acquired two adjoining parcels on Cooper Square, at East Fourth Street, as a site for a four-story $750,000 garage.
The growing boycott of West Germany's goods and services in protest against its halt in arms shipments to Israel is to be discussed here next week at meeting of a major Jewish group.

AN ascending star in the local arena is 15-year-old Walter Browne. Managing all phases of a French Defense like a veteran, the young expert defeated Edmar Mednis, a master, in the current Marshall Club championship.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Labor Department announced today that manufacturing payroll employment last month reached the highest level, after adjustment for seasonal factors, since July of 1953.

FULL many an expert is born to bid unseen, and waste his card play on the desert air. One such is Paul Lukacs, a Hungarian now resident in Tel Aviv, Israel. Although barred by geographical circumstance from international competition, he has acquired a world-wide reputation as an analyst.

CARL SNAVELY has been away from big time college football coaching for more than a dozen years and away from even the low pressure brand for half that time. But this hard-rock fundamentalist refuses to budge from an opinion he always has held.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Nominations for short-subject Oscar awards at the April 5 presentations of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences were announced today.

PERTH, Scotland, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The American-born Marchioness of Lansdowne died him gunshot wounds today in the same hospital where her daughter, Lady Caroline, died after a shooting accident eight years ago.

Three junior high school girls, residents of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, were charged with assault and robbery yesterday in the aftermath of a subway disturbance in which several parochial school girls were threatened.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The largest collection of drawings by Domenico Tiepolo remaining in private hands will be sold at auction in London on May 4.

NEW ASHFORD, Mass., Feb. 17 -- Add Brodie Mountain to the list of new machine-made snow resorts for next year. Jim Kelly, the youthful head of that new ski center, made the short drive yesterday to neighboring Jiminy Peak to see that area's snow machines in op eration and was envious.
ALTHOUGH Thomas Scherman makes modest disclaimers about his cooking abilities, he is, in the opinion of several of his friends, an excellent amateur chef.
YESTERDAY was matinee day, but several hundred well-coifed and well-dressed women chose to watch the fashion show at Elizabeth Arden.

With the possible exception of some suburban real estate developers, no one has done more to blight the American scene than the hawkers of billboards. President Johnson has now asked for stronger regulation of billboards on roads built with Federal funds, but he has not spelled out the kind of additional authority he wants.
Sales of a group of 32 leading chain stores and mail order houses in January fell seasonally to a seven-month low of $1,614,652,121, a survey of The New York Times Showed yesterday.
THIS is the story of the reconstruction of an unreconstructed Southerner. It is also a parable for all men and women, everywhere, told with uncommon candor and force.
The list of insiders of the Chrysler Corporation who in recent weeks were sellers of the company's stock continues to grow.

Total assets of New York City's five pension funds have topped $4 billion, Abraham D. Beame, city controller and custodian of the funds, announced yesterday. The city's funds are second only to those of the Federal Civil Service Retirement System, Mr. Beame said.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 17 -- The Episcopal Church rescinded today a two-month-old measure that would have curbed the civil rights work of its priests outside their own parishes.
MOSCOW, Feb. 17 -- Another high Soviet official dismissed by Nikita S. Khrushchev when he was Premier was restored to office today.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes, feeling "1,000 per cent better" following an operation, returned to his desk yesterday after a two-week vacation in Miami and expounded on three subjects:
A sharp controversy has developed within the American Jewish community over the issue of Federal aid to church-supported schools.

Other possible members of the plot to blow up the Statue of Liberty, the Liberty Bell and the Washington Monument were being hunted yesterday by local police, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Royal Canadian Police.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 President Johnson said today the United States would persist in the defense of South Vietnam and would continue actions that are justified and necessary.

The New Yorker magazine, which reaches the age of 40 with the issue out today, received a delicate, feminine advance yesterday from the Vassar Class of 1925. An anonymous, belated Valentine arrived at the magazine office with "greetings on the occasion of OUR 40th anniversary".

BIG PINES, Calif., Feb. 17 (UPI) -- Joan Merriam Smith, who flew solo around the world last year, was reported killed, today when a plane she had borrowed crashed in the mountains near here. A woman companion also died in the crash.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- With Administration forces firmly in control, the Senate opened debate today on the bill repealing part of the 25 per cent gold-cover requirement behind the nation's money supply.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House approved today a three-year extension and financing program for theUnited States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. The roll-call vote was 302 to 63.

Louis Whiteman, a gifted young American pianist who has studied and performed extensively in Europe, made her New York debut last night at Town Hall. It was hardly an exciting evening, but it was one with a full measure of thoughtful, serious pianism.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics, with strong second-half shooting performances by John Havlicek and Sam Jones, tonight scored a 121-114 National Basketball Association victory over the St. Louis Hawks.

MIAMI, Feb. 17 -- Sparkling Johnny of the Harbor View Farm had the benefit of a smart ride by Mike Venezia in the Everglades Stakes at Hialeah today. As a result Sparkling Johnny registered a 3 1/4-length triumph in the $32,700 test, with the long-priced Naturalist second and George D. Widener's Eurasian third.
The nation's electric power production rose 5.7 per cent in the week ended Feb. 13 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

Stock prices recovered moderately yesterday following a sharp drop in the late trading on Tuesday. But all the key market averages did not reflect the market's strength because of weakness in one or two heavily weighted issues.
YONKERS, Feb. 17 -- Mutuel machines, dormant around these parts since midnight of last Dec. 12, will be whirring again tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
A New York mathematician believes that his solution to an old problem may have important effects on the design and construction of buildings, bridges and heavy machinery.
Ten domestic airlines serving New York have formed a Metropolitan New York Airlines Committee to improve services for the community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The White House Press Secretary is what the President makes him or allows him to make himself. On this choice depends whether he will be the President's principal and authoritative deputy for disclosing those actions and reactions to events and speculations that the President chooses not to convey in person.

Mrs. Constance Baker Motley, the State Senator proposed for Manhattan Borough President, reportedly with Mayor Wagner's active support, has also been recommended for a vacant Federal Court judgeship by Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Labor Department intervened today in the battle over the election held last November by the International Union of Electrical Workers.
Ing. C. Olivetti Co., S.p.A., is an internationally minded company and it was logical, therefore, to appoint an internationally minded executive to direct its operations.

A Congressional investigation of Haryou-Act was called for by Kenneth E. Marshall yesterday after he had been dismissed as program director by Livingston W. Wingate, executive director of the Harlem antipoverty project.
When the New York Knickerbockers are bad, they resemble that little girl with the curl -- they are horrid.

Robert Moses is probably right in predicting that a new crossing of Long Island Sound between Nassau and Westchester is inevitable. The growth of traffic between New England and eastern Long Island eventually will overburden the Throgs Neck and Bronx Whitestone Bridges, and enabling the flood of cars to bypass New York City would be of benefit.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Pegasus satellite is registering strikes by meteoroids and all its instruments seem to be operating properly on its first day in orbit, the space agency said today.
Ranger 8, a spacecraft designed to photograph a portion of the moon's surface, was successfully launched into a moon-bound course yesterday from Cape Kennedy, Fla.

Know of two, not-too-expensive apartments in the neighborhood of Lincoln Center, for the Performing Arts? Something for a man with a wife and three, well-behaved children? Herbert Blau and Jules Irving would appreciate hearing from you.
Prices of spring-crop Maine potatoes for future delivery dropped another 9 to 19 cents a hundred pounds yesterday in heavy trading. The new-crop November delivery rose 3 cents in light trading.

Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., has achieved records in sales and earnings every year since 1955, when Chesebrough and Pond's merged, and Jerome A. Straka, president, said 1964 was no exception. He noted that fourth-quarter results also were the best in the company's history.

If the United States has a policy in South Vietnam, its outlines do not emerge with any clarity from the statement President Johnson appended to his speech before the National Industrial Conference Board yesterday.
SELMA, Ala., Feb. 17 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King left a sickbed tonight and appealed to Negroes to adopt a more militant campaign in Selma.
PARIS, Feb. 17 -- A struggle to democratize the French Communist party widened today with publication of a sharp exchange between its Politburo and about 100 party intellectuals.

The Dancers Theater Company, a repertory group that gave its first New York performance last year, returned to Kaufmann Concert Hall last night with a program that offered Charles Weidman's "Waltzes, Op. 39" and "Flickers," Joseph Gifford's "The Pursued," Ray Harrison's "Jazz Suite in Three" and Ruth Currier's "To Wish . . . Together . . . Fearsomely."
CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- The Chicago Board of Health started a birth control program today in its own clinics, open to all, regardless of income or married status.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that members of the United Steelworkers of America and not the International Longshoremen's Association were entitled to load the S.S. Columbia at the United States Steel Corporation's works at Morrisville, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Teodoro Moscoso, former United States coordinator of the Alliance for Progress, has charged that the Johnson Administration has forgotten the political meaning of the Latin-American revolution and is concentrating instead on "money and skills and bureaucrats."
The preferred and common stockholders of the Seiberling Rubber Company emerged from a special meeting yesterday with the promise of receiving dividends on their stock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The State Department acknowledged today that the United States was an indirect partner in the German-Israeli arms deal.

Burl Ives and Bert Lahr will be the stars of separate half-hour situation comedy shows next fall on the American Broadcasting Company network. It will be the first time either has appeared on a weekly series.
A $10.5 million mortgage for 23 years has been arranged for Norwood Court Apartments, a 772-unit complex being built on the Mark Twain Expressway in Norwood Court, a suburb of St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A treacherous, unseen accumulation of ice on the horizontal control surfaces of the tail probably caused the crash of an airliner at Freeland. Mich., April 6, 1958, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.
New York University will oppose Georgetown and Manhattan will face Temple in college basketball tonight at Madison Square Garden, with the Jaspers and Owls meeting in the first game at 7 P.M.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The United States and Britain came under pressure today from Western Europe for not applying sufficient economic restraints to balance their internat ional payments. The forum was a quarterly meeting of economic and financial officials from the 21 countries that form the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17 -- Thirty-six Americans were killed in action last week, the costliest of the Vietnamese war. One hundred ninety-six were wounded, and one was listed as missing.
RENO, Feb. 17 -- Chief Justice Frank McNamee of the Nevada Supreme Court was in critical condition today after suffering a savage beating in his apartment at Lake Tahoe, where he lives alone.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 17 -- The glory that was Charles Pasarell's and John Cooper's last night with their victories over Manuel Santana of Spain and Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy turned to ashes today in the national indoor tennis championships.

DETROIT, Feb. 17 -- Consumer optimism flattened out at a high level during the last quarter of 1964, despite favorable business trends, but the short-term outlook for consumer spending remains favorable.

In your columns recently appeared news articles describing action of the Mississippi Economic Council and the Mississippi Manufacturers Association urging that all Mississippians make adjustments to abide by the Civil Rights Act.
William Zeckendorf Sr. was accused yesterday of seeking kickbacks from three maintenance companies for their service contracts with four midtown office buildings.

Net operating earnings of the Irving Trust Company have been running 10 per cent above the levels a year ago since the beginning of January, but a somewhat smaller increase for all of 1965 is expected, officials said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Cuba and the Soviet Union signed in Moscow today a five-year financial agreement and their long-delayed trade pact for 1965.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 17 -- A 43-year-old woman set a startling example in county government today -- she refused to accept a $7,000 increase in salary.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The Senate and Assembly did not meet today. They will not meet tomorrow. They will not meet again until Monday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Walt Bellamy, who failed to start for the first time in his National Basketball Association career, left the bench and scored 24 points to help the Baltimore Bullets gain a 125-114 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Feb. 17 (Reuters) -- Hondurans elected today a constitutional Government likely to be headed by the air force colonel who has been chief of state since a military junta took power in a coup 16 months ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The State Department Recreation Association is canceling a charter flight to Europe in September because President Johnson believes Americans should see America first.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A bill to help Federal employes who lose their jobs because of closings of military bases was introduced today by Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Mrs. Hubert H. Humphrey said today that she believed the Vice Presidential family should have an official home large and suitable enough to meet the needs of the second highest position in the nation.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 17 -- The Indian Government told Parliament today that English would "continue to be the associate official language" as long as Indians who do not speak Hindi, the language of north-central India, wanted it.

BATHURST, Gambia, Thursday, Feb. 18 -- The Union Jack fluttered down over Gamble at midnight this morning, bringing an end to the last outpost of British colonial rule in West Africa and giving Africa its smallest and poorest independent state.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- The Government supported today an official ban on public showings of the controversial play The Deputy" in Rome. The police, meanwhile, were studying the possibility of a link between the dispute over the ban and the bombing of a gate to Vatican City early today.

Employes at Stern's department store rejected an offer of $6 a week in wage increases over a period of three years last night and said they planned to strike on March 1 if no agreement is reached by then.

MONTREAL, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens, getting shutout goal-tending from Charlie Hodge and a pair of power play goals from Henri Richard and Claude Provost, scored a 2-0 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Millsaps College today became the first all-white college in Mississippi to lower racial barriers voluntarily.

The Metropolitan Opera has found itself a first-rate baritone, ostas Paskalis, a native of Greece, made his debut with the company last night in the role of Don Carlo in Verdi's "La Forza del Destino," earning a well-deserved ovation for his commanding voice and stage presence.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The state is considering making birth-control information and funds for contraceptives available to unmarried welfare recipients who are at least 18 years old.

The old Merchants House, one of New York's most important historic houses and the only one with its original early 19th-century interior still intact, is facing sale and demolition, with dispersal of its contents.

The American Electric Power Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday record earnings of $75,449,000 for the 12 months ended Jan. 31. This was 7.8 per cent above the $69,982,000 reported one year earlier.
The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday price increases of up to 1 cent a pound on a broad range of aluminum sheet and coil products. The increases take effect today.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union, which have been feuding for three years over control of amateur sports in the United States, held an amicable, top-level conference yesterday and agreed to meet again within 30 days in an effort to settle their dispute.
The big event at the Associated Dry Goods Corporation in the fiscal year ended Feb. 1 was the "resurgence of downtown."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Johnson announced today that the Administration was about to extend more than $700 million worth of tax relief to business.

On the evening of Jan. 21, a telegram was sent to Barnett P. Torffield, 922 East 101st Street, in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, reading: "Please come to Cumberland Hospital emergency room to see physician."

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 17 -- Harold Pryor, representative of the Brotherhood of Railroad, Trainmen, said here today, that orders would go out Monday for a one-day stoppage on the Long Island Rail Road. The stoppage will be on April 22, opening day of the World's Fair 1965 season.
Qualified undergraduates at the senior colleges of the City University will soon have an opportunity to study abroad for a year, even if they cannot afford the cost.
United States battle casualties in Vietnam -- below 2,000 in four years of war -- have had no tangible effect upon service morale.

The New York Philharmonic will play at Philharmonic Hall tonight at 8:30. Josef Krips will conduct, with Gina Bachauer, pianist, and Walter Trampler, violist, as soloists.

There is little chance of any early results from the Kennedy Round of bargaining to liberalize trade. The preliminary sessions, devoted to industrial products, have ended inconclusively. Negotiations on agriculture, which the United States had hoped would begin this spring, have been postponed until September, mainly because the Common Market countries have yet to formulate a unified policy that can serve as a base for bargaining.

The Moscow visitors to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts yesterday were like any other tourists -- they took pictures, gaped, looked puzzled at the art display, expressed their admiration and talked animatedly about the architectural dimensions of the cultural institution.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- "19-year-old dancer seeks part-time work," says a notice on a shop front in that part of West London where the naked bodies of six strangled prostitutes have been found in the last 15 months.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- New orders for durable goods rose slightly in January after a big jump in December, the Commerce Department reported today.
ANTIQUES shows have tended, in recent years, to weaken in quality because of shortages and the unwillingness of one-man or one-woman shops to take on a double burden.
TORONTO, Feb. 17 -- Some resistence is being encountered by the first offering of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) to be made in Canada in 10 years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- All pro-Western groups in the United Nations put pressure on the United States today to relax for one day the voting ban on the Soviet Union and other countries that are in arrears on assessments.

THE community theaters of the country, the source of so much vital experimentation in drama and perhaps the truest expression of the mounting viability of the national culture, joined forces last night with the television medium in a venture of significance for viewer and artist alike.

The Corn Products Company had a decline in earnings last year from the level in 1963 despite higher sales, according to the report yesterday of A.N. McFarlane, president. The drop was attributed to a five-month strike and high costs of a new-products program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The White House announced today it had acquired two important paintings by John Singer Sargent and Winslow Homer, generally regarded as among the greatest American artists.
A transparent coating material that is said to have less than 150th of the thickness of common household wraps has been added to the family of plastics by the Union Carbide Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall suggested today the need for a national energy policy to deal with such problems as developing the oil-rich shale lands in the West.
Angry tenants were not the only ones yesterday who called the city's special telephone number, WO 4-3000, to register housing complaints.

The management of "Baker Street," the musical hit that opened Tuesday night at the Broadway Theater, said yesterday that the production cost was $610,000. This was close to the estimate of $630,000 made last-week by Alexander H. Cohen, producer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- In Congress, in the diplomatic corps and in mail reaching Washington, there is more and more talk in favor of "negotiation" over Vietnam. But the Administration continued today to shun that word or any other suggestion that it might wish to bargain for peace.

BATHURST, Gambia, Thursday, Feb 18 -- Other African heads of state drive Rolls-Royces or Cadillacs. Some, like William V.S. Tubman of Liberia and Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast, have built themselves million-dollar palaces.

CH. CARMICHAEL'S Fanfare, the Scottish terrier who rose as high as a show dog can go when she won the best-in-show award at the Westminster Kennel Club event in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night, will not be seen in a ring again.
Why is a Well-brought-up girl like a 1965 Buick? Answer: Because they both possess the virtues of thrift, honesty, modesty, thoughtfulness and promptness.

Lincoln Center agreed yesterday to postpone the demolition of part of the High School of Commerce for three years while a proposed new academic high school seating 3,000 students was being constructed.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 17I -- The Army basketball teaml }ran its won-lost record to 16 -- { ]7 today with an 82-67 victory I over Massachusetts.

Merck Co. has realigned its chemical division by separating its marketing and production units, it was announced yesterday by Henry W. Gadsden, president.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- Stan Mikita scored with less than six minutes to play tonight to gain the National Hockey League scoring lead and give the Chicago Black Hawks a 5-4 triumph over the New York Rangers.
WHILE Bonwit Teller has roamed the world in its search for fashion news, it had to go no farther than Chicago for the cosmopolitan designs of Walter Holmes.
BELLEVILLE, Ill., Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Air Force announced at Scott Air Force Base near here today that its air-traffic controllers had saved 113 military and civilian airplanes during 1964.

TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- The State Senate passed four bills today involving two plans for redrawing New Jersey's 15 Congressional districts and reapportioning both houses of its Legislature.

I am baffled by the attitude of the New York City Art Commission in turning down a proposed memorial to the Jewish victims of Nazism for one of the city's parks. Judge J. Skelly Wright of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia predicted last night that the Supreme Court would eventually hold that de facto school segregation was unconstitutional.

Blyth Co., Inc., which hast been a large factor in the so-called third market -- trading listed stocks off the New York Stock Exchange and maintaining active trading markets in a wide number of listed and over-the-counter stocks -- announced yesterday it would apply shortly for membership on the Big Board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A big dish in a dome will be built atop an Arizona mountain peak as science's latest instrument for tuning in on the raucous "music" of the heavens, the Government announced today.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 17 -- The resignation of Dr. Lucile A. Allen, dean of women at Stanford University, was followed today by the resignation of her associate dean, Miss Bonnie Fitzgerald.

HONG KONG, Feb. 17 -- Liu Shao-chi, head of state of Communist China, declared tonight that his country firmly supported North Vietnam in what he termed its "righteous struggle to counter United States imperialist aggression."

The Celanese Corporation of America announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $78,859,800 of convertible subordinated debentures due in 1990.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Attempts to cooperate with the Soviet Union on space matters have proved frustrating, a high space agency official said today.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 17 -- The four parties that overthrew the Government of Premier Ismet Inonu Saturday fell to quarreling among themselves today, much as Mr. Inonu had predicted.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The Democratic leadership in the Legislature announced plans today for an investigation of the structure of hospitalization insurance, including medical services, in the state.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Dr. John S. Toll, a theoretical physicist, was chosen today as president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I.
