WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Dean Burch, the Republican National Chairman, said today that his party must consolidate its gains in the South without resorting to racist appeals, "overt or covert."
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 17 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury involved in a controversy between the Justice Department and a Federal judge was dismissed without comment today.

OTTAWA, Feb. 17 -- The Royal Canadian Mounted Police may be internationally known and admired for "always getting its man," but the "Mounties were in trouble today because they don't always catch the man in both English and French.

TOKYO, Feb. 17 -- Finance Minister Kakuei Tanaka said today that the Soviet Union had offered to sell Japan about $200 million worth of gold. But since the offer was not made formally, the Japanese Government gave it no serious consideration, he declared.

The second largest offering of this week's calender of new municipal issues, Wisconsin State Agencies Building Corporation's $35,335,000 of revenue bonds, was "about half sold," a spokesman for the winning syndicate said late yesterday afternoon.
A $2.25 million suit, the first one in the aftermath of the crash of an Eastern Air Lines plane off Jones Beach on Feb. 8, was filed yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 17 -- Negro farmers and housewives told the United States Civil Rights Commission today that they had been subjected to day-to-day terrorism for asserting their political rights in Mississippi.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- State Senator John J. Marchi was upbraided today by a colleague, who accused him of irresponsibility in his investigation of the New York City Mobilization for Youth organization.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17 -- Educators will have to start practicing what they teach if they are to convince their students of the hazards of smoking, a public health expert said here today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- It was neither a bird nor Superman that drifted out of the sky here yesterday -- just a beige and khaki-striped helicopter bearing Charles H. Revson, one of the least accessible tycoons.

The Coast Guard disclosed yesterday it had asked to take over Governors Island to consolidate its New York area facilities and move in a training school from Groton, Conn., which has a $2.5-million-a-year payroll.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Vice Adm. Roy L. Johnson will become Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific fleet.

Distinguished world leaders are in New York for a convocation centered on Pope John XXIII's great encyclical, Pacem in Terris. As they began their search for peace and order, they read headlines like these which appeared on the front page of yesterday's Times:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Real Estate Board of Greater Baltimore -- the nation's fifth-ranking urban area in percentage of Negro population -- appealed to President Johnson today for an immediate and far-reaching extension of President Kennedy's 1962 executive order on discrimination in housing.
A special Federal grand jury in Brooklyn investigating alleged graft and corruption in the Internal Revenue Service yesterday indicted 14 men and a woman.

Charles G. Bennett's Feb. 11 news story "Planners Oppose Garage in Park" (meaning Madison Square Park), says: "The commission declared that public funds should not be used as a matter of policy and public welfare to invite still more private automobiles into our central business district."

Konrad Adenauer will receive an advance payment of $70,000 from the Henry Regnery Company of Chicago for the projected three volumes of his memoirs, according to the publishing concern. The first volume is scheduled for publication late this year.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 18 (Reuters) -- United States jetfighters took off from here in the direction of Laos on a secret mission today and returned four hours later.

Four hundred boycotting Negro students broke through police barricades outside Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn yesterday in a brick-throwing, window-breaking riot. Three policemen were struck, one youth was injured and nine were arrested.
Carl T. Rowan, director of the United Stats Information Agency, gave his side yesterday in the war of words between Madison Avenue and Pennsylvania Avenue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- The United States announced today a pledge of $24.7 million for the 1965 operations of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency in Palestine, subject to the condition that the ineligible persons be removed from the relief rolls.

The Xerox Corporation, manufacturer of copying machines and photo paper, is going into the educational and instructional business through the purchase of Basic Systems, Inc. for stock valued at $5,396,063.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 17 -- Pierre Salinger was talking on the telephone and a cloud of cigar smoke hung over his desk. "Use my influence?" he was shouting into the receiver. "If I had any influence I wouldn't be here."
An increase of 3,304,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
Most ports in the East and South remained strikebound yesterday, the 38th day of the longshoremen's walkout.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The Government virtually challenged Britain's National Health doctors today to carry out their threat to strike over pay.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 17 -- The Government of India took several steps today to check the decline of its foreign exchange reserves. The moves were:
BONN, Feb. 17 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard attacked President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic today in a bitter parliamentary debate on West Germany's Middle East policy.
The Navy offered a long-term charter yesterday to any private ship concern willing to build and operate a large, fast "roll-on, roll-off" vessel.

THE Senate antitrust and monopoly subcommittee hearings on baseball begin in Washington today. The first spotlight will be trained on the Columbia Broadcasting System's purchase of the New York Yankees last summer, with William S. Paley and Dr. Frank Stanton, top C.B.S. executives, scheduled to testify along with Dan Topping, the man who sold the club and who is still its president.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, warned today that steps taken by the United States to curtail the outflow of capital abroad were harmful to international investments.
Discussions are being held at the highest level of the state land city governments with a view to changing the image of the World's Fair for its 1965 season.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 17 -- Bill Radcliffe, a 6-foot-3-inch junior from Prospect Park, Pa., set a fieldhouse record of 41 points in leading Navy to a 70 -- 62 basketball victory over Hofstra today.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 17 -- The president of the National Football League's champion team said today that there was little chance for a peaceful resolution of the costly war between the two professional football leagues.
Stocks rose on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, led by blue-chip shares and gilt-edge securities.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- A bipartisan committee of the State Legislature added its voice today to the growing opposition to the proposed Consolidated Edison power plant at Storm King Mountain, on the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, 18 -- Young Republicans were told today that the party must make itself more attractive to Negroes, Americans of foreign extraction and other minority groups to win future elections.

IT wasn't a large item. But Ank Scanlan wasn't a large man. The item reported the death of Anthony J. Scanlan, the football coach at Holy Cross for three seasons, and made casual mention that he had had a key part in what is generally considered the most astonishing upset in the history of college football, the 55-12 rout of unbeaten Boston College by Holy Cross.

Despite an eight-month-old state law requiring hospitals and members of the medical profession to report suspected cases of child beating to welfare authorities, doctors are still apparently reluctant to comply.
HONG KONG, Feb. 18 -- Marshal Chen Yi, Communist China's Foreign Minister, declared tonight that there could be no Vietcong cease-fire before the United States withdrew from South Vietnam.
BOSTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A new heart-lung technique holds promise of saving the lives of some 38,000 Americans a year, a Texas surgeon said here today.
TOMS RIVER, N.J., Feb. 18 -- An executive of the Toms River Chemical Corporation poured an ounce of the company's waste into a glass of water today and drank it. Nothing happened to him.
BILL NAUGHTON writes fondly and humorously of lower middle-class English folk in "All in Good Time," just as he did in "Alfie," which had a brief life here earlier in the season.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 18 -- India's Home Minister declared today in a written statement to Parliament that the "left Communist party" of India planned to "launch a violent revolutionary struggle -- which they hope will coincide with a fresh Chinese thrust on our borders."

Recent increases in short-term interest rates, together with figures released last night by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, have convinced many Wall Street observers that monetary authorities are tightening the availability of credit.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States last month was the highest for any January, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it would contribute $50,000 a year to the American Academy of Dramatic Arts to help finance the training of young actors. It will donate an extra $12,000 a year to underwrite scholarships for 16 students selected by A.B.C. and the Academy.
PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 18 -- The National Football League decided today upon a 40-player squad limit for the 1965 season, the same as in 1964, but liberalized ways to replace injured players.
The Ranger 8 spacecraft, launched Wednesday from Cape Kennedy, is speeding toward the moon with "fantastic accuracy," according to a spokesman for the Jet Propulsion Laboratory of Pasadena, Calif.
The New Haven Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for permission to end passenger service to four Westchester County stations on March 29.

The salary of Mrs. Hortense W. Gabel, City Rent and Rehabilitation Administrator, was raised yesterday from $22,500 to $25,000 a year. This increase, together with others was made known through budget modifications published in The City Record.

Enthusiasts for fine printing plan to form a Goudy Society at a dinner here on March 8. That date is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Frederic W. Goudy, noted type designer. Dr. J. Ben Lieberman of 202 Beverly Road, White Plains, who operates a private press, is making reservations for the dinner at the Roger Smith Hotel, Lexington Avenue and 47th Street.
Industrial stocks led a moderate advance yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
The New York Typographical Union will resume negotiations for a new working contract next week with the Publishers Association of New York City.
New York University's basketball team experienced one of its finest hours last night in Madison Square Garden.

Three hundred rampaging Negro students from boycotted schools swept through streets in downtown Brooklyn yesterday, hurling bricks at policemen and breaking windows of stores in a second day of rioting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Johnson Administration asked American corporations today to draw up their own individual balances of international payments and to reduce by 15 to 20 per cent this year their net flow of dollars out of the country.
MISSOULA, Mont., Feb. 16 -- The middle-aged woman stepped off the plane from Spokane and went straight to the taxi to go home. She asked the cab driver, after exchanging greetings:
Alvin L. Mitchell went on trial yesterday for the second time in the murder of Barbara Kralik in Springfield Gardens Queens.

Just two days after his 69th birthday, Alexander Brailowsky returned to Carnegie Hall for his first recital here in more than three years. The concert, originally scheduled for Feb. 4, had been moved up to last night because the pianist had a virus infection.
As an occasional New York area helicopter passenger, I was interested in your Feb. 6 editorial comments in support of continuing Federal subsidies for that service.

BRASILIA, Brazil, Feb. 18 -- President Humberto Castelo Branco's revolutionary Government, trying to change the leadership of the Chamber of Deputies, was defied by Brazil's biggest political party today.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 18 -- Mayor Wagner declared here today that New York City's "worst blight" was "a special underworld of the poor which preys primarily upon the poor."
The World's Fair yesterday suspended its efforts to raise the 3.5 million it needs to open its 1965 season.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Huge Television antennas are an increasing hazard to aviation, the heads of two Federal agencies said today.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 18 -- New Jersey won its fight today against property owners challenging the state's aerial spraying program for gypsy moths.
BATHURST, Gambia, Feb. 18 -- On this, the first day of the Gambia's independence, the smallest and poorest of the new African states is already causing Washington a diplomatic problem.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Iowa Legislature today abolished the death penalty, which has been in effect since 1878 after Jesse James began to make murderous forays into the state.
The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the issuance of an order banning public-school boycotts was a matter for the state courts. The order thus remains in effect.
The 39-day longshore strike has brought critical losses to the nation's export business, particularly in grains.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 18 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, in an unusual exposition of nuclear war studies, estimated today that more than 120 million Americans would die in the event of a Soviet missile attack on the United States in the early nineteen-seventies.

The Metropolitan Chapter of the Finlandia Foundation will hold its annual dinner dance in the Jade Room at the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 27. Proceeds will go to the Sibelius Scholarship Fund, which makes possible the exchange of music students between Finland and the United States.

The New York Philharmonic will play at Philharmonic Hall today at 2:15 P.M. Josef Krips will conduct, with Gina Bachauer, pianist, and Walter Trampler, violist, as soloists. Fritz Kramer will present a pre-Philharmonic Concert Lecture in the Choral Room of Philharmonic Hall at 11 A.M.

A new series of ads using unconventional photos of men and women is designed to give a youthful new image to the 50-year-old clothing company of Pincus Brothers-Maxwell, Inc. (PBM). At least that's what the release says.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The United States decision to let the Soviet Union cast a vote in the General Assembly today is regarded as a tactical retreat from earlier Administration policy. The retreat stemmed from a decision to avoid at all costs a showdown with the Soviet Union.

Mieczyslaw Horszowski has been playing here regularly for almost 40 years and demonstrating that his diminutive figure holds a mind and spirit encompassing a vast amount of musical literature. In 1954-55 he played 12 programs that included almost all the music that Beethoven wrote for the piano, and time and again he has returned to the works of that composer.

Small, complete cities on the outskirts of major urban centers will be necessary in the future, even if the central cities are revitalized, the president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards said recently.
TRENTON, Friday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Two key Republican measures aimed at reapportioning the New Jersey Legislature were defeated in the Assembly early today.

" The Days Between," a new play by Robert Anderson, author of the successful "Tea and Sympathy," is to be performed in at least 32 university and 11 community theaters. Arrangements were made by the American Playwrights Theater, a nonprofit venture jointly conducted by the American Educational Theater Association.
Action on the Federal, state and city levels may save the old Merchant's House, the New York landmark that is threatened with demolition after resisting for more than 130 years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) -- A manufacturer of electronic eavesdropping devices told Senate investigators today that a private conversation in the nation's capital could be monitored in Hawaii.
Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain stopped off briefly at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, on her way to Kingston, Jamaica.

AT the great age of 83 Augustin Cardinal Bea, a thin, bent, ascetic man with a gentle smile, has brought to fruition his unremitting campaign, begun under the auspices of Pope John XXIII, to establish a bridge between the Roman Catholic Church and the world of Protestant and Orthodox churches.

IN "Patrick -- The First," the author, Father Brendan Larnen, demonstrates that plays about saints need not be solemn preachments. They can be lighthearted without being impious and instructive without being pontifical.
NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 18 -- Spring may be a month and more away, but today a lot of people in the suburbs were trying to prod its arrival.
" The Whitmore case has given confessions a bad name," an assistant district attorney said ruefully the other day.
Five men and a youth, who jostled each other in a crowded IND subway train last evening, engaged in a brawl in which one man was stabbed while passengers climbed over each other to avoid injury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Representative Adam Clayton Power took the House floor today to accuse three men of murder, charge police corruption, attack the press and review his personal problems in the courts.

Foreigners and women, both in unparalleled quantities, will compete in Madison Square Garden this afternoon and tonight on the opening programs of the Amateur Athletic Union national inndoor track and field championships.

Waddell Reed, Inc., predicted yesterday that approval of its new brokerage subsidiary as a member firm of the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange would mean greater competition among the nation's stock exchanges.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Feb. 18 -- Premier Sir-el-Khatim el-Khalifa bowed to right-wing pressures today and submitted the resignation of the Sudan's 15-man caretaker Cabinet.

The David McKay Company, which will distribute 'Who's Who in World Jewry -- 1965," gave a reception yesterday marking publication of the book and also the 80th birthday of Harry Schneiderman, its co-editor.
Mother is no longer the chief family purchasing agent, according to David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York.

THE recent fascination with interior decoration of the nineteen-thirties has burst into full flower in Altman's newly redesigned modern section of the eighth-floor furniture department. A show of new furniture called Design Perspective '65 opens there today.
Earnings of the J.I. Case Company fell sharply in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31 even though sales rose, Merritt D. Hill, president, told the company's annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.
New York State plans to sell $43.61 million of housing bonds on March 9, Arthur Levitt, controller, announced yesterday.

The 70-city, 240-performance tour by the Metropolitan Opera National Company is three-quarters booked. The announcement was made yesterday by officers of the Met and its national company at Clowes Hall of Butler University in Indianapolis, where the company will begin its first season Sept. 1 20.
SEATTLE, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Three Seattle University basketball players, one of them the team captain and top scorer, were expelled from school today in a point-shaving scandal.
MARION, Ala., Feb. 18 -- About 50 state troopers fought crowds of screaming Negroes with night sticks in the town square tonight.
Federal indictments will be sought next week against the four people charged with conspiring to blow up the Statue of Liberty, the Liberty Bell and the Washington Monument.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange staged a moderate advance yesterday in active trading.
The Administration's approach to the balance-of-payments problem, while "an essentially negative" one, may have a good chance of working reasonably well.
The frozen body of a boy, found last Friday at a Boy Scout camp near Alpine, N.J., was identified yesterday as 9- year-old David Irizarry of the Bronx. He had been missing since Dec. 23.

When the Rev. Dr. Milton A. Galamison started his abortive school boycott, his supporters called the action a "curriculum in social protest." The shocking violence his group has engendered around the Board of Education headquarters in the past two days can only be viewed as a lesson in delinquency.

The New England Electric System's rights offering of 698,227 common shares to its stockholders at $26.25 a share was oversubscribed, William Webster, chairman of the utility holding company, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) -- The Air Traffic Control Association denied today that a near-collision was a factor in the crash of an Eastern Air Lines DC-7B near New York Feb. 8.
BOAT builders will get a chance to make a better "sandwich" hull this season with a new material billed as the greatest filling since tuna fish salad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Representative Richard L. Ottinger introduced legislation today offering tax advantages to those who contribute to the cost of political campaigns. He hopes to induce more people to donate funds.

The public and government, on all levels, have had a long grace period since the first desperate warnings of countdown to end of commuter service on the New Haven. Now that countdown has really begun, with the bankrupt road's trustees filing request with the Interstate Commerce Commission for abandoning some schedules and curtailing others.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- The weakness of the United Nations was never more obvious than in its present paralysis over the Vietnamese crisis. It could not hope to settle that conflict, for it was never organized to deal with the disputes among the great powers, but at least it was organized to talk, and it is not even talking about Vietnam.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The body of Mrs. Joan Merriam Smith, the 28-year-old flier, was identified today.
CAIRO, Feb. 18 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser declared tonight that the United Arab Republic could get along without West Germany's economic aid.
The wholesale commodity price index dropped to 102.1 on Wednesday from the revised figure of 102.3 on Tuesday.
The spot rate on the British pound and the 90-day forward rate on the Canadian dollar enlivened transactions on the foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The Chilean Government and the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., have reached an agreement for the purchase of Foreign Power's electric utility subsidiary in that South American nation.

THE convulsions of recent history have been so great, the behavior of many people so horrible and the sufferings of many more so terrible that writers of topical fiction are almost forced to deal in both melodrama and tragedy.
The American Stock Exchange has reported the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- In an atmosphere of complete mutual understanding, the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee listened today to Dan Topping of the New York Yankees and Dr. Frank Stanton, the president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, describe the circumstances of the network's purchase of the ball club last August.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The House voted 288 to 92 today to provide $750 million toward loans for Latin America.
Several more aluminum producers, large and small, announced yesterday they had decided to increase prices on a wide range of fabricated products effective immediately.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- British expectations of favorable results from the meeting between Prime Minister Wilson and President de Gaulle have risen markedly in recent weeks.
A bus returning from opening night at Yonkers Raceway with 71 persons aboard collided with a sanitation truck early this morning at Broadway and 133d Street, the police reported.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Hungary, after a delay of five days, expressed regret today for last Saturday's incident in Budapest when about 200 rioting students broke into the United States legation.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 18 (AP) -- New Jersey is still in a drought that began three and a half years ago, an official of the Weather Bureau said today.
STEWART, B.C., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Forty men were trapped today, 25 of them in an 11-mile tunnel, when an avalanche struck at the Granduc mine.
Time, Inc., reported yesterday record earnings of $26,526,000 for 1964, a gain of 87 per cent over the $14,204,000 earned in 1963.

A survey of social problems in the West Side Urban Renewal area, issued yesterday by the Housing and Redevelopment Board; takes the city to task for permitting slum conditions to exist in tenements it had taken over on the West Side.
ALBANY, Feb, 18 -- "My dear man, we only started putting our staff together this week." That was one State Senator's reply today when asked how soon. the committee he heads would begin work.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 -- The Labor party gave qualified endorsement today to United States actions in Vietnam but called for a cease-fire and negotiation to settle the conflict there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The State Department expressed disapproval today of the boycott of West German goods imposed by some American manufacturers and Jewish groups in retaliation for Bonn's halting of arms shipments to Israel.

BONN, Feb. 18 -- Transport Minister Hans-Christoph Selbohm charged today that his fellow Sudeten Germans had suffered incomparably more at the hands of the Czechoslovaks than the Czechoslovaks had suffered at the hands of the Nazis in World War II.
Negotiations between the United Steelworkers of America and the can industry will resume in New York City next Tuesday, though the outcome of the union's election remains in doubt.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 18 (AP) -- The personal income of Americans climbed $3.7 billion in January to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $509.6 billion, more than 6 per cent higher than in January, 1964, the Commerce Department reported today.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Unemployment was reported down today to a nine-year low, and production figures rose sharply.
A statewide bond referendum in Arkansas on Saturday, Feb. 27, is expected to provide one of the first significant portents of strength for an election to be held in 1966.
Elston Gene Howard was subjected yesterday to baseball's offseason tribal ritual known as the contract-signing.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 19--South Vietnamese marine and army units marched into Saigon today and announced the overthrow of the military strongman, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 -- John R. Gaines said today the largest single thoroughbred bloodstock transaction in history, a purchase and syndication agreement with Rex Ellsworth involving $3.7 million, had been completed.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Feb. 18 -- James Baldwin, the Negro writer, won a two-minute standing ovation from nearly 1,000 Cambridge University students tonight with an emotional talk on the plight of the American Negro that wound up as an indictment of American society.

Your Feb. 6 editorial on the honor system does a fair and accurate job. However, in the interest of the clarification and elucidation you urge, I wonder if the cause might not be served by placing honesty and honor in separate categories where they could be individually considered.

Employes retreated to the rear of a store, fearful of the rampaging Negro student rioters. An elderly woman cashier stared terrified from her outdoor glass-enclosed cage of the motion-picture house as they banged on the window.
ROME, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Vatican's Film Review Commission has given American movie production in 1964 a higher moral rating than films made in Europe.
DOLGEVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The body of a 23-year-old cave explorer was sealed in the bottom of a cavern today by tons of earth and rock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Justice Department is investigating the proposed merger of the Union Oil Company of California with the Pure Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- President Johnson named J. Irwin Miller today to the chairmanship of a new committee on trade relations with Eastern European nations and the Soviet Union. Mr. Miller, of Columbus, Ind., is an industrialist with wide-spread business interests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Government removed today a major restraint on the award of Federal contracts to four companies involved in the construction of a $32 million Federal office building in Cleveland.

Detective John C. Devlin's Police Department trial closed yesterday with a defense argument that the detective "had to" shoot Gregory Cruz because the clerk, a suspect-by-mistake in a murder hunt, had assaulted the detective.
Government intervention in the activities of shipping conferences has been bought at a "high" price; Thorkil Host, president of the Moiler Steamship Company, said last night.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A mob of Communist-inspired youths attacked the United States consulate in Medan today in the fifth such assault on official American properties in Indonesia in the last six-months, as United States diplomats protested.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara's statement to the House Armed Services Committee:
BONN, Feb. 18 -- The solidarity of 20 defendants in the Frankfurt war crimes trial crumbled today when one of the accused charged another with "thousandfold murder."

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 18 -- Senator Suat Hayri Urguplu attempted without success today to weld Turkey's four opposition parties into a new government. He said tonight that he would resume his efforts tomorrow and expected to be successful.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Representative William Fitts Ryan of Manhattan was reported today to be considering the possibility of opposing Mayor Wagner in the Democratic primary for Mayor this year.
The rational voice of The Times concerning the debacle in Vietnam deserves the full support of responsible citizens everywhere.

PALM DESERT, Calif., Feb. 18 -- At the National Football League's annual meeting here this week, the only moment of crisis came when a stubborn golf cart being used by the wife of one team owner began to smoke, frightening the women's foursome.
Both factions in New Jersey's warring labor movement have accepted a formula for healing their split.
The Police Department here reported last night that an indictment had already been returned in the killing of Powers, who was called Power by Mr. Powell.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 (UPI) -- Three men indicted on charges of conspiracy to libel Senator Thomas H. Kuchel, Republican of California, were arraigned today. A fourth accused in the same indictment agreed to return voluntarily from New Jersey.
The psychoanalyst's couch may not be the best place for the ad man to determine buying motivation, after all. The courtroom approach may prove even more scientific.

WALTER CRONKITE is in line for a viewer's highest decoration. He has fearlessly suggested that in 1968 both the Republicans and the Democrats bar television's walkie-talkies and strolling reportorial packhorses from the floors of the conventions and bring an end to the "wild scramble" of electronic filibustering that marked last summer's deliberations in San Francisco and Atlantic City.

JERICHO, Jordan -- If it were not for the cheerful personality of Antranig D. Bakerjian, the refugee camp of Aqabat Jaber might look miserable and morose. Mr. Bakerjian is the administrator for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency.
TODAY is the day winter-bound outdoorsmen any age, size or sex can cease snarling at co-workers and family and find serenity at the Coliseum.

YONKERS, Feb. 18 -- Harness racing returned to Yonkers Raceway tonight and 40,752 fans, putting their money where their thoughts had been these last two months, poured $2,839,113 into the mutuel machines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Some air and sea extensions of the distant early warning line (DEW line) will be eliminated by the middle of next year at an eventual saving of $266 million, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today.

SAIGON, Friday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The coup leader, Col. Pham Ngoc Thao, said he had the support of the 25th, the 9th, the 7th and the 5th Army Divisions, which are stationed in areas adjoining Saigon, part of the Marine Corps and part of the Air Force.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 18 -- Uneasiness about France's general economic health mounted today in the European Economic Community in the wake of charges that the Government of France has been concealing new evidence of further deterioration of France's world trade position.
The Federal Government was urged yesterday to pay more attention to guarding welfare clients against infringements on their constitutional rights.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A lengthy Congressional investigation of whether the state and the automobile manufacturers are promoting highway safety was announced today by Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 -- A United States Embassy spokesman said today that the South Vietnamese Navy had a right to operate off the shores of North Vietnam.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Wes Ellis Jr. of West Caldwell, N.J., smashed the tournament record today with a seven-under-par 65 for a two-stroke lead in the first round of the Bogota open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- An 11-member labor advisory council has been appointed to help Sargent Shriver deal with such problems as employment and training in programs tied to what President Johnson calls his war on poverty.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 18 -A 20-foot jump shot by John Stevens with two seconds left gave Fordham a 67-65 victory tonight over Rutgers. Stevens, who scored 27 points, ran his career total to 1,006.

A new idea to save the nation's ailing commercial helicopter services has been offered by Senator A.S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, who is chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee's aviation subcommittee.
The Building Trades Employers' Association has elected Jeremiah J. Burns, head of a metal furring and lathing concern that bears his name, as president for the coming year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- The United States and the Soviet Union joined today in defeating Albania's attempt to force a showdown in the General Assembly on the question of unpaid assessments for United Nations peace-keeping forces.
OTTAWA, Feb. 18 -- The Liberal Government moved today toward broadly expanded health and pension plans.
ALBANY Feb. 18 -- The Democrats abandoned today their plans to hold a number of hearings in various sections of the state on Governor Rockefeller's $3.48 billion budget.

In The Times of Feb. 15 you have a Page 1 story saying that Robert Moses wants $100 million to build a bridge across Long Island Sound to relieve the city's "congested core." [Editorial Feb. 18.] On Page 20 (and in a letter from our new junior Senator) we read that every trip of a New Haven passenger train may be the last -- for want of $12 million, give or take a bit.

BONN -- West German policy is rigidly limited by insistence on severing relations with any country -- save Russia -- that recognizes East Germany. Nevertheless, Bonn is making serious efforts to broaden economic ties with Eastern Europe.

The New York Stock Exchange revised yesterday its plan for a new building near Battery Park. This change of mind could save the exchange nearly $30 million. The Big Board announced it is negotiating with private interests to acquire a portion of land near Battery Park on the southern tip of Manhattan for a new home for the exchange.
PARIS, Feb. 18 -- President de Gaulle invited Prime Minister Harold Wilson today to visit him here in April in a significant move to mend relations with Britain.

ROME, Feb. 18 -- The police said today that Claudio Volonte, younger brother of Gian Maria Volonte, the actor-director of the banned Italian production of the play "The Deputy," was implicated in the explosion of a bomb at a side entrance to Vatican City early yesterday.

A SHARP contrast in soloists, last night at the concert of the New York Philharmonic, presented Walter Trampler and Gina Bachauer. Mr. Trampler played Walter Piston's Viola Concerto, and Miss Bachauer was piano soloist in Beethoven's "Emperor."
MOSCOW, Feb. 18 -- In the view of well-informed diplomats here, it would be dangerous to overestimate the desire of the Soviet leaders to improve their relations with the United States.

GENEVA, Feb. 18--The Roman Catholic Church took a major step today toward cooperation with other Christian faiths in the search for unity.

Bruno Sammartino, the wrestling champion who yearns to get away from responsibilities (ambition: disc jockey), took his 5-foot-11-inch, 262-pound frame, which has supposedly sustained 10 broken noses, 70 head stitches and numerous shattered ribs, into the Madison Square Garden ring last night.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh was negotiating the final terms of his withdrawal from Saigon politics tonight, with no public voice raised in regret over his departure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon disclosed today that under-withholding of income taxes last year probably totaled only about $400 million to $500 million instead of well over $1 billion as had been assumed earlier.

John P. Kearney was named general manager of the Libbey Products section of Owens-Illinois Glass Company's consumer and technical products division yesterday. He will be succeeded as general manager of industrial and electronic products by W.B. Achenbach.
Quincy Porter, the composer, will retire on July 1 from both his posts at Yale University -- Battell Professor of Theory of Music and Master of Pierson College. He is 68 years old.
Like the Continental Army at Valley Forge, thousands of New Yorkers braved the bitter wind yesterday because of George Washington.

SEATTLE, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court, stressing the significance to the world of Chinese population growth, advocated today the demilitarization of Taiwan and the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
The New York Yankees signed two pitchers, Jim Bouton and Steve Hamilton, to 1965 contracts yesterday and the New York Mets brought one of their pitchers, Galen Cisco into the fold.
SEATTLE, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The possibility of developing a manned telescope to orbit the earth 200 miles out is being studied by scientists in an aerospace laboratory in Seattle.
Following are tributes expressed last night on the death of retired Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter:

NASHVILLE, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A Federal judge permanently lifted a Senate floor ban against The Nashville Tennessean's reporters today. The judge called the ban "a dangerous step toward press control and censorship.''
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 22 -- A red-checked young man in horn-rimmed glasses, tricornered hat and military cape strode up to the sentry box blowing on his hands.

TOKYO, Feb. 22 (Reuters) -- Masanori Murakami, the left-handed pitcher claimed by both the San Francisco Giants and the Nankai Hawks of Japan, said today he had "no intention" of playing baseball in the United States.
High-ranking military officers joined the Sons of the Revolution in a dinner dance at the Plaza last evening to observe the 233d anniversary of George Washington's birth.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Duke of Windsor came to London today for treatment of eye trouble.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Dangerous conditions on the mile-long Mount Van Hoevenberg run caused competition in the international bobsled races to be canceled today for the second time in three days.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 22 (UPI) -- A reporter and a lawyer disagreed today on the question of pretrial publicity in criminal cases.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Unseeded Steve of Vehstage of New York, a three-time national intercollegiate champion, today captured the 54th United States men's squash racquets title at the Hartford Gold Club courts.
GENEVA, Feb. 22 -- Britain's unhappy European trading partners expressed "warm satisfaction" over the announcement today that the 15 per cent import surcharge would be reduced two months from now.

The American Friends of Vietnam, a private organization of specialists on Asian affairs and others who know the area through government and academic work, has issued a statement announcing its support of the recent air strikes in North Vietnam and calling for a "stronger American action and involvement."

Some unusual subway posters are going up around town -- from Kulicke's frame shop on upper Madison Avenue to a variety of Greenwich Village bars. If one looks closely at them, one will see beneath a scrawl of red paint the familiar Levy's Indian.
BONN, Feb. 22 -- The United States, Britain and France are rallying to West Germany's aid in its efforts to limit the effect of East Germany's political breakthrough in the Middle East.
Every third merchant ship in service in the world last year became disabled in part, according to a leading British insurance association.
Manhattan's eight Councilmen will meeet again today to try to pick a new Borough President.
Robert Moses rekindled yesterday the controversy over the bridging of Long Island Sound between Westchester and Nassau Counties.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 22 (UPI) -- Ohio State pushed Michigan State deeper into last place in the Big Ten tonight with a 101-90 defeat that ran the Spartans' losing streak to 10 games.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI) -- William Haggin Perry's Jacinto raced to his fifth straight victory and to major Kentucky Derby consideration today, capturing the $57,900 San Felipe Handicap for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita by a neck.

In the first half of last night's concert in Carnegie Hall, George Szell conducted his Cleveland Orchestra in a performance of Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony that radiated a gleaming clarity of detail. It was so extraordinary that anything thereafter threatened to sound anti-climactic.
Flags flew last evening in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom in honor of the Air Force men who gained triumphs for the United States. The event was the second annual Air Force Salute.
Plans for the establishment in Harlem of a repertory theater and school were announced yesterday by LeRoi Jones, playwright. The project will be known as the Black Arts Repertory Theater/School.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 -- George Meany urged the United Steelworkers of America today to extend contracts with the basic steel industry beyond the May 1 deadline when the union will be free to strike.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations initiated a nationwide drive today to win support for repeal of a section in the Taft-Hartley Law permitting states to prohibit the union shop.
PARIS, Feb. 22--North Vietnam recently urged France to intensify her efforts for a negotiated settlement of the war in South Vietnam, a reliable French source said today.
THE Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional tournament at the New York Hilton ended last night with the Team of Four event after four days of play.
Queens College took 10 of 11 events yesterday to win the City University of New York indoor track championships. The Knights scored 75 poin ts.

MIAMI, Feb. 22 -- Hail to All was last on the backstretch but first at the wire today in the seven-furlong Hibiscus Stakes at Hialeah. The fast-finishing colt, owned by Mrs. Ben Cohen, wife of the secretary-treasurer of the Pimlico track in Baltimore, scored by a neck over the Jumping Brook Farm's Hi-Hasty in the field of 11 contestants.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Democratic sources said today that party leaders were considering the elimination of the State Commission of Investigation or the ouster of Governor Rockefeller's investigator, Herman T. Stichman.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- -Andre Malraux, the Minister of Cultural Affairs, has opened another round in his personal crusade against the painters of the 19th century. According to reports here today, he is about to commission a new contemporary ceiling from Andre Masson for the 285-year-old Odeon Theater.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 22 -- A bequest of $7.8 million to be used mainly for scholarships at the Protestant Episcopal George Mercer Jr. Memorial School of Theology was announced here today.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- A leftwing Labor Member of Parliament accused two British publications today of contempt of Parliament in articles saying that he had accepted Communist hospitality in a visit to North Vietnam.

The major part of the street floor on the six-story building under construction at 620 Eighth Avenue, the northeast corner of 40th Street, has been leased by the Chase Manhattan Bank for its Port Authority branch.

Objections by David Brown Corporation of Britain to the proposed merger of Hewitt-Robins, Inc., into Litton Industries have been resolved and the acquisition will take effect tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.
BONN, Feb. 22 -- A new edition of the Kochel listing -- the Bible of all who love the works of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart -- has been brought out by a West German publishing company.
HAVANA, Feb. 22 -- An official of Premier Fidel Castro's regime said today that Cuba and Spain had agreed, in the face of United States opposition, to increase their trade over the next five years.
PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Rubin (Hurricane) Carter knocked out Fabio Bettini, an Italian living in France, 15 seconds before the scheduled end of their 10-round bout at the Palais des Sports here tonight.
Following is an appreciation of Felix Frankfurter written by former Secretary of State Dean Acheson in The Harvard Law Review of November, 1962:
MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (AP)--A Russian aircraft designer has hinted that the Soviet Union will put into operation by 1975 an airliner capable of flying 1,500 miles an hour.

Soviet intellectuals will welcome -- but not altogether without caution -- the article by Pravda's editor promising greater freedom of expression for Russian writers, artists and scientists. In the months since Premier Khrushchev's removal there have been several different, seemingly contradictory, statements of party position on cultural freedom.

AT 11:30 one recent morning, Anna-Lisa, Margreta, Birgitta and Evy, a Swedish foursome of exceptional culinary talents, put aside their pestles, pastry boards, wire whisks, choppers and sieves to light a pair of votive candles for their coffee break.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 22 -- A Belgian coffee planter described today how he led his wife and six other Europeans on a 15-day, 150-mile trek along uncharted wilderness paths to escape from rebel territory in the northeastern Congo.
Private financial support to 50 leading American colleges and universities reached a record total of $373,446,000 last year, an increase of 11.3 per cent over 1963.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22 -- With the formation of a new Government on Saturday, Turkey appears to have a chance for long-term political stability and, as a result, long-term economic prosperity. The significance of the change is that the army allowed the beloved Ismet Inonu to be thrust aside as Premier, and that the political elements opposed to the 81-year-old leader and his People's party were able, despite old jealousies, to agree upon a regime.
A nervous stock market in London fell under a barrage of sell orders yesterday, and prices were driven down across the board.
A Black Muslim building in the heart of Harlem went up in flames early this morning, apparently after a fire bomb was tossed through its fourth-floor window.

BILL van Breda Kolff, Princeton's basketball coach, admitted yesterday that Yale had some virtues, the most important of which was its victory over Cornell last Saturday. Princeton and Cornell are battling for the Ivy League title.

The speed with which young people are cascading into the labor market in search of work is reflected in the Labor Department's estimate that the national work force will rise to more than 101 million by 1980. This represents an increase of nearly one-third over the 77 million now in jobs or looking for them.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- After 47 days of frustration, the Assembly pushed through the first bill of the 1965 legislative session this afternoon. It took less than a minute.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Bond issues totaling $49.6 million will be placed before Kansas City voters tomorrow in a special election.

The "Temporary" State Commission of Investigation was established in 1958, during the Harriman administration. Its fact-finding function is to examine whether laws are being effectively enforced, whether public officers and employes conduct themselves properly and whether public safety and public justice are protected. The commission initiates inquiries; it also acts on request by the Governor.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music could serve as the permanent home base for the Metropolitan Opera National Company, according to Reginald Allen, special assistant to the president and to the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association.

Steel production in the United States soared to a record 2,757,000 tons in the week ended Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 3 per cent above the preceding week's output of ingots and steel for castings.
400,000 shares of the preferred stock of the Potomac Electric Power Company are being offered today by an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and Johnston, Lemon Co.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 23 -- Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, assailed today the views of airline officials who oppose the building of a fourth jetport in the metropolitan area.

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that a husband's concealment from his wife that he allegedly was a German officer during World War Hand II and a former Nazi who remained "fanatically" anti-Semitic did not constitute fraud legally affecting the marriage.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Labor's top leaders warned today against what they called a last-ditch effort by the American Medical Association to block passage in Congress of hospital care for the aged under Social Security.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The State Department said today that it had lifted its passport restrictions on three American crewmen of a mystery plane that had landed at Malta with a large cargo of weapons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Johnson took a Congressional cue today by announcing appointments to the new National Council on the Arts.
Residential construction in New York City dropped sharply last year, according to the annual summary of building permits issued yesterday by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Brian Curvis, the British and Empire welterweight champion, used a jabbing attack tonight to outpoint Gaspar Ortega of Mexico in 10 rounds at the Royal Albert Hall. The fight, lacking in action, was unpopular with the crowd of 5,000 fans who stamped their feet in disapproval.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator Gaylord A. Nelson introduced today a bill that would impose minimum safety standards on new automobiles, beginning with the 1968 models.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Argentina turned back today to private enterprise for help in exploring its oil reserves just 17 months after canceling contracts with 13 private concerns.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The "other" side had its inning today in the Senate hearings on professional sports, but instead of swinging away, it put down what appeared to be a sacrifice bunt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The White Houe announced today that President Chung Hee Park of South Korea would visit Washington May 17. But the White House would not talk about President Johnson's own travel plans:

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Mrs. Nancy Johnson will ask a court to annul her marriage to John (Fritz) Johnson, Omaha sportscaster who has been revealed to be an Ohio salseman declared legally dead five years ago, her lawyer said today.
Representatives of the New York newspaper publishers and leaders of the printers' union met yesterday in a five-hour bargaining session devoted almost entirely to the issue of automation.

Your Feb. 13 editorial on the conclusion of an investment guarantee agreement with Brazil labors under a misapprehension of the purposes of the United States Investment Guaranty Program and fails to take account of the pressures which have compelled developing countries to sign these agreements.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Feb. 23 -- Premier Moise Tshombe's new political party, the Congolese National Convention, ended its first conference today with the announcement that it represented the fusion of 49 of the Congo's 223 parties.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 23 -- Arthur Bottomley, Britain's Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, was greeted by African chiefs in red and purple robes at Dombashawa near Salisbury today when he tried to find out how traditional rulers felt on the independence issue.
Ralph Berger, who was convicted in December on a conspiracy charge growing out of the State Liquor Authority scandals, was sentenced to 30 days in jail yesterday for contempt of the grand jury.

A Transit Authority bus driver testified in Queens Supreme Court yesterday that Alvin L. Mitchell, on trial a second time for murder, boarded his bus at a stop in Springfield Gardens, Queens, a short time after the fatal stabbing in the pre-dawn hours of July 20, 1963.
Part of the heart of St. John's University was removed last night as Joe Lapchick coached the Redmen for the last time at Alumni Hall in Queens. Lapchick is retiring when the season ends.
The American youngster, who is "in" this year, is likely to own a "Stingray" or a "Barracuda" or a "Mustang." If he drives a "Playboy 88," he may insist that his girl friend own a "Bunny."

Both the projected $25 million rapid-transit tunnel between Manhattan and Queens and the proposed $100 million Lower Manhattan Expressway came under heavy attack yesterday at a public hearing in City Hall on the capital budget.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Heavyweight Boxing Champion Cassius Clay said today that if he was the intended target of assassins, "I am here -- they can come and get me."

No diplomat is more conscious of protocol than George Meany in his dealings with the big international unions that make up the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The federation president scrupulously avoids public interference in the autonomous right of these unions to shape their own bargaining policies. But Mr. Meany also recognizes that there are occasions when this concern for diplomatic niceties must take second place to protection of the national welfare.

In a surprising development, Frank W. Waiters has resigned after nine months as president and managing director of Stern, Brothers, a New York department store with units in Paterson, Paramus and Wayne, N.J.
A strong stock market grew stronger still in late trading yesterday after record steel production figures were flashed on brokerage house screens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- For the fourth time within a week, the House Foreign Affairs Committee failed to muster a quorum today to decide whether Americans should see a Government-made film about President Kennedy.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 23 -- "Mary Poppins," "Becket" and "My Fair Lady" dominated the nominations announced today for the 37th annual Academy Awards.

Matthew J. Culligan is about to resign as chairman and a director of the Curtis Publishing Company. He resigned as president and chief executive officer last October after having been charged by two dissident board members with mismanagement.
A mild midday rally failed to spur an advance on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and the list closed around the day's lows.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Gov. George Romney of Michigan said today that most of the policies of the Johnson Administration were a series of "basic contradictions."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- President Sukarno declared today that Indonesia could no longer afford freedom of the press. He ordered the banning of anti-Communist newspapers.
A strong cash market in Maine raised prices of potatoes for future delivery by 15 to 21 cents a hundredweight yesterday on the old-crop contracts. The new-crop November contract dipped a cent.

The Diana Stores Corporation, which operates 290 retail stores in 32 states, has transferred its headquarters from Manhattan to a one-story office building and warehouse at 7801 Tonnelle Avenue, North Bergen, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The inauguration of President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey may wind up in the red or just break even.
MADRID, Feb. 23 -- The special border passes of all foreigners living in Spain and commuting to work in Gibraltar will be revoked March 7, a Spanish Government spokesman said today.

MIAMI, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Brenner Pass, a horse that could not reach the winner's circle a year ago, scored his third victory of the Hialeah meeting in the eighth race today under a strong ride by Don Brumfield. The victory was Brumfield's third of the afternoon.
A "Dictionary of Scientific Biography," designed as a standard reference work in the relatively new field of the history of science, is planned by the American Council of Learned Societies.

A new line of "mannish-tailored" women's hats for sport and leisure wear has been developed by the Hat Corporation of America, the country's largest producer of men's hats, Charles H. Salesky, president, reported yesterday.

Lucia Chase, Oliver Smith and the directors and stars of the American Ballet Theater will be honored on March 16 at a champagne supper party in the New York State Theater after the company's opening performance.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Penthouse, a British version of Playboy magazine, will enter a growing men's magazine market this Friday amid a flurry of Parliamentary and legal invective.
The Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company had the highest sales and earnings in 1964 in its 108-year history. It also had the best quarter on record in the final three months of last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- A brief private service will be held tomorrow for Felix Frankfurter, the former Supreme Court Justice who died on Monday at the age of 82.

Militant teen-age Negroes, angered by a refusal of support for the boycott of public schools, staged a noisy sit-in yesterday at the office of Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
LONDON -- The Englishmen who care most about clothes and spend more of their time and money acquiring them are not aristocrats in Savile Row suits but youngsters from the working class.

James Farmer, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said yesterday he believed the killing of Malcolm X was a political act, with international implications and not necessarily connected with black nationalism.
A State Supreme Coourt jury awarded $250,000 in damages yesterday to a 28-year-old Queens man for injuries he received when his car ran into a wall on the upper level of the Queensborough Bridge.
A Federal grand jury began hearing evidence yesterday into a plot to dynamite the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument and the Liberty Bell.
FROM January to July in 1962 a 50-year-old Austrian writer-adventurer climbed mountains, explored jungles and endured a monstrous variety of hardships and misfortunes in Western New Guinea.
ARRAS, France, Feb. 22 -- The neo-Gothic town hall of this northern French city is one of several thousand bastions in France that President de Gaulle's political opposition is trying to hold.

A. Philip Goldsmith, who last year led a proxy fight at the Elgin National Watch Company that gained him three of nine board positions, said yesterday that he had resigned as a director and sold his 40,000 shares of Elgin stock in the open market.
Felix Frankfurter was the heir and exemplar of several traditions that have mingled successfully in the rich tapestry of American life.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth S. Ekblom's Sun's Desire became a candidate for future 3-year-old stakes here at Bowie Race Course today when he ran six furlongs in 1:12 2-5 to win at $5.40, $4 and $3.20 for $2 across the board.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Tomorrow is the reporting date for the New York Yankee pitchers and catchers, and most of the players and coaches were arriving today. Only a rookie, Tom Dukes, who is in school, is expected to be late, and he has permission.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Admiral of the Fleet Chester W. Nimitz, described by his colleagues as one of the most self-effacing men who ever went to sea, turns 80 years old tomorrow.

Reduction of Britain's 15 per cent tariff surcharge on imports was termed encouraging by most exporters here yesterday, but reactions varied on how much the cut, to be made April 27, would stimulate sales. The lowering of the import levy to 10 per cent cent was announced by the British Government on Monday.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The State Senate overrode Republican opposition today to give the City Council of New York permission to redraw the districts from which its members are elected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Among America's allies in the Atlantic and the Pacific today there is a great deal of criticism about the central policies of the Johnson Administration but absolutely no agreement about what policies should be put in their place.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 23 -- A naturalized American citizen was hanged as a spy early today in a public square in Damascus. A Syrian Army major accused as his accomplice was executed by a firing squad.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- The American Institute of Men's and Boy's Wear and the Menswear Retailers of America honored men's fashion editors and their publications today for their reporting of fashion news during 1964.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange staged an advance over a broad front yesterday in very active trading.
Enrollment in Jewish schools in the city and suburbs has more than doubled in the last quarter century, the Jewish Education Committee reported yesterday.

PARIS -- When Foster Dulles fathered SEATO in 1954 he saw its principal purpose as giving our President legal authority to intervene in Indochina. Although the alliance has virtually dissolved, this purpose remains valid and provides the background for increasing United States involvement.
PARIS, Feb. 23 -- The Soviet Union declared today its support for President de Gaulle's call for a negotiated settlement of the war in South Vietnam.

Patrick W. (Pat) O'Brien has been appointed supervisor of racing at the New York Racing Association tracks, succeeding John F. Kennedy. The appointment was announced yesterday by James Cox Brady, chairman of the board for the association.
The president of the United Housing Foundation characterized as "worthless talk" yesterday an architectural committee's criticism of the design of the Co-op City housing project in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor named a special committee of nine businessmen today to advise him on means of carrying out the Administration's program for reducing the nation's payments deficit.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- A polka-dot speckled space glider rocketed over a 13,300-mile-an-hour suborbital course today and radioed valuable information on rugged materials and techniques for future manned spaceships before it was lost at sea.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 (AP) -- President Anastas I. Mikoyan said today that "peace-loving countries" were firmly determined to halt the expansion of the conflict in Vietnam, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.
WASHINGTON -- They're not calling Mrs. Lloyd Nelson Hand "glad hand" in Washington yet, but it will come, it will come.

SELMA, Ala., Feb. 23 -- Capt. Wilson Baker, Selma's Commissioner of Public Safety, persuaded 100 Negro youngsters marching on the courthouse to turn back just before nightfall today, thus avoiding the potential dangers of a night march in the Deep South.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- An emergency campaign to vaccinate every preschool child in the state against measles was proposed today by the chairman of the Senate Committee on Public Health.

The chief figure in an alleged bribery plot to get the city to use Duncan Parking Meters was ordered yesterday to be ready for trial tomorrow -- whether the counsel of his choosing is ready or not.
Government bond prices rose slightly yesterday in light trading.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The remains of Roger Casement, the Irish patriot hanged on charges of high treason by the British in 1916, were sent to his native Dublin today from a London prison grave designated only by a mark on a chart.

Creation of a new city agency to develop industrial parks and plants for lease and sale to like the findings nor the recommended in a study made for the City Planning Commission by the consulting concern Arthur D. Little, Inc.
State Senator Constance Baker Motley continued her meteoric rise in politics yesterday by winning election to the Manhattan Borough Presidency.

Cornell MacNeill sang the title role in Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" last night with the Metropolitan Opera. It was the baritone's first time in the role with the company, and he can count the occasion an utter triumph.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A bill to add $750 million in United States contributions to funds for multilateral loans to Latin America came under attack in the Senate today and all voting was put off until tomorrow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 -- About 3 o'clock yesterday morning a barrel-chested American Air Force general wandered out of a smoky conference room where South Vietnam's military leaders were in the 10th hour of meetings.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- John J. (Taps) Gallagher, 61 years old, the Niagara University basketball coach for 31 years, will retire at the end of the season, officials said today. He will retain his post as the athletic director.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- Soviet officials regard the Cairo visit of Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, as a major victory not only for the East German regime but also for the Soviet Union.
The election of L. Edwin Smart Jr. and Robert W. Purcell as directors of the Bendix Corporation was announced yesterday at the annual shareholder meeting in Detroit.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Ed Jucker, who led the University of Cincinnati to two successive National Collegiate basketball championships and a runner-up position in the third year, resigned today as the head coach of the Bearcats, effective at the end of the season.

A Federal grand jury indicted three men and a woman yesterday on charges of conspiracy in shipping mislabeled horse meat from South Kearny, N.J., to the Queens plant of Merkel, Inc., meat processors now out of business.

In a 2-to-1 decision yesterday the United States Court of Appeals held that a bus company that sells a through ticket beyond its run is not responsible for the culpable actions of a connecting carrier.

DONETSK, U.S.S.R., Feb. 23 -- Despite the priority given to oil and gas in the Soviet economy as a whole, coal is still the king so far as authorities of this Ukrainian coal mining center are concerned.

CAIRO, Feb. 23 -- Walter Ulbricht, East Germany's President, arrives tomorrow to fulfill an invitation that many Western diplomats are convinced resulted from pressure on President Gamal Abdel Nasser by the new Soviet leadership.
The Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., announced yesterday the election of John F. Gallagher and Lewis B. Harder as directors. The action increases the board to 24 members.

UNTIL about 15 years ago, Rossini's comic opera, "Il Turco in Italia" had been slumbering for a hundred years or so. It was long forgotten. Then, with the postwar revival of interest in bel canto opera, thanks to Maria Callas, the Rome Opera brought it back as a vehicle for her. It since has had a few productions, here and there, but not many.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- The Distillers Company, Ltd., one of the world's largest Scotch whisky concerns, touched off a possible "whisky war" today by ending its support of retail prices.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois urged today the enactment this year of a new voting-rights law whether or not the Administration recommends it.
The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company announced yesterday that it would reopen its sulphur mine at Gulf, Matagorda County, Tex., and install a new unit using the Frasch process there.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh, the deposed strongman, will soon go to the United Nations to present evidence that North Vietnam is directing the war in the South, Maj. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Men's clothing and furnishings manufacturers are sympathetic to the nation's international payments problem, but they say they will continue to purchase some of their fabrics overseas.
OTTAWA, Feb. 23 -- A Quebec judge today summoned Yvon Dupuis, a recently discharged Federal Cabinet Minister, to answer three criminal counts.

YONKERS, Feb. 23 -- Robert A. Glasser, the chairman of the New York State Harness Racing Commission, said today the commission was studying proposals to make it mandatory for tracks to pay winners of large twin doubles by check.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Kermit Gordon, Director of the Budget, spelled out for the first time today the stimulus for the national economy contained in President Johnson's budget program.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- A Republican legislator introduced today a bill that would outlaw the participation of children less than 16 years old in civil fights demonstrations.

The State of Maryland's $31,920,000 offering of various purpose bands "did not go as well as we expected," a spokesman for the winning syndicate said late yesterday afternoon. There was an unsold balance of $20,625,000.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Wisconsin scored 10 points in overtime to defeat Northwestern tonight, 93 -- 87, in a Big Ten basketball game.

Bernice Massi, whose performance as "a kind of vicious, rich python" in "What Makes Sammy Run?" was praised by the critics, will be elevated to stardom in the musical, which reaches its first Broadway anniversary on Saturday. She will be co-starred with Steve Lawrence and Robert Alda.
ATHENS, Feb. 23 -- Greek Communists, whose party was banned 17 years ago, began a campaign this week to regain freedom of movement in Greece.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Critics of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency called today for its abolition or a sharp cut in its spending.
BOSTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The first Boston Medals for distinguished achievement were presented last night to Richard Rodgers, the composer, and Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra.

IN last night's program, "I, Leonardo da Vinci," the producing team of John Secondari and his wife, Helen Jean Rogers, furthered their ambition to expand both the substance and form of the television documentary.

New York University and Notre Dame, which met in the first Madison Square Garden basketball double-header in 1934, play in the second contest of tonight's twin bill at the Garden. Manhattan and Connecticut will meet in the first game at 7 P.M.
Increased volume and profits were predicted yesterday for the nation's paper industry.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP) -- A New York widow accidentally flew the first leg of her vacation trip to Florida in the Kennedy family plane, the Caroline, after boarding the wrong plane at the Saranac Lake, N.Y., airport.
Boom, boom, the Beat resounds through the American literary West.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Treasury auctioned $1 billion in one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 4.062 per cent.

TRENTON, Wednesday, Feb. 24 -- A 60-member screening committee of the Republican party in New Jersey chose State Senator Wayne Dumont Jr. early this morning as a candidate for the party's gubernatorial nomination.
" It was a vicious sneak attack," said Joseph X.
Mrs. Claude Foussier was awarded custody yesterday of her two children who had been living with their father, Philip Uzielli, a Wall Street investment broker.
Jackie Mason, the comedian, filed a $3 million libel and slander suit yesterday against Ed Sullivan and Robert Precht, producer of Mr. Sullivan's television show.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 23 -- A "three-language formula" has been worked out as a solution to India's bitter split on the question of a national official language.
Sales of gift merchandise for the home and the individual are running well above last year's level, according to reports yesterday at the New York Gift Show.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The vanguard of drivers and machines for Sunday's 2,000-kilometer continental race moved into Daytona International Speedway today in the midst of a rainstorm, Carroll Shelby's Ford team of seven cars and a dozen drivers was first to arrive.
WHEN performed on Broadway 11 years ago, Jean Anouilh's "Colombe" did not make the grade. As if to right a wrong, it is being produced afresh at the Garrick Theater, where it opened last night.
The Canadian dollar continued to decline, while the British pound advanced in a substantial volume of transactions yesterday on the foreign exchange market here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Another plan to keep the New Haven Railroad running was proposed today by Senator Jacob K. Javits and Representative Ogden R. Reid.

MONTREAL, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Stan Mikita increased his scoring total in the National Hockey League to 72 points, 5 more than his teammate, Bobby Hull, by scoring four goals and assisting on six others last week.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Duke of Windsor will undergo surgery within a few days for the second time in two months.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 23 -- Present circumstances make it virtually impossible to enforce Norwalk's Housing Code and ensure better health conditions in the city's 2,800 substandard housing units, according to Dr. Francis J. Kalaman, the city's medical director.
HAWORTH, N.J., Feb. 23 -- The police in this Bergen County community of 3,600 disclosed today that a gambling operation involving at least 50 high school students had been broken up.
RICHMOND, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A group of religious leaders here will sponsor a local building fund drive to aid in the reconstruction of 36 Negro churches that have been bombed or burned in Mississippi.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Ondine, a sleek yawl flying the Stars and Stripes of the United States, caught a Westerly wind today and reached port first in the Buenos Aires-to-Rio de Janeiro race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Senate Rules Committee received today written replies from Walter W. Jenkins to a list of questions it had submitted to the former White House aide in lieu of a personal appearance before the committee.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today he would soon join other Senators in suggesting legislation to control narcotics imports and to help protect victims of illegal narcotics traffic.
THE delicate tap, tap of an engraver's chisel on steel is quite lost in the bustle and noise of the crowds at the Sportsmen's Vacation and Travel Show being held this week at the Coliseum.
A former Probation Department typist, alleged to be "insolvent and unable to meet any obligations," has been barred from soliciting funds for a proposed Off Broadway production.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- President and Mrs. Johnson held the fifth of 10 receptions in their series honoring members of Congress.

Andrew Moss was driving to work in a rented car yesterday because his own sedan had been stolen the night before. Suddenly a car that looked very familiar whizzed by him on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and off went Mr. Moss, "with a banging heart," in a great chase.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Paterson's Golden Age Center knows a golden opportunity when it sees one.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Britain offered today to make a permanent commitment of logistical support for as many as six infantry battalions in a United Nations peace-keeping force.

After being in the ship-repair business in Hoboken for almost 50 years, the Todd Shipyards Corporation announced here yesterday that it would close its division there not later than December and would concentrate its local activities at its Erie Basin yard in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- House Republicans completed the reshuffling of their leadership today by electing Representative John J. Rhodes of Arizona as Policy Committee chairman.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- A small tornado touched down at an airport here, skipped past a jetliner waiting to take off, then cut through a mile-square section of town, where it injured three persons and did at least $140,000 worth of damage.

When Constance Baker Motley reports to the handsome wood-paneled office of the Manhattan Borough President on the 20th floor of the Municipal Building, she will be assuming a position that has slowly declined in effectiveness over the past half century.
