" Things like this certainly do not help the war effort." Those were the words General Khanh used yesterday to sum up the maneuver by which his fellow officers dumped him as Saigon's strong man. He did not seem too disturbed by it all. He gave his interview in a South Vietnamese mountain resort, and soon he will start for New York to begin his duties as a roving ambassador.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 23 -- Providence College tumbled to its first defeat of the basketball season tonight. A. wild chorus of screams shook the Villanova gym as Villanova whipped the Friars, 71-57, and ended the streak of the nation's only previously unbeaten major college team at 19 games.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Feb. 23 -- A $24 million stadium, the future home of the Los Angeles Angels, is rapidly taking shape among the citrus groves of Orange County.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A legal representative of the West German Government arrived here over the weekend to re-examine American records on Nazi war crimes.
Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., conducted a successful stockholder's meeting yesterday -- well, not entirely. The film projector did not work for a time.

The Borden Company had some rich news for its stockholders yesterday -- a proposal to split the stock on a two-for-one basis, a possible increase of the dividend and a record in 1964 sales and earnings for the sixth consecutive year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The State Department announced that Ambassador Harriman left this afternoon from West Palm Beach, Fla., on a round-the-world diplomatic mission that will take him to four or five capitals in the Middle East, South Asia and the Far East.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23 -- As a new major epoch in the history of the New York Yankees begins tomorrow, the man squarely on the spot is Ralph Houk, vice president and general manager.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The British Government has made it clear that it is willing to take part in any useful steps toward negotiation on the Vietnam problem, but it has indicated a most cautious view of the prospects.

Les Crane, the bad boy of local television who reformed for his network show last fall on the American Broadcasting Company, will end Friday night his daily 105-minute smorgasbord of conversation, jokes and celebrity interviews.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- The American airline industry's top spokesman denounced today President Johnson's proposed tax on jet fuel as a "tax on progress."

MONROE, Wash., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Washington State Reformatory prisoners ate warmed-over hamburgers today in the first break of a three-day hunger strike, but the more than 700 inmates were kept locked in their cells after a night of screaming, cursing and burning paper.
Walter Lippmann and Andrew Wyeth have been awarded annual gold medals of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

ROME, Feb. 23 -- Pope Paul VI said today that the elevation of Joseph Cardinal Cardijn to the purple marked for young Christian workers the beginning of "more generous" apostolio action to render the Roman Catholic Church "present and active" in labor.
BONN, Feb. 23 -- East Germany has official representa tives in 36 non-Communists countries.

Unilever, N.V., and Unilever, Ltd., the giant Dutch and British producers of household and industrial products, achieved record results in 1964. They control companies in more than 50 countries and have identical boards of directors.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Tonight's revival of "Don Giovanni" at Covent Garden not only served to introduce several newcomers to the cast, but was welcome in its own right.

" CONTEMPORARIES #1," an exhibition of 26 realist or semirealist painters that opened yesterday at Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art, could have been an important show. It isn't even a good one.

Stockholders of the Carrier Corporation approved a three-for-two stock split at their annual meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- New York's Governor Rockefeller called today for a sharp increase in Federal aid to help fight water pollution.

" Journal of a Soul the diary of Pope John XXIII, will be published by McGraw-Hill on April 7. In 1961, when the Pope was 80, he presented the diary that he had begun when 14 to his private secretary, Don Loris Capovilla, with permission to publish after his death.
PARIS, Feb. 23 -- James Bond has just entered the most frightening phase of his long, unpredictable career as Secret Agent 007.

Talks in the 44-day waterfront strike in Texas ports took a hopeful turn last night, and negotiators said there appeared to be a good chance for settlement.

The New York Knickerbockers ignored Philadelphia's previous mastery over them last night and routed the 76ers, 132 -- 104, in the featured National Basketball Association game of a Madison Square Garden double-header.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Twenty years ago, Sir William Haley, then director of the British Broadcasting Corporation, was surprised to get a letter from an American Supreme Court Justice, Felix Frankfurter. It complimented him on an article Sir William had written about the limits on freedom of speech and informed him that the Justice had cited it in an opinion.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Robert Livingston Ireland 3d, a New York banker who was stripped of most of his clothing and left unconscious in an alley in freezing weather after an apparent robbery-assault, remained in critical condition today in University Hospital.
Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said here yesterday that Americans were not ready for overseas travel until they had seen the United States first.
Police concern about a vendetta by followers of Malcolm X mounted yesterday after fires wrecked a Black Muslim mosque here and scorched another in San Francisco.
The Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation became yesterday the first of the big three in the men's Shirt manufacturing field to announce the introductory date for a permanently pressed dress shirt.

WARSAW, Feb. 24 -- The United States and the Chinese Communist Ambassadors met today in a spacious hunting lodge, a relic of prewar Poland.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday record operating revenues and net income for 1964.
A Manhattan leasing specialist has cautioned businessmen that the standard form of office lease used by most landlords does not necessarily cover all of the rights expected by a tenant.

Investment bankers had a busy day yesterday bidding on new issues and making changes in old ones.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 24 -- A 36-year-old carpenter who has been accused of rape and murder has been deprived by the police in Queens of food and medical attention and been beaten, his wife charged today.
The Board of Education estimated yesterday that 80 per cent of the boycotting students had returned to school.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- A mighty snowstorm swept across the midsection of the nation today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 -- Francis A. Capell of Zarephath, N.J., surrendered voluntarily here today to face an indictment charging him and three others with conspiracy to commit criminal libel against Senator Thomas H. Kuchel Republican of California.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller rejected tonight the idea that the Republican candidate for Mayor of New York City should be chosen by March 1. The statement was seen as weakening the likelihood that either Senator Jacob K. Javits or Representative John V. Lindsay would be willing to accept the nomination.

The Federal Government directed one of its physicians yesterday to check on the reported heart attack on Tuesday of the man believed to have taken over the Mafia "family" of Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, missing racketeer.
NAMPA, Idaho, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- A young Negro who runs a cleaning establishment here is carrying an official Ku Klux Klan membership card.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 1 24 -- Organized labor is planning a major drive to elect friendly candidates in 1,000 city and county elections across the nation this year.

LONDON, Feb. 24 - The young English composer Richard Rodney Bennett has written several film scores and one-act operas, but "The Mines of Sulphur," commissioned by the Sadler's Wells Opera Company and performed by it tonight, is his first full-length opera.

The Student Nonviolent coordinating Committee, which recruited hundreds of young persons for last summer's civil rights campaign in Mississippi, said yesterday that it would concentrate next summer on applying political pressure in Washington to unseat Mississippi's delegation in the House.

Knickerbocker Hospital at Convent Avenue and West 130th Street announced yesterday that it had become the first of the 79 voluntary hospitals in the city to appoint a Negro as chief of a medical service.
Reports of a spurt in potato consumption lifted wholesale prices in Maine by another 10 to 15 cents yesterday. On-the-farm prices there were quoted at $3.90 to $4.05 a hundredweight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment 95 years ago ended the dispute over whether the Constitution had established voting as a "right" or a "privilege" of citizenship. The argument was based on the fact that, in Article I, Sec. 2 (1), the whole matter of qualification to vote had been left for each state to prescribe within its own boundaries.
The Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation raised prices yesterday by about $10 a ton, effective March 15, on corrugated shipping containers.

Dr. Calvin E. Gross, Superintendent of Schools said yesterday that Mayor Wagner's allocation of $151 million for school construction in the 1965-66 capital budget was about $59 million short of requirements.

Robert N. Bavier Jr., and Mrs. Jane Pegel received Martini and Rossi trophies yesterday for outstanding sailing accomplishments in 1964.

STRATTON MOUNTAIN, Vt., Feb. 24 -- Professional Alpine racing is about to make a comeback. About two dozen racers representing ski areas from the Green Mountains to the Rockies are primed to swing into action on March 5 at Boyne Mountain, Mich, in the first of three events listed for this winter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that the failure of the pilot to use his de-icing equipment and available engine power probably caused the crash last year of a chartered airliner carrying ski club members.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee was told today that Americans who wanted to receive Communist propaganda from overseas could do so now without fear of possible harassment.

The Pepsi-Cola Company is planning to make a party of it by adding corn and potato chips to its line of soft drinks. Discussions of a merger between Pepsi-Cola and Frito-Lay, Inc. of Dallas were confirmed yesterday by the two companies. Their directors are scheduled to vote on the proposal today.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is using automated mass-production methods to bolster a comeback in heavy industrial equipment. This is comparable to the use of Robert Hall methods by a custom tailor.
TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- The State Supreme Court prohibited today the construction of a tower-like motel overlooking Manhattan on the Palisades in Fort Lee.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 24 -- The National Council of Churches will expand its civil rights activities this year to include involvement with the problems of Negroes living in the ghettos of Northern cities.

CAIRO, Feb. 24 -- The United Arab Republic rolled out the red carpet today for Walter Ulbricht, the East German President, at the start of his first official visit to a non-Communist country.
Benton Bowles, Inc., has added two vice presidents to its executive roster, William R. Hesse, president, announced yesterday. The two, account supervisors, are Dallas Corser and John Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Senate defeated two amendments to a bill to add $750 million in United States subscriptions to the Inter-American Development Bank today in debate punctuated by a heated exchange between Senators Wayne Morse of Oregon and Russell B. Long of Louisiana, both Democrats.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The chairman of an influential bipartisan commission said today that it would probably propose that capital punishment be abolished in New York State.

ROME, Feb. 24 -- True social equality can be reached "in the not too distant future" in the United States if "moderates" retain control of the fight for racial justice, Lawrence Joseph Cardinal Shehan, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Baltimore, said today.

William Steinberg, guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic for 12 weeks of subscription concerts this season, will lead the orchestra for the same number of subscription weeks in 1966-67 and 1967-68. Mr. Steinberg will also be guest conductor for four weeks during 1965-66.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 24 (Reuters) -- United States Ambassador Howard P. Jones has denied that any American agency has supported any movement hostile to the Indonesian Government, an embassy spokesman said today.

The Torah Umesorah, the representative body of a network of all-day Jewish schools, disclosed yesterday that it had established special state commissions to deal with the distribution of Federal funds for private schools in the event that President Johnson's education bill is passed by Congress.
Tom Farrell and Bill Crothers, healthy again, will run tonight in the 46th annual Knights of Columbus track meet at Madison Square Garden. Sam Perry, not so healthy again, will not run.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Batteur, ridden by Manuel Ycaza, took command midway in the stretch today and went on to an easy five-length victory in the $34,700 Santa Barbara Handicap.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The Democratic National Committee was sued for $50,873.29 today by the company that staged President Johnson's inaugural parade.
A New York City detective gave testimony in the murder trial of Alvin L. Mitchell yesterday that differed with earlier evidence offered by another prosecution witness.

MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- Representatives of two Moscow synagogues declared today that enough matzoh would be available in the capital this year to satisfy the needs of Jews who wish to observe the dietary laws of Passover.

Villanova accepted a bid yesterday to the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden less than an hour after rejecting an invitation to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tourney. MIAMI, Feb. 24 -- Old Hat won the Black Helen Handicap in smart style today, the 6-year-old daughter of Boston Doge registering a three-quarters of a length success over Steeple Jill in the 1 1/8-mile fixture at Hialeah, with Windsor Lady next by three lengths.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed corporations.

The British pound dipped slightly in fairly heavy trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. It closed at $2,7960, down 2 points for the day.

TORONTO, Feb. 24 -- Howard D. Graham, president of the Toronto Stock Exchange, suggested today that the United States and Canada should work seriously toward economic union.

THE Museum of Modern Art's new optical art show, "The Responsive Eye," which opens today, is worth the risk of being crushed and maimed to see, risk that will certainly be involved. During the year that the show has been in preparation, optical art has become such a rage that even a routine show at the museum would have drawn a crowd.

Columbia University and a group of associated institutions won a legal battle yesterday to oust the operator of a hotel near the university because it harbored narcotics addicts, prostitutes and other undesirables.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Fritz Schunk, an airman stationed at Macdill Air Force Base, got the Dixie tennis tournament off to a delayed start today with an upset victory over Rafael Osuna of Mexico. The scores were 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP- -- Representative William H. Ayres, Republican of Ohio, said today that under the Administration's school-aid bill "the rich get richer and the poor get very little."

The Tyrone Guthrie Minnesota Theater Company will open its third season on May 10 with "Richard III." Congreve's "The Way of the World" will be done on the next night. Two future scientists tied for top score in the Regents college-scholarship examinations, the State Education Department announced yesterday.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 24 -- The Australian Government is under strong pressure to increase the rewards of the developing oil production in this country.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- A total of 4,777 doctors have submitted notices of resignation from the British National Health Service, post-dated to April 1, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- President Johnson joined close friends and associates of Felix Frankfurter at a private memorial service today for the retired Supreme Court Justice who died on Monday at the age of 82.
BONN, Feb. 24 -- West Germany's economic aid to the United Arab Republic was halted today with the arrival of President Ulbricht in Cairo.
A basket and a free throw by Len Zandy with 4 minutes 22 seconds remaining broke the 16th tie of the game and propelled Fordham to a 75-67 victory over Wagner College last night.

Japan plans to increase its steel exports to the United States and other nations by about 4 per cent this year, but has no intention of taking advantage of possible difficulties in the American market, a top Japanese steel executive said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell lifted his one-man blockade of the administration's $1.25 billion school-aid bill today.

THE pornographic explosion of the nineteen-sixties has become a bore. Unlimited tedium is apparently the price for unlimited license. The supply of shockers far outruns the market of people willing to pay cash to be shocked. Income balances among hot-breathing iconoclasts are in peril. Today's books illuminate their dilemmas.

This is the slow season at the West 79th Street Boat Basin, but for the dozen or so families that live in this nook in the Hudson the year round, winter is the most peaceful, neighborly time of the year.
TOKYO, Feb. 24 -- Japanese officials voiced little enthusiasm today over Britain's decision to reduce her 15 per cent surcharge on industrial imports by 5 per cent.
CHARLES MUNCH led the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall last night in a concert very reminiscent of a few years ago years ago when the orchestra was his own.
BONN, Feb. 24 -- The West German Cabinet voted unanimously today to support the proposed extension of the statute of limitations for the prosecution of Nazi war criminals beyond the May 8 deadline.

Looking a little older, a stockier, a little more complacently cherubic, Mischa Elman turned up at Carnegie Hall last night to play a program that might have daunted a man half his age. Now 74, the famous violinist was soloist in three concertos with members of the American Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Jose Iturbi.
The Carver Federal Savings and Loan Association, New York, announced yesterday the appointment of Oscar N. Whitfield to the new post of senior vice president. He will continue as secretary.

A big question lately in the minds of countless investors is: "How can I get some shares in the General Aniline offering?" This question is triggered by some tan talizing known facts. On Tuesday, March 9, a block of 11,166,438 shares of the General Aniline and Film Corporation will be awarded to one of two huge underwriting groups.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Walter W. Jenkins denied for a second time today that he had ever used coercion or pressure on Don B. Reynolds, an insurance salesman, to buy advertising time on a Texas television station owned by President Johnson's family.

President Johnson has been busy making fresh efforts to win friends in the business community. He proffered the sizable plum of a $600-to-$800 million reduction in corporate tax bills by relaxing the rules applying to write-offs of plant and equipment. And he asked business to cooperate in halting the outflow of dollars; specifically, he pleaded for a cut in foreign loans by banks and in foreign investments by corporations.

The General Telephone Company of California sold $35 million of first mortgage bonds yesterday to an investment banking syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and Stone Webster Securities Corporation.

Harry Williamson of Starkville, Miss., in a letter published Feb. 8 protested "Operation Freedom," currently being sponsored by Manhattan's Ansonia Independent Democrats and the Reform Independent Democrats. These clubs are collecting food, clothing and money to send to Negroes in Starkville as part of a plan to "adopt" that Southern town.
The newspaper drivers' union decided yesterday to ask Federal mediators to enter its contract negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York City.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 24 -- The United States Embassy disclosed today that American jet aircraft were sent on air strikes against the Vietcong in South Vietnam during the last week.
The C.I.T. Financial Corporation wants to go into commercial banking by buying, for cash, the Meadow Brook National Bank.

THE chess club of the American Museum of Natural History is just one year old, but it is flourishing, active and studded with talent. The club, which has its own room, includes employes from all departments.
Robert Moses received a vote of confidence at a meeting of the executive committee of the World's Fair yesterday.

THE one thing missing from today's well-equipped kitchen is a well-equipped handyman. If more than one repair problem occurs at the same time, the housewife often has to take her juicer for an oiling to one service center, her mixer with its bent beaters to another and her frying pan with its severed handle to a third.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- The amateur court tennis championship of the United States began today at the Racquet Club without the defending titleholder, Jimmy Bostwick of Westbury, L.I.

With the bankrupt New Haven Railroad asking the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to curtail and abandon commuter service, two leading New York members of Congress have come up with a realistic plan to meet the problem head-on.
" The Flying Dutchman" will be given tonight at the Metropolitan Opera at 8.

The municipal bond industry was buried yesterday under an avalanche of 17 new issues totaling about $155 million, but by the end of the afternoon, most dealers were agreed that the market bore up well under the burden.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Miss Jennie Lee, Britain's mistress of the arts, announced today a radical 30 per cent increase in support of the arts as the first step toward a "gayer and more cultivated country."
The directors of Mack Trucks, Inc., omitted the dividend action at yesterday's board meeting. The last payment on the common stock was 25 cents a share in September, 1964.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Because of the balance of payments deficit, the Government is asking American tourists to visit the United States this summer instead of going to Europe. It is a splendid idea. A visit in the United States is just the thing for the American who wants to get off the beaten track.
MONTREAL, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Henri Richard scored three goals and added two assists in Montreal's 6-1 National Hockey League triumph over the New York Rangers tonight.
The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in ', 1964 sales, revenues and net income.

Three leading architects have resigned from the seven-member jury set up to choose a design for the development of Borough Hall Square in downtown Brooklyn. The resignations were to protest a site that they consider "totally inadequate."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. contended today that revisions in the immigration law asked by President Johnson provided new discriminations in the guise of eliminating discrimination.
CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 24 -- A measure that would ban "subversives" from the use of state facilities in New Hampshire met with strong opposition at a hearing here today.
THERE is nothing quite like the National Antiques Show at Madison Square Garden for a spectacle of man's creative impulses, his mastery of craft techniques and also his misdirected energies.
" Kremlin Chimes" -- the fourth and final New York presentation of the Moscow Art Theater -- contains a dramatic example of a genuine Soviet "unperson" -- in this case, Generalissimo Stalin himself.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- Premier Phan Huy Quat said today that his country was "suffering too much" and "we want to end the war with honor."
NEWARK, Feb. 24 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America appears to have edged a little closer in 1964 to the front-running Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
IF you were a playwright in the Soviet Union, how could you beat a work built on sure-fire elements like Lenin, love and the conversion of the backslider?
The election of Samuel S. Auchincloss as president of AMP, Inc., was announced yesterday by U.A. Whitaker, chairman and chief executive officer of the wire terminal producer.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Feb. 24 -- The directors of the Vancouver International Festival accepted last night the resignation of its general manager, William Crawford 3d of New York. The directors said they were hopeful the festival would continue.

THE American Broadcasting Company's weekly news feature program, "Scope," came up last night with an interesting novelty -- a half-hour sampling of the Soviet Union's top popular variety program on television.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 24 -- A student demonstration turned a lecture by Walt W. Rostow into a riot tonight.
Hundreds of small trucking operators have gone out of business in the metropolitan area as a result of the long dock strike and its aftermath, a spokesman for the industry declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The latest United States air attacks in South Vietnam called attention today to the array of modern planes that have been brought into the Southeast Asian guerrilla conflict.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 24 -- The State Board of Education agreed today to comply with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and thus prevent the discontinuation of Federal assistance to public schools in the state.
NEWARK, Feb. 24 -- State Senator Wayne Dumont, named early today by the Republican party's screening committee as its gubernatorial candidate, said he thought a primary fight could be avoided.
The pace slowed on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and small declines outnumbered gains at the close.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued yesterday to respond to favorable corporate news and rose in active trading.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Texas Court of Civil Appeals rejected today an appeal by former employes of one of President Johnson's family's television stations who sought payment from a profit-sharing plan.

An assemblage of 52,000 square feet of land between 31st and 32d Streets in Union City, N.J., has been completed by Stephen Mencher of Clifton, who plans to erect a three-story air-conditioned garden-type apartment building.
PARIS, Feb. 24 -- A high official of Air Canada accused the United States Civil Aeronautics Board today of seeking to dictate international air fares and charged its chairman with "arrogance."

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals refused today to review Jack L. Ruby's conviction for slaying President Kennedy's assassin until his sanity is judged. The court appeared to have set the stage for a sanity trial by jury for the condemned killer.
New York University nearly ran Notre Dame off the court in the first half, then had to fight tenaciously after the intermission before scoring a 60-54 victory in Madison Square Garden last night.
MARION, Ala., Feb. 24 -- The campaign for Negro voting rights in the Alabama Black Belt relaxed today.

To the Editor: As a rabbi I wish to register my dissent to the view of the Jewish War Veterans, in an advertisement published in The Times of Feb. 18, concerning "weaknesses and defects latent k the German character."
NINE young mothers and their children joined Miss Merle Lister recently in a newly formed dance class at the West Side Young Men's Christian Association, 5 West 63d Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- The Governors of New Jersey and Pennsylvania pledged today to work for the improvement and rehabilitation of the deteriorated Camden-Philadelphia port area.
PARIS, Feb. 24 -- France and the Soviet Union have agreed to press for an international conference to negotiate a settlement of the war in South Vietnam.
It is time for someone in Washington to remember John F. Kennedy's words in his Inaugural Address: "Let us never negotiate out of fear. But let us never fear to negotiate."
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Democratic leaders have almost abandoned their plan for ending tuition fees at the State University at this session of the Legislature.
Despite a long strike and a $55 million cutback in military contracts, the White Motor Company lifted its 1964 net profits 14.4 per cent, to $18,056,152 highest in its 65-year history.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 24 -- Agriculture ministers of the European Common Market worked through the night to reach an important three-part agreement early today on common prices for farm products.

" Life Begins at Fifty," by Walter Pitkin Jr., will be published by Simon and Schuster on March 4. The author's father, Walter Pitkin, wrote "Life Begins at Forty." It was suggested to the junior Mr. Pitkin that he update his father's book, but he found that revision would not suffice.

THE bridge beginner who is weak in mathematics can take comfort from the fact that bridge arithmetic is almost always simple. Addition and subtraction of numbers up to 40 is normally sufficient, and multiplication and division are not required.
The induction yesterday of Constance Baker Motley as Borough President of Manhattan turned out to be as much a tribute to Earl Brown, the man who did not get the job, as it was to Mrs. Motley.

Almost everyone under the sun has a recipe for making commuter-rail service profitable. The singular feature of Ben W. Heineman's recipe is that his works. The Chicago North Western Railway, which Mr. Heineman heads, is the only one of the 14 railroads operating as completely private enterprises to boast of the thriving profits it realizes on suburban passenger service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Administration tacitly acknowledged today that it had changed the rules of United States involvement in the war in South Vietnam. It cited Congressional authority for the move.

David Blum's Esterhazy Orchestra ended its fourth season of Town Hall concerts last night, with two soloists and a chorus participating in a concert version of Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euridice," Act II. A large audience responded with great enthusiasm to the singing of Shirley Verrett, the mezzo-soprano, who sang the role of Orfeo and also was heard in Mozart's "Parto, parto," from "La Clemenza di Tito."

HONG KONG, Feb. 24 -- A Peking newspaper declared today that American "ruling circles and racists" murdered Malcolm X, whom it depicted as a martyr in the Negroes' fight against "U.S. reactionary" forces. Jemmin Jihpao, official organ of the Chinese Communist party, declared in an editorial:

The roles of the real estate developer, appraiser and mortgage lender will be discussed at the twenty-fifth annual conference of the New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers on March 19, at the Commodore Hotel.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fin., Feb. 25 -- Whitey Fords arm, Andy Robustelli's exercises and Johnny Keane's ascension to power were the items of interest today as the New York Yankees began spring training. By the end of the day, none of the three had any conclusive impression to report.

An opponent of the Lower Manhattan Expressway charged yesterday that the city would have to lay out $100 million in construction costs if the road was built. He said it also would run the risk of being "stuck" for interest payments on the construction loan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The action of United States District Court Judge W. Harold Cox in Meridian, Miss., today came as no surprise to lawyers and officials of the Department of Justice.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Such is the respect for the Gedney Farms' Gun Bow and Rex C. Ellsworth's Candy Spots that Saturday's $145,000 guaranteed Santa Anita Handicap, expected to have a field of at least 12, will be only an eight-horse race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that North Vietnam must indicate a willingness to end its aggression against South Vietnam before the United States will agree to negotiate the end of the war there.

CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Friday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A United States general court-martial convicted Airman 1st Cl. Larry D. Cole of Marshall, Mich., today of unpremeditated murder in the shooting of a Filipino youth on a Clark Air Base bombing and gunnery range last Nov. 25.

One hundred and thirty-six Italian artists, accompanied by 600 of their works, arrived in New York last night on a promotional tour. Their visit, arranged by the Italian art and tourist magazine Valigia Diplomatica (Diplomatic Pouch), will include a White House reception this morning and a City Hall greeting on Tuesday morning by Mayor Wagner.
Mary Martin has agreed to star in a new Broadway musical, still without a title, based on "Hobson's Choice," the Harold Brighouse comedy first presented here in 1915.

A taxicab driver was stabbed to death in Brooklyn yesterday by two bandits. It was the second murder of a cab driver in 12 days; both took place in slum areas of Brooklyn and both times the killers escaped.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- The Communist Government of North Vietnam has notified the Secretary General, U Thant, that it is receptive to his suggestion for informal negotiations on the Vietnam situation.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that profits climbed 12 per cent in 1964 as sales rose to a record for the fourth successive year.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Albert Cardinal Meyer underwent a 4-hour-and-20-minute brain operation today in which a portion of "abnormal tissue" the size of a large walnut was removed.

ON a warm, humid night in Dallas in 1959, Cliff Livingston attended a swimming party at one of the city's numerous private pools after an exhibition game in which he had played with distinction for the New York Giants against the Baltimore Colts. During the evening, someone made off with his street clothes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Rise Stevens shared a Senate subcommittee stage today with six educators -- all urging the Government to aid the arts and the humanities as it now aids the sciences.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Senate approved the addition of $750 million in United States contributions to loan funds of the Inter-American Bank today, after passing two Administration-opposed restrictions but rejecting efforts to slash the total.
MADRID, Feb. 25 -- About 2,000 University of Madrid students voted today to stage a classroom sit-in strike after the suppression of a march at University City yesterday.
MOSS POINT, Miss., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Two girls arrested during a civil rights sit-in at a lunch counter were freed on $750 bonds today, ending a jail-cell hunger strike.

PARIS -- Averell Harriman went to Jerusalem to straighten out the aftermath of the German-Israeli arms deal. Bonn's diplomacy has displayed sorry ineptitude and Washington, apart from hoping to soothe enraged Israeli feelings while keeping the Middle Eastern lid on, has a moral responsibility in the affair. We invented it.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 25 -- Five sticks of dynamite were found in an abandoned car by the police here tonight after they received an anonymous telephone call saying that it would be used to demolish a Black Muslim mosque.
Because the Ranger 8 photographs have suggested that the moon may have features in common with southern Indiana, a request has gone out for aerial photographs of the snow-covered Indiana landscape.

SAIGON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- In the jet bomber strikes at the Vietcong, United States military authorities indicated today, the American fliers have used a new type of anti-personnel missile. Although these weapons are strictly under wraps, a recent development is a casing that opens after being dropped and looses small bombs that burst along a line more than 100 feet long.
The Federal system of justice in this country seems headed for a grave debacle in Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee heard a prediction today that the Communist dream of world domination would be realized by 1980 if the Western powers adhered to policies that exacted no political concessions from the Soviet Union in return for easier trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A series of lawsuits against segregated branches of the Young Men's Christian Association in the South is being started by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc.
Negotiators representing the printers' union and New York newspaper publishers agreed yesterday to recess their contract talks to study their positions on automation.

When 5,000 students of the University of Madrid, led by four of their professors, march in protest through the streets of the capital, something new is happening. The brutality of the police in breaking up and arresting the demonstrators was, unhappily, not new.
Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday it had ordered 24 short-to-medium range twin-jet DC-9 airliners from the Douglas Aircraft Company.
MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- The Soviet leadership continued today to maintain almost complete silence about Soviet diplomatic activity in favor of political negotiation on Vietnam.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Top-seeded Davidson got 59 points from Fred Hetzel and Dick Snyder today to defeat Virginia Military Institute, 86-73, in the opening round of the Southern Conference basketball tournament.
A six-story apartment house at Nagle Avenue and Arden Street in upper Manhattan has been sold by Sorkin Associates for cash over mortgages of $452,000.
Sales and earnings of the F.W. Woolworth Company reached record proportions in 1964, the variety and department-store chain reported yesterday.

Josef Krips will conduct the New York Philharmonic in Bruckner's Mass No. 3 in F minor, with the Ave Maria added, for his last three subscription concerts with the orchestra next week. They will be on Thursday at 8:30 P.M., Friday at 2:15 and Sunday, March 7, at 3.

St. John's, Texas Western of El Paso and the University of New Mexico accepted bids yesterday to the National Invitation Tournament. Their acceptance brought the number of teams to six for the basketball competition at Madison Square Garden March 11 to 20.
Municipal bond sales took place at an active tempo yesterday as yields on these tax-exempt securities increased enough apparently to attract more investors.
Directors of Windsor Industries, Inc., and the Bates Manufacturing Company have approved an agrement to merge the two companies. At present, Windsor owns 74 per cent of Bates.

Dusting off a technique it had not used since 1958, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has averted the out-right failure of the Malone (Tex.) State Bank, which has gone into voluntary liquidation.

As one who recently worked in Mississippi as a post-graduate interne for the Law Students Civil Rights Research Council, I was extremely interested in a letter written by Erie Johnston Jr., director of the Mississippi State Sovereignty Commission, published Feb. 18.
Tin Pan Alley and Wall Street, as far apart for some New Yorkers as the Bronx and Staten Island, are coming to a meeting of the minds.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- G.H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr. of Westbury, L.I., made his first appearance in the United States amateur court tennis championship today at the Racquet Club and advanced to the semi-finals with three Philadelphians.
The election of J. Grandel Jones and Ralph E. Ward as directors of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., was announced yesterday by Jerome A. Straka, president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said today that talk about passing the Administration's immigration bill to get aliens with special skills was "just sanctimonious propaganda."
Commercial banks' free reserves rose this week, but not enough to cast doubt on the general belief in the financial community that the Federal Reserve has tightened credit in the last few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Representative John V. Lindsay, Republican of Manhattan, proposed a health care plan for the aged today that he said could provide a breakthrough in the Congressional impasse over the issue.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The Conservative party, departing from centuries of tradition, announced tonight that it would elect its leaders, not select them after secret consultations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- John Doar, who has been nominated to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, told Senators today that additional legislation was needed to assure voting rights in the South.

DALLAS, Feb. 25 -- Jack L. Ruby, who has not been outside his jail cell since last April, will go into court Monday for a hearing on an affidavit that he is insane, District Judge Joe B. Brown said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Pierre Salinger, the former Senator and White House press secretary, and his wife, Nancy, confirmed today that she would seek a divorce because of a difference of interests.
PORTLAND, Ore, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- The general board of the National Council of Churches adopted unanimously today a policy statement urging a complete change in the treatment of narcotics addicts.

John L. Eyre, senior transportation consultant for Arthur D. Little, Inc., told the committee the American meat packer "suffers because he pays more for transportation, on a ton-mile basis, than his foreign rival."

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Farhan Attassi, a naturalized American who was hanged in Damascus Tuesday as a spy for the United States, left his Brooklyn-born wife a $200 bank account and ordered that their two children remain in Syria.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A bill designed to help clear overcrowded jails of chronic alcoholics by giving them rehabilitative treatment was introduced today in the Legislature.

ROME, Feb. 25 -- With modern simplicity, Pope Paul VI conferred the cardinal's insignia today on 26 new princes of the Roman Catholic Church. He called on them to "help us carry" the weight of the pontifical keys.
A 49-year-old textile dealer who lost an arm when he allegedly attempted to commit suicide by jumping in front of a subway train was awarded $200,000 yesterday by a jury for the injury.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt today suggested ways to trim $65 million from Governor Rockefeller's budget.

Your Feb. 23 editorial "Freedom for Soviet Artists?" was much to the point. No doubt, the universal artist will find freedom in heaven only because he is always bound by something even if it is only himself. But to be restricted as the Communist artist is by ideology and a narrow power structure creates formidable if not insurmountable barriers.
The stock market trekked uphill yesterday, but gains were modest when measured against the major strides of Tuesday and Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Intercity truck tonnage for the week ended Feb. 20, was 11.7 per cent above the volume in the corresponding week of 1964.

THE two model apartments that are major attractions of Bloomingdale's fifth-floor furniture department have just been redecorated and furnished with a collection of reproduction French country furniture.
ATHENS, Feb. 25 -- Anglican and Orthodox church leaders have agreed to discuss their doctrinal differences as a first step toward Christian unity.

The managements and labor unions of nine New York harbor shipyards are jointly planning a series of meetings with Congressional delegations to overcome what they call "Government indifference" to the shipyards' plight.
Members of minority groups who are denied housing will be able to call a telephone number next month and receive advice on how to file complaints and collect evidence.

YONKERS, Feb. 25 -- Reversing their order of finish of a week ago, Irish Napoleon beat Cold Front tonight in the $10,000 division of the Snowball Pacing Series at Yonkers Raceway. This time though, the margin of victory was two lengths, compared with the half-length that marked the difference in the first segment of the series.
The nation's electric power production rose 6.8 per cent in the week ended Feb. 20 from the level in the corresponding 1964 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

The directors of the Pepsi-Cola Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday by 5 cents to 40 cents a share on the common, for an annual rate of $1.60 compared with $1.40 previously. The quarterly dividend is payable March 31 to stockholders of record March 17.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A Republican debate now going on over the registration of Negroes may significantly shape the party's future.

MIAMI, Feb. 25 -- Blustery winds, more remindful of mad March in the Northeast than of balmy Florida at any time, tumbled the form about and generated an assortment of unexpected payoff figures at Hialea today.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The second English Roman Catholic priest within a week was disciplined today for expressing views in favor of birth control. He was barred from preaching.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Extra precautions were taker tonight against a possible attempt on the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A theater where he attended a movie was scoured for a man suspected in the theft of 1,400 pounds of dynamite.
BONN, Feb. 25 -- Chancellor Ludwig Erhard is weighing a recommendation that he move to establish formal relations between West Germany and Israel.

More than $35 million of tax-exempt state and municipal bonds were sold at competitive bidding yesterday in a scattering of small and medium-sized issues.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A prominent New York banker found beaten and near death here early Tuesday remained "in danger of death" today, but doctors at University Hospital said, "We expect him to survive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The search for a Republican candidate for Mayor of New York broke out into angry controversy today at a high-level party conference on Capitol Hill.
NEW names have been added to the roster of French, British and Italian designers in Macy's Little Shop, a repository for some of the freshest talents in European ready-to-wear.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- The winter's worst storm crippled the Midwest today and then pushed on east with its ice, snow and 70-mile-an-hour winds.
HADDAM, Conn., Feb. 25 -- Alarmed conservationists are organizing a drive here to block moves they believe would turn the beauty of the Connecticut River into "an industrial quagmire."
ATHENS -- Fly two hours west from Beirut across the Mediterranean and Athens seems like a return to home.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 25 -- The National Council of Churches' general board, representing 31 Protestant and Orthodox churches in the United States, adopted today a resolution urging President Johnson and his Administration to engage in persistent efforts to negotiate a cease-fire in South Vietnam.
A Harvard nutritionist ridiculed yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, the claims made by an advertising agency for a diet pill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The House approved with a 358-to-29 vote today a $370,000 1965 operating fund for its Committee on Un-American Activities. It defeated, 332 to 58, a proposal that the committee be required to justify its budget at public hearings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A Senate committee was told today that 21 United States steamship companies were considering an experimental rate reduction to help promote the export of chilled beef to Europe.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 25 -- Steve Nisenson scored 35 points last night to lead Hofstra to an 80-76 victory over City College in a Tri-State League basketball game on the winner's court.

The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported yesterday operating revenues of $239,970,178 for 1964. This compared with $233,088,068 in 1963. Net income rose to $28,240,209, equal to $1.40 a share, from $27,656,751, or $1.25 a share, in 1963.

Last night's program by the Contemporary Music Society at the Irene E. Guggenheim Auditorium of the Guggenheim Museum presented four works, Two were for cello and piano; one was a piano solo and one a cello solo.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25 -- George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, called today for improved relations with Moscow and a reduction of American involvement in thoe Far East.

While potato traders talked about the weather yesterday, they bid futures up as much as 26 cents a hundredweight in hectic trading.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Seventeen House members from New Jersey, Vermont, Pennsylvania and Connecticut asked Congress today to urge New York to raise its legal drinking age from 18 to 21.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday unanimously reversed the conviction of Herbert A. Ellenbogen on charges of giving an automobile and $3,000 to a Government purchasing agent.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Ondine, Sumner A. Long's big yawl from Larchmont, N.Y., became the over-all winner of the 1,300-mile Buenos Aires-to-Rio de Janeiro ocean yacht race today when time ran out on the Class C yachts that had a chance to win on a handicap basis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The House Judiciary Committee approved today a bill that would require Congressional districts to be nearly equal in population.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 25 -- The Executive Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. began a drive today against the use of lie detectors by public and private employers.
Computer Sciences captured most of the attention yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
Marc Dufour the leading scorer in the Central Hockey League, was called up yesterday by the New York Rangers to replace Phil Goyette, their ailing center.
The Romero family, four Spanish guitarists, returned last night to Philharmonic Hall, where they were last heard on Feb. 7, 1964.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given every Friday on this page. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. Four stars pertain to restaurants regarded as among the finest in the area.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb 25 -- United States and Israeli officials began an intensive review of the Middle Eastern situation here today.

A new trial has been set for Nathan Jackson, the 28-year-old Brooklyn man whose conviction for murder in 1960 led to a far-reaching Supreme Court decision on the use of confessions as evidence in criminal trials.
The State Department of Social Welfare has ordered Mount Morris Park Hospital in Harlem to stop caring for city charity patients because it assertedly has failed to meet fire safety requirements.

" An American Dream," the first novel by Norman Mailer to appear in nine years, will be published by Dial on March 15. It is a story of 32 hours in the life of a war hero, college professor, television performer and husband of a wealthy woman.

Exhibitors at the World's Fair appealed yesterday to "all interests in the city, the state and the country" to "set aside their past differences and join in a united effort to make the final fair year outstanding in every respect".

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 25 -- A busload of 35 student Freedom Riders from universities in Sydney, seeking to expose and eliminate racial discrimination in New South Wales, has aroused a mixture of praise and hostility.
WASHINGTON Feb. 25 -- The Republican Association of Governors has agreed on five members to represent it on the new Republican Coordinating Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Not every United States military man in Vietnam gets special combat pay, officials pointed out today. Only about 20 to 25 per cent of the 23,000 American military men there receive such pay.

SELMA, Ala., Feb. 25 -- A group of white community leaders held a long private meeting here this afternoon amid reports that influential elements of the city are looking seriously for a solution of Selma's racial difficulties.

After lying half a century in an unmarked London prison grave, the remains of Roger Casement have been sent home to Dublin for a hero's burial. Casement had sought German aid for the Irish Rebellion in the middle of World War I. The English hanged him as a traitor in 1916.
The Sisterhood of Temple Israel will hold a benefit luncheon and fashion show in the Terrace Room at the Plaza on March 9.

Richard E. Kelley, the Small Business Administration's deputy administrator for investment, told more than 150 officials of privately owned small business investment companies here yesterday that they needed a "new public image."
The designation of two candidates for directors of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) to be voted on at the company's annual meeting in San Francisco on May 19 was announced yesterday.
Contracts for future construction work in the continental United States in January totaled $3,127,351,000, according to the monthly report of the F.W. Dodge Company, construction information agency.

IN the three years he has been a Federal District judge, Wiliam Harold Cox has not always endeared himself to civil rights lawyers. But they agree he is an articulate, competent lawyer who does his homework.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Senate passed a bill today to authorize a $100 million 10-year water resource development planning program.

The discussion around C.C.N.Y's expansion raised in the letters of two history instructors (Feb. 5), Provost William M. Birenbaum of L.I.U. (Feb. 10) and President Buell Gallagher (Feb. 22), fails to reflect the overwhelming desire of the City University faculty to combine quality education with enlarged opportunity.

The Times of Feb. 11 reports Senator Kennedy's letter to Senator Zaretzki concerning the desirability of filling positions connected with the Legislature "on the basis of merit." Senator Kennedy is quite right. One would hope that men would be appointed to these positions on their ability.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Eisenhower urged the Government today to move toward a policy of tighter money, with higher interest rates.
MEN are more fashion-conscious than women, but it is all negative, asserts John Weitz.

The long-delayed perjury trial of Bernard Gittelson, alleged go-between in a conspiracy to pay a city official $50,000 to help the Duncan Parking Meter Company win a contract, began in Supreme Court here yesterday with the swearing in of the first prospective juror.

The appointment of Edward A. Gibbs as chief of the Bureau of Neighborhood Conservation was announced yesterday by Herbert B. Evans, chairman of the city's Housing and Redevelopment Board, the bureau's parent agency.
The election of Peter O. Lawson-Johnston, John M. Schiff and Roy W. Simmons as directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation was announced yesterday by Frank R. Milliken, president.

New York City's boxing renaissance meets another test tonight when Zora Folley, ranked fifth among heavyweight contenders by the World Boxing Association, faces Oscar Bonavena, a hard-hitting Argentine, in a 10-round bout at Madison Square Garden.
The managers of Horn Hardart's cafeteria at 250 West 42d Street have long felt that their clientele has included too many old Broadway layabouts with little interest in the culinary art.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 25 -- Federal District Judge W. Harold Cox dismissed today the Government's felony indictment against 17 of 18 white men accused of conspiracy in connection with the death of three civil rights workers last summer.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 25 -- United States jet bombers continued air attacks on Vietcong forces today.
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had arranged a restructuring of $140 million of long-term debt.

New York's Russian colony danced and danced last night at the St. Regis Roof, where the Mi-Careme dinner was held. The event was one of the last festivities before Russian Orthodox Lent, which starts Sunday.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Plans for developing a 135-square-mile "semi-urban pastoral complex" 70 miles southeast of Los Angeles that will be three times the land area of San Francisco were announced today by a California real estate company.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 25 -- A spectacular fire today destroyed an immense enclosed pier in Upper New York Bay here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Communist party of the United States was indicted today for the second time for failing to register under the Internal Security Act. The key portion of the indictment charged that the party had not registered even though it knew there was a volunteer willing to register on its behalf.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- The Secretary General, U Thant, issued a statement tonight disclaiming any intent to suggest that the American people were not well informed "or that the Government of the United States is withholding information from them about the situation in Vietnam."

City Hall advisers are urging that a white person be named deputy borough president of Manhattan to allay misgivings that the borough presidency, filled by Negroes since 1953, is now being regarded as an exclusively Negro office.

Should Tompkins County (Ithaca), Beauteous Gateway to the Finger Lakes, stand like a ragged mendicant at the foot of Cayuga's waters, holding out a tin cup for alms?

HONG KONG, Feb. 25 -- Communist China today criticized Soviet moves in the United Nations and asserted that Soviet leaders had failed to give militant support to North Vietnam in the struggle against the United States.
Robert H. O'Brien, president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., had a sunny message for the rain-drenched stockholders who attended the annual meeting here yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

The Assembly of Captive European Nations presented awards yesterday to 21 newspaper men and women, writers and scholars, the magazine New Leader and radio station WEVD of New York City for their reporting and studies on Eastern Europe.
The The New York Philharmonic will play at Philharmonic Hall this afternoon at 2:15. Josef Krips will conduct, with Pierrette Alarie, soprano, and Rudolph Firkusny, pianist, as soloist.
OTTAWA, Feb. 25 -- A national commission reported today that Canada was in her "greatest crisis" over the problem of meshing her two languages and cultures -- English and French.
Two thousand Trans World Airlines stewardesses have scheduled a strike for noon today, their union said yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Adam Clymer, Moscow correspondent of The Baltimore Sun, who was expelled by Soviet authorities, said here tonight that he had been "set upon by a bunch of thugs" during an anti-American demonstration in Moscow. He is on his way home.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The price of gold creeps forward day to day -- a symptom of the uneasy conditions in international finance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Administration's $1.25 billion school-aid bill ran into its first real trouble today, but prospects are still bright that it will emerge virtually intact from a House committee.
PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Qualified sources said today that France was opposed to any United States or Chinese Communist preconditions to an international conference on Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Carl T. Rowan, director of the United States Information Agency, said today that African and Asian countries interpreted the murder of Malcolm X as the martyrdom of a great integrationist because they did not know what he stood for.
James Farmer, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, yesterday endorsed the waning boycott of Boys High School and 2l allegedly segregated junior high school.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that it was the continuing policy of the United States to help maintain a military balance of power in the Middle East between Israel and the Arab states.
Walter Cassel sang the Dutchman in Wagner's "Der Fliegende Hollander" last night for the first time with the Metropolitan Opera, and the company now has a top new man in the title role.

New York University took a 14 1/2-point lead over Fordham at the end of the first five events in the 20th annual Metropolitan collegiate swimming championships, held at Quigley Pool in the Bronx last night.

HONG KONG, Feb. 25 -- Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Khanh indicated today that he was willing to assist in diplomatic measures to reach a settlement of the war in South Vietnam. "Militarily the war will continue," the recently deposed commander in chief said, "but this is the time when diplomatic activity must proceed along with military." The Uptown Chamber of Commerce rejected last night a Harlem organization's demand that stores on 125th Street close at 3 P.M. today and remain closed all day tomorrow in "respect" for Malcolm X, the murdered black nationalist leader.

A copper company executive who was dismissed in 1951 as director of the Government's Defense Minerals Administration for "inefficiency" was honored last night with the Copper Club's Man of the Year Award.

Biographers and historians interpret and re-interpret, champion and denigrate, always themselves influenced by their personal convictions, prejudices and passions. To some authorities Napoleon is a brilliant scoundrel, to others he is a hero.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Retail sales in the week ended Feb. 20 rose 1 per cent above the previous week's total and 8 per cent above that of the corresponding 1964 weak.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25 -- Pedro Ignacio Calderon, a young Argentine conductor, is planning to perform the Latin American premiere of Leonard Bernstein's Symphony No. 3, "Kaddish," as one of the highlights of next season.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 25 (Reuters) -- President Sukarno asked today for an end to American press attacks on Indonesia and said in return he would try to stop anti-American demonstrations here.

The Post Office Department seems to be digging itself deeper and deeper into a hole of its own making. First, it admitted that it has a list of 24,000 persons whose mail has been put under special surveillance in the past two years at the request of various investigative agencies. The Post Office is currently studying a demand for this list from a Senate subcommittee investigating the department's practices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Robert Rauschenberg will receive first prize of $2,000 and the Corcoran Gold Medal tomorrow night at an invitational preview of the Corcoran Gallery's 1965 Biennial of Contemporary American Painting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Johnson was briefed today on the journey of a space vehicle heading toward Mars and was told that the project was going smoothly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- A House committee voted today in favor of allowing Americans to see a Government-made film paying tribute to President Kennedy.

A group of American Jewish leaders will seek an appointment with Secretary of State Dean Rusk in the near future to urge him to exercise the State Department's influence in urging West Germany to resume arms deliveries to Israel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey and Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach made an unpublicized trip to the Capitol late yesterday to talk over voting rights legislation with a group of liberal House members who recently visited Selma, Ala.

Charges of procrastination, lack of foresight in school planning and fears that overcrowding will increase were heard yesterday at City Hall as hundreds of parents pleaded for action to provide more classrooms.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25 --The Syrian Government, through the Baathist party newspaper here, today denied the version of the Elie Cohn spy case that was reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The United States total gold stock declined by $262 million in January, the largest loss for a month in two-and-one-half years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

AT the Sportsmen's Vacation and Travel show at the Coliseum the other day, a leathery tree-licker was seen reading newspaper reports from Washington detailing the hearings on television buying baseball.

A. 137-pound collegian and a 130-pound schoolboy made the biggest impressions last night in the 46th annual Knights of Columbus track meet at Madison Square Garden. That was only fitting, because it was a lightweight meet marred by the nonappearance of many leading athletes.
A new effort to exchange food and medicine for 100 political prisoners in Cuban jails was disclosed yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25 -- Walt W. Rostow, chairman of the State Department's Policy Planning Council, ended a four-day visit today convinced that Argentina would make "positive progress" toward bringing inflation under control.
Art Heyman, the problem child of the New York Knickerbockers, has drawn another fine from club officials.
Industrial issues led a modest advance yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- A 170-pound fruitcake, waiting to be claimed at a Queens warehouse, appears to have confounded United Nations officials, the British delegation, and airline and customs officials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- David Waters, a Foreign Service officer who has been an assistant White House press secretary for five months, will become information officer of the United States Embassy in Madrid next month.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency told the nation's airlines today it wants flight recorders made more effective in solving air crashes.

Britain has pleased her trading partners by announcing that the 15 per cent surcharge imposed on industrial imports will be cut to 10 per cent at the end of April. The British payments position is still far from satisfactory, but the Labor Government felt that it could not count on the cooperation of other countries if it maintained this emergency measure to curtail imports.

A battle looms over the controversial proposals made by a Presidential committee for increased regulation of one of the nation's biggest and fastest growing pools of capital -- the $75 billion in private pension funds.

The Greek Line yesterday started a linguistic experiment that, according to the instructor, is guaranteed to provide anyone with a basic 500-word Hebrew vocabulary in the two weeks it takes to sail from New York to Haifa.

One of the high points of last summer's Newport Jazz Festival was an afternoon devoted to varied piano styles, from the early Harlem and Chicago idioms of Willie (The Lion) Smith and Joe Sullivan to such contemporary performers as Dave Brubeck and Thelonious Monk.
The board of directors of the Community Council of Greater New York yesterday urged action to protect open land in New York City and to-create additional open space for the enjoyment of all citizens.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The steelworkers union called today for a resumption of contract talks in basic steel and the companies agreed.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 -- A 27-year-old Negro cleaning woman stood in the dark living room of her tiny house today, its shades drawn against the dazzling sun, and gently pleaded with the wife of the President of the United States.

The Kellogg Company last year continued its long, unbroken string of increased profits. The Battle Creek, Mich., producer of ready-to-eat cereals yesterday reported earnings up 16 per cent on a sales gain of 9 per cent, both setting new records.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- South Vietnam accused North Vietnam today of a "persistent policy" of aggression, which it said was "supported and assisted by other Communist countries."

THE heavy and pratical butcher's block is beginning to make its weight felt in a surprising variety of home furnishings.

The Continental League, a new professional football group, will hold its second organizational meeting here today at the Park Sheraton Hotel. A commissioner is expected to be named and perhaps additional franchises will be granted beyond the 10 represented here on Feb. 6.
To permit its shares to be traded on the New York Stock Exchange, the Chase Manhattan Bank filed a registration statement yesterday with the Federal Reserve Board.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- The New York Caledonian Curling Club No. 1 rink began defense of the Wicks Trophy championship today as the 10th annual St. Andrew's invitation mixed bonspiel started at the St. Andrew's Golf Club Ice Arena.
WASHINGTON, -- Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board banned the public advertising of charter flights today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands has elected a first Congress, the Department of the Interior announced today. Approximately 70 per cent of the registered voters exercised their suffrage.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz cautioned two possible Republican candidates for Mayor yesterday that their refusal to declare themselves was "impeding the organization of a vigorous campaign."

PLAINVIEW, L.I., Feb. 26 -- Superintendents of seven Long Island school districts have concluded after a year's study that they could provide better education by sharing special talents and resources.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Joyce Davenport, a recent Mount Holyoke College graduate, reached the semi-final round of the United States women's squash racquets championship by defeating third-seeded Mrs. Newton Meade, the 1964 runner-up, 11 -- 15, 13 -- 16, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 12, tonight at the Philadelphia Country Club.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 26 -- The new Premier, Suat Hayri Urgulu, said today that Turkey would cooperate with her partners in the Atlantic alliance but would put more emphasis on an individual foreign policy, particularly in developing better relations with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A rural task force "to help wage the nation's War on Poverty in rural communities" was announced today by the Administration.

The Rev. Walter Decoster Dennis Jr. has been appointed a canon residentiary of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 26 (UPI) -- The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. told a Jewish temple audience tonight that the Negro was in a "wilderness of segregation and discrimination" and must move ahead toward a promised land of equality.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Princeton reached the top of the Ivy League tonight by defeating Columbia, 93 -- 60, while Penn was beating Cornell, the erstwhile leader.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Penn, clinging to its slim chance to tie for the Ivy League basketball championship, upset Cornell by 79 -- 70 tonight. Stan Pawlak and Jeff Neuman scored 46 points between them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Senator Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, said today that he had been blocked in an effort to question Walter W. Jenkins, former White House aide, about President Johnson's broadcasting and other business interests.

The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday it planned to raise more than $325 million through sales of stock and debentures.

William McChesney Martin's warning of a possible tighter monetary credit policy if the nation's balance-of-payments problem does not improve sent a soft ripple through the Government-bond markets yesterday.

DALLAS, Feb. 26 (AP)--A hearing to set a sanity trial for Jack Ruby, the condemned killer of Lee Harvey Oswald, was reset today for March 8.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The index of wholesale primary market prices declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 101.1 of its 1957-59 base during the week ended Feb. 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices of farm products and processed foods fell, while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (AP) -- School boards that delay desegregating the longest must from now on complete the process in the shortest time, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit said today.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 26 -- Middlebury's skiers, who have been dominating the carnival circuit this season, made an impressive start toward their third straight triumph today as their own 34th annual winter jamboree got under way.

The broad traffic safety program Governor Rockefeller has submitted to the Legislature contains two overdue and highly desirable reforms: Periodic inspection of all new cars and a probationary six-months license for new drivers. SAIGON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Authoritative military sources reported today that elements of a new Communist division trained and equipped in North Vietnam had shown up to reinforce the Vietcong rebels in the I Army Corps area fronting on for the 17th Parallel.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The United States sharply denied today Soviet accusations of military interference in the affairs of South Vietnam.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 -- The Hialeah Turf Cup will be the main attraction tomorrow, the final Saturday of the meeting. A handicap race with an involved history, the Turf Cup, under its present conditions, will have its 25th running.
Bond sales in February declined to $1,127,700,000 from $1,204,500,000 in January, but were greater than the $1,089,000,000 offered in February, 1964.
Dr. Angelo Procario, a 61-year-old surgeon, was found guilty yesterday by a jury in Federal Court of failing to report $46,000 in professional income and evading $22,000 in taxes.
An off-duty patrolman shot and wounded a 19-year-old motorist yesterday who, the police say, first sideswiped the policeman's car and then beat him.
BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority has received State Supreme Court authorization to proceed with plans to rebuild Greater Boston's transportation system.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week irregularly higher yesterday in active trading.

One radar set of the Israeli liner Shalom was incapacitated by the impact last Thanksgiving morning when the $25 million vessel collided with the Norwegian, tanker Stolt Dagali, the liner's chief radio officer said yesterday.
GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- Swiss voters will determine Sunday whether emergency Government controls on the country's economic activity will be prolonged to prevent prices from running wild.
The British pound declined yesterday 17 points to $2.7942 from Thursday's closing price of $2.7959. The fairly substantial drop took place in active end-of-month trading.
A Federal court in Ohio has ruled that a prosecuting attorney in a state court may not comment to a jury on the refusal of a defendant in a criminal trial to testify.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- In a match lasting nearly 3 1/2 hours, James L. Van Alen 3d of Philadelphia defeated William T. Vogt, also of Philadelphia, after losing the first two sets to gain the final round of the United States amateur court tennis championship today at the Racquet Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Equipment invented by a Long Island engineer promises an easier ride for the truck driver and his cargo. The White Motor Company, Cleve land, has begun to produce the units at the rate of 250 a month.

BRIDGE is big business for hotels. The Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League are fourth in rank in the annual listing of conventions, and this is only one of 450 tournaments held in the nation.
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange made historic highs, as measured by leading averages, during February and closed with a small gain.
ST PETERSBURGH, Fla., Feb. 26 - Casey Stengel led the youngest New York Met team in history in this Gulf Coast paradise for the elderly today to begin the Mets' fourth season in the Major leagues.
A joint vesper service of the Northern and Southern Presbyterian churches, which went their separate ways at the beginning of the Civil War, will be held here tomorrow.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Attempts were made here today to reconcile conflicting American and European interests on the use of the Early Bird satellite of the Communications Satellite Corporation.
ROME, Feb. 26 -- Pope Paul VI today denounced the "brutal violation" of elemental human rights in the recent outbreaks of violence in Africa and elsewhere.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 26 -- The coalition Government of the Netherlands resigned tonight after the Cabinet was unable to agree on a method of introducing commercial radio and television.
PARIS, Feb. 26 -- France objects to the new plan for enlarging the International Monetary Fund because she considers it soft on Anglo-Saxons.

BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Feb. 26. -- Arthur Bottomley, British Secretary of State for Commonwealth relations, met with representatives of 40 unions today in his continued effort to sound out public opinion on the deadlocked issue of Rhodesian independence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board called the deficit in the nation's balance of international payments today "an emergency situation," and "the most serious problem this country has faced in a financial way in many, many years."

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 26 (UPI) -- The quarter-final round of the men's singles in the Dixie International tennis tournament went as expected today, setting the stage for a rematch tomorrow between the finalists of the National indoor tennis championships.
George Barbezat scored 15 of his 18 points in the second half Friday night to lead Long Island University to a 69-64 victory over Rider College at the Blackbird gymnasium in Brooklyn.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.; Feb. 26 -- Nationalist China is dub to be excluded from the new General Assembly committee that will try to end the deadlock over the authorization and financing of United Nations peacekeeping operations.

WHEN 2,500 skins of pink mink are put on sale Monday at 10 A.M. at the Hudson's Bay Company on West 30th Street, Finn Birger Christensen will be among those bidding for a bundle of the newest and most snobbish of the luxurious pelts.
YONKERS, Feb. 26 -- Smoky Mountain, with Del Insko posting his 10th driving victory of the meeting, captured the $5,000 division of the Snowball pacing series tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
