Once again "The Deputy," Rolf Hoehhuth's controversial dramatic version of the Vatican's wartime response to Nazi persecution of the Jews, is the center of a storm -- this time in Rome. Since its 1962 Berlin premiere, acclaim and outrage have greeted "The Deputy'' wherever it has been performed.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 26 -- Stockholders of the Franklin National Bank were assured here today that if their bank extended a loan to the World's Fair they would be fully protected.
The Emhart Corporation increased its quarterly dividend yesterday to 50 cents from 45 cents, proposed a two-for-one stock split, and reported record sales and earnings for 1964.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A House committee approved relatively non-controversial provisions of the Administration's $1.25 billion school aid bill today and agreed to vote tomorrow on the main section.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 26 -- District Attorney William Cahn of Nassau County announced today that a grand jury had failed to return true bills after listening to evidence on criminal charges brought during last fall's political campaign.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Any doubt as to the identity of the outstanding cars and drivers entered in Sunday's 2,000-kilometer Continental was dispelled today as all of the contenders went through qualifying tests.
WASHINGTON, Feb 26 (AP) -- Kenneth E. Belieu, former Army colonel, moved up to the office of Under Secretary of the Navy today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- An authority on Communism warned Congress today that the Soviet Union would aid Communist China in any hostilities with the United States over Vietnam.

The Plaza's Grand Ballroom and Terrace and Crystal Room echoed with Hungarian dance tunes last night for the 13th annual Piarist Ball. More than 1,000 members of the Hungarian Piarist Alumni Association took part in the event.
An adventure series produced in Britain about a secret agent will replace "The Entertainers" April 3 over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
FORT LAUDERDALE Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Dick Shoemaker, a 54-year-old club pro from Cleveland, took the first-round lead today in the Seniors Teacher Trophy championship with a four-under-par 68.

New York City has some 50,000 drug addicts -- half the country's total -- sick and disturbed adults and youths who are not getting medical help on their problems. These addicts are pawns of the underworld, whose profits from the illicit narcotics trade are second only to gambling.
Negotiations are under way that may lead to the sale of West Coast refining and marketing facilities of the Tidewater Oil Company. No definite commitments, however, have been made.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Traffic picked up momentum today through the snow pack laid down by a storm that in two days swept across most of the eastern half of the nation before blowing out to sea.
TRENTON, Feb. 26 -- Thomas J. Gangemi, former major oft Jersey City, today won the right to run again for the office in May.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 -- The 72-foot ketch, Ticonderoga, packing great sail power, swept across the Gulf Stream today at near-maximum hull speed and became first to finish in the Miami to West End (Grand Bahama) yacht race.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Republicans gave the Administration another nudge today to hurry the production of a bill to put meaning into the right to vote.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- A legislative subcommittee recommended today the establishment of 30 scrap centers throughout the state to reduce the growing number of cars abandoned on highways and streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Johnson enlisted Henry Cabot Lodge today as special consultant on the Vietnam crisis. Meantime, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said that a "few hundred" more American military men would be sent to South Vietnam and indicated that long-delayed plans to expand the South Vietnamese Army by 100,000 men would be carried out.

SELMA, Ala., Feb. 26 -- Jimmie Lee Jackson, a 26-year-old Negro who said he was shot by a state trooper as policemen broke up a civil rights march the night of Feb. 18 at Marion, Ala., died today in a hospital here.
BONN, Feb. 26 -- A sequel to a religious conflict stretching back three centuries was written today when the Holy See signed a concordat with the West German state of Lower Saxony.
The classical depiction of Neptune churning through the deep in a chariot drawn by dolphins may not be so very far from reality after all.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 26--Indonesia announced today that she was taking over American-owned rubber plantations in North Sumatra. The value of the seized property was estimated at $80 million.
TRENTON, Feb. 26 -- The State Supreme Court upheld today the right of a new trial for a Negro couple convicted of keeping their daughter out of classes during a school boycott in Englewood in 1962.
BOSTON Feb. 26 (AP) -- World Airways Inc. has sued Northeast Airlines for $18 million alleging a restraint of trade conspiracy.
The Swiss took over Carnegie Hall yesterday evening with a gala concert presented under the patronage of their consul general here.
Air Taxi Company, a charter operator, will begin a scheduled air service Monday between metropolitan airports and Red Bank, N.J., James Loeb, president of the company, announced yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Coming to this resort with the serious pursuit of dining in mind may border on the bizarre. Palm Beach suffers the ailment common to most seasonal outposts -- the inability to maintain a permanent staff.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. said today that voter discrimination against Negroes in Mississippi must be stopped.

MANILA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Hsieh Yung-Yo, a 31-year-old Taiwan pro, shot his second straight sub-par round today and held the lead at the halfway point of the Philippines open golf championship with 68, 71 -- 139.

Malcolm X did not "spawn the darkness" of the Negro's fanaticism [Editorial Feb. 22]. He came out of it, and with clarity and precision focused the light of his own honesty on it to show us the danger in which we all walk, white and black alike.
Two records were broken and one tied last night in the second of three nights of competition in the 20th annual Metropolitan collegiate swimming championships at Quigley Pool in the Bronx.

Mozart's "Cosl fan tutte" was given last night in its fifth performance this season at the Metropolitan Opera. The only new face in the cast was Helen Vanni, singing Dorabella for the first time with the company.

WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., Feb, 26 (UPI) -- An Air Force jet bomber and a jet tanker with a total of eight men aboard collided during a refueling operation early today. Both planes crashed into the Atlantic in flames.

CLARK AIR FORCE BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 26 -- A United States airman whose shooting of a 14-year-old Filipino boy on a firing range last Nov. 25 triggered a wave of anti-American sentiment here, was sentenced today to three years' confinement with hard labor.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 26 -- President Jomo Kenyatta declared today that foreign intervention in the Congo not only had made peace more difficult to achieve there but was threatening to cause the war to spill over into neighboring countries.
BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The management of the Boston Maine Railroad blocked today an attempt by Patrick B. McGinnis, former president of the line, to obtain representation on the board.

CAIRO, Feb. 26--President Gamal Abdel Nasser has reasserted his differences with world Communism, apparently to quiet Western fears that the United Arab Republic is veering dangerously toward the Eastern bloc.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 26 -- The New York Central Railroad asked for a fare increase today of $1.596 million a year on commuter trains from New York to Poughkeepsie on the Hudson Division and to Pawling on the Harlem Division.
HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- The Communist parties of Latin America have been "deeply concerned" by the Moscow-Peking dispute and demand an "immediate end of public controversy," they stated formally today.

Justice Charles E. Ramsgate ruled "with extreme reluctance" yesterday that he had lost jurisdiction over the Rev. Milton A. Galamison, 33 other adults and a minor in truancy cases arising from the school boycott.
SEATTLE, Feb. 26 -- A recalcitrant House of Representatives passed a compromise redistricting measure today, thus ending a 47-day deadlock that had tied up the state Legislature.
DERBY, Conn., Feb. 26 (AP)--The Home National Bank of Derby had a short life. It was established this morning and went out of business this afternoon.
BONN, Feb. 26 -- The West German Parliament today approved a $16 billion balanced budget for 1965 despite sharp opposition from the Social Democratic party.
A large audience turned out last night at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to hear four seasoned professionals play chamber music.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26 -- All the New York Yankee pitchers and catchers go through the same routine here in the early stages of spring training, but it is far from the same experience for each. The mental climate and emotional tone can be entirely different for two men performing the same action side by side.

A once prominent criminal lawyer, now serving a Federal prison term, was sentenced in state Supreme Court yesterday to one-and-a-half to three years in prison for taking part in defrauding a widow of $800,000 in securities.
The Radio Corporation of America reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings for 1964. The final figures, released yesterday, exceeded earlier year-end estimates.
The value of bonds called for redemption in February before maturity fell to a six-month low of $68,413,000, a survey made by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 26 -- The building trades and the industrial unions of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced agreement today on a plan to resolve their dispute over the picketing of construction and industrial sites.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 26--The Railway Labor Executives Association said in a statement today that it would like to meet with leaders of the nation's railroads to discuss ways of improving conditions in the industry.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 26 -- Judge W. Harold Cox of the United States District Court ruled today that Sheriff Lawrence A. Rainey of Neshoba County and 16 other men must stand trial under a misdemeanor charge in the deaths of three civil rights workers last summer.

Oscar Bonavena, the brash, young heavyweight from Argentina who had won all eight of his previous professional boxing matches, discovered defeat for the first time last night in Madison Square Garden.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26 -- Premier Aleksel N. Kosygin declared today that unless the United States halted its "aggressive actions," the war in Vietnam would "inevitably transcend its original boundaries."
Inspector Frederick W. Hains, commander of the New York District Attorney's detective squad since 1954, retired yesterday.
Prices moved irregularly lower in quiet, selective trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

A 61-acre wooded camp on Staten Island, part of the city's planned green belt across the center of the island, has been sold by the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York to an undisclosed company.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- A former soldier who is the British disarmament negotiator will arrive in New York Wednesday to try to persuade the United States to join Britain in breaking through the disarmament deadlock.

Marking renewed confidence in Brazil, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday its first credit to the South American country in nearly six years.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 26 (AP) -The New York Shipbuilding company reporLed net income today of $1,608,365 for the year ending Dec. 31, equal to $1.19 a share. This compared with $1,057,136 and 78 cents for the previous year. The company said it had a backlog of $107,g00,000, compared with $152,600,000 for 1963.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- The television industry has been advised to make its nonfictional, nonentertainment programs more interesting so that young viewers will get a little painless learning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The American Institute of Architects announced tonight the recipients of its five annual medals, to be awarded during its national convention here June 14 to 18.

GEORGE TOWN, Grand Cayman, B.W.I. -- Symptomatic of the changes now being wrought by tourism almost everywhere in the Caribbean are several new developments here on Grand Cayman, the largest of the three islands that make up this tiny British Crown Colony.

OCALA, Fla. -- Over the years, motor traffic has been steadily increasing in and out of this central Florida city. Last year, its main attraction, Silver Springs, had 1,750,000 visitors. Now, Ocala has become more accessible as a result of the recent completion of Interstate 75, which passes two miles to the west.

ROME, Feb. 27 -- Pope Paul VI took the occasion today of an audience with Lawrence Joseph Cardinal Shehan, Archbishop of Baltimore, and several hundred pilgrims from the diocese, to bestow blessing on all the people of the United States.

THIS May 8 will be the 20th anniversary of the end of the war in Europe and the collapse of the Nazi regime. On that date, the West German statute of limitations on Nazi crimes runs out. Under West German law, no new indictments after May 8 will be permitted.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (UPI) -- A Soviet fishing official today described as "an absolutely groundless concoction" reports that a Soviet vessel tried to seize an American fishing trawler in distress on Feb. 18 in the Atlantic off Montauk Point, the eastern tip of Long Island.

Vietnam was the No. 1 item of business at the White House last week. Lyndon Johnson discussed it often and at length with his top aides -- Secretary of State Rusk and Under Secretary Ball, Secretary of Defense McNamara and others.

It is an opera that illustrates the ups and downs of Shostakovich and of Russian ideology, and its story will bear retelling.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- A contractor from Arlington, Va., told this week how he planned to raze the old United States Courthouse and make a profit doing it.

TELEVISION is cited constantly as a menace to children's eyesight. Most recently, Japan's Ministry of Education issued a report holding that the growing incidence of near-sightedness among Japanese school children was due to too many hours in front of the TV set. Queried about the validity of this theory, a distinguished American eye physician's ready answer was "Malarkey!"
DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- Three University of Michigan economists have warned that Michigan can no longer depend on the automobile industry to "carry the employment load of the state's economy."

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The murder of Malcolm X has made no great impact on world opinion. Malcolm himself is not generally being treated as a martyr, even in African and Asian areas sensitive to the American race problem.

TUNIS -- At the moment, Tunisia is far cheaper for tourists than any other Mediterranean land. This situation is the result of administrative moves last fall, when the national unit of currency -- the dinar, roughly equivalent to $2 -- was devalued by 25 per cent.

COCOA, Fla., Feb. 27--Luman Harris pushed aside the shingles, the hammer and the nails before climbing down off the roof of the house to answer an urgent phone call. He was all smiles when he scaled the ladder to finish his day's work. His brother, the contractor, looked questioningly at him. Luman fastened one more shingle and then gave forth with the news.

BERLIN, N.H., Feb. 27 (UPI) -- John Balfanz, the defending champion, of Stockdale, Ill., put together leaps of 243 and 242 feet today to lead a field of more than 100 skiers in a warmup meet for the national jumping championships.

March originally was year's end and year's beginning, when the calendar keepers began their new round of the seasons with spring's arrival. It still partakes of both winter and spring, with the vernal equinox only nominally marking the change; and by the equinox it is two-thirds winter.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- This Spanish-speaking United States commonwealth has gone a long way toward making American visitors feel at home under the sun. An audience of about 400 persons warmly received yesterday afternoon's Town Hall recital by Ray and Helen Gordon. Mr. Gordon, a classical guitarist and baritone, and his wife, a mezzo-soprano, offered a varied program of art and folk songs.
HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- A five-day international symposium of brain specialists that ended here today indicated that participants from Communist countries were receptive to Western research methods.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) -- One of the greatest archeological finds of all time -- the Dead Sea Scrolls -- will be displayed to Americans beginning tomorrow in a traveling exhibition prepared by the Smithsonian Institution.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands -- The Dutch pride themselves on living in a country that offers a strange, but pleasant, mixture of the old and the new, the romantic, and the dynamic. The face of the Netherlands changes as industries and harbors expand, new highways are constructed and old villages become part of the growing larger cities.
PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Britain and France are near agreement on joint production of two military aircraft, the British Defense Minister, Denis Healey, said today.
Alhajj Malik Shabazz, who was called Malcolm X until his pilgrimage to Mecca, was buried yesterday as a Moslem.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 (AP)--A spokesman for the Great Lakes vessel industry said this week that the industry viewed with "amazement, alarm and disappointment" the plans to close the remaining Public Health Service hospitals on the Great Lakes.

Bill McClellon, who has been having more trouble lately with physical problems than competition, came up with another injury yesterday. But the 17-year-old De Witt Clinton junior scored 21st straight victory in the high jump and posted a Public Schools Athletic League meet record to boot.

OTTAWA, Feb. 24 -- Many residents of Ottawa -- the diplomats, most newcomers and not a few politicians -- have been shocked this winter to learn that they live in the midst of a Canadian "Appalachia."

An 83-year-old man was killed early yesterday in a four-alarm fire that swept three five-story buildings at Second Avenue and 52d Street and forced more than 100 persons to flee in their nightclothes.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) -- This year, like 1964, promises to be pretty much of a more-of-the-same year for tourism here, with one or two exceptions. One is the opening of Israel's new national museum in Jerusalem; the other is the completion of the excavations and restorations at Masada, in the Negev desert.

John Hay Fellowships in the Humanities, totaling more than $500,000, have been awarded to 70 public senior high school teachers, Dr. Charles R. Keller, director of the John Hay Fellows Program, announced yesterday.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that it had granted about $5 million to American universities for the expansion of research on world population problems.
EDISON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- The three dropouts sitting at their tables in the machine-shop classroom won high praise from their instructor.

THE Ramapo Kennel Club show has gained the ranks of those with better than 1,000 dogs in its third year of operation. The entries dosed with the Mansfield organization of Alexandria, Va., with 1,165 dogs, a gain of 266 from last year.

Philip Johnson, the architect who will receive the Elsie de Wolfe award of the American Institute of Interior Designers tomorrow night, introduced this country to the all-glass house and the interior reflecting pool, refined theatrical lighting principles for use in the home and revived the use of great covered arcades for public buildings. CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Surgeon General, Dr. Luther L. Terry, said tonight that the United States was "at least 10 years behind in terms of controlling the pollution of our environment."

OTTAWA, Feb. 28 -- Continuing conversations between the Canadian and United Kingdom Governments so far have failed to resolve a major trade collision that both countries would like to avoid but which is looming increasingly as inevitable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States Commission on Civil Rights found widespread discrimination today against Southern Negro farmers in the administration of Government farm programs ranging from education to land conservation.

The moderators of the two largest Presbyterian churches in the United States stressed the need for church unity at an unusual inter-Presbyterian vesper service yesterday, sponsored by the Presbytery of New York City.

The hundreds of Red Cross flags flying over many of the city's major buildings today are there as a reminder that March is Red Cross month, the period in which this great humanitarian organization turns to all New Yorkers for the support it needs to perform its essential tasks.

The success of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation's bid for control of the Meadow Brook National Bank was virtually assured yesterday. The bank announced that each of its directors had "indicated his intention" to sell his stock to C.I.T. at the tender-offer price of $31.75 a share.

The United Steelworkers of America struck the American Can Company and the Continental Company today. The strike, affecting 36,000 union members, began at 12:01 A.M., after the breakdown of negotiations dating back to last October.

License Commissioner Joseph C. DiCarlo could not check his hat at a Broadway theater he attended recently. He said yesterday that an employe of the checking concession told him there was no room for hats, parcels or umbrellas -- only overcoats.
The appointment of three divisional vice presidents of Bonwit Teller was announced over the weekend by Miss Mildred Custin, president. The New York department store is a subsidiary of Genesco, Inc.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, Monday, March. 1 -- Vice Admiral Paul P. Blackburn Jr. taking command of the United States Seventh Fleet here today, declared that this powerful naval force had "shown the world our ability and our determination to meet the challenge of world Communism."

Joel Shapiro played with the same discernment that marked his choice of music for the piano recital he gave in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. Two sonatas by Antonio Soler, Beethoven's Sonata in A (Op. 101), two Debussy etudes.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- A shutter flapped against the smashed bay window as a handful of firemen entered the attic, littered the floor with newspapers and kindling wood and set the mansion aflame.
A group of World's Fair exhibitors has urged the fair to cut its night admission rate this season in an attempt to draw larger crowds. The proposed rate would be $1.50 after 6 P.M.

A campaign to enroll 10,000 on-call volunteers to serve as members of an emergency blood donor panel will begin today at a booth set up in the Pennsylvania Station.

Though eliminated from the Eastern Hockey league playoffs, the New York Rovers played like champions yesterday and outclassed the Clinton Comets, 4-2, before a matinee crowd of 6,145 at Madison Square Garden.
